comments.text: i like this idea, it's so flexible and i think with alot of the other ideas, some are too constricted, this is nice because there are no guidelines means there is no limit!!!

Love this idea! You mentioned making them team activities- I think this would make the challenges more beneficial as it would bring colleagues together and allow them to bond over the activity. Great thinking overall :)

annual_wellness_check_up.description: Similar to an annual health check the annual wellness check would cover not only your physical health but also your mental health, wellbeing and happiness.
annual_wellness_check_up.creator: 78b421309e310f1950b83b418b1ebc04

comments.text: Hi Suzy,I love the supportive, subjective angle on this. I think asking an employee whether they are feeling grounded mentally is just as important - if not more so - than measuring the blood pressure, BMI or heart rate.Your concept would be a great building block for the 'Glassdoor for Health and Fitness' idea I am refining at the moment, and i'd love to hear your thoughts on whether it would be valuable to share the data from the wellness check-up anonymously on a site like Glassdoor. If you have a spare couple of minutes and would like to contribute to the survey, please follow the link on the concept description too!http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/glass-door-for-health-and-fitness-ratingMany thanks!James

Hi Suzy, nice concept! Who would this group of 'experts' be? Would it be fitness experts and psychologists? Or would it be a group of volunteers recruited internally? What questions would be asked to get an idea of happiness?
Perhaps this may be a positive health care initiative though maybe not something that encourages active get off your butt healthy living.

Hi SuzyI really like this idea.  One way that one might make it work is using an online tool such as the one we use in Bupa - our positive health assessment.  In summary, this is an interactive tool that asks questions about the users health and then dives deeper into particular areas such as whether there is cancer in the family or a history of heart problems.  The survey takes about 15 minutes to complete but provides the user with an immediate diagnosis of their current 'physical' age, potential risks and how they might reduce them.  There are gadgets to allow the user to make immediate changes so, for example, a smoker could see the immediate impact of giving up, or the potential changes of taking more exercise etc.  When run in the UK under the campaign 'Are You As Young As You Feel?' we had an extraordinary response from our people, and it went viral.  Using the results to discuss with a doctor or health professional (such as a nutritionalist) provides a powerful and very cost effective way of:1. Gaining health data about your people2. Understanding the potential areas of health concern3. Giving your people an ongoing tool by which to measure their own health risksThanksHamish

annual_wellness_check_up.title: Annual Wellness check-up

open_space._open_opportunities._.description: The ideas that I am outlining below are inspirations from my current workplace - Toronto's Centre for Social Innovation (CSI).
open_space._open_opportunities._.creator: 19bb8737fdd21a2b91268121854d7441

comments.text: This concept really does build up an environment for team work and team creativity. Well done Lucas, I really like this.

Lucas, You are very lucky to work in an uplifting environment!Just don't remove all the cubicles - remodel them by all means. There needs to be some space for those who don't get their energy from the crowd.   Yes a well planned open plan is great for the majority, but there are a number of creative people who gain their inspiration from others but create their most insightful and innovative work on their own.  As in everything, a mix is best!  This is where couches are great especially for those who prefer one to one interaction rather than activities in larger groups.

I love this concept Lucas! You've talked of 3 really simple changes that could be implemented easily in any work environment, and I really feel they'd make a difference! I'm assuming you're suggesting them because they've helped at your workplace, and I can see them working for others. Removing the cubicles and adding couches is a great way of bringing colleagues together in environments that allow for more socialisation. I also love the salad bar idea, again it would bring people together- and not only does it promote healthy eating but also adds an element of fun to it.
You got it Asma and thanks for the kind words :)

I love the open space model of the CSI and of The Hub. It definitely does create an enabling environment to enhance creativity, team-work, sharing and to unleash human potentials. It would be also great to improve diversity competence through the open space model. One way would be for employees to share with everyone their unique or not unique working styles, underlying the benefits and premises of these different approaches...At the same time, this opens the way to sharing success stories at the individual and group or corporate level, finding out that success is often built on failure :)

Fantastic Concept! I agree with the fact of having more open spaces will make people feel better, having to work in cubicles/dividers can make people feel depressed. Removing the cubicles will bring sound and freedom to the working environment, which will make it more fun and exciting to work there, as the workers will be able to communicate with each other. I love the Salad Bar idea aswell, sounds really fun! These 3 changes are simple but will make a huge difference. Great concept!

Great concepts about wellness based on happiness, Lucas!. Have you thought about creating a walking or running club to strength the sense of community? Everyone running with the same colorful T-shirt could bring the inside health and happiness out to the neighbourhood. Really good work!!
Thanks Gabriel! Absolutely, there are endless possibilities that can be built on top of this idea in the future! :)

Yes, I think the same! It would be the perfect solution. Thank you for your comment Areca.
Good ideaa!!! :D
Thanks!!
Good concept! I think is a great way to create communication between workers while they are keeping fit.
I agree with you Carles

Great idea! I like the fact that you've developed both a webpage and app for people to communicate and meet up. This could really work, evoking both social interaction and keeping fit simultaneously! Good concept.
I agree with Megan; this would be a great way to encourage social interaction, while doing something to keep healthy. Great idea Maria!
Thank you for your comments!
Great concept! I think that you can add a relation with Zed's concept because both are related about good relation and enviroment between the mates at work.

Good concept Marian! I think is a good idea having an app as well as the webpage because is a good way to communicate between the workers and they can check their own personal records to improve on their healthy lifestyle.

Nice concept. I think that the option to develop an app, it's so useful for the workers. Because of if they have some inconvenient to arrive at time, they can inform it, without give personal details

cook_meet_with_co_workers.description: Great parties always end up in the kitchen. Cooking and eating are activities that bring people together. What if companies had a kitchen/meeting space, transforming lunch breaks into a team building activity while promoting a healthier diet?
cook_meet_with_co_workers.creator: 8705a0d82b93db7b544027326d221134

comments.text: yes, nice idea, food definitely brings people together, sharing food and sharing cultures might be the best way to have lunch and bond!
Awesome collaboration with Anson & Alicia.  Feel free to incorporate some of their ideas into your own post here if you'd like.
Hi Nathan,Thanks! First time using Open Ideo, this is pretty fun!

Yeah, a number of us have ideas that involve creating food boding opportunities - both for health and building organizational culture. I think we could combine them into an epic program!  :)  To make it more affordable, you could do a "big an ingredient" potluck program - participants each bring  a part of the meal (one of my concepts was salad potlucks- bring a salad topping, put it all together and share). This eliminates the need for the ingredient delivery, but you do have to have employees motivated to see it happen every week.

Hi Krista, salad potluck is a good idea. "how do we motivate employees to see this happen every week".Whether it is salad potluck, cooking together or hiring chefs, if people aren't motivated to change eating habits, it wouldn't really work. I was also thinking about a comment Anson brought up  (posted on a thread in his concept) -- how to involve the insurance company into the equation.Perhaps instead of approaching possible solutions for people to eat healthy at work, we should think of what would make people want to eat healthy at work - then whether they do a salad potluck, cook together, hire a chef or all of the above, they can decide according to resources/time/etc.I'm a big fan of thinking about behavior changes in a positive/negative reinforcement framework. Saving money is always a good reinforcer... and everyone needs to eat. Could the insurance company sponsor healthy groceries/food for the employees of the company, that they could use at work and at home?

workplace_fountain.description:
When employee drinks water, his/her account updated through the card. The amount of water is showed in an application on each employee’s computer or mobile phone.
When time that employee doesn't drink water exceeds the limit, he/she is alerted.

comments.text: Good concept, I like the idea of the application alerting the user when to drink water also knowing how much water the individual has consumed weekly is another great feature, also you might feel like your spending to much time sitting and working at you work station also the benefits are good as users can get up and move around and meet people and feel more refreshed so they work better.

Great concept! I always forget to drink enough water and being alerted throughout the day is an excellent idea. I also really like the fact that it can also get employees up and out of their seats, allowing them to meet up with fellow co-workers and create a stronger social interaction amongst employees.

I really like this concept of being alerted when your low on water. I know I definitely don't drink enough throughout the day! And it's usually just because it doesn't occur to me to go get water once my water bottle is empty- so I would love to have something like this to remind me!

Great Concept Ozge!  I know if I don't drink lots of water I feel tired and don't know why.  This can be a key to workplace happiness.  My only question is can the app feel less big-brother-ish?  I can imagine that having your work tell you when to drink water could feel imposing.  I wonder if there's a way for co-workers to encourage each other to drink more water by making special flavors of water or encouraging people while on breaks to chat and drink water.  Good work!
Thank you Nathan for comment. I will think about application and its manner.

your_world_is_your_gym.description:
Thinking Beyond the GYM - Your Environment and Surroundings IS Your GYM. 
''when everything looks like an uphill struggle - just think of the view from the top''
your_world_is_your_gym.creator: 3189a47e8b984357061db4764511bd89

comments.text: Love this, really good idea.

This displays great inspiration. A lot of people do not have the time to go to the gym whilst others use a long day of work an excuse for refusal to workout. Unconsciously working out whilst performing your normal day to day tasks could benefit those with this problem. This also gives people more than one place to work out, rather than depending solely on the gym.

I like the obvious but often forgotten point that we are burning calories with almost everything we do, but when were made aware of it, even making it cumulative, we begin to be made happy by doing dull things.
the photograph says it all, great motivation!
Great inspiration! Would be interesting to follow this through into the concept stage.

I really think your on to something great here Ahmed! alot of people do not have the time to go to the gym whilst others are psychologically deterred to go to the gym after a long days work. What if people were able to work out, get in shape, whilst performing menial tasks and day to day objectives. Working out unconsciously could be a benefit to us all.

Completely agree Julian. The majority of people who join a gym have the right intention of attending regularly but in actual fact they are finding every excuse not to go, wasting money and time to physically become healthier. If the mundane and tedious everyday tasks could be transformed into something useful then that could be very powerful indeed. Look forward to the concept phrase!

comments.text: Breakfast is said to be the most important meal of the day, which I know personally, is really easy to skip. This is a great idea. I like the statistics you have brought into the discussion, which show that this concept could not just improve a balanced diet, it could also prevent other seriouss health issues in the long term.
I'm a big believer in the importance of good breakfast and a lot of people I know either skip it or skimp on it.  Great idea.

Great concept, definatelly something i would casually like to get involved in, breakfast is a nesessity to me and i believe it shuld be for every working person. i would gladly recommend this idea to every person in order to get their day started with a head start.

I know I definitely cant have a productive day without having my breakfast either, although I am not sure how healthy my two eggs and cheese one a bagel is I do drink orange juice with it!....I think it would be nice to have this available at work and if everyone's tastes and particulars are included in the decision making process it could work really well. I know though at least for myself that if the company compromised on the quality of the the food or beverages available, I would find myself walking outside to one of the cafes nearby.  That said I do support this concept :)

Suggesting certain meals they could eat is a great way in getting people to eat breakfast. They need to be quick and easy to make as people don't have much time in the morning as we all know. Thanks Megan The simple ideas  are alway the best

Simple but great idea! Without a decent breakfast I find it nearly impossible to function, by the employees ensuring they all realise the importance of a breakfast will provide a more productive workforce. Well done.
Breakfast is key to a happy start of the day.

Thanks! (Apologies if you see this reply twice. Think my original was lost during the servers outtage) Agree need both top down and bottoms up approach. I imagined it would begin with a company-wide announcement, at least that's the case for the pilot, in order to get the ball rolling. It may be merely 1 aspect of a bigger company health initiative, so there may be organization-wide goals, team competitions, and other incentives involved. plant_the_social_seed.description:
Lets get people, meeting people!

Transforming the workplace into a social hub.
plant_the_social_seed.creator: 3ef99147feef7ebceee02c864e8c85ee

comments.text: I like the concept of "creating" the activities through voting.  One suggestion is that you could tailor the interface to various companies, as the flower analogy just may not fit for all.  For instance an automotive company would start with a frame and voting would add parts to the frame to create a complete car.Also I think it would be important for management and executives to commit to this project.  All employees need to know the activities are considered valued by the company, in order for everyone to feel safe and confident in attending.  I've worked at many companies that tried to involve the workforce in fun activities.  Unfortunately the moment things got busy most employees felt uneasy about attending since management rarely showed up.  People started to worry how their attendance of such activities was perceived by their bosses.Perhaps some sort of positive incentive for suggesting and participating in the events, that is still fair to those who are legitimately too busy to join in.

I agree, I just used the flower as a generic visual. However your suggestion of tailoring the visuals for specific companies is a very good one. I also agree that management should participate in the activities too. Its a shame that nowadays a lot of employees don't really come into contact that often with members that are high up in the workplace hierarchy.Thank you for your feedback :)

This is a great idea! And I do agree also with Brett that time-management for the participation in the planning and in the development of events can be an issue. Maybe it can even agreed upon to devote a defined amount of time, for example 15-20 minutes daily to the cause...And maybe this can be piloted as a policy measure of the company itself that then stimulates employees to take rewarded 15-20 minutes to join in...Great metaphor with plant and flowers growing :)

Great stuff Jono you've definitely captured something with great potential here! I agree with Burns it could be used as a tool for people to voice their own opinion within the company suggesting new initiatives to help the company progress.

Perhaps as well as this concept achieving its goals of bringing the workplace together, it can also provide a platform for opinions to be shared. This would almost be an in-formal way of replacing the 'suggestion box'.Thank you for your feedback :)
I love it!!!
Thank you :)
Great concept and awesome graphics!! It's a good way to interact with the others and create a nice enviroment! Good work Jonathan! :)
Yeah I'm glad you agree. I think if employees had more 'family-like' friendships then the workplace would be submerged in a more relaxed atmosphere.Thank you :)
Great concept! Moreover the pictures say it all.
Thank you :)

It also works well when these types of initiatives are not scripted but happen spontaneously.  This could be initiated by employees or leadership of the organization, but is not something that people have to vote on and plan on attending.  For example, just turning on some music and having an impromptu dance party, bringing in some food for everyone to share, or passing around a card for people to write down a compliment for the next person that receives the card.  Really like the idea!

Brilliant concept Jonathan. There is definitely a lot of potential for this concept to grow (please excuse the pun). I love the idea that there is a democratic selection of social activities, not everybody wants to do the same things so this is a great way of combating conflicted interests. I also agree with Burns and Lee it could be used as a platform for voicing opinions. Great work!
COOL. Love the humour of the picture it made me laugh.

I have always been a fan of your concept and like Bernhard mentioned it can be used in a number of ways to achieve a democratic result. Develop it as an app as well for accessibility and expansion of your concept.
GREAT!!! I totally agree, sounds like me and you are on the same page.

Cool concept, makes me think of a quality management tool. People could plant seeds on what to improve within the company. If there are a lot of votes, they might go for it. Would optimize workflow, improve workflow and help people identify as member of the firm. This can lead to a healthier community.

Great concept! This can evoke great social interaction between employees, I like the fact that you can anonymously vote along with the delightful use of flowers to illustrate the voting results! Good work.

Digging the flower analogy, Jonathan! To help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. preventative_healthcare_rewards_card_sti.description: Create an employee rewards card that incentivizes a holistic approach to preventative healthcare.
preventative_healthcare_rewards_card_sti.creator: f3dfcc5c5ba4f2df56175d9fe896f18d

comments.text: In looking to scale this idea, I am wondering how this might be adapted to offer benefits to lower income individuals or smaller businesses that cannot afford benefits. Is there a way to offer incentives based on healthy behavior changes as well, instead of just purchasing behaviors?

Perhaps this takes away from the idea that this card tries to provide, but instead of providing incentives like gym discounts could the card offer professional development opportunities for those that use it to check in at local gyms/health food stores or heck even those that can show they worked a reasonable amount of time? I say this because there are people for whom going to the gym is not a matter of cost, but a matter of prioritization against work. If healthy behavior is tied to professional development (e.g. company sponsored professional certifications, conferences etc) the employer gains by having not only healthier employees but also better trained employees (increases ROI). Easier to scale because the employer doesn't have to negotiate wellness deals with suppliers like gyms - and instead they just lay out the reward (maybe the employee can bid for rewards)I started to tease this in http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/show-me-the-money/ but I really do like this rewards card concept because it is so personalized.

Kareem, this is a great idea! And I think that Riyaz's comment made it even better! By offering a system of winning points and bidding for rewards related to professional development, it is a win-win game for both the employer and the employee. I would add that it could be interesting to promote collaboration among employees. Therefore, people who encourage another workmate to have a healthy behavior, can get extra points. For example, if a workmate starts coming to the gym with me, I will get an extra point, only after the other person comes at least 3 times. By this way, we can make sure that the workmate is not coming to the gym only to help me with the extra point I needed for the reward, but he is also benefiting from a healthy habit.

Hi Kareem. thanks for this concept. There is a no-claims bonus for car insurance so this could be similar? and it links to another concept http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/health-leave-not-just-sick-leave/Perhaps there could be a tie-up? Points for making good health choices can add up to health leave? or a reduction in insurance premiums? How about a reward for no sick leave? If a whole division has no sick leave perhaps there's an extra special reward? That could get groups of people encouraging one another to greater wellness through good health choices. I think all these could add up to greater awareness and longer term benefits through prevention of the illnesses that you mention. As an add-on to the report card there could be a health age assessment? http://www.bupa.com.au/health-and-wellness/tools-and-apps/tools-and-calculators/quick-health-age-checkThe results could be a way to chart progress? Again divisions or groups of people could work towards a combined "years gained". This also seems to build positive on positive so I imagine that people would want to pass the idea along. And a catchy name......

Lots of goodness here, Kareem! I'm digging the notion of individual health reports so users can track their own progress. Looking forward to what names folks come up with. I'm throwing one in the ring: The Wellness+ Card (trying to combine the wellness and rewards aspects)
Thanks Meena! I think I want the name to a bit more edgy/contriversial, something that people will remeber when the hear you know?
Good point. The Chipper Card? Looking forward to hearing suggestions from others... and if you're name storming offline, perhaps you post some of the suggestions here too.

I really like this idea too! It would be great to combine it with a location-based mobile app to help guide you to places where you could use your card, and a way to personalize the app, as you suggest, to address your specific health needs.  here's one name idea :  TakeCharge Card

That sounds like a great idea, it also seems like people are interpreting this concept more as its own service that would be used a sort of employee benefit by all companies. But I feel like quite a few of these concepts could be combined there are so many great ideas, well see how it goes!

Can we emulate the old Chinese idea of paying a doctor only as long as the patient remains healthy. The organization employs medical practitioners and health workers who coach employees and are paid on the basis of the health measures of the employee.

Thats a very interesting model and Ive been reading more about it.  However maybe we could modify it slightly for our concept, as all medical employees are extremely in demand in todays market they will not and should not work for free.  Heres my shot at the modified statement:The organization employs medical practitioners and health workers who coach employees.  Substantial bonuses and other forms of compensation are rewarded medical practitioners whose patients/clients show growth and improvement. Thanks for the feedback! Let me know your thoughts.

How about "team points" b/w the practitioner and provider.  Let's face it, health/wellness is often a team sport and rewarding only the quarterback (whoever that may be) doesn't always make for a great team.  We know there are health benefits from social interaction b/w patients...can we leverage this with practitioners as well?
I really like this idea!  Could imagine having the card resemble an 'insurance card' format like when we pay for medications.  Only this is for wellness...and you get wellpoints.

preventative_healthcare_rewards_card_sti.title: Preventative Healthcare Rewards Card (Still namestorming…ideas?)

I like this concept. The workplace can sometimes be a very stressful place and providing somewhere for people to blow off steam by engaging in fun activities may de-stress people. that is what i was thinking, and exactly a stress relieving tool.

This would definitely be beneficial. We added a few physical activities to our conference room, and we found it helps people get off their feet and often opens up thinking, while we're trying to solve tough problems.
That is amazing, so there is a similar system in place that already works.

We had a chillout area at my previous company, which included an x-box connect which after every lunch we used to get active. It's great if you are too lazy to leave the office, or weather is not the best outside. Getting fit, active, and socialising.
I like the idea of utilizing games to enhance communication and stress relief. Great Concept !
Good concept. Bringing people together for fun whilst at work would work really well, its much better than the usual breaks at work.
Nice concept Imrat. Giving people the options to do things instead of just having a room with limited activities is a good way to go about it. I think it will encourage people to take a proper break!

Cool concept! I love that it brings people together providing them with a space to enable social interaction and stress relief. I feel that employees would benefit from an area to escape to and unwind; therefore increasing productivity as well as creativity. I also like the fact that there is choice in what activity you want to participate in as not everyone shares the same interests. Good concept.
Great idea! I think the best way to de-stress is to really have lots of fun. I also like the addition of building blocks/lego. It's a unique way to relax while boosting people's creativity.

This concept is a great way of releasing stress at work. The fact that there are multiple of tasks that you can participate in, means that there is something suitable for everyone. this can be used to bring people together and build identity amongst the work group.
This concept is a great way of releasing stress at work. The fact that there are multiple of tasks that you can participate in, means that there is something suitable for everyone. Great work Imrat.

comments.text: Hi Sarah. I really love the sentiment behind this. I had a great experience of such as system; no app was necessary, just a boss you didn't mess with! :http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/don-t-eat-at-your-desk/I can see the value of the app system though.. I think there would have to be a kind of manual override for times such as deadline days etc, but overall I don't see why it couldn't work. Perhaps adopters would also have to think one step ahead; if they are expelling employees from their desks for an hour, they would do well to ensure that there are places either within or close outside the office where staff can eat comfortably and affordably.

I really like this Idea, but I agree with James that they'd have to be allowances for deadlines and days when working through lunch is actually a necessity. And ensuring affordable places to eat is also a good point. They'd need an incentive to want to get away from their desk, or the lack of internet at lunch might end up being something they view negatively.

global_status_update.description:
‘The fluid Workspace’
Managing the balance between work and private life.
global_status_update.creator: 46defce884d1be32019f20864172323d

comments.text: This is quite a viable concept. Separating working and private lives may well help to reduce stress and depression. It also gives the employees the opportunity to literally 'switch off' and refresh themselves for the next working day. What makes this concept extremely powerful is that the user is in complete control of setting global status'. For example, a few people may find it more comfortable to perform simple working tasks at home so they could control the status from whatever environment they are in. The fact that other people would be able to see the status would encourage others not to mix the users work life with private life and vice versa. And of course for emergency contact I presume that directly calling the user would be sufficient.Great work Berns

Thanks Jono, totally agree that the status would trigger a chain reaction, I never saw this aspect so thank you for pointing it out.Today I was reading the inspiration for this concept again and in one of the comments I discovered a point that should have been included in this system. For those of us who are working around the clock, it should log and evaluate the amount of work we produce in unpaid time. This would then enable the employer to see and reward those important hours.There is still so much to do around this concept, we are really just at the starting point. Thank for the great input.

Yeah thats very interesting to keep track of the amount of work we produce away from the workplace. Would be a good visual in a graph to see how productive people are as well. This may even encourage companies to allow their employees to work from home every now and again with pay if the job is still getting done.

The video is very useful to put your point across, and the idea of a separation between your personal and work which is great to find balance between their professional and private lives.A really good concept.
Thank you Imrat. I'm glad you see the potential.
This is a very good concept and one that could really improve the quality of peoples lives long term providing they use it honestly and are able to make the usage of it a regular habit.
Hey Kas! :} yes I agree. The system should be designed so the user doesn't need to make a big afford to maintain it. Otherwise we add even more work.
We are too connected to new technologies and social networks. I like your concept.
Thanks Jordi, connection is good but there should be a limit or at least a way to evaluate how much work we actually do off the radar and without reward from the company.

Really beautiful video and the concept as a whole is all in the visual message - so it is absolutely fulfilling its purpose and maintaining aesthetics!!!! Very interesting concept...I am just thinking about the fact that our behavior is "dictated" by how the machine is set...It's a little scarry to me :)

Thank you for your comment Gaia. Are our lifes not dictated by machines anyways? But yes i agree, the fluid workspace really prevents you from some messages coming through, unless you choose to change the status or settings. For us it sounds absurd but for future generations who grow up with the internet in their pocket, i think its important to protect ourselfs from working 24/7. Unless we want to. And with "working" i also talk about Net"working" in our private life.
Great concept! I like the fact that it can be used at work and at home. Besides the video is simple and perfect to explain your concept.
Awesome video Bernhard.  I think you've got a real talent for making great videos.

Thank You guys the video could have had more impact. I was expecting more collaboration and feedback on this concept. But it was a very good exercise. And nice experience whats achievable when working in a big great team.
Keep it up, it'll pay off.  Seems like you got a pretty great response too, at least I liked it a lot.
Check out this video too, it's a great example of using video to explain a concept really effectively: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/bupa-openhealth-platform/
I agree Nathan the video is very nice, a lot of work in those vector animations. lots of keys. thank you for redirecting me.

Bernhard....firstly great video. I love how you've used the Sims to great effect! I think it communicates your concept rather well. In addition I also think that the whole concept itself is great and has a real emphasis on creating healthier lives for employees in and outside the workplace. It would be nice if you were able to tailor make your experience as im sure certain people in society would like to be able to access certain features at home to do with their business. All in all. Great concept!

Hello Julian, thank you for your comment. You are talking about a customisation on what networks or services are available in different status settings, and I 100% agree with you. Let us assume someone has 2 twitter accounts, one for working and one for private, this user could set his fluid workspace to automatically sign in the different accounts depending on status.When it comes to the Status type itself I think more than 4 different modes would overcomplicate the system and prevent people from using it. What is your thought?
Thanks so much Bernhard (and your awesome team!) for reposting this amazing video. Top effort!
I had all the files so it was not a big deal. Thank you

Love the video Burns! Completely understand the concept being able to control your social networking life automatically and fluidly inter-changing naturally between private and work is very effective. It is a great concept and some real potential to move on further. Congratulations Burns!
I agree on the potential and it will become increasingly important as our workspace becomes more digital. Thank You Lee
Burns, this is an awesome concept! great work guys!
thank you much appreciated

flash_mob_management_routine.description: For many workers, constantly having the same routine everyday can affect their general wellbeing! By changing the daily routine using flash-mob management, it will enable a completely different and unique change to workers lives.
flash_mob_management_routine.creator: e8f1ed0d530b9e9cc3d120dfc757a124

comments.text: Good work Nihal, this could really change the mood of a standard working environment
Thank you Aj Ay.
Really great idea Nihal, I think it could really help put people in a better frame of mind at work- activities like the pillow fights you're suggesting could be good for stress relief!
Thank you for your feedback Asma! :)

Is there a possibility that adults wont feel like its appropriate to partake? Plus busy work lives may not be able to adapt to such spontaneous action. I'm sure if these can be addressed it is a great concept and really beneficial for those involved.

That is a good question. The idea of having something that's random and spontaneous can seem bizarre. Some adults may not feel it's appropriate, however employees do have the choice to participate or not and they have the choice on the types of flash-mob routines they would like to suggest. Employees should always feel comfortable in what they are doing. It could be a flash-mob where people are in their own comfort zone. So for example, it could be a design meeting sitting down in an office or studio, where the employees are brainstorming ideas by writing down one word then immediately getting up and sticking it up on the wall, until it is completely full of words. This is spontaneous, different, fun and collaborative. So they are participating in a flash-mob while they are working. Yes, a lot of busy work lives may not be able to adapt this, but it could simply be 5 minutes where the employee is not constantly working but doing something different, which could still be working but in a more spontaneous, fun manor, as described above. Appreciate your comments. Thanks Will!
This is a great concept! I really like the spontaneity and social interaction this brings and the inclusion of helping a charity and showing awareness.
Was going to say the same thing!
Thanks guys, I appreciate the comments!

work_family_social_overhauling_our_ways_.description: The way we work is changing.  The relationships between employers and employees are changing. But still we manage via monitoring, rather than results and insist on leaders who put work, rather than family or even society first. Why is this?
work_family_social_overhauling_our_ways_.creator: 3d596263b52e3cdcd8ce91c71c2fda1d

comments.text: Yes Jessica, I do agree a lot. And if I may add to the subject you opened, yes is about styles of management, but mostly on the roots of the symptom which is about how we design organizational systems, which is the foundation on how effectively a company works, and how this effectiveness affects us. Let me explain. If we take a deeper look on companies or institutions, and apply Systems Thinking, what we have is that they all are organizational systems which elements of construction are three: People, Technology and Resources.If we take a side the most valuable element, which is people, and we could imagine the system working without us, we could see that a healthy system, an effective one, is that which has its processes running effectively using technology and resources. The more flowing the processes are, the most effective and healthy the system is. Ray Kroc, the creator of the concept of McDonald's as we know it and it's first CEO, saw this. What he saw is that he needed to build an organizational system people proof, but not in the negative way, in the positive one, he saw the quality of the product needed a standard of procedures to ensure the client he will get the same kind of hamburger in Main or at Orlando. He saw people as we are, the asset that can transform or update that system using our creativity and our minds.We do not have to forget that we, as part of an organizational system, we go to fulfill a function, we go to execute tasks. With us, without us or despite us, the system requires that that function must be performed. As you correctly put it, the system requires certain results from each and every position existing in the company or institution. And that's why we should be measured by results and not by how many hours we spent at work looking busy.Organizational Systems, companies or institutions are built by us, and if we understand that we should design them better, from the foundation, we are looking towards a healthier life, because we would need to understand us better, on how we better perform and would design them thinking on us and the world around us. So then, as you say, our style of management would change, because the systems we work at would be more effective and would need a more effective style of management.

Hi Isaac, thanks for commenting.  I agree that the issue goes beyond management styles and into how the status quo limits organisations and individuals from getting the best outcome.  Whether it be relying on sight as a management or unintentionally reducing the talent pool as the likely strain on family and friends required to be senior leader encourages individuals opt out of the race. Certainly, it is the organisational systems that you refer to that reinforce the status quo.

work_family_social_overhauling_our_ways_.title: Work family social:overhauling our ways of working

bike_commuter_s_hub.creator: e0abda69cce90db2629931ad8fc01106

comments.text: I used to work for a startup in San Francisco that was focused on the peer-to-peer bike sharing economy. We rode our bikes to work every day and because we had them at the office would frequently take a break and cruise around the city for lunch. Great way to connect with your coworkers outside of the office in a healthy and active way. One thing to keep in mind, however, is bike commuting can be limited due to seasonality (e.g. NYC in the winters). How could you transform the bike hub in off seasons to promote a healthy commute to work? Wacky idea but perhaps turn the bike hub into a spinning room during the winters.Regarding the pilot piece to this concept. Perhaps look into Google as they have an inter-company bike program where employees can grab a bike outside any office and cruise between buildings. I imaging there is a lot of data to support that the quick trip on a bike boosts employees happiness at the very least.Great idea!
I think this is a fantastic idea, Emily!

I used to work for a startup in San Francisco that was focused on the peer-to-peer bike sharing economy.  We rode our bikes to work every day and because we had them at the office would frequently take a break and cruise around the city for lunch.  Great way to connect with your coworkers outside of the office in a healthy and active way.  One thing to keep in mind, however, is bike commuting can be limited due to seasonality (e.g. NYC in the winters).  How could you transform the bike hub in off seasons to promote a healthy commute to work?  Wacky idea but perhaps turn the bike hub into a spinning room during the winters.Regarding the pilot piece to this concept.  Perhaps look into Google as they have an inter-company bike program where employees can grab a bike outside any office and cruise between buildings.  I imaging there is a lot of data to support that the quick trip on a bike boosts employees happiness at the very least.Great idea!

I agree, Emily that it would improve "health" in both physical and psychological and social terms to create an enabling environment to recognize bikers, reward them and attract other to do the same :) maybe, in the "small experiment" phase, it could be arranged to organize control groups that would allow to compare the group of bikers with the group of non-bikers. Indicators for measurement of the predicted benefits form biking could range from physical health to attitudes towads work, cooperation, family and life in general. It could also be tested how biking becomes important for efficiency during the execution of assignments/duties at work :)

I like this idea! I agree with James the lack of showering facilities can have an impact on one decision to cycle or not. It is a great way to keep healthy and you don't have to cycle by yourself. There could be a group of use meting up and cycling it to work. You can encourage each other and who knows this can lead to cycling not just to work but anywhere.

i like this idea, its is very encouraging to be regularly active physically and mentally and at the same time able to aviod the stress from morning rush hours. with the mass production of cars hight number of train users i do believe that cycling to work is definately the way forword.

Great Idea. The simple lack of showering facilities at work stops heaps of people from cycling when they already posses the desire and capability. Reliable security would be another incredibly valuable selling point.Nailing the scale(s), and the incentives for companies/employees would be crucial to this. I imagine a variety of scales would be suitable for different densities of site; in really dense areas, perhaps a whole floor or a skyscraper can be rented out, and a kind of bike valet service put in operation, whereby the bike is handed over upon arrival, and there in reception waiting for the owner (with the aid of a text message/app function to warn the valet) when he/she leaves the office.In terms of piloting, perhaps one potential experiment to start with would be to modify some of the larger gyms located centrally; if they were to be able to secure a few more sqm of space as a dedicated storage facility, then their existing showering facilities could be made available to users of the scheme. At first maybe limit to members but then expand to include people who don't belong to the gym; as a bonus they may attract more members in the long run.Slightly removing it from the immediate office environment might be a bonus too; standing in a towel next to my co-workers waiting for unisex showers was an interesting experience, but perhaps a little anonymity in amongst a larger hub would be more comfortable!

flip_the_work_day.creator: ea730fd6255c151bd2c2ee17476fd39e

comments.text: I think this is a great concept but how will employees work after a long day out? This could cause laziness and employees to decrease productivity at work. I do however like the fact that they will be able to enjoy nice summer days instead of dreading the idea of going to work.
Maybe a few comments on where sleep fits into the "flipped" schedule?

It would have an impact on a persons social life also as everyone would be at work when you are free in the day. However this would benefit others who work more productively at night but would still affect their health on a social level.

I guess I'm imagining more of a student type of schedule.  In my experience most people did a little work during the day, but then almost everyone was at the library at night until maybe 10 or 11.  (And also did work on Sunday nights.)

A flexible schedule makes sense in our evolving, connected workspaces. We check email late, take meetings from different time zones, our work schedule is already shifted in some ways. What if we fully enable a flexible schedule with more asynchronous communication? Discussion boards, shared documents, project tracking, much of the work we do can be autonomous. Maybe reserving the afternoon for face time and allowing the other half of our day (morning or night) to be flexible. I see many benefits, give us personal time for fitness or the dentist, or it gives us focused time to work.

Interesting concept Joe. I like the points you raise about being able to avoid the mad rush of the daytime and enjoy a bright sunny day. I do agree with Sam though that when it is could and the days are short this concept would be less effective. Perhaps as a summer program workplaces could adopt a system a little like in southern Spain where workers work until midday and then enjoy a prolonged break (normally for a siesta) while the sun is at its hottest and then return to work in the afternoon until evening.
Thought provoking concept, but how would it work during the colder months when people would rather stay inside?
Bundle up and grab the skis, snowshoes, etc.!

Thank you Maroun!
Nice concept Florin, smart and simple way of encouraging people to get up from the chair to take a break. I agree with Nate might be better with a vibration system instead.
Yes, definitely, a vibration system is a better option.
What if the chair vibrated instead of an audible tone? That way it would be too annoying to ignore, but also wouldn't distract other coworkers.
Standing desks are definitely the way to go -- or maybe desks and chairs that can be raised and lowered?

But, usually is hard to work standing for long time in the same time, changing the position of the body (up and down  working standing for couple of minutes and then sitting on a chair) maybe could help in a way

Interesting idea Florin. I think a physical reminder is better than just an app or sound alert. Great way to encourage people to move about.

Florin,Great idea for a pressure sensor detector built onto a work chair. We spend at least a third of our lives working, and a good amount of that time is sitting! We all need reminders of some kind to get up every 20 minutes to an hour.
Someone or something should remind us that we are humans not robots... :)

Really interesting idea Florin! By alerting the employee that they have been sitting down for too long would be very helpful, seeing as many people get too into their work....maybe some sort of chair alarm with vibrations or shocks would really get people moving!
Thank you Risha for your idea! Its better to have an alarm system with vibrations, no with sounds, could be nosier in a working open space area, for instance...

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel wondered how could this idea be sustained beyond a sponsored event?  How might it include people who don't need to lose weight?  What other metrics could be measured?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Fantastic!Happiness factor as well as job satisfaction could be considered. Employees could all write down a list of mutual bad habits they have such as smoking or under exercising. They could then come together to fight these problems as it would be far easier.Measuring quitting smoking could be the number of days gone without a cigarette. For under exercising it could be the amount of hours spent at the gym.

Thanks Bidur, me too!
The company can work together, each person setting a goal and the whole team working towards that goal to meet each individuals target.

Great concept Aj! A couple of ideas to contribute to your concept: Building up from a comment by Christine Fam, companies spend a lot of money on employees' health insurance. A great way to measure the success of this program, would be to keep track of the health insurance expenditure over time, after the implementation of the program, and compare it with historical records. On another hand, if a program like this is implemented, there might be an opportunity to create a business. My idea is the following: Healthy food shops could 'pop up all over the place' offering its healthy foods to employees of companies in a certain area, through an online marketplace. Employees can login to this website, create a profile, and order any item (fruits, vegetables, etc.) and pay with their credit card. Profiles would have stats and be ranked in a company scoreboard (nutritional value purchased per month, point system, badges, etc.). Companies can set a monthly goal. If an employee reaches it, the company rewards the employee and covers all of the expenses + a small bonus, just like you suggested, and the proceeds can go to charity.

Eating correctly is hard for everyone. It is always much easier to pick up something from a fast food place then finding a healthy food place to eat. Introducing a monetary incentive to eat healthily is a great way to keep people engaged. You could also link this to exercise which runs parallel to a balanced diet. People could complete a challenge like 5 miles a week? Good concept!
Thankyou for your comment, that is a very interesting idea

Ayy its a fantastic idea, the world needs more healthier people, obesity in our community is on a rise and it need to have a limit. I believe this concept would be a great to use and tackle that problem. Especially for those that are based in stationary work place or inactive working environment.

I like it.I wonder if there is a way to link this with insurance premiums? I figure that if people made better choices for their health, they would be less likely to need costly health care. Could there can be a number placed on the value of these choices that could be translated into discounts on premiums? In Singapore and other parts of the world, there is a "no-claims" bonus paid to the car owner who makes no claims during a specific time frame. This affects the behaviour of drivers. For that matter if there were no insurance we'd all drive very differently. How would people make choices if there were no health insurance? To push it further, how would people make choices for their health if there had not been the kind of advances in health care we know today? I am not suggesting that we scrap insurance, I am looking at this from the idea of a fundamental point of view. What do you think?
That is a very interesting concept, thankyou for your input
Good idea Aj. Especially the group day outs, could definitely make more opportunities for colleagues to socialise and create a sense of community in the workplace.

I know fruit is more 'snackable' than veggies, but there are a lot of very healthy diets that limit fruit to a couple of times per week, given the damage sugar can do to health.

Would appreciate if you can all circulate it (and take part!) so we can get some initial feedback and refine this a little more accurately! How many survey responses do you have so far?
Nudging 40...

Awesome James. And glad to see you're getting a push on Twitter for this. Wow  that place does sound amazing  especially the massage on call! We love it when OpenIDEATORS reach out to engage others with their ideas in these kinds of ways. Check out this concept from a while back: http://www.openideo.com/open/impact/winning-concepts/opentranslate/and the amazing collaborative translation that Sarah managed to elicit from folks in our community & beyond: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0Ar6XirNnCg26dHowNV9DRGJ2U3YyOWhweHRKeGVqM1E&hl=en_US#gid=0

Results are up! What is most encouraging or surprising? For me the single biggest take-aways is were that 90% would potentially be willing to share their health data anonymously, and over three quarters would be keen to look at this data comparatively. Some proof that we're onto something!
Wow  so impressed with the level of collaboration on this concept. And way to go Wout on your impressive visualisation!

Hi James!Very interesting concept and integration into an existing website!You mentioned measuring things like "BMI, Blood pressures, aerobic fitness and fat percentage" but have you thought about measuring other things as well? Perhaps an employee's access to a fitness center on their work site - or give the company a percentage rating of how many employees have a gym on site and then give employees opportunity to rate the gym equipement (adequate, horrible, etc.) and classes offered. It would be interesting to see in the experiment if people who filled out the questionnaire online were honest about their personal health data.Another possible way to collect data for a company could be through a free health day. Several large companies have these in place already, and maybe glassdoor could attend, or ask if they could be put on a consent form, and get the employee's data anonymously that way. Collecting data this way through medical professionals would be accurate, and glassdoor users could trust it's accuracy.Last thing to think about is location. Large companies with several sites (and different departments) might have huge differences in health data. It would be good to test if this is indeed correct, or if the location of employees and health don't have a major correlation.

Hi Valerie, you've highlighted a few areas that really do need a bit of thought, thanks!Firstly, I'm still torn between weighting the data collection more objectively or subjectively; what kind of data does Glassdoor really want? One or the other or both? If you look at their existing features, it's a mixture. Salary and bonus is objective, but all sorts of other measures, like do you approve of your CEO, are entirely subjective.. I'd be interested to hear which data sets people would be more interested in comparing. Maybe it's worth creating a quick Survey to get an idea. Survey Monkey perhaps. Would also be fantastic to get an insight into how people are prepared to enter their data - or have it entered anonymously on their behalf. The company health days you mention are one potentially very successful way of doing it; surely it's a perfect environment for Bupa to be marketing their policie, offering a free check-up at the same time. I'm sure they already have mobile health units - buses etc for doing this. Perhaps blood donation collectors could offer a similar service/data collection.Your point on location is a great one too... it would be fascinating to compare the relative health of people in the same job working in different cities, or even different offices within the same city. Lastly, the elephant in the room that I keep coming back to, is that if you follow the basic incentivisation of this idea, i.e. that companies will be judged against each other on how healthy their staff are, then eventually companies might discriminate against unhealthy employees or applicants. In the light of this, perhaps the prototype phase should focus more on the things a company does to allow an employee the chance to look after their own health, rather than focusing too much on their state of health.Will try to get a survey online in the next day or 2, please make any suggestions you like!

An afterthought... technical detail.. The whole point of Glassdoor is that information is volunteered.. perhaps the Bupa collection/bus/clinic can email the collected personal health information to the individual recipients and provide them with a hyperlink that auto-enters it into Glassdoor (provided the individual signs up or is already a member).. all each person would have to do is to confirm the usual name email and personals.. then they can add the rest of their info to GD.This kind of reverses the dynamic; Glassdoor would now be using Bupa as a channel to collect more members; Bupa's contribution can therefore surely become cost-neutral as Glassdoor pick up the tab..

Thanks for adding me to the team James, I look forward to helping develop and refine the idea with you and everyone else! :)Going along with the health fair idea:Your idea of Bupa emailing the employee with their health information after the health fair is a great idea. Like you said, the email can ask or refer them to glassdoor, and then the employee can decide if they would like to add their information (anonymously) to the site. The barrier to entry it easy for the employee, since the information from the health fair is already filled out for them - all they need to do is consent to glassdoor using this info, and create a new account. Once the account is created, the employee might be even more inclined to anser questions about other health incentives offered by company ( gym's onsite, metro passes, etc.), and the company's work environment itself.Focus more on a company's health incentive offerings:Your point about focusing more on a company's health incentives for this prototype may be the right way to go. The numbers found in a physical can be personal, and we wouldn't want to push people away from a company because they don't see themselves fitting within the average of the typical employee there - or not sign up for glassdoor because they think someone could find out this information about themselves. If focus is instead put on the incentives the company offers, potential employee can most likely see if that company is a good fit, or not.  I saw that you created a survey to collect data on what incentives peoples employer's offer, great job! Can't wait to see the results!

Hi James, absolutely great concept! I love the idea of putting companies against each other in essentially a battle of "who's treating their employees better?" I can imagine this being a great incentive in encouraging companies to invest in the health and well-being of their employees- Good job :)  I was wondering if my concept of a wellness app that allows the employees to rate their well-being could be useful in something like this. It would allow individuals comparing companies to not only compare health statistics, but also the feelings of the employees that work there. Just a thought, I'd love to know what you think.

Hi Asma, I absolutely think the two ideas are compatible, and yours is also a great stand-alone app in any respect. Am gonna have a think about what the balance should be between objective and subjective data: 'How do I feel vs what are my vitals' etc... What are your thoughts so far?Some of your commentors also made some great points about looking after data entry anonymity, and considering in real detail how it is collected and displayed. Will post some more thoughts/pictures soon!
Nice one guys! We love it when folks cross-pollinate insights and highlights from each other's concepts. This is the kind of collaboration which makes our community thrive.
This is a great concept. The Glassdoor survey could also include questions about the physical work environment, as this has a huge impact on mental well-being, in my experience.
Thanks! And I agree on the work environment survey. If you have on thoughts on the specifics of the questions, do go on and post them here. Cheers!

I really like the concept! Companies act on what is measured.There are other websites that do similar things, for example Forbes' "Best Companies To Work For".The ranking of the top companies was determined by taking cumulative average ratings from the half-million employees who responded to the 18-question survey between Nov. 24, 2011 and Nov. 13, 2012. The survey asks employees to rate their satisfaction with their company overall and key workplace factors, such as career opportunities, compensation and benefits, work-life balance, senior management, culture, and values. (http://onforb.es/12kghzV)

Hi Wout, thanks for the info. I definitely think Forbes should consider a companies attitude towards their employees' health and fitness when they put together their survey questions. I think perhaps the benefit with something like glassdoor is that it is a bottom-up growth. By this I mean that it is always open to contribution and the depth and breadth of information only increase over time. In this way the existing annual rating surveys like Forbes are complimented by a live feed, tracking the ups and downs of companies as they strive to improve.

James, yes you're right. Letting employees add information adds much more knowledge then just giving a rating based on survey questions.I really like the update! Again, companies act on what is measured, but now, the data is real, and not just a perception of reality. Great scenario's; I can imagine that companies who already do big efforts to increase health will be eager to start this off. Others will jump aboard to show they are working on it as well.With this kind of data available, and knowing that health issues costs the society a tremendous amount of money (cardiovascular disease, heart disease, cancer, mental illness) the government could give benefits or lower taxes for companies that reach a certain threshold.If a government or state would say; we'll lower income tax with 1% for companies with a health&fitness rating above 85%, I bet a lot of companies would start measuring and improving health right away.One small side note, let's be cautious that we don't stimulate discrimination, as hiring "unhealthy" employees would lower the company's score. The data is anonymous, but obesity is hard to hide. So maybe we should not just look at the current health score, but pay more attention to how employees improve during their career. I'm sure that a good scoring system can be developed that takes everything into account.Maybe this picture could help selling the concept (just to visualize it); http://omycrom.com/GD1.jpg

Hi Wout, thanks so much for the visualization, it's up already! And I totally agree with you that there should be fail-safe protocol for ensuring potential employees with chronic conditions are not discriminated against for fear that they might affect a company's standing.

Thanks! I hope one of these concepts has the chance to be refined.I was thinking, it'd be great to have the possibility to 'merge' concepts when both authors agree. It would combine the best of different worlds and promote collaboration. I might send Meena a message one day with some thoughts to improve openIDEO.Anyway, I think this concept combined with 'How Does My Health Compare' could have a big impact on employee health & fitness!

I agree totally! Have made my own suggestion for a 'plug-in' type relationship tool, and a few others have come up with similar ideas.. why don't you have a look at these and add some thoughts.. strength in numbers!https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/21347181-unite-concepts-pluginhttps://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/22586032-plug-in-conceptshttps://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/20057623-creating-combo-concepts

Great concept!
Digging the idea of prototyping between a few companies, fostering competition and building from there. And great visualisations!
Precisely! Re-directing that competitive nature within the companies and putting it towards something that will benefit the local environment as well as the employees.

Fantastic idea - perhaps the produce could be provided to employees or even used in office restaurants?This concept reminds me of the carrots in the car park inspiration, where a whole town in England has created vegetable gardens for it's citizens: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/carrots-in-the-car-park-.../
