treadmill_desks.description: A work station where you can walk, cycle and exercise while using your computer (and other tasks) -- Coming soon in one of the upcoming prototype storefronts for made in Lower East Side!
treadmill_desks.creator: e42683996625a90919063543481b8f3b

comments.text: This is brilliant, and something I should be doing myself. Sitting at your workstation all day is inherently unhealthy. I have a friend who works at a "walking" desk. He is a "stand-up" working person, who likes to pace around when negotiating deals, so instead of pacing back and forth behind a desk, he paces on his treadmill. Not enough to work up a sweat or to sound out of breath during conversations, but more than a saunter. He has lost 10 pounds in three months and feels so good he often goes to the gym after work to get a "real" workout.

I've been looking into the standup desk option since the summer of 2012 for my desk at work. For the last month I was able to evaluate the WorkFit from Ergotron that provides a standup/sit down option in one unit. Before that, I was using my own homemade standup desk. I also looked into the treadmill option.I don't think it's possible for people to stand for an entire 8-9 hour work day and still be fully productive. Even with a standup desk, I still wanted to sit down from time to time for activities like paperwork (I work in an engineering environment) and lunch. Sometimes, I was just tired from standing. I also sat a lot when I sprained my ankle this Christmas.Behavior: One thing I noticed in an engineering environment is that almost everyone has a laptop and are on the go a lot. This makes portability options viable. I've also noticed some people would go and hide at an empty desk to avoid disruptions and get some work done.Suggestion:I suggest creating a bank of treadmill desks (3-5 units depending upon space) that would be open for anyone. They could be scheduled like a conference room or just open. It would provide the walking benefit for limited periods of times and be more cost effective as it could be used for all employees instead of just those that have one at their desk. If it catches on, more walking desks could be added later.Conclusion:The treadmill desk is a great idea and I believe these types of work stations are the future for progressive companies. Old school companies have a hard time believing this will benefit anyone and they don't want to spend the money.
Hi Kevin! Thank you so much for these amazing insights. I think it's a great idea to have these workout stations kind of like a conference room that people can pop in and use.

I've seen this concept beginning to take shape in smaller corporations with great effect.  Some are also adding heavily subsidized aikido or yoga classes to the mix as well.  Yoga has been an offered general benefit to all employees and the aikido class has been used to purposefully build strong internal teams amongst management and members of working groups.  The standup / treadmill desk approach offers a unique individual style of health and productivity.
Thanks Jason!

Hi Sarah, I just thought I'd share this link I came across via Amazon today while searching for compact exercise machines for my home: http://fitdesk.net/It looks like someone has already brought to market a product that is designed to allow people to cycle in place while working on their laptop! Perhaps if your concept goes into realization (good luck!) you might find some insights from the fitdesk.
I love this! I'm thinking of getting one myself ^^

Hi Sarah!Great concept! Looks like a good way to help employees balance work and life - while still at work!I agree it would be a good idea to have experiments on existing treadmills to find out what is most important to workers.  A few things I think would be good to test would be:1. Size of work/desk/laptop area: how much space do workers need or want?2. Do workers/companies want the ability to buy an all-in-one machine that will come with desk pre-installed? Or, do they want the ability to retrofit an older treadmill? 2.1 Retro fitting another treadmill might be a cheaper option for the worker/company, especially if they already have a workout room at their office.3. How much does noise have an impact on the work space? If the set up is in a big open area does this have a huge impact on sound, and does that matter?Last thing that probably needs to be considered is the wear and tear on the treadmills. They will be used at low speeds, but workers could use them for many hours a day potentially - or several workers could use them each for a few hours. There needs to be a way for the treadmill to inform the walker how many miles/hours they have walked per day (in total) and let them know when they are getting close to the limit that is allowed in the warranty.Treadmills getting a lot of use will require maintenance, the treadmill company needs needs a way to make sure the walker isn't abusing the motor/etc. by walking more than is allowed - voiding the machine's warranty.

Where I work, two people have built treadmill desks. They both have iMacs with extra monitors, so they built out full sized desks. They are both very quiet and not disruptive to the other people nearby. The keyboards are louder than the treadmills.
That is great to hear that the desks can be modified to be very large, and are quite! Thanks for the input!
Thanks Elil for chiming it! Glad to see it working with your colleagues.

I think it might be interesting to see clinical trials measuring CRP (C-reactive protein, a biomarker for inflamation) levels in the blood, comparing effects of a variety of activities: working on computer seated at desk, working on computer while walking on treadmill, and walking on treadmill without computer work. I don't think CRP levels give real-time, instantaneous data, so I don't think you could have subjects jump on a treadmill and watch CRP start falling real-time. Maybe trials could have subjects work only at desk for say a week stretch and measure their CRP, then have them work on the treadmill for some hours per day for a week and measure the CRP. I'm not an authority, so I'm just speculating. Anyone know more about this sort of thing? In any case it seems like having some quantitative data would be interesting. Anyway, I love this treadmill workstation concept, and can see it really taking off.
Thanks James! I'm no expert either, but it definitely seems like a good way to prove whether this is useful or not.

There is this phenomenon called exergaming. it is the idea of implementing exercise in games. Exercise bikes hooked up to racing video games or other things of the like.Perhaps creating an active break room in the office, where the options of things to do are play a quick race on a bike, dance on a dance game, or even climb and indoor rockwall treadmill. This would allow employees to utilize their break for healthier activities and engage their minds in something enjoyable.It's Funtertaining!http://www.exergamefitness.com/

I like the idea of gamifying the work out while you work idea. Maybe it could be combined with the climbing everest challenge so that your team makes progress on that goal while going about their work day.
Agreed! Great idea Bobby!

Perhaps starting off with something cheaper might convince employers to make the investment in treadmills eventually. I currently use a stability ball on top of a Bosu as my desk chair. This combo is more difficult than just a plain stability ball, offers more variety, and is great if you're vertically challenged. :)  If I want to stand, I can do Steps on the Bosu. I can also pop off and do sit ups on the stability ball. Yes it's probably an OSHA nightmare but it may cost employers only around $100. Once they've accepted a cheaper idea, it may be easier to upsell to the treadmill desk.
That's a great idea Reba! I was also looking around Craigslist, and there are a lot of used treadmills, bikes, etc. that are around $100 as well.
Interesting insights from the BBC today:Treadmill desks: How practical are they? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21076461
How can we make this concept different from what already exists?

Hi Sarah, just a small suggestion for this concept:Focus on incorporating speech input technology so emails and documents can be created without a keyboard. This way you don't have to isolate your upper body and you don't need to rely on the foam padding mentioned in the video. Especially since the padding could cause too much pressure on the forearms, if people rely on it too much as a stabilizer, or tension in the shoulder.

Amy, I would be concerned about the disruption that would cause in the office. Imagine 50 people in an office all talking to their computers! I see your point about posture and such, but maybe the idea would be to use the time to mostly read, or respond to a few emails, rather than do a lot of typing.

I definitely agree with you, Nigel. I was actually envisioning this to take place in a more open space, perhaps outside on the terrace so the sound levels don't get out of control in a room. The machines can also be staggered a few meters a part (I know this will have to be a big terrace!). Also, there are headsets/mics that you can speak right into so the speech is captured better and easily. I think this will help with the noise level because people won't be yelling at their computers.

Hey Sarah, thanks for adding me to the team! I also came across a blog post of a guy who uses a treadmill desk and kept a log to see when he had "walked across the country" on his treadmill. That made me think that this concept could be combined with some of the other wellness concepts on here for office team-building or competitions.Here's a link to the post that gave me the idea:www.treadmill-desk.com/2007/07/walking-across-america.html
I think this is a great idea Adam. I think it could work really well with the climbing Everest challenge.
Oh, that's a good cross-pollination idea - did you post on the Climbing Everest challenge about it? Otherwise, I can. Thanks!
I did, crediting you of course!
Great work guys  we love it when folks cross-pollinate goodness between the awesome concepts our community has posted!

Building on James' idea, many workplaces already have fitness facilities. Perhaps utilization would be higher if someone could continue their work day while doing some power walking on a treadmill or a bit of spinning. Simply by adding laptop mounts to fitness machines, people could seamlessly continue their workday while getting a light workout. This would also overcome one potential issue - smelly coworkers. Keep the workout in the workout room, but support people getting their work done at the same time.If it is a given that a certain amount of work needs to get done in a day, then most people would choose to spend the extra time at home with their kids. However, if you can work out and work at the same time, there could be a higher uptake.

I hadn't looked at the concept in this way, but the word "treadmill" does evoke running and/or workout. I guess I think of the concept more as a way to help people stay in motion and change positions while working more than permitting one to do at workout while at work. Walking, no matter the pace, or even just standing, instead of sitting statically all day, dramatically improves health. I agree that running on a treadmill in the office could create environmental (e.g. odor, noise, etc.) issues. Perhaps these could be specially designed for walking...
YES! Exactly Areca. That's absolutely what I was thinking as well.

Okay, I get it. It also doesn't really make sense to be running at a fast pace because you wouldn't really be able to get anything done. But maybe you can do both. Have the ability to use a treadmill in the office while working at a slow, steady pace, and have laptop or iPad stands on the gym equipment so you can review reports or do other more passive work while doing a workout.

Hey Sarah,  You asked for a document regarding the correlation of physical activity to increased learning and memory.  Here is a paper from The Salk Institute. van Praag, H.; Christie, B. R.; Sejnowski, T. J.; Gage, F. H.; Running Enhances Neurogenesis, Learning, and Long-Term Potentiation in Mice, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America, 96 (23), 13427-13431, 1999It studies a group of white mice who exercise on a treadmill/ "hamster wheel" contraption....no disrespect to the mice but it was clearly the hamsters design.  (perhaps a refinement of mechanical design to be considered). To paraphrase in my own voice, one group of mice was strapped to the "hamster wheel" and  after a period of exercise repeatedly performed a challenge maze where they needed to locate a camouflaged platform submerged under murky water.  (they hate to swim and the platform allowed them to stop swimming).  The other couch potato mice could not find the platform unless it was coated with pudding and rainbow sprinkles....sort of.....you get the picture. Sprinkles aside, exercised mouse remembered location and performed better than couch potato mouse.I am also aware that the correlated effects can be quick and fairly dramatic and "may" even be utilized for things such as cramming  densely packed mission details into operations personnel.  Did someone say "military application"  or "national security interest?" One other thing,  We spoke bout using the treadmill as a platform for part of a  sensor array feeding information on relevant user stats like heart rate time on machine, calories burned etc for correlation with some memory/learning performance routine...like maybe the user repeats a  string of mixed digits and letters that pops up at intervals as the user does their other work. Haven't really thought about that item much. ( I do think  health clubs etc might consider it as an add on to their wellness programs....call busn dev.)However, what I do know is that SRI made a nifty correlation engine (that's a tame description) for the application that became Apple's virtual assistant called, "Siri". You could try to get a license of the source code for the SRI product and develop mobile apps on smart phones (design treadmill to smartphone blue tooth interface...easy)  turning them into into node collectors and like Siri, it would report and learn the behaviors of the users...."all users" and put the correlation together to discover optimal time...calories burned etc. to achieve optimum results with exercise as a means to memory/ learning enhancement. It would take a code development effort integrating  the SRI source code for the mobile app and probably a "healthy" license fee to SRI....who knows OpenIDEO or IDEO relationships with SRI might pave the way for a test case deployment for free or priced based upon some projected revenues....  or they might decide to agree to wait for  future equity in the venture.Either way....(and I apologize if it has already been said by someone)...but, "I love this idea on several levels....I'd run with it...."

Thanks Eric for sharing these really great insights. I agree that the sensor side of things would provide great metrics to track and monitor, but if it becomes too difficult to implement technically, an easier solution would be to just use targets that sports equipments already use (granted, they should be comparable between one another).

Re: "too difficult technically"...do you men expensive? We should talk as I have few possibilities already in progress in other applications....I need to check  few things on my side first  ..Thanks for including me Sarah...

An implementation questions to think about, as well as a couple of conceptual solutions:What about sweat? Perhaps you could have a dock on the side of the machine that holds a laptop out of the way and then there was waterproof keyboard, mouse, and monitor in front of you (or touchscreen/ipad)Also, after reading this I thought about having a gym based machine that already had a computer/ipad built into it and people could simply use GoToMyPC and get access to their desktop while being at the gym. So rather than integrating the gym into the workplace, put the workplace in the gym.

Really good point Kyle! To be honest, I have not thought about this in the context of a big heavy workout, more for like walking and just getting people to move. I'd imagine that having employees conduct complicated workouts might actually go against their work productivity...But I definitely see the point of the spin-off and I like what you and James are trying to do with the gym!

The employees at my work that have treadmill desks tend to rock out a slow, steady pace. They don't really work up a sweat, but the long term, lower impact movement is far better than sitting or standing all day. I would think you still need to work higher impact workouts into your week at least 2-3 times. I also think there are workouts that are essential that require 100% of your focus (such as yoga) that could never be replaced by this.
Definitely!

Sounds great, Sarah! I would love to try one of these myself.  Do you have any challenges or areas of opportunity for Treadmill Desks that you'd like to share to help folks understand where they might join the conversation?  Or perhaps insight into how to convince your office this is worth the cost?

Hi Nathan,Very good point. I guess it depends a lot on the office environment, but some workplaces are more inclined to invest in things that make their employees happier and healthier (e.g. workplaces that offer free meals, or gym memberships, etc.). I would assume the argument would be easier in this case. For other workplaces, the case would have to be built around how an incremental investment can have a significant impact in employees' well-being, thus impacting both how well they work and how long they are willing to stay. It's difficult to put hard figures around this given the nature of the experiment, but there's definitely enough management literature to back up the general idea behind it.

I love this idea, and a few earlier commenters have made suggestions that might be less expensive and therefore easier to try and ease into than having to purchase treadmills and either standing desks or desks that could transition between sitting and standing. The biggest is walking meetings, which in many offices would be very easy to implement. Another option for incorporating exercise into meetings would be adding something like ten minutes of yoga to the beginning of staff meetings, or another short burst of activity. For offices where conditions make walking outside less accessible, there might be ways for companies to incorporate yoga, stretching or another light indoor activity like tossing a medicine ball into meetings, particularly one-on-one.As Nigel mentioned, for companies that already have gyms, figuring out a way to create simple laptop attachments or mounts would be another great way to inexpensively let people try out working at a treadmill desk or cycling desk. Something that could even be created among employees with or without financial involvement from the organization would be something of a health library, that could include anything from fitness/ health books or exercise DVDs, to ice skates, rock climbing equipment or kayaks.
I agree with you Emma, and I definitely like your point re: companies with existing gyms and making the mounting easier.

If the spin bikes had stands for laptops, etc., it would also be wonderful to harness the energy to power the laptop such as http://www.environmentteam.com/concept/recycle-bicycle-gadget-harnessing-pedaling-energy/
This is brilliant. Employees could earn rewards for powering their own workstations!
Agreed!
Great way of keeping fit while you work! especially for people who struggle to find time to go to the gym. Good idea.
Thanks Megan!

There is great opportunity here for collaboration with another concept in refinement called "Climbing Mount Everest". By combining treadmill desks with a platform/app that does distance tracking and visible shared progress toward a community goal (eg. climbing everest virtually), we might be able to much better traction for walk-working.I could definitely see a company providing the hardware and the software platform together as one service. Then sell-install-maintain for larger companies.
Absolutely! I agree with you David and I can definitely see ways to link this to Climbing Mount Everest!

My former employer had these, and one thing that made it easier to stick with using them was that they were placed in good locations. The ones I used were near some windows and skylights. The bright, sunny area and the view definitely helped motivate me to actually use them, as a way to escape my cube for a while!
Interesting. Thanks for sharing your insights Adam!

Actually, I am aware of real scientific evidence that physical activity causes conditions in the brain that greatly enhance the ability to learn and retain information.  The desks could be sensor stations piping reports of worker activity level...heart rate etc and then correlate some performance based evaluation of learning/memory on the job.  This could correlate ideal conditions for optimal learning under the activity-increases-learning hypothesis.Of course if job performance lags you may find your treadmill speeding up....."Faster Sarah you have that big presentation tomorrow!"
Mmm... That's really interesting, Eric. Would you have a link or a document to share about that?

i don't know about the short-term effects (e.g., exercise now, better memory/performance for things i'm doing now), but there is a large and growing scientific literature on long-term links between physical activity and mental sharpness. for instance, one major protective factor against cognitive decline and dementia due to aging is regular physical fitness.here's a website for a lab i'm familiar with (same university) that studies this intensely: http://www.pitt.edu/~bachlab/LabSite/Home.html
Thanks for sharing this link Joel! Interesting stuff.

This is a great way of keeping fit whilst working instead of having to make time to do either of these activities separately. Perhaps this could be implemented with other training machines such as bikes or leg press machine as well as a treadmill.Great work
Agreed!

Hey Sarah, congrats on getting this one through to Refinement. It's a great idea and so much room for shoot-offs and individual interpretations.On seeing the really simple device in your picture, I had another thought - you could very easily reverse the paradigm and suggest that gyms make all their treadmills laptop-freindly during working hours! This is their off-peak time so naturally it would be beneficial for them to attract more attendance, and then stressed employees could take a couple of hours away from their desks (and possibly their internet connections, added bonus!) to pile through that mountain of work while striding along and keeping an eye on the sports match going on on the tv etc...It might not be everyone's cup of tea but adds another variation to a great idea. :)
interesting thought! i would guess this would work more for cycling machines than treadmills. i already see people catching up on reading while cycling at the gym.
I agree, with Joel, quite an interesting idea! Probably a reason to get me into the gym in the first place :) Thanks James!

Totally agree Sarah. It is so true that sitting for 8 hours at the workplace degrades someone's health. The most apparent indication especially for men is the belly shape change :D. While most of the hours a day, at least at my working place, is spent on meeting, I'd suggest that meeting rooms should be placed on a reasonable walking distance!
Thanks Agung!

I have a standing desk at my work, because they will convert any desk into a standing one at the employee's request. Many people have it, but we have sitting in all our conference rooms - I would love to see standing set ups in some of the conference rooms as well.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel felt there was potential for  inspiration from Zombies, Run! https://www.zombiesrungame.com. They also wondered what if this was implemented using bikes? And could there be tie ups with the evolving Climbing Mt Everest concept? Perhaps you might reach out and add the concept author to your Virtual Team.Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Hi Sarah. Great concept. I recall seeing a commercial, I think it was by Verizon, where a gentleman was delivering a speech from tredmill/moving-walkway style podium. I'm not attempting to extinguish the flame of your idea. But trying to build on it based on what I didn't see in that shot. His audience wasn't active. Curiously, all of them were seated. My suggestion... I think you should go Wii Fit!The Nintendo Wii (with fit) transformed the living room into a family workout room.  I never thought I would see the day where my family and I would engage (as a group) in physical activity in front of the television. Your concept has the ability to do that for the workplace. Think StarTrek. Think Gattaca. Offices can transform individual workstations or create ROOMS with "Active Work" and Relaxization/Rejuvenation equipment. These rooms could include tredmills (like the mockup above), stationary bikes and eliptical machines with complete work stations.Lots of the concepts for this challenge only focus on the being active part of wellness. What about the mental and emotional aspects of wellness too. There could be a corner of the room with a sound dome pictured here: http://www.powerview.com/20InchSoundDome.html The dome could play relaxing music. It can be an area where workers meditated or praticed tai chi - a gentle way to fight stress. You could add a projector and have video with calming images to ehnance the mood or an instructor to ehnance the experience.In addition there is an opportunity to leverage experimental/emerging technologies to address other aspects of wellness like channeling focus. For example, there is an exhibit at the museum of science and industry - Chicago. It challenges to individuals to "out relax" each other. http://www.msichicago.org/whats-here/exhibits/you/the-exhibit/your-vitality/mindball/ This would be a fun and creative addition to the "Active Work & Rejuvenation" space.Ok I've said a lot. But I won't leave without a suggestion on how to bring this idea together in a neatly packaged concept. If I were tasked with pacakaging this Idea, I'd find/hire an tradeshow booth designer to render concepts of this futeristic space. I've worked with many designers that do an amazing job of blowing out concepts like this.Good luck in the refinement stage Sarah. I'm easy to track down if you would like to chat.Landon
I like the idea.  It would be cool to somehow self generate power to power your computer, ipad, etc.  Make the entire console carbon neutral.
Ha, interesting! Maybe even have the entire floor as a giant power generating mat :)

Another thought would be to incorporate a cycling desk.  While you would still be sitting which is one of the things you're trying to overcome with you concept it would be an easy way to generate power. Just a thought..
...just saw that people have already suggested that.  Woops.  Didn't mean to copy anyone!
No worries at all! Great minds think alike :)

Hi Sarah, great idea!Naomi has picked up something I wanted to suggest - cycling. The fact that your legs can motor away while your arms and hands are free to carrying on typing interruption-free would perhaps offer a comfier set-up for some people. It might also be a nice half-way house between being completely sedentary and standing up.In terms of a pilot project, perhaps one option would be to test out a few differently types of workstations in one of those pay-as-you-go type of shared workspaces for freelancers. In this way your are getting a direct feedback from the workers themselves, rather than getting filtered feedback diluted by companies and their differing agendas and existing efficiencies.Would be intrigued to try one of these!
Hi James,Thanks for bringing that point up again! I am not that familiar with stationary cycling but I could definitely see your point.Your second point is really great, I added it to the concept!

Sarah, This is a great idea! You could even push it further and have treadmills as an integrated part of all workstations. Desks could go up and down (crank or electronically) as desired. Chairs could collapse so they could be rolled aside. Monitors and/or laptop docks could be on adjustable arms. The treadmill could be integrated into the floor, so at any moment one could get up whenever desired and start walking (say, while taking a conference call or reading a report).I love the idea of being able to move between sitting, standing, the chair, the exercise ball, mouse on the left or right, walking, even jogging within in seconds.
Thanks Areca! I'm absolutely with you -- the modularity aspect to it would definitely make it more usable and less "imposed" in the workspace.

Great idea Sarah! I really like the suggestion you made about it being a "bonding exercise for employees to build this together" too, it could be a fun team experience that brings people together and encourages them to use it later on.
Thanks Asma! And agreed :)
Hilarious and awesome
Thanks Evan :)

I love this idea! I also think that workplaces that focus on modifying the way employees use their desks will allow this to be possible, without complicated infrastructure. Laptops have become a big preference in the workplace due to portability and personal preferences and I think this could help increase the options of moving around during the day. Treadmill desks could be set-up in particular areas, in addition to other types of exercise and modified stations, like standing desks, or even bike or stairmaster ones. Employees could then move themselves around given how they feel that day or the extent of activity they want to perform. There could also be areas more conducive to meetings, with a bit more space and compatibility for this purpose. I think even just relocating a lot through the workday can help get everyone up and moving and foster this mindset becoming a habit. For those individuals that need a larger setup or can't use a laptop, they could have a choice of a designated actual workstation where they can have a regular desk chair when they want to sit but also have a treadmill desk or some other setup to allow them to have this as well.
Thanks so much for your comment Naomi! And I definitely agree with your point re: modularity and flexibility of the workplace and its furniture.

comments.text: How could this work?
Could this principle be applied to the user's entire diet at home as well as work?

In regards to rapid prototyping and implementation, you could utilize an Arduino Chip. Arduino is an open-source electronics prototyping platform based on intuitive hardware and software. Arduino senses environments by receiving input from a variety of sensors. The sensors can affect the surrounding environment by controlling lights, motors and actuators, which could identify properties of a fruit to determine whether its ripe or spoiled. Visit http://www.arduino.cc for more information.

Daniel thanks for the comment thats exactly what I had in mind I was also looking into using Processing. Combined with Open - Cv base code for object recognition i.e. blob detection and colour differentials.Thanks it would great to get some more feedback later on in the refinement phase

"Combined suggestive Nudges and recommendations to new and exciting fruits, keep people engaged with healthy" is what really stood out to me, as i totally agree.I definitely think this concept would work as all it takes is a little encouragement to get people on the right track to healthier living.
Exactly my thoughts thanks

You could even implement the long term health benefits of fruit for certain individuals that require specific vitamins in their diet. Letting them try new fruits which may have same benefit to them.Giving people a choice rather than just the basic apple, banana or orange.

taking_a_break_at_break.description: Is thinking or stressing about work on your break really a break? A stress free zone is an area where employees can disconnect themselves from the hard work so they are able to recharge,relax, socialize and release their stress.
taking_a_break_at_break.creator: 06c56a89949d617def52f371c357b6db

comments.text: Great concept, having breaks at work is very important. I think all work places should include these concepts.
Good point, have breaks at work is so important . I use to have breaks meanwhile I have to do some works, it's so useful because I continue with mor energy after the break.

This concept is grate! Many time I take a break and we spend our time talking and thinking how much work do I have to do, or making plans for doing it. Encourage people to make a important disconnection in the breaks is very interesting for the healthy of the employee.
The concept is award winning

I like how its sound: stress free zone! Its interesting to observe that people from office areas are trying to personalize their personal space with a lot of small things, like posters, personal photos, gadgets, in order to fell better or to reduce the stress level.

Great concept and great imagery, a break should be 'work free', otherwise its not really a break. 'A simple and effective break can really have an impact on how you spend the rest of your day.' - I 100% agree with this statement.
Cheers Tommy.

Good concept! I love the fact that it gives the employees have an area to relieve stress and relax, along with a place for employees to socially interact via different activities. I also like the fact that theres not just one activity for employees to participate in, but numerous as not everyone will want to do the same thing.
Thanks Megan. Yes it can be a soical platform as well as giving yourself a mental break. Either way when you go back out to work again you should feel fresher and put in more effort.
Wicked idea Mohamed.. you should also make it a no tech zone so know one will be using there mobiles for emailing, calling or anything. It would just be nice to switch off from everything and chill.
Thanks Chris. Yeah that also can work, a chance to disconnect from the tech world.
Clever consept Mo, many people in there breaks oftenly smoke to relief stress so i think your activities would be great for them tokeep healthy and prevent breaktimes for only smoking.
Thanks, yeah that is true. As well as being a healthier option it is also a chance to be social and to take a break from the working environment
Greate concept Mohamed. I like the fact that there's a wide range of activities for people to choose from, depending on how they want to release stress.
Exactly the idea behind it, giving people more to choose from will therefore cater for a wider range of people

comments.text: In a more specific sense, you can look at this as simply saying "No" to things. Of course - in a polite way and backed up with reasons. Not to be rude. This can lead to great increases in productivity, since you can focus on the important tasks (say, that presentation on Friday) as opposed to the less important distractions (your inclusion on a 500-person thread that does not need your input).The action in this case? Ask to be removed from the thread. Quite often we're included by default, but have no need to be involved in the conversation. Of course, if you are able to add value, then this doesn't apply.This thought pattern should be applied to meetings as well, which isn't new information, but still happens so often at work. If someone doesn't need to attend, they shouldn't. They can use the time to focus on what's important for them.Doing less is really a means to an end - that is, increasing focus. Numbers 3 and 4 in your list are what I'm playing off of here.Thanks Denny!

comments.text: Nice concept Fay. Besides from learning you get to share what you know with others which will get them to communicate with each other aswell.

I really like the idea, im not sure about the "horse riding, cycling or singing" specification as not everyone may be into it, however that aside i think the concept is great, and you communicated it well.

Thanks Djorn! Those three activities were just meant to act as examples, but reading it back I realise that might not have come across! I think this concept could apply to any activity or hobby as there is always an argument for improved wellbeing from something you enjoy.

Love the idea! :)  Well, I am sort-of partial because I just posted a very similar idea! Check it out: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/leverage-workplace-diversity/In my concept, I was thinking about teaching colleagues for free - but depending upon the subject matter, I agree that some of them could be offered at a subsidized cost.

trying_to_raise_the_bar.description: Getting workplace wellness initiatives off the ground can be difficult and motivations are not always where you think they are going to be.  People have a lot on their plate when they are at work, how can we make health easy for them?
trying_to_raise_the_bar.creator: 78b421309e310f1950b83b418b1ebc04

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Lots of great thought-starters on this one! I'm especially digging the simplicity of the example to make healthy food an easier option.

Yes!This reminds me of the BE, DO, HAVE model.  In most cases, people think they need to DO things in order to HAVE things in order to BE who they think they should be. DO, HAVE, BE is a thing of the past and it really has never worked.However, with the BE, DO, HAVE model, the team leaders and executive management become that which the employees can reflect.... and respect.  Gleaning from your example, Bobbie provides and shares a healthy food option (she is BEing) an example of health, therefore others DO by choosing her offerings and what HAVE you? A healthier workplace.Engaged leaders BEing examples by eating well, joining in on ping pong, and breaking cultural norms by taking meetings for a walk outside creates a ripple effect and more engagement among teams. It increases morale to not only the teams but also their families and friends through a ripple effect. This applies to all industries from design to fabrication; from legislation to education.Question is, how do we cultivate our future leaders and transform our present leaders to BE a cause in the matter of creating healthy workplaces and communities?Well, that could come in training, in inspiration through seminars, or a restructuring of the current management model, but where it must come from first is by the leader's mettle and integrity.Through their BEing, they will undoubtedly take the steps and DO what's necessary to attract a talented supportive team with which they HAVE a tremendous ripple effect of success.As you said, Suzy, we must raise the bar!

Nice build Rabekah and it echoes thoughts from another one of our interviews with the Institute for Mindful Leadership, http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/mindful-leadership/?at=1353009244

trying_to_raise_the_bar.title: Trying to raise the bar

electronic_free_area.description: phone charging locker outside the electronic free area.
electronic_free_area.creator: b18e7465f66bcb6420b5015c7ce7b4af

comments.text: I like the idea of avoiding technology during your free time at work. This concept is effective as it will allow people to leave there devices and instead socialise with colleagues and relax in the electronic free area. This idea of charging devices would impact the business on energy efficiency though but over all it is a great idea.

Really like the concept Kas. Leaving all your cares and troubles behind before you enter a calm and tranquil environment would certainly help me relax and return back to work with a fresh and energised mind. It would be interesting to see how different environments or choice architecture can influence the individual's state of mind and how you can cater for a large number of people occupying the same space.

Lots of potential in terms of designing this spaces. I agree. Not only can you use this space to take a break, also to take an important piece of work there and get it done. Everyone can see you are working, even you are not answering calls or mails for a minute.

Hi Lee, many thanks for you reply. I do agree with you about the environment affecting people's state of mind, and it is useful to know that you feel such an environment would benefit you personally. Research has shown that people who are happy psychologically produce better results at work. In terms of catering for the numbers of people using the space, it will come down mainly to the design of the room and how the furniture is arranged within it as to how much space is available for users. For example, larger furniture like desks and tables would be in corners of the room close to walls, not taking up the  important space for people who wish to use the majority of the area to make use of bean bags and cushions, in less restricted positions. Bernhard, I do agree, and using the space to complete work is an option, although I personally would like to use the area only for relaxing and doing activities unrelated to work, such as reading so I feel more focused when i return to my work, however, this is not necessarily the case for everyone.

I find fascinating that in a short period we are switching from the pursuit of pervasive connectivity to the need of connection-free areas: from free-wifi zones to wifi-free zones. Kastriot, I think your concept is a good interpretation of a growing need. The recharging shelf concept description seems well defined, I was wondering if you had more details regarding the electronic-free area, as the space organization of this environment as well as its activities are key to demonstrate the value of your concept.
"from free-wifi zones to wifi-free zones" brilliant quote!

Hi David, thank you for comments. In response to your question regarding the organisation of the environment and the activities taking place in there; I think the idea's would come mainly from the trial run that would be tested out in advance. Ideally the area will be designed using a minimalistic concept in order to keep the mind of the user free from distraction. For example; simple, calming colour schemes and furniture designed using clean lines and comfortable furnishings. In terms of activities, the users of the room should, on entering the room, feel instantly relaxed and calm, and should want to carry out only quiet relaxing activities such as reading and drawing etc. I don't feel there needs to be any particular activities available in the space aside from books, tables, and pillows/bean bags.

I really like this concept. Most people own smartphones and can't seem to put them down, even when they are eating. In a workplace it would be great to see a phone-free zone. It would be like stepping into a completely foreign territory. People tend to get caught up with the happenings on the outside world when they are using their phones and maybe it would be better for the user to direct their attention to the workplace, and have less things to worry about.Great work Kass

I like the idea of getting away from the electronic equipment for a while. Its also similar to some shopping centers I've seen lockers where people can charge their phones and return after their phones are charged.The concept could be powerful in reducing levels of stress and returning with a fresh mind.

"The concept could be powerful in reducing levels of stress and returning with a fresh mind." very true. Also i see a lot of potential in this area to be used as workspace. No disturbance from mails or streaming digital data flow, will raise productivity.

Very nice idea about locking away and charging your phone, wouldn't it be interesting if we could flip the concept. Having people entering a charging station/cubicle to rest and relax literally recharging themselves. This could be quite an interesting incentive to take regular small breaks. From Lees comment you could possibly have adaptable rooms that can be changed by the users to become more personal. I.e. Personal music selection projection mapped scenery creating a desired environment.

I get your point but i think you are proposing a different concept here. The point of the "Electronic free area" is to get away from your digital stress, to get some stuff done. Also people using this area would most likely have time to chat and have real discussion, conversations we know from the "pre mobile device age". I can also see the benefit from from small cubical like spaces for people to go and switch off. In this concept i think the shared communal electronic free space is an advantage.

Great concept! I love the fact that by having an electronic free area, this can allow for the employees to escape from the hectic stresses of daily working life. This room may also become an area for social interaction a place for people to catch up or even just have some time on their own to re charge. Good concept.
I agree with you Megan, like in the old days ;)

Very nice concept! Employers should encourage people to take a break from digital responsibility's to get important stuff done.Its combining the good of the "Internet age" with the good of the "pre Internet age" Well done.

electronic_free_area.title: Electronic free area

This would be entertaining, Great idea.

Truly good, I remember years ago during my apprenticeship in a sports store we use to have little ski pole "sword fights" in the warehouse. Its the kind of stuff that makes me smile when I remember. Good Times !

Unusual concept but i think it could work very well. I really like this. Laughter is always a missing factor in a lot of workspaces so bringing this important ingredient into our workplaces will reap all kinds of healthy benefits. Good work

awesome thoughts on how humour and play can relieve stress and promote healthier living in and beyond the workplace? Do you share  it collaboratively or do you observe, perceive and reflect individually? comments.text: Nice work, Georgie! Very imaginative. Just wondering, is the concept exclusive for larger companies who would have the financial means to make the 'dream' happen? When I first read your concept title, I thought how cool it would be for people to share their actual dreams they may have dreamt that night, simply by writing it down, or drawing a picture. It could be inspirational for co-workers. Just a thought.

I love this idea, Georgie! A good reminder that employees are not machines but people with likes, dislikes, hopes and dreams!I definitely think this is an idea worthy of an experiment. Could it be possible to incorporate some crowd funding element to this too? Allowing people to make financial contributions to people's dreams, as well as perhaps a financial contribution from a company for the top dreams?
crowd-sourcing is an wonderful idea and it increases the sustainability and the scaling of the initiative :)

Great and inspirational!!!! It is wonderful to think about psychological and emotional health in the workplace. I wonder, also, how to make the "dreams" an asset for the company that invests in them and in social capital at disposal. I mean, of course, more satisfied worker in an enabling environment are also more productive. However, it would be also further stimulating for companies to invest in dreams that increase their capital/products a little more directly. This way, there would be a larger number of companies/businesses/work-places that are stimulated to invest in their employees...

music.description: Music reduces muscle tension and improves body movement and coordination. Also,
music.creator: c21692874e7108cf3046ba29b139499d

comments.text: Of course!!! at my jobs we had stereo, with radio, so the work team were designated one week per person that was in control of the music. Like human jukeboxes. one would choose a radio station, another one brought their entire cd collection with them to work, another one plugged in his mp3-player with playlists that were adapted especially for the teams musical flavor...

That is cool...I want to work there! That is a good story; it sounds like it brings back memories. I have never worked in an office that allows music to play openly, but during the holidays I recall the office playing Christmas and other holiday music. It completely changed the atmosphere.

by having equal designated timeslots in a rotating schedule, you kind of remove the potential arguments and conflicts. It is like, you have no right to complain about the music this week, because we did not complain about the music you choose to play last week!In sweden it almost like a custom to have radios on and playing (but not in a too loud volume of course) And of course christmas songs during the whole of december was occuring on many workplaces and shops.
I like how this involves everyone from the team to be responsible for the workplace and the atmosphere there.

...inexpensive to implement, as well. many social commentators have observed how our cultures are becoming more plugged in and isolated. Music has power to connect us to one another, communally (think concerts). I read in a Washington Post article (2007, Noise Pollution Takes Toll on Health and Happiness, by Rick Weiss) that uplifting music increases helping behavior.

Nice! Do you know if it is typical for companies to promote employee groups, such as bands? Because that would be a great way to build community while allowing employees to express themselves in ways they may otherwise not be able to.

I think it depends on the company and type of work it performs. Some organizations have a headphone policy, which is much different than having low volume music playing openly for a shared communal experience. Some music, preferred by some, may be objectionable to others. However, if you have ever been in a coffee shop that plays classical music in the background, it is hard to leave. :)

some shops and cafs with few tables play sometimes so annoying rock music or radio station with annoying advertising breaks in it, it is to get people not staying as long by the table, to cause high rotation of new customers. the smaller caf the louder the music and the crappier sound quality blaring. It is for economical reasons, and staff there hate it.I guess that most people working 9 hours in an office cubicle, would love to have jukeboxes with a new theme each work day Spotify? Pandora?

music.title: Music

wellness_worx.description: How can health insurers, employers and employees work better together and all win in the end?  Let's use health premiums to offer a suite of wellness services to improve the health of workers and communities.  That's how Wellness Worx! (UPDATED)
wellness_worx.creator: b137fe5f102f71582f3681fa3bc3d642

comments.text: Hey there Amol  If you're interested in pursuing your idea further, you might want to check out the Knight News Challenge. They're focusing on the topic of health and the winning entries will receive grant funding to bring ideas to life. You can check it out here http://kng.ht/1aunB0h.

I like this concept a lot, but for insurance companies to truly embrace it, there needs to be a clear definition of what "participation" means. If I'm an insurer, I don't want to give away discounts because someone signs up at the enrollment period and never attends the classes/gym/etc. I think you would need to either: involve the organizations offering the healthy services to track that patients are actually attending (this would have logistical implications, but perhaps could be managed by the insurer mandating that the employer present this information for the select group of programs they choose), or track average outcomes vs. the nation/region or vs. baseline (this would be easier to implement but maybe more controversial).I see why you wouldn't want to track patient-specific outcomes, but as the insurer I need to have some metric that my money is being used well. I think this could be implemented as just an exit clause for the insurer, if you haven't improved average outcomes by x%  by the 2 year mark, discounts on premiums are reduced, if you have improved then discounts remain. If you've gone above and beyond, then maybe discounts even increase. The same could be done based on outcomes.

Wow you've done you're homework! Love that you've got lots of the numbers here. I think money is definitely a good motivator for people. I wonder if there's a way to make the money that goes into the employees pocket bigger? I remember hearing about Weyco a few years ago - they gave employees 1.5 years to quit smoking, at which point they were fired if they were still smoking. If I remember correctly over 75% of the smokers stopped smoking. I'm not suggesting firing people of course, but in the Weyco case, the financial impact to the employee was significant and the ultimate motivation.Another issue that others have alluded to is changing employee behavior. I think part of the employer message needs to be that we're all in this together - i.e. employers are supportive and involved together with employees. For example, company leaders are actively participating in the wellness programs alongside the other employees. Maybe have a routine morning calisthenics session, like what you see in some East Asian countries, where entire teams, including the leaders, take a 15" morning break for guided stretching routines.

Hey reba, thanks for the comment.  Definitely agree that employers have to do more than just cheerlead...they need to get involved (including management)!  I really think if we look at this whole thing as an ecosystem rather than a zero sum game we can all come away with significant benefits.  I like the monetary motivation and at first would just like to give kudos to one who participate.  The program can always be tweaked and ramped up later as people get their health mojo!Here's to collaboration...hopefully the next wave of wellness.

Amol -- this type of insurance offering is already happening at Blue Cross Blue Shield (of Michigan).  I have friends who work there and can enroll, if they choose to, in a program that provides massive discounts to health insurance cost and in some cases they actually pay the employee every month for staying healthy and saving the company money.  Here is a website with similar offerings (although I don't see the exact same plan that my friends have enrolled in -- perhaps it's just for the insurance company's employees).http://www.bcbsm.com/index/healthy-living/healthy-products.html

Thanks for the great link!! It helps to show how things can work.  Definitely similar concept though as you mentioned your friends' plan seems a bit more robust.  I couldn't find any offerings for wellness services sponsored here or involvement of community...but those are just tweaks (but I think important ones).  I also would like a little less emphasis on outcomes (rather than participation) because for some that's just demotivating.  Again another tweak...

Very interesting! It assumes that the target/prospect market is actually informed and aware! And on this basis, this idea is actually an empowering tool for employees themselves that can increase their decision-making over their own needs...Maybe also some tailored coaching could be envisioned - targeted to the diverse needs of employees in this system ;)

Spot on!  One of key learnings from this site is that people see health in different ways depending on their personal needs.  Large organizations could aggregate many of these services...allowing employees to be responsible for choosing their own services from a menu.  I think coaching services for those a bit perplexed is an awesome idea!
AWESOME!!!! thanks for adding me to your virtual team! I am looking forward to cooperating :)

Solid concept. I like the ideas of insurance companies promoting preventative activities. It could actually save everyone money in the long term and encourages people to be proactive about their health by taking advantage of local health service providers.As a side effect, it would give the local economy a boost as well as people sign up for local health services in bulk. Good work!
Thanks Alan!  Woud love to have your contributions if any...

I love the idea of how these companies already have massive networks to tap into.  The concept feels a little vague still, I wonder if there are 4 or 5 test services you think would be best to prototype with first or if you can tell a story (like the one you point to from Cleveland Clinic) to give us a bit more of a feel into what this development would look like.  Great job!

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel loved the potential of this idea. Would be great to think about how the data might be aggregated and by whom.  What sort of advice / offers / benefits might be included in the scheme?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

We'd also suggest you take a look and join collaborative conversations on this concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/-201c-measuring-201d-the-company-s-state-of-wellbeing/Let's get some cross-pollination going between these ideas and build upon the goodness that each has to offer!

Comprehensive thoughts, Amol! With over 3 weeks left for Concepting, you may want to think about visualising your "General Idea" section to help folks grasp your fab thinking. Check out this example of a visualisation by another OpenIDEATOR: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/the-amazing-singaporeans/ to get you inspired Looking forward to seeing more of you across challenge conversations...

wellness_worx.title: Use current insurer and employer networks to sponsor healthy lives...Wellness Worx

pass_around_a_healthy_cook_book.description: "Going Healthy" doesn't have to be stressful - it can be fun! Let's pass around a Company Cook Book, where everyone adds his or her own personal healthy recipe. That way, going healthy is a creative and fun team effort, where everyone works together.
pass_around_a_healthy_cook_book.creator: d19227d0c110c67fdfced0da352b082f

comments.text: Neat idea! I can already think of things that I'd contribute to the cookbook. I'd first recommend that people buy a German Romertopf clay cooking pot for baking meals in the oven. Even novice cooks can produce delicious, healthy meals, just throwing a bunch of vegetables and perhaps some chicken into the pot and putting it into the oven. The only thing you need to learn is that you soak the clay pot in water for 30 minutes before cooking, and put the pot into a cold oven without pre-heating to avoid thermal shock to the clay.
Had no idea what a German Romertopf clay cooking pot was, but you just had me googling it and I think I want one now!

Great idea Katie! I think it would be even better if it was also based online and not just in a book- this way everyone can access the recipes at any time, and also add to it when they want.Kind of reminded me of this website I love to use: http://allrecipes.com/ -It's just a forum for people posting up recipes, which are rated by people who've tried them out etc. People also add tips for how they've adapted the recipes of their peers to suit their preferences. The workplace cookbook could also work with a similar kind of website maybe?Love this idea overall it would be such a great way to not only promote healthy eating, but bring colleagues together too :)

Great stuff Katie! And I wonder whether there might be a Facebook page or site to compliment this so folks could hare photos of stuff they'd cooked from the book. Also got me thinking (in terms of scale) whether a third party  even someone like our challenge partner Bupa  could offer a service for doing cookbooks like these for multiple companies. They could provide templates, ideas of what to include & how to get employees involved and a print to order service once the content has been submitted to them.

comments.text: One thing that came to me is that besides been fun, it's new. It broke their routine and made their everyday "path" into something interesting.

Making it fun is definitely key, and I love the reference!I believe that when it comes to making healthy decisions, the key issue is not having the right information, but having the right motivation and incentives.Using myself as an example: I am pretty well informed on the health risks of a bad diet and lack of exercise, and yet many times I end up making "bad" health decisions, like ordering pizza instead of buying veggies, or hitting the snooze button instead of going for a run. Sometimes making healthy choices feels more like a "punishment" than a "reward."In my case, I found that involving other people and setting tangible objectives makes it a lot easier (and fun!) to keep healthy habits: running with a friend, cooking at home with my boyfriend, signing up for a race, etc. To me, adding the human interaction component and the achievement component was the trigger I needed.Different people have a different set of motivations, but perhaps an interesting angle is thinking about what the "positive reinforcement" is for each person can help transform healthy habits from a punishment to a reward.
I like the idea of creating little distractions to break up the mundane routine that many people go through, mental and social well being is just as important as physical well being.
A great inspiration.
I love your inspiration and I think that the video is so good to sum up it.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

I really like this idea. I think it would be great if we could incorporate more physical movement in work tasks such throwing a ball into a net when completing a task. Something that could be more of a physical representation than just simply clicking a mouse. I think it would add to the sense of accomplishment and motivation. As an example I enjoy throwing my completed to do list across the room into the bin. It would be great if the entire work environment is built around having fun or getting satisfaction from completing a task.

make_wellness_fun.title: Make wellness FUN!

comments.text: We did the same at the company which I worked at and it certainly helped. It was really nice to catch up and chat with those that aren't on your desk. It's also really good for hygiene. But what about a solution for individuals that don't like to talk to others, or socialise whilst eating? (Most workplaces have at least one) What would be for them?

Great share James. I'm not sure why this would be harder at larger firms... seems to be a matter of prioritising a positive, healthy work culture. As we approach the Concepting phase  it'll be great for folks to think about fresh ways to motivate workplace communities to embrace this kind of thing. Looking forward to where all this fab Inspiration is going to lead!

Hi Meena... the fear about scaling up is purely logistic. At the firm I was at, there were only ever 7-8 of us in the office, and the one meeting table was big enough to house us all over lunch. I'm not sure firms with 50-100 people would have sufficient space for everyone to eat (and then clean up after themselves in the kitchen etc) It's one thing to ban people from eating at their desks, but unless you offer an attractive alternative it could cause resentment - having to eat out is expensive in some countries (actually cheaper than brining your own food in Singapore though!). Bigger firms would most likely have to provide a purpose built canteen, a la Google etc. Rest assured, not defeated yet though, they will be workarounds to discover I'm sure!

comments.text: Great to have you join us from Mexico, Isaac! Can you think of any local Mexican companies which are inspiring in regards to workplace health? Looking forward to seeing more of you on conversations across this challenge.

Yes! Here in Mexico there is a University that has a system of campuses all around the country, it's name is ITESM or Tec de Monterrey (in English, Monterrey Institute of Technology). At the Campus in the state of Mexico (Campus Estado de Mxico) they have facilities only for employees where they can exercise without having to use the gym designated for students. There is a health program that they installed in which they can enroll to. They have a personal trainer and a nutritionist that measure their progress. Imagine they do not need to pay for a membership at a gym, they have it at work and they only need to enroll and assist. The opportunity is there for them to harness. It has been running for quite a few years now (at least around 6). And it all started with a coach, with whom I trained too, that invited teachers and people who work there to join him at 6am every day to stretch and run.
Great stuff, Isaac! It's amazing all the global examples we collect on OpenIDEO. And I'm sure the productivity of staff who use the facilities at ITESM is boosted by such initiatives.

Yes they are, and this is one of the big reasons why some people think twice to move to another company. As a University it has a list of perks that make the working experience a nice working experience, but having this opportunity to workout at work and with a very well prepared program, really is a plus for them. Some people that have move out really miss it. I read somewhere, don't remember where unfortunately, that when you are used to do some exercise regularly, since your body is used to some amount of endorphins and suddenly stop, you get depressed. For how long? That would be worth studying as well as how it impact your performance at work and with your relationships.

comments.text: I love the video and refined idea you've added Fred and that you've cited your inspirations.  That's just the type of collaboration we're all about!  Do you think there'd be a more grass roots way to prototype this out?  What if there was a prototype toolkit that covered many of these concepts you've illustrated here but allowed for a few employees to take an unused room and turn it into a dojo for a month to explore the potential benefits for a company before building and designing a new space?

Hi Nathan. I appreciate your feedback. I very much like the idea of a prototype tool kit to help people jumpstart this concept, thank you for sharing that insight. I also absolutely agree with you that using available space to try out the dojo concept is a great way to start. If employees find available space suitable for their use, they may not need to even build something new and simply adapt it to their particular needs. New space may potentially come at a later date to support the need for greater capacity or new requirements. In my experience, getting people together for the sake of health and wellness is often less about the structure and more about its shared purpose. The quality of the training content, shared learning experiences that generate a sense of enjoyment and satisfaction, and the passion of competent teachers/trainers play an integral role in the success of a health and wellness dojo.
Glad to hear it helped.  Great concept Fred!
I would like to acknowledge the transformative work of Richard Strozzi Heckler, Ken Wilbur, Terry Patten, and George Leonard which helped inspire and inform this concept.

the_health_and_wellness_dojo_a_vital_com.title: The Health and Wellness Dojo: A Vital Component of Healthy Workplaces and Communities

The idea of having the messages come randomly is so interesting, it really could prompt users to track more of their work than a tool like Basecamp.  I also love how you think about testing it as a MVP.  Let me know if you do test it, I'd love to know if randomness can help people track their work.

fun_healthy_gains_2013_a_game_of_healthy.description: Self-selecting groups of employees engage in fun & games with a specific healthy goal. Online tracking platform/app, pop-up challenges, text messages, bonus points... and a few surprises, keep everyone motivated and on track. Everyone wins!
fun_healthy_gains_2013_a_game_of_healthy.creator: 429732f96d4ac39303008ee641100eba

comments.text: This is a really genious idea! And I very much appreciate the interaction between virtual and real life game!!!! The two of them reinforce themselves. As someone reaches different stages of achievements, s/he can also follow the improvements on the screen and increase the motivation by visualizing the goals :)

Great concept and the new part added is really interesting! I find this concept related with mine "MY-Me&You", so I added your concept on my right side about build upon concepts if it's fine for you.:)
I just updated this concept with some builds from the comments below. I'd be interested in any feedback / builds. thanks

Hi Sylvia,I love this idea. It seems like you've thought really hard about the gaming elements and have a strong idea of the flavor. I came across an initiative and posted it in the inspiration stage, which may be of some use. While it doesn't go nearly as far as your idea in the fun stakes, it might provide a useful example of the group collaborative foundation you need for this:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/canada-s-healthy-workplace-month/

I wanted to share a few articles / inspirations that I came across in the past two weeks which support and / or provide learning / red flags for the Fun & Healthy Gains concept:First, an article in Forbes that talks about a web program called Prevent developed by Omada / Sean Duffy (an IDEO alum!).  Participants who are at risk of developing diabetes enroll in a 16-week program that focuses on healthy eating and exercise. They are placed in groups of 10 to 12, based on age, body mass index (BMI) and residence, and work with a health coach who tracks their progress and lends extra support.  Duffy says teaming up people who live in the same location is important, because it gives them the opportunity to meet. Ultimately, the goal is to create a sense of community, where people are motivated by their peers. This successful program seems to support the team approach, but I think the addition of the health coach is a good one that seems to be coming up a lot.(http://www.forbes.com/sites/zinamoukheiber/2012/12/11/if-this-diabetes-prevention-program-were-a-drug-it-could-be-a-blockbuster/)____________________________________Second, a story on NPR about the tension between health apps / workplace health initiatives and privacy. Just a red flag, and important to address in this concept.http://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2012/12/26/167970303/who-could-be-watching-you-watching-your-figure-your-boss____________________________________________________Finally, I came across an existing concept that looks lot like Fun & Healthy Gains. Its called Keas (http://keas.com). I cant tell much from the website, however from the description below it looks like there could be a lot of learning here.Employers like Reed Elsevier, the publishing company, are using a Web-based game service from a company called Keas that encourages workers to stay healthy by grouping themselves into teams of six and collecting points for achieving mental and physical fitness goals. Among the challenges Keas assigns: laughing randomly for 30 seconds. The members of winning teams at Reed each get $200 gift cards.http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/24/technology/all-the-worlds-a-game-and-business-is-a-player.htmlLots of food for thought, and some exciting areas for innovation.

I like this concept, I like the idea of meeting your goals and participating in Fun and healthy gains game, the encouragment focuses on moral and healthy behaviors, which wants me to participate in your games, great idea.

Thanks Gurdeep. I have been trying to build the 'fun' aspect of this concept. How to bring more gamification into the experience while keeping it a collaborative team effort around unified goal? Any ideas welcome!

A great concept, i like the idea of the team encouragement. This will bring the workforce closer together, making each member more comfortable around each other. Setting goals within a team, seeks all team members help to achieve each and every persons designated goal.

Thanks Dalv: I agree that the dynamic of the team working toward a unified goal is an important part of this concept. I am thinking about ways to strengthen this dynamic. For example, some other concepts have mentioned Health Coaches. Perhaps the Bupa / the International Diabetes Federation could provide a Health Coach to support each team in reaching its goal. They could provide motivational content, offer suggestions based on data / learning from the Fun & Healthy Gains network, etc.  Curious what you think of this?

The concept is great, I especially like the idea of supporting this with an online platform to visualize the progress and connect this with activity tracking devices. I know at least one large company who is having a yearly program of departments competing with each other in fitness challenges. What they are lacking is this automated mechanism. So far everything is being manually counted and reported in Excel. There could even be a reward for very active members of getting special health insurance discounts or perks.

Thanks Marko - I agree that an important part of this concept is a personalized, employee-centered dashboard that tracks individual and group progress, provides relevant content (activities, mini-challenges, motivational  / support / social etc), and more. The design and interface should be fun, engaging...something the employee wants to view many times throughout the day... I will try to design a prototype at some point. You raise the idea of departments 'competing' with each other. Perhaps this is a good direction, however I'm thinking this concept should focus on the collaborative benefit of a team working toward a united goal vs the competitive structure that pits one team versus another. What do you think about this?

Really like the idea of putting the goals in perspective, like you have stated the 'Walk to Florida'. Another good feature might to have an ongoing tally of miles and relate that back to real world, so 'You have currently walked x number of miles which is equal to walking from here to....'

Agreed. Perspective certainly helps understand the greatness of 'how far they've walked' or any other task and it would be awesome to see that after a few months you may of walked the distance from 'New York to California'.

This is a great idea / build... some way, as part of the group challenge OR after the challenge to track your personal progress, a way to visualize your 'miles walked' on a map. You could even create your own itinerary and 'visit' different parts of the country. When you arrive at location you might be treated to a video or some other surprise reward. For all I know, this already exists! Just one note: the 'walking' challenge seems to have appeal, but this concept should be able to support any cumulative group goal ie weight loss, lowering blood pressure / cholesterol level, healthier eating habits (how about a ' Slow Food/Smaller Portion' challenge ??), even stress-reduction...

Love the idea of working in teams within companies and companies as one large team. That certainly brings employees and colleagues closer together (better for work productivity). I also think the idea of setting targets and goals works brilliantly. Are there any more examples of what people could do? And how would this be tracked? This concept certainly builds good team morale :)
Thanks Will. I plan to post a beginning list of possible challenges, as well as tools (tracking and beyond) so others can build on it. might take a few days though.

Awesome Sylvia! And there may be learnings you can draw and build upon from http://www.stickk.com It seems to be more focused on individual goals  I'm loving how you've gone beyond this too group missions. And you know what big fans we are of collaboration we are, here at OpenIDEO ;^)

Thanks Meena - I will have another look at Stickk. One piece of learning that I remember from the last time I looked at the site: When working toward a health goal, some people are more motivated by what that have already accomplished, others by focusing on what they still have left to accomplish in order to complete the challenge.  For this concept, perhaps individuals could personalize their own dashboards (ie progress tracking visual) to reflect their own 'motivation profile.'
This concept reminds me of this app/community SuperBetter - have you seen it? https://www.superbetter.com/

Thanks Nathan - I just had a look at SuperBetter. Lots of good support for this concept. For my taste, however, I find it a bit complicated, a solo journey to get emotionally strong, and steeped in virtual gaming / role-playing. The vision for Fun & Healthy Gains is much more straightforward: A group of colleagues get together and decide on a combined goal, they help design the 'game,' track their progress, and have some fun along the way to 'getting the job done.'  It's good to know about SuperBetter though. There are hundreds of apps out there that do pretty much anything we can think of as far as tools / virtual aides, the idea here is to streamline them it into one format that supports these group challenges. ...all to say, thanks, and please keep sending examples ...
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Great Plan

Good point.  Your idea of competitions could also make the network have more activity.  If you think you have something to offer, post a note for Stephen.  We're here to collaborate and make all of these ideas better.
