lower_barriers_to_health_insurance_and_g.description: Freelancers or sole traders will often enjoy very few of the insurance perks available to those working for bigger firms. Could Bupa provide a participatory program for these people to attend gym/classes to prove their health and enjoy better rates?
lower_barriers_to_health_insurance_and_g.creator: 7e7dcb823cb8bac78bee007e8041492e

comments.text: Great idea - I wonder if big companies could 'adopt' a number of freelancers or small businesses. We would probably need to set some minimum use criteria for the gym etc - could there be a buddy system between freelancers and members of the company - a kind of social contract to deliver a minimum amount of healthy behaviours between them to maintain good membership rates?

Hi Georgie, I love the adoption scheme!.. kind of CSR.. allowing the bigger firms to adopt freelancers into gym memberships, buddy programs etc. Let the company HR walls become more porous and allow those you do business for and with to benefit from the purchasing power of the larger firm.

I work in corporate relations for a small non-profit organization that, in the interest of keeping low overhead, does not have the budget for benefits such as gym membership. The companies that I work with are always looking for ways to engage their employees and help their non-profit partners through alternatives to standard corporate grants. I think this is a fantastic idea that could be easily folded into partnership proposals!

Great idea James. this benefits so many stakeholders. Setting some of these partnerships and package will also help gyms attract more members (it's a well known fact that gym's don't manage to hit full capacity).Even for bigger organisations (who don't have a gym within the establishment) could partner with local gyms, and employee could access these services during their lunch breaks, or right before/ after work.Subsidies could be offered by the employer (for small businesses, not freelancers), organisations such as BUPA, and the gyms themselves!

Hi Vishal, thanks for your thoughts. In my (limited!) experience, quite a few bigger firms already have existing corporate rates with gym chains; some are lucky enough to share buildings with them. so employees can indeed work out at lunch or before/after work without adding to their commute times at all. Lucky for those guys!So, what I'm searching for with this concept is to find a way for huge insurers/health providers like BUPA to level the playing field for employment benefits, so that smaller business can attract talent, and individuals do not have to give up health benefits for themselves and their families by choosing to strike out on a business venture alone.Any thoughts on how strength in numbers from smaller firms/individuals banning together might help, would be appreciated!Thanks

Wow, that's a great idea Amy!I love the connection to investors and companies interested in reducing  health risks. We should remember that there are huge savings to be made by Governments, businesses and tax payers in keeping people healthyMade me think about social impact bonds as an interesting and new way for Governments and NGOs to work together - money is paid on outcomes http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_impact_bond If this was scaled, this kind of mechanism could release a lot of investment into these kinds of programmes...

workplace_health_buddies.description: Networks of work colleagues with similar health goals for encouragement, moral support and ideas for reaching those goals
workplace_health_buddies.creator: 6c1a6f5a15dc1e8a03e6a3438cfcd683

comments.text: This is a great idea. I think that if there is a way to connect people in their local areas, that might be even more effective than connecting people with the same health concerns from say Boston and Seattle. To me, having personal interactions (rather than a confined web community) may help participants feel more accountable for holidng up their end of the bargain!

Hi Stephen, great idea. I think there are a few building blocks in this existing program in Canada that could help to prototype your idea, particularly in the respect that anyone can sign-up for free and create a challenge for their immediate colleagues or workers spanning any number of offices: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/canada-s-healthy-workplace-month/Really hope you manage to get something off the ground and up and running!

Thanks for adding me to the team Stephen! If you were to think to extend your social media network to include a mobile app:There is a new "dating" mobile app, "Tinder", that is going viral on college campuses that your idea reminded me of. It is actually pretty creepy but I thought your idea could be easily extended to this kind of mobile interface. It essentially matches you with people in your area based on their pictures, but in your case it could be their health profile including workout plans or healthy recipes! it is very user-friendly you might want to check it out!

Yours is a good idea and is doable, practical, easily implementable in different types of workplaces. I particularly like your idea of using social media tools to keep people engaged. I do have one question though -- what are the ways you might measure the impact of this project? Since employees will likely have different health goals, there might need to be several indicators of impact.

I'm sure that a piece of research could be run if there were enough people to measure goal achievement for a networked group against an un-networked control group.But actually, what would be simpler would be to simply survey participants on a reasonably regular basis.  The key question that would need to be asked is whether they thought that the network had helped them achieve their goals - their perceptions may be the most important factor in determining whether it actually does make a difference.

Great examples to help communicate your idea Stephen.  The fact that this is social yet so flexible to meet anyone's specific interests excites me.  Do you think there's a certain type of business that would make for a good first prototype?

Thanks Nathan.  I'd be looking for larger organisations and/or those that have multiple sites (ie those where the network participants are unlikely to meet/discuss their health goals through the normal run of business).  And probably those that have a more progressive attitude towards social media at work too.
I like the idea of approaching orgs that are all about sharing, that seems very important.  Great post!
Maybe a tech company, Stephen? Many of them have advanced health programs as well as a progressive attitude to social media. Potential opportunity to link it to an intranet sites etc...

I really like your concept beacuse most of the times people know that  must do exercise and must be more healthy but they put excuses for no practising. With this network it could be easier for them and more encouraging.
I agree, there's nothing more compelling than knowing you can't let someone down!

Interesting idea. There are probably a lot of offline versions of this sort of thing already, that you could use as a model. I've run several networks like this, albeit not focused on health/wellness. I've found that success requires (1) a ring leader to keep the group together, and (2) either a certain level of commitment to the goal or to the specific people involved.To run a small experiment, you could pick a specific health condition to focus on. For example, I've found that people with food intolerances are pretty networked within their communities, and are motivated to educate themselves and get involved. This may be a good group to start out with.

I like this. I would like to see "check ins" around the office. Each person could "check in" at different places around the office. This would encourage both a sense of community in the office and encourage people to move throughout the day. Simple movements and check points at a water cooler for instance could also remind individuals to drink water throughout the day.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel encouraged you to look at Patients Like Me http://www.patientslikeme.com for inspiration. They also wondered: How might buddies connect?  What sort of skills might buddies need to make them really effective?  Could this spread outside the workplace?  If so how might this happen?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Thanks for the comments.  I'd seen - and joined - patientslikeme.com before proposing this.  I guess that the difference is that patients like me tends to be about sharing details of and data concerning a health condition and medication etc, whereas my concept was more about sharing objectives, aspiration and advice/encouragement for achieving our goals (whether these were health/condition related, or about fitness, exercise, body shape, etc).I don't see this necessarily as one-to-one buddying either.  People will connect by joining, or establishing, online groups, and participating in online discussion, initially within the group but potentially outside it and offline too.  The main attributes buddies might need is a desire to make a difference to their own health/fitness, and a desire to help and encourage others to do the same.  I can see that for some types of goals it could be really important to have a quality community manager or moderator to ensure that there sharing of tips is both safe and doesn't turn into amateur medical advice, but equally all such communities tend to have rules and impose responsibilities on participators and these networks could be no different (which might obviate the need for moderation).I'm sure that this could spread beyond the workplace (providing that there are appropriate online communities), though workplaces do provide a useful way of ensuring the 'bona fides' of participants (maybe the first step is to connect up local workplaces into a wider network).

Great thoughts, Stephen. During the Refinement phase, be sure to add any new thoughts you're really keen on to your actual post. That's the part which our community + expert panel will be assessing during the upcoming Evaluation phase. (You can make edits to your post by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right) Looking forward to seeing you on more conversations across this challenge...

Hi Stephen! Great idea!I think there is a lot of potential in the shared-goal setting aspect of your idea! I think it would be great to be able to track fitness goals together (or privately) via the business social media network that you mentioned. But because tracking your personal fitness is annoying, the process of signing up for a particular activity through your site could do the tracking for you!It would be interesting to see if different intramural sports or masters programs could develop out of high participation. Competing or local companies could have competing sports teams.

We'd also suggest you take a look and join collaborative conversations on the following concepts:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/motivating-companies-to-become-engines-for-chronic-disease-prevention-/http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/health-coaches-in-the-community-/Let's get some cross-pollination going between these ideas and build upon the goodness that each has to offer!

Stephen, I posted a similar concept about having health competition, pairing up with someone else for support.  (http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/health-competitions/) I like your idea of virtual networks, and think that the idea of competitions in order to make it more fun and engaging for everyone. The company could sponsor one challenge every month to promote different health topics.

Hi Daniel.  Thanks for the comments.  We've been running those sorts of competitions in my workplace and they have certainly got lots of people involved.  I'd want to ensure that they were optional though as competitions may be inappropriate for some shared goals (eg to better manage high blood pressure), where the encouragement of someone that has a shared experience may be worth more.  There are also some people that don't respond as well to competitions as others.  But I do think that competition could be one of the important components.

Great idea - always useful to workout and network at the same time! I'd encourage you to check out November Project (http://november-project.com/).  They use the "Tribe" concept to encourage people to show up to grueling workouts at 630 AM in the dead of winter in Boston.  I can rationalize sleeping in if its just me, but if I'm letting down my "tribe" (in this case, coworkers), I'm less likely to flake.   Adding shared goals for the team (combining this concept with the Mt. Everest concept), might also be of benefit.

Great idea, Stephen! The Health and Wellness club at my school created a similar buddy system, and it worked really well! I like your virtual network add-on because it's a good way to keep everyone in touch.

comments.text: I love this idea. I think it not only encourages ideas and community creativity but also as you stated, allows people to feel at ease at work/ be themselves. What if the company selected an idea every month from these interactive space to be developed or to make a realisation? whether it be work related or social?

Love this. In fact workplaces, schools and other similar environments should have more of these spaces where anybody can write their thoughts, jot down inspiration and share their ideas easily.However, what would stop others from abusing it, writing profanities, drawing silly drawings, etc? Office Graffiti Police? ;)

Will, I think if the organization does its hiring properly, this shouldn't be a problem. I don't think that being anonymous will give many the urge to write distasteful things. Maybe I'm being romantic :)Of course, there would be some sort of code of conduct, just like there is for intranets, acceptable use of workstations, etc.
A code of conduct would work in most environments. I just love the idea of being able to write and draw freely - and it's such a useful tool to develop ideas with peers!
It also allows workers to post ideas anonymously if they don't feel comfortable sharing their ideas directly with others.

I think this is a great reason to do it. Sometimes meetings can be... not so open to new ideas. Especially if someone in a leadership position has a view of the way things are going to go already. Sometimes this is good (execution, time crunch), but sometimes it can be a deterrent to share.
Another really simple idea to shut out monotony and get people using their brains in more engaging and social ways. And start with the boardroom!
Glad you like it!

Its great idea! Taking it one step further, people might like to know that their ideas are not going into a black hole. What if the employer randomly (not on a schedule) promoted one of the ideas? If a leader read something on one of the white boards and was inspired to create or implement something, it would encourage more people to share and view the other things on the board.

I like the idea of anonymous work so that any thoughts, words, ideas etc that somebody has written down can get praise from a leader in passing. It's also really nice to have creative conversations at an inspirational wall, plucking out key words.

Love this idea. I remember trying to convince my former workplace to use "Idea Paint" (http://www.ideapaint.com/about/ ). They liked the idea but didn't make the switch, whereas when I suggested it to my university, they actually made it happen. I still walk past and watch students use it well.So instead of whiteboards everywhere, wouldn't it be amazing to have all the walls and potentially even the desks painted with this special dry, erasable paint. I'd be thrilled to see work and community spaces encourage us to really brainstorm anywhere. And what better invitation than writing on their (erasable) walls or tables!

I've just shared the idea paint link with my colleagues. We were in a meeting yesterday where someone drew on the desk to map their thinking... i really like the playful of this idea and thinking about how co-working spaces can provide shared platforms.

That's awesome Jen. I hope they make it happen. I also wrote about co-working spaces (more specifically) as comments to some other inspirations.PS - I wish I could paint my entire house with erasable paint!
I think this is good that idea could add on whenever or whoever when somebody have new idea. And it is a very open and transparent communicating platform.

I really like this idea not only for the serendipity of running into some one else but also for its ability to get people out their chair or cubicle.  Too many electronic devices (phone, email, text etc.) to communicate with other workers ow that hardly anybody moves from their chair except to go to a meeting or lunch.  I wonder if these boards could be placed strategically in various areas so that people are 'forced' to walk a certain distance throughout the day?  What electronic communication could we eliminate in the workplace that would make employees have to use the board at least once a day?  Maybe block all numbers to co-workers on the same floor! lol!
Or even put some of these boards outside in gathering areas? Encourage employees to take the talk outdoors.

comments.text: Great interest in this design concept. People tend to be hunched all day whilst working, and do not take notice of the way they are sitting and are careless about their posture which has major affects later on. This design is great and very effective to those who spend their whole day sitting at a desk. Keep the good work up Tremayne.

Great concept! So many people have stereotyped a workplace as a typical office, but you have thought outside the box, more towards an active workplace where people are impacted by their bad posture.This is such a simple thing that can have huge effects for both the worker and the company, and also a long term benefit for the worker.Totally get it!
Thank you Djorn!
great concept well thoughtful of you.
Thanks Emmanuel

This is an excellent idea!  I love the idea of people having instantaneous feedback that can trigger a change in behavior, particularly for people sitting in an office chair all day.  Think about how instantly people respond to seeing a text light up on their phone, or an email message arrive in the corner of their screen.  Imagine if a "bad posture" notification could cause attention and illicit an immediate behavior in the same way.As for benefits, the article below talks about how detrimental bad posture can be.  According to a researcher at UCLA, just a slight shift forward in your average neck alignment (from injury or bad posture) can reduce your lung capacity by 30%.  Such an oxygen deficit leads to all kinds of long-term issues like as asthmatic conditions, blood vessel problems, heart disease, and even intensified pain sensations.  http://www.naturalnews.com/030956_posture_health.htmlFor sedentary workers, this is an excellent opportunity to increase health without having to plan for an additional activity, or crave out time from your work day.

Thank you Ashley! I will update this concept. I like the idea because when people receive an alert on their phones, it's almost like a necessity to check what it is or to reply. Maybe the notification could alert you and give advice on how to correct you current position?Thank you for the link, it sounds interesting, I'll have a read on that!
Awesome concept! Like the way you have implemented the idea in different contexts and through different mediums. Great design hacks of the nike bracelets aswell!

comments.text: Love the idea. I'm always trying to stand up whenever I can. This also generates better blood flow, which also increases creativity. Who knows what this might hold!
Thanks for commenting and the nice feedback. Nice angle as well on the creativity side of things. Know if there is any research out there to back this up, or shall we just take it as read? :)
Great idea Alexander, I really like what you're proposing. And I love the image you've chosen too!
Many thanks for the positive feedback. That image... too many late nights staring at that bloody screen mocking me!

This is a great way of framing the real problem here - there's principally two activities in a work environment; meetings and producing content (whether documents or emails). Plenty of the start-ups already hold stand up meetings but your standard office person in say finance that's sat down for a meeting for the last 20 years isn't going to break that habit, swapping the furniture out for something that makes you stand up would eventually form a new habit. Maybe the management buy in for this could somehow could come under CSR and be facilitated by government grants or healthcare insurance premium reductions? Maybe pads on the floor could measure the time standing and calculate the benefits gained? Maybe there's something to be learnt here from habit formation http://www.nirandfar.com/The second problem is producing content - this needs a change in interface, I could see something like lighttable working for programming but in my opinion we need more interfaces like this for email and writing documentshttp://www.kickstarter.com/projects/ibdknox/light-tableIt's my first time here so I hope that builds on this in some way and is in the right place!

Hi MarkThanks for comments, links and insights. Fascinating stuff and very helpful. I like the way you've broken it down further into office activity. It'd be interesting if this could even form part of some sort of consultancy offer for established businesses to help ask themselves why their office looks the way it does, and whether that is the right thing. Bringing up the CSR angle is interesting as well. I wonder if established offices could even be encouraged to donate their archaic furniture models to local schools/charities etc and unlock some sort of government subsidy/tax break. Linking health gains to health expenditure is always a tricky one given all the different variables... even though that would be ideal. It'd be great to find someway of bringing together examples like http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/ibdknox/light-table into one space so organisations can start to package together and model their new working environment in one place - maybe a ready reckoner of what it would cost, what it would save, value fo what they could give up/recycle as well as some stock tools for measuring the impact of changing how they operate. Hmmm... think I need to start revisiting this concept...

Measure the cost benefit to a company might not actually be that far fetched; I was looking at Gekoboard earlier, it's a dashboard that takes in data from salesforce, mix panel etc and displays it in one panel that a company might put up in reception for example. Companies are starting to bring data in to one place so it would be fairly easy to measure an uplift in productivity / revenue inline with the introduction of the new furniture / initiatives. If it was on a free trial basis it seems like quite an attractive offer! The interface stuff seems some way off but just improving meeting rooms would be a start!
I've been wanting to do this for a while in my office! Would be happy to connect!

Thanks for the comment. I think what I am most intrigued about is how to set up a system/offer where organisations/departments feel this is both easy to do and very good for their ambitions. Would be interested to know, given that you've been wanting to do this for a while, what barriers you have found that have stopped you :) ?

de_construct_my_office.title: De-construct My Office

comments.text: David i like your photos that you have put it on. i would love to hear more examples of how employees could advocate or change their environments in scenarios where the employer hasn't yet realized this need.

"What if your office desk could turn into a sofa?" Id probably get less work done.I understand that your somewhat encouraging people to be more comfortable at work which makes perfect sense. I know that right now im laying in bed typing when i should really be sitting properly at a desk.I think its a good idea to have furniture that has multiple uses. Makes perfect sense.However is this product suited to a typical office? In a typical office would you need to continuously change your furniture? or have a desk for working and a sofa for relaxing?Encouraging people to get comfortable, which could lead to slower productivity, and then "taking a nap", is that necessarily something an office environment would want to encourage. I think you got a great concept and would definitely work, but in a different environment not an office.

Really good concept David! I'd have to agree with Djorn though, it might not necessarily be suitable for a typical office environment as it may lead to a decrease in productivity- but it could be something better implemented in a different work environment? Maybe for people who work from home and don't have much space to work. It could be great for people who tend to have to work long hours aswell.
I like the thought process of this concept, and encouragement.The flexible office furniture that gives users (options) great concept

Good concept! Everyone has different working conditions in which they work better in. By creating a flexible work space allowing for people to feel comfortable and take a nap is great! I often have power naps and find they really work and increase productivity. This is a Great idea.

Good concept David. This concept might work really well for people who work from, and don't have enough space for their furniture and office desk in the same room, so it will save space as it is an multi-functinal product.
Love the idea of flexible and ergonomic office furniture - i'm often moving around whilst doing work. Could a standard design be developed to fit as many users as possible?

flexible_working_hours.description: You can adjust what time suits you the best for your office and family matters. This simple behavior can affect a lot of employee's advantages. While your employee is on advantage, so does your company.

comments.text: I agree. I think there is still a stigma with flexi hours, perhaps do to lack of trust or fear of not putting in "face time." It has to be made more culturally acceptable at most companies.  Practically, flexi-hours may be challenging due to team projects and work coordination amongst colleagues.  However, I think with good planning and communication, and smart use of technology nowadays, we can solve this issue.

Hi Gloria I think there have been numerous studies to show the positive correlation between the amount of face time and likelihood of a promotion. Can there be a way to counter this bias to get that shift in the cultural norms?

I agree Niven, speaking specifically about the United States, a majority of people don't even have the opportunity to take off to take care of their own health or take care of a family member, which only increases stress and negatively impacts the workplace. Flexible work hours will allow people to take care of themselves and their loved ones. Studies show that people who have more flexible work arrangements are happier and it also has positive economic benefits for the company/business.

I have a stand up desk at home and LOVE IT. I'm back working 4 days a week in an office and the sitting down is killing me. bad posture, sore hips, arm pains. Hi Mark,Just wanted to mention that I switched to a standing desk about 3 months ago and it makes a very big difference.  I am with you on this 100% :)

reinventing_vending_dispensing_.description: Workplace eating is largely determined by food availability.  Making vending choices healthy and free, eliminating unhealthy snacks and drinks, and utilizing ID information to track healthy choices can lead to healthy competition among colleagues.
reinventing_vending_dispensing_.creator: b00998a9143d6127a6b00c58f69b34ce

comments.text: Even though it might be cost effective for companies to invest in supplying and stocking new vending facilities, Sandra's point below suggests that a starting point might be better-focused on creating a full-service vending company that could offer workplaces viable/healthy alternatives to existing services.

This is a great idea, Jim. Even taking steps to improve the nutritional value of the content in vending machines is a "quick win" that companies should just get on and do. But I love the idea of using some of the tech aspects to track consumption, to make it fun, to incorporate rewards etc.

I fully support your idea - I think there are some real simple and effective elements - healthy food - buyer recognition and reward and the opportunity for a company to influence the choices. I think also the location should be considered, as having to move your body to get there is also a health factor, so perhaps the most convenient location may not be the right one. I guess one challenge would be the provider of the the vending machine and contents - they will be driven by what sells and it will not always be the healthy option - what incentives could they have to support the initiative? Certainly, there is a window of opportunity for the provider to be the first to offer something like this and corner the market initially.

Totally agree, Sandra!  Expecting workplaces to stock and administer the machines might be too problematic.  There does seem to be a good opportunity for new providers of this service to corporations!

Cheers for the Concept Jim! Here's a quick tip: we're starting to see a couple of related inspirations around vending machines and you might want to connect them to your post using the Build Upon feature. This helps us all join the dots between related posts and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus you'll get more DQ points!. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Search terms like 'vending machine' and drag anything relevant over to your Build Upon field. Keep up the great work!  Check out this link as a starting point: http://www.openideo.com/search.html?text=vending+machine
Great, thanks for the tip!

Forgot to mention that the machines can be programmed to dispense complements (based on simple shape/color recognition and posts from co-workers) like:"Love the blue dress, Angie!""Heard that presentation went great today, Greg!""I love the way you caress my keys, Frank"  (maybe not;-)"Really workin' that hat and scarf, Beth!"

reinventing_vending_dispensing_.title: Reinventing Vending Dispensing

power_points_in_parks.description:
We live in a wireless world but lack of amenities in public areas are holding us back.
Let's change this!
power_points_in_parks.creator: 2b7c8d8c9a1294b4d6acb9511a3bc414

comments.text: Great concept Will! I think that bring the work outside to a nature place is very interesting and useful because it can make you be more relaxed and with better enviroment to breath fresh air. Good work!
Thanks for your input Sonia. Do you think that  a range of utilities and hardware in these areas would be beneficial too? It would be great to hear your thoughts.
It would be interesting but not too much, just trying to not taint the park and keep it as nature as possible.
Because as I worked on my concept, the trees and nature give you positive energy! ;)

I agree with keeping the parks as natural as possible - after all they are beautiful places because of what they are. The last thing we'd want to do is change this. Do trees create positive energy? If so, parks would create great workplaces!

Yes! :) Well in my case the positive energy is created when you touch and feel the trees, so if you are in a park I think you can feel it aswell. And of course if that happens the parks would be the best place to work!

Great concept of utilising the outdoors and changing the 'working environment' suitable for a range of working contexts...definitely could promote a healthier, happier community within and beyond the workplace.Could also be a great place for collaboration of individuals/companies and communities with the possibility of sharing interacting and sharing skills, interests and experiences making it a more enjoyable, happier and healthier workplace.An outdoor/green cafe sounds cool; many parks already have pavilions/shelters and perhaps if wifi access is provided here could be implemented relatively easily...  some parks utilise solar power to provide wifi so this can also be an option...
also... powerful image!

Thanks Ahmed, really great to have your thoughts and feedback.I certainly agree that if a space was available to share skills, interests and experiences then it would make it much more interesting. If the space had some sort of designated area for this then it could be a sought after place, attracting locals to work and meet. I believe that health is not only of a physical nature but also mental; if the brain is well and used regularly, then your body is well.I'm also interested in renewable energy sources; an area that could provide for itself. If this area was in a park, it may be that part of the energy could be fuelled by children's play (e.g. exercise bikes = kinetic energy) whilst their parents work and use the space. It would be nice to create something that isn't just a part shelter or outdoor shed with seats and tables. Thanks for your thoughts.
If we could utilise renewable energy to power plug sockets, wi-fi and other hardware devices then i'm sure this could prove to be a popular work destination.

On a daily basis, I would and could use such PowerPoints. Realisation is easy and not to expensive.My favourite concept so far!Great level of detail, and good context in all points.I would love to look into how we could also cover the colder months of the year.

Thank you for a a positive and constructive response. After hearing feedback, there has been popular interest in using public space for educational use as well as group and individual study. I think at the moment, one of the biggest things to think about is change in weather and how we can adapt these public areas to withstand this (without being a clumpy shed or shelter). Thanks Bernhard :)

Education in a public space is great. Imagine people who just come by could learn something new for their life, or discover an interest in a particular subject.A natural approach to the shelter would be great. What if the shelter is provided by a plant? Many times in my life a tree did serve as umbrella at bus stations.Also important in my opinion is how we provide energy in these public spaces, solar energy? Definitely something renewable!

I am very interested in looking into renewable energy sources to provide power. Solar energy is certainly one way; they are expensive to start off with but after a number of years, they pay for themselves and then provide more then is used (usually).We could also look into kinetic energy. If a space was created by a children's play area, then there could be a set of bikes (or something similar) which, when used provide energy. This could be great for parents so that when the are working in the space, their children are occupied and are doing something useful!What are your thoughts?

Bernhard, I really like the idea of creating natural shelter. There have been some great shelters created by plants and vegetation and so if local authorities could incorporate this then i'm sure it would be a popular work destination!

Very fun idea. I always thought along similar lines when in school (why can't we have class outside ever) but never think this when I'm at the office. Not sure why.This would be a particularly neat facility to have for things like public meetings or council meetings or political debates, especially when hot topics are being discussed and there isn't space for everyone that wants to participate. As an urban planner I think it would be such a cool thing to present to council outside.Love it.

Thank you Crispin for your thoughts and feedback - really useful to have at this conceptual stage of the process.The type of place, size, use hasn't been decided yet and so those thoughts are really useful. It would be great to have something that accommodates more then one type of person; if meetings and debates could use the space then that would be really cool! We don't tend to have those thoughts of working outdoors anymore (whilst we did when we were were younger) so how can we promote that again? If there was something available for the public and private companies to use/ hire, would that invigorate it again?
How could we incorporate this into an area like that? And how could it be beneficial?

Really like this concept. It would be great to have utilities like power points and wi-fi hotspots in public places. Often in workplaces, people find themselves trapped within four walls and use breaks just to get some fresh air. This would rather solve this issue and maybe people might be more productive as a result.Great work Will

Thanks Jonathan, great input! I agree with you about the utilities - if there were more that may encourage people to spaces to be creative and get work done. Fresh air is another positive but I think the main point is to get workers out of mundane workplaces and into a new environment to boost workflow. What other utilities would you benefit from?

I like the concept, what comes to mind when reading this is the lack of interaction the working man/woman has with the environment and "real world",because full time workers operate in a typical 9-5 they miss out on all the things the outdoors has to offer, especially in the summer.They miss out on interactions, inspirations and just general satisfaction of having a choice to their surroundings. The fact that you have demonstrated that people are already trying to take this approach with coffee shops shows that it does work, but theres headroom for further developments.One key thing that i will point out is your mention to schools. Great idea get the kids out of the 4 walls and in a more hands on working place.Could you imagine 20 kids doing biology and actually picking up things they found in the park, creatures, insects and doing real biology from a hands on point of view. It would really help the kids put things in perspective for them.

Djorn - thanks for a great response! Very intuitive and caring thoughts for the environment and general health. I certainly agree that the standard working hours (9-5) don't allow for full time workers to use the great outdoors that we have around us. Isn't that a shame? In the past, I've worked in various coffee shops and have seen many people use the facilities during the day to get work done - these are freelance workers and flexi-workers whose jobs allow them to choose their hours meaning they can work when they want, where they want. After speaking with them, they've all told me that their work rate and quality has risen due to the fact that they're simply out of the uninspiring office. They went on to say that in times of good weather, they use local parks and public squares in central London for standard document writing but that they're frustrated with lack of charging points and wi-fi. Can we solve this problem?With regards to the using the outdoors as a means of education, I think that's a great input. Back at school, when we had classes outside, it was often the most exciting point of the day and all would be eager to take part and learn. London has 38% green space including vast areas of forests, reserves and lake; perfect for learning about the environment. If this concept was taken on, we could push to provide bases for working and learning in these public areas which could result in healthier living, better work and an understanding of the environment from children through to working adults. Thanks for your feedback and please continue to think about it :)

Great idea Will! Just a point here is that it may not entirely be feasible in LMIC 's (Low middle income countries) where we may have less open spaces, no wi-fi and too many permissions to be sought for any activity to take place in a public or private park. But yeah these spaces can be used to advocate and promote physical activity, or give an occasional educational lecture on healthy choices or for an awareness drive on various issues.

Thank you Ranjani - really great to hear your thoughts and have your feedback. At the moment, nothing's set in stone and so your ideas for different scenarios and in different countries are certainly welcomed. Really love your feedback and please continue to think about how we can best use this space and concept it.

That is super cool! Especially good for those among us who work remotely and typically end up working from home. Working from home all day is sort of "claustrophobic"... a park can be such an energizing place. I know it is outside of this specific concept, but this also made me make a connection to the other challenge around "How might we inspire and enable communities to take more initiative in making their local environments better?" If people start using their local environment more often, there will definitely be more personal investment into making them better.
Good points, and its not exclusive to a group of people. Everyone benefits.

I also think that working by yourself can become remote and, sometimes claustrophobic. I (and lots of others that I know) are always looking for the 'next place' to work. Often, we find ourselves in coffee shops and caf's but although they can be great places, they can also be distractions in the small space  (and you have to buy a drink or two:) ). So what's next? Public spaces? Parks? Sub-letting unused office space? If we could work out part shelters, free wi-fi, good facilities and begin to create a community, then it may be the next place! Thanks for your contribution :)

power_points_in_parks.title: Power Points in Parks

comments.text: strong inspiration and great thoughts! when a woman at work is pregnant - other colleagues who have previously experienced pregnancy and motherhood share tips, experiences and stories. what to do, what it feels like etc... designers get together, collaborate, discuss ideas, share and tell stories. many people have different skills, interests and hobbies - teach someone yoga, boxing, sewing or how to make that dish you always wanted to know how to... perhaps you share a skill or talent in return for another? are you rewarded for peer-peer learning or is it self-satisfaction and self-development? works great - promoting collaborative healthy communities and social wellbeing! A fertilisation of skills - dispersed through sharing, and collaborating in the community...
Thanks for your input Ahmed
very interestingThe people could do mini shows of their work or hobbies at their office and invite small group along.
Yes, it could be an option. Thanks for your input
great idea and an inspiring picture to compliment it too. good work.
very interesting! not only can you learn something from one another, you also get to meet new people and maybe develop new interests & hobbies.

strong inspiration and great thoughts! when a woman at work is pregnant - other colleagues who have previously experienced pregnancy and motherhood share tips, experiences and stories. what to do, what it feels like etc... designers get together, collaborate, discuss ideas, share and tell stories. many people have different skills, interests and hobbies - teach someone yoga, boxing, sewing or how to make that dish you always wanted to know how to... perhaps you share a skill or talent in return for another? are you rewarded for peer-peer learning or is it self-satisfaction and self-development? works great - promoting collaborative healthy communities and social wellbeing! office_recess.description: Who said that recess had to end just because you became an adult? Engage with your co-workers, release stress and burn calories with Office Recess! For an hour each day the office shuts down for physical and/or mental workouts to let you recharge!
office_recess.creator: dab3b7fd72c58720311e2205e302c935

comments.text: Great idea! Allowing adults to break out of their shell and unleash their inner child! This would be a great way of relieving stress to run around with out a care in the world again! I love this concept, it would create a more positive, creative and productive workforce. Good concept.

Again great idea. Even beyond office workplaces, jobs that involve some amount of labor  or physical strain could have a different kind of recess where there could be a designated area to stretch and healthily unwind rather than simply collapsing on a plastic chair in a break room. Having some kind of stretching, or mental games (board games) could help maintain health of workers as well as strengthen community.
I agree with scott, different kinds of recess to maintain the health of workers.
I like this idea, its a way of trying to bring out the kid in every adult. Being able to run around with a load of stress taken off your shoulder by other employees who will encourage one another.

Wicked idea! Just by reading your title i started to reminisce the fun times i used to have during recess back in school. Stress free to run around and not think about anything. These days work is taken way to seriously and people are just glued to their desks. By incorporating this into the work environment would relieve any tension and would bring employees together. Great work!

Love it love it love it.  I used to run an office of 10 people.  Every so often we would play stupid games - office softball, chair races.  Stupid things but it removed tension and made people laugh.It brought people together and helped them focus on the job afterwards...The key to this is inclusion - making sure that everybody can benefit.  Whether or not they decide to benefit from the inclusion is their choice, but it works if everybody wants to do it!

Matthew, I really like this idea. As a kid, school was so much fun because of recess and that's where the real connections happen. It also provided a much needed break and helped manage energy during the day. Recess time at work places would be awesome. There's a culture creeping in of employees just eating at their desks not only affecting energy levels but also social interaction. How amazing would it be to step away, enjoy a game of table-tennis, indoor golf, basketball... or even just foosball or a push-up competition!

I agree with Vishal! I think it could be a great way for employees to actually have the opportunity to meet up and socialize at work. New friends are made and from this a community can emerge which is great for the company.

Forming teams could give us support to work together and help generate ideas for reaching our health goals while contributing to work goals at the same time. Take a look at Company Sneakers Spark Healthy Teamwork Activity, which I wrote up that has a similar approach through teams--to accomplish our health and wellness goals. - Ann

breakfast_with_the_boss.creator: c518f4c247d9208dab8dfe90e6915dd7

comments.text: Quite right old boy... for some reason the answer to the last question tickled me. It painted a picture in my head of eating breakfast with the gaffer on a miniaturised table... Absurdities aside, It gave me a brainwave on perhaps also doing this as an "afternoon tea with the boss" too, as a less hearty meal, but similar premise for the same outcome.
a great way of communicating with people you may not always feel comfortable with, good concept!
Good concept Zed! I always think that it's really important to have a great enviroment at work, furthermore of a good relation with the people you work with! So this is a good idea to do it! Great!

You have a very valid point Zed, it is so important for people to feel their work and/or opinions are valued. Having a scheduled time when a working community can socialize in a non-hierarchical circumstance is a powerful idea. Perhaps this tool could be used for more than just breakfast or meal times. Social activity is key to any persons well-being. Maybe group breaks of other social interactions would be equally important. And also empowering any employee to instigate these breaks would create even more equality.

I agree with Jack. A session where ranks or the status of a person does not matter and just to enjoy each other company can be a great way to bring people together. I think this can improve the employee/employer relationship.

Love this.  It's amazing what you can encourage people to do with loyalty schemes.  I also like Andrew's build on the group dynamic.  Peer pressure can be an incredible motivator so I could see activity increasing dramatically.

This approach could be even stronger if it helped people gather "ground miles" together in groups - maybe for shared rewards (for a workplace, a family, a friendship group, or for a street). Would help incentive the recruitment of new people....

organise_your_health_organise_your_life.description: A way to manage, organise and remember to take the medication you need
organise_your_health_organise_your_life.creator: 521fda9ec009af6bd314f767522fac67

comments.text: I think this is a really intresting concept Alex. I actually forget to take medication often when i'm sick- so this would be a pretty useful gadget!

I really like this idea.  My senior design project involved creating a medication box for a woman effected by macular degeneration.  I love this concept because of the design of the device and wish I had a similar ideas during that project.

You have some interesting thoughts Alex, but perhaps this concept is a little too specific to a small section of any working community. The idea of a reminder service to do something good to promote health is great. But there are already many services in place to help remind people in need to take their medication. Also there is a very valid point that many people who need reminding are of a certain age and are probably not working. Great principle I just feel it is a little too specific to a minority of people. Perhaps a reminder service to promote healthy activity would have more potential.
I would like to know  which age group  is likely to forget taking the medicine most Then maybe having take the first  run of test on your system

"This Feature gives a unique selling point over any other product in the market, as none integrate and notify via your phone."Could this be because its not necessary?Users who have multiple medication to take in the morning or throughout the day can purchase a sorting tray for a few pounds if that. Which is extremely popular!They have to insert the medication into the system which is no different to what you are proposing, and initially would have a reminder, but would get into a routine and naturally take their medication without reminder.Presuming they have a smart phone, If need be they could just set an recurring alarm on their phone.I think the concept of reminding people to take their medication and making it easy for them does work however the execution seems to be lacking

Nice one Jo. And if a company wasn't looking to spend too much money  perhaps there might be something around supplying seeds and a growing medium. Might be a great way to incentivise active participation from staff if they were to grow plants themselves. I can even imagine different floors of a building battling it off for the best garden patch ;^) Looking forward to some more fresh thinking around urban gardening in our upcoming Concepting phase  starts in 18 hours! Hope to see you there...

Meet with each other on the move. Joining a conference call? Do it away frm the desk. Inside, outside, whatever there could be a range of options with low effort and cost to adopt. Whether you incentivise or gamify for early adoption (steps taken at work on pedometers for example) is another consideration.

I've seen some of my coworkers hop on here and there. Not on the regular but some days get long and they need a break!
Great to hear, Emily. That's got to be an improvement over never getting on at all :^)

motivating_companies_to_become_engines_f.description: A healthy workforce would not only improve a company’s bottom line, it would motivate teamwork and benefit individual employees by improving their health and work-life balance.
motivating_companies_to_become_engines_f.creator: 8f0d733df82ac00ca1c5d3dd913fd53a

comments.text: This is a great idea being put into place in many areas of the world. One initiative I've been involved in is the Workplace Wellbeing Charter, developed by Liverpool PCT and supported in many areas across the UK: http://www.wellbeingcharter.org.uk or http://neweconomymanchester.com/stories/1476. The Charter is evidence-based and has supported over 350 businesses so far.There is a series of standards for the organisation around not only good health but also the focus of 'good work' - a place where employees feel valued and respected, have some control over their day jobs, understand the demands placed on them and the support provided etc.Any questions, sure they'll get in touch.

Thank you for pointing out a really great resource. We will definitely refer to it time and again.  Wanted to let you know that we looked at a number of global efforts, especially what companies in the US do, and the WEF Workplace Wellness Report as we formulated the framework for our India guidelines. But, we wanted our Healthy Workplace Criteria to resonate within India, so we developed them with multistakeholder input, including that from medical experts and IT industry in India.   It is reassuring for companies as we approach them that these Criteria are new, were developed for India with Indian input, and are therefore practical and viable in India.
So important to ensure that this is not a one size fits all approach - well done Kelli,it sounds like a fantastic idea

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel encouraged you to think about how this might be delivered and by whom?  What could the key metrics be?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

We'd also suggest you take a look and join collaborative conversations on the following concepts:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/workplace-health-buddies/http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/health-coaches-in-the-community-/Let's get some cross-pollination going between these ideas and build upon the goodness that each has to offer!

We are so thrilled that we are top in 20 in this challenge; it has reenergized the entire organization.  We believe we have outline the key metrics and we are looking at feedback from the OpenIDEO community on other metrics we could measure. IT companies are our first target for they hire young professionals in large numbers and are at the forefront of India's economic growth. Arogya World has developed the Healthy Workplace criteria with PHFI, and will lead on the implementation of the awards program.

Great stuff Kelli. I think it may help our community grasp all the goodness on this comprehensive concept better if you might have the time to add a scenario or two to your post. See our tips here: http://bit.ly/oi_refine to get more of an idea on that. Looking forward to seeing you on more conversations across this challenge...
Thank you very much for your encouragement in this refinement phase. We are working on it so watch this space in the next day or so!
Nice one, Kelly. We know you must be busy going great work on the ground. We super appreciate any efforts you can manage.
We got to work this past week and have updated our content. Be sure to check out the "benefits" section.
Brilliant use of a scenario to help others grasp the goodness on this idea and how it might connect to other concepts, Kelli. Way to go Team Arogya!

Great idea!  Getting companies to supply information is the real trick here.  Nobody wants to look bad.  So, I guess my question is:  How are you gonna get access to actual data here?  I'll try to think of some solutions.
Thank you, you have hit on a major concern. We are putting on our thinking caps on as well. Look forward to hearing from you!

Sounds great, Kelli! During our OpenIDEO Refinement phase we hope that our community will collaborate to strengthen and build ideas, together. Do you have any challenges or areas of opportunity for Healthy Workplaces that you'd like to share to help folks understand where they might join the conversation? Perhaps you'd like to add those in at the end of your post description. (To edit your post, hit the Update Entry button on the right)

Our challenges are getting the endorsement of industry bodies of this concept, persuading companies to invest healthy workplace programs, and to collect data on impact and ROI in India. We are tackling this one company at a time but any suggestions from members of the OpenIDEO community on how we may articulate our arguments to encourage company leaders in India to invest in healthy workplaces would be most welcome.

motivating_companies_to_become_engines_f.title: Motivating Companies to Become Engines for Chronic Disease Prevention

convince_your_boss_or_coworkers_to_walk_.description: Meeting  on the move serves a few purposes.  First, it gets oxygen flowing to spark new ideas and insights.  Second, it gets people physically active.  Third, it reduces the social anxiety associated with having to sit around a boardroom table.
convince_your_boss_or_coworkers_to_walk_.creator: 2fc6e1c0641f700337cab8b1af05777d

comments.text: Great thinking Matthew  and we were excited to see this also come up in our Inspiration phase: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/walking-meetings/ Fab start. lively_london_step_by_step_.description: Encourage Londoners to take the stairs on the underground by installing oyster card readers at the top & bottom of each station's flight of stairs. Allowing commuters to record the number of steps they've climbed & descended! Also possible in offices
lively_london_step_by_step_.creator: 12f85fdf12a50de1f8f209c9080ea937

comments.text: Hey there Ryan  If you're interested in pursuing your idea further, you might want to check out the Knight News Challenge. They're focusing on the topic of health and the winning entries will receive grant funding to bring ideas to life. You can check it out here http://kng.ht/1aunB0h.

I was really captivated by this idea; particularly in applying it to the office. As a context, I work in a 10 story building, with approx 2,500 employees in the building at any one time. There are 12 lifts, and 4 poorly positioned stairwells that function as fire escapes rather than 'real' travel routes between floors.There is a gigantic 10 story atrium which could easily accommodate a well designed stairwell, encouraging people to use the lifts less and be healthier. The problem is in the fundamental design of the building (which is brand new). How do we present a compelling business case for a stairwell? Through a health-linked initiative like this!With that in mind, I approached our facilities team to see if we could use our existing infrastructure of staff ID-Pass readers which are positioned at the entry and exit of every stairwell door. It'd be simple enough to read the access data of each 'swipe' of an employees ID pass, along with the time and location, and plot against a leaderboard of floors climbed per day/week similar to the City Peaks challenge already mentioned.In reality, my initial test/prototype raised a number of issues that we'd need to address in our own business; and which you may also need to address in any roll out of a scheme on the tube or in similar office environments;Firstly the issues with data protection; people always get a bit concerned when they think they're being tracked around the building. Next up was access to this data. While we generate data on who swipes thier ID where and when, the data isn't owned by our firm. I've been told we'd need to contract (and pay) the third party software provider to get access to the SQL server where this data sits. Then there were liceing issues around this, snowballing in to issues around testing, business continuity and compliance. A headache.Not impossible, but not as easy a win as I initially thought. Still, I think this has the power to fundamentally change the way people move around buildings and fundamentally the design of a lot of new office buildings.Best of luck in the considerations for the finals!
Great stuff Robert  and fascinating issues you've raised here. We're big fans of prototyping and applaud your efforts on this.

Such a good idea!The companies could also save on energy bills as the lift would be used less. I don't think a cash incentive is necessary. Just being able to track your progress would be enough, and to be able to see what other people are achieving.Good Luck!

To improve participation, some financial incentives could help. For example:1) Cash prizes for the top 3 stairwalkers as registered on the website.2) 10 pence off your Tube fare if you took the staircase exit in/out of the Tube station.

I like the idea, however, I think rewarding the top 3 would only act to encourage the fit stay fit. The reduced rail fare incentive is a good idea although it may be hard to organise, plus I don't think it is sensible to encourage people to take the stairs late at night. Alternative suggestions: 1) The monthly leaders of each group of stairwalkers on the website are entered into a prize draw to win cash prize or prize donated by sponsors. 2) 10 pence off tube fair if staircase taken in/out of tube stations - between say 7am and 7pm. Thanks for the thoughts they are much appreciated, I will add you to the virtual team - please feel free to contribute any other thoughts you have.

I make a point of taking the stairs at the tube station every day (London Bridge - about 80 stairs every morning!!) and I don't think you'd need a cash incentive; after all, the incentive is in getting fitter. A way to record your cumulative steps, or convert the number of steps in to calories or some other tangible measure would be great. Oyster readers would cause a bottleneck during peak times, as there are often queues just to join the escalators in the mornings.Thinking about incentives however, you could look at what Nectar (Sainsbury's) do when you bring your own bag; you earn separate 'green' points which can be redeemed in another way. The only challenge is finding a way to record the steps, and prevent abuse of the system. Perhaps personal acknowledgement and benefit is where it starts and finishes?
Checkout City Peaks from Digit London: http://digitlondon.com/our-work/project/city-peaks

Nice find Samuel  and great design they've used. I'm going to let the guys collaborating over on the Climbing Mt Everest concept http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/climbing-mount-everest-one-step-at-a-time/ about this as well. Hope to see you on more conversations across the challenge...

I think the ability to compare and convert your efforts in to something tangible like calories / building heights would negate the need to 'pay' a cash incentive. Just look at frequent flier tiers; thousands of people take flights JUST to achieve the next tier; in this case, the next building, and as Alek points out, the 'bragging rights' of getting there.

I saw once @ uni ... the # of burnt calories (printed on each stair step) to encourage people aiming for their health.The number was increasing as the user was getting to the top of the staircase , summing the last number.

A superb low-cost, low-tech approach to getting the message across. You'd need a different approach for moving stairs / escalators however (perhaps rolling increments every 10-20 stairs: "+ XX calories")

I wonder about the cost of implementing this concept and who would cover the cost.  I like the idea of rewarding people for utilizing the stairs and maybe the reduced electricity costs would offset the cost of implementation.I just wonder about the limited application of only being at the Underground stations and wonder if currently available pedometers or GPS-enabled fitness tracking apps couldn't be utilized to implement a similar idea with less new infrastructure required.

As a thought if this became a successful thing. I assume  the card readers would be electrically powered. What if there were little weights on the handrails that you could push up as you go up the stairs that could power the card readers as they fell back down to the bottom of the staircase via electrical braking. Each time you pushed one of the weights up you would get more points/discounts etc.

Really sorry guys, been very busy with job applications and interviews recently... After the weekend I will do a big refinement on this concept as some really interesting things have been pointed out! Please get as many ideas flowing as possible so we can move things forward.

This is just awesome, Ryan  and I love how it builds upon an existing platform like the Oyster card (and could be scaled to other locations by building on their own similar cards) One thought I had  to build on your idea of creating healthy competition between friends and co-workers  would be to have stats show who is doing be best my week / month as well as overall. That way folks who haven't done so well overall may still be incentiised to compete to be best of the week / month. Looking forward to seeing more of you across challenge conversations...
OMG. Just realised how many spelling mistakes crept into that last comment  the down side of auto-correct! Hopefully you've pieced together what I was on about ;^)

I can already imagine swarms of commuters climbing the stairs at Covent Garden station to win those extra 'bragging rights'. Perhaps it could go even further into the depths of the underground and take into account the smaller sets of staircases the tube has to offer?

great idea! nicely leverages the principle of "nudging" (http://www.amazon.com/Nudge-Improving-Decisions-Health-Happiness/dp/014311526X), and lots of interesting opportunities for gamification.i wonder about funding for reduced fare incentives program(s). perhaps companies can publicly sponsor such a program (the incentive for them would be to demonstrate their commitment to worker wellness), or perhaps these reduced fare programs could be internal to companies (even more "bragging rights")?
Great builds, Joel!

Great way of encouraging people to use the stairs, if you do add the reward idea of taken money off the fair it will enoucourage people even more. It will also keep people fit and healthy at the same time.
I agree with Gul, I think that if there is another reward maybe people will be more encouraged to do it.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel loved this fun idea! Could customers also get a discount on their Oyster journeys (or a bonus) for taking stairs instead of lifts? How could we work with TFL to reconsider wayfinding to make stairs more compelling than lifts? Perhaps Google The Fun Theory's piano stairs for inspiration as well. Could you use your phone for example? Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!
