They're focusing on the topic of health and the winning entries will receive grant funding to bring ideas to life. You can check it out here http://kng.ht/1aunB0h.

I have been doing some research and I feel to potentially resolve the cost issue all one would have to do it create a team using the Nike+ community or the Adidas equivalent. However, the cost of the electronic would be difficult.

Hi Sara, love this idea. For example if one was to use Nike+ an employer could visually see which employee is going well being seeing it on the Nike+ community or equivalent. How do you see or feel this could be put forward in terms of cost?
This would be nice paired with the "Gamify microexercise" idea by adding unique achievements and awards that could be accomplished through this aggregated data.
Great idea! Thanks for your feedback Anthony.

Sarah  during our iterative Refinement phase, feel free to add any thinking you're keen on from the comments section to your actual post so it's all set for the Evaluation round. We're looking forward to seeing ideas grow from these collaborative conversations!

Sarah, this feels like a great idea but also really hard to do. It feels like a technical problem How do you get the different platforms to talk to one another? Perhaps you could tweak your idea to add a way to make a start on this idea? As a suggestion I think the first thing that has to happen is to create an open format and get the different Fitbits, Nike + of this world to use it. Bupa would be well placed to own this open format, which would benefit everyone.
Hi everyone, thank you for your comments! How would you think this could work on a large scale, ie. millions more lives across international markets?

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel really liked that this isn't trying to re-invent the wheel. Mint.com is a great analogy. They thought it would be great to think about how this might get started quickly, given what data is already available.Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Nice idea to be the aggregator of the health data that's out there.  Would the individual user be the one to control the health data that's aggregated?  I really like the idea and want to avoid it feeling like your employer has access to your all your health data.  Maybe if Bupa are the aggregator they can give the individual options for what they alone have access to and what they are happy to share?

Hi Sarah -Another great concept.  This one seems to have incredible potential to vastly improve someone's wellness.  To help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. This concept is great! Many people get stuck during rush hour whilst driving to or from work. This idea is efficient, inexpensive and most importantly, healthy.

I like this concept Daniel. I agree that cycling is a very good alternative to transport in terms of fitness and environment. This has been backed up by the explosion of amount of bikes used in cities, and schemes like the Barclays Bikes in London. I like Meena's suggestion about third party companies getting involved. Maybe they could help sponsor the scheme.Great work Danny

Having internal support for a program like this would hopefully help address this awkward "I've shown up in my bike gear with my bike and now have to figure out how to look professional for the day, where to put my bike, how to get the wrinkle out of my pant leg, etc..."

Way to go, Daniel! I also wonder whether this could be run by a third party to enhance scale  and individual companies could sign up and get their logo put on the bikes they pay for by a yearly subscription.
Great Concept! Very good points in terms of impact on society. I wish people would cycle more and go less by car.

comments.text: Very strong concept I like the idea of everyone getting involved and losing stress. Great idea!
Great idea! The best way to work well is removing the stress and keep calm! I like the way to share the activities and the rewards!
Yes, of course! It's so necessary

I really like this idea, Andrea!  I think the key to successful implementation will be integrating this concept into the company's culture.  Your idea for having employees suggest the de-stressing activity allows them to take ownership of the idea, helping it to become part of the culture.Nice!

I agree that company culture is an important part of this design. I think you could find push-back from companies as this is a system that takes employee time and therefore there must be proven value. Maybe you could use this as a cross-sectional opportunity to improve collaboration - so your paint ball team has to have someone from accounting and sales. Or maybe the value could be in an activity you invite clients to. I think that showing the value of this idea will be important to get the buy in of those business professionals looking at the financials.
Thaks a lot for your inpunt folks!
I think this concept is a good way to improve the relationships between the workers. Moreover, keeping relaxed and fitted, the production in the workplace improve. Grate concept!
Yes, The production will improve if the workers do that.
It could be fine do it at work, a different way to disconect and keep relax. Congratulations Andrea.
Yes, it could be so fine! Thanks for your input
Stress fails productivity, innovation, happiness, good attendance nad motivation at workplace and your concept provide the platform to get rid of this health problem.
Thanks for your input Ernest :)
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks :)
Congratulations Andrea! I like your concept because is a good way to disconnect and also creates a friendly environment on the workplace on each employee could participate and take part of it.
Thanks ;)

Great concept. i like the idea of using a physical contact situation to tackle/ resolve the release of stress and better well being in at the work place. might even considering to use this strategy in a schooling environment for angermanagement therapy.
Thanks ;)

Love the concept Andrea! Getting workers involved in fun daily activities and giving them the opportunity to suggest different activities each day will let everyone have their say and hopefully get everyone involved.On the other hand, I could be an individual moment of relaxation needed, finding a quiet area to pull free from the daily burdens of work.Great concept and nice visuals it explains the concept well!
Thanks ;)

I start my classes (I teach college students) with a short quiet time. We don't call it meditation as some may have preconceived notion and associated feelings - positive or negative. I start it with no sound for 2 min. then gradually increase the time. As it gets longer I introduce simple sound such as Tibetan singing bowl or collection of rain drops in a forest.  By mid-semester, i don't have to say anything, when I start the sound, students settle and close their eyes. Offices can have something similar, in a small unit - part of cubicles, then one floor, one department, one area.  Toward the end of semester, if we skip the quiet time, my students ask for it  "I really can use some quiet time today" as they pull out the white cord of iphone from their ears.

My Art teacher used to do something similar at the end of her lessons to get us to relax before we left- in the beginning we all thought it was odd but we grew to love it- so much so that we wished the other teachers had tried it! I think it's great that you do this with your students, to have a moment to just sit back and zone out once in awhile is so beneficial for our mental well being and could be a useful tool for de-stressing in the workplace.

Great idea! I like that it takes into account what the employees would actually want to do by allowing them to vote for their preferred activities, that should definitely encourage people to take part.

Love the concept Andrea! I like the fact that you are using the social platform to allow employees of small and large companies to collaborate suggesting different activities to combat stress. Varying the activities each week is an effective way in keeping them engaged and guessing what's next? Creating positivity for the individual to relieve stress, for their company to work together in a healthy environment and lastly with other companies sharing activities and networking. Great work Andrea!!
Digging the enabling nature if this idea, Andrea + great idea to piggy back on existing social media platforms to spread the word.

I like the idea of utilizing social media platforms to spread the word, however it may prove challenging.According to a recent study 54% of U.S. companies say that they have banned workers from using social networking sites like Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn and MySpace while on the job.Perhaps this concept would be a valid reason to advocate the use of social media during work.

Nice concept! Bringing in fun activities can help people relax a bit more on their breaks. I like that employees get to vote on the activity and throwing paint/water balloons is great fun.. and would be even better if you could throw them at someone
haha, yeah throwing it at someone definitely sounds fun :D it's like paintballing and waterfights an enjoyable, interactive experience alongside de-stressing.
I like so much your idea. I think that reducing the stress is important in the workplace because affects negatively to workers and productivity. Good work Andrea!

Definitely agree with Jorge, stress is a state - if it becomes too excessive and prolonged, mental and physical illness may develop. Relieving stress in a fun and enjoyable way whilst socialising, interacting and sharing 'stuff' is awesome...

Great concept and thoughts combating reducing/relieving stress through social/personal activities in a common space.Really like the idea of utilising existing social networking and technology to facilitate and share the concept as this can be easily implemented and many companies [big & small] already use them. The idea of sharing skills, interests, experiences alongside building friendships/relationships when meeting together at break/for activities is awesome. Really interesting how it can work in different contexts - especially when you mention smaller companies can collaborate with other local/individual companies on a common platform!

Good concept! Stress is a major issue within many working environments and if we can just find simple but effective ways to reduce this, it would benefit workforces abundantly which they might possibly do. I also love the fact that it arouses social interaction creating  a less stressful working environment. Great work
this*

switch_off_at_5pm..creator: 46defce884d1be32019f20864172323d

comments.text: i am very glad to see an inspiration that makes point of this ever rising issue. Its a sin to think that people are doing masses of work for an employer and gaining nothing for it but un-happiness.

Thank you Zed, I agree with you that there must be a reward for the work, employees do outside of the agreed working hours a system that logs this activities would be a starting point. Its in the interests of the employer as well. Great input.

The picture says it all Bernhard well done, captures ecactly what your trying to convey! The idea of completely turning off id a great idea, maybe not so viable in the larger companies where around the clock working is needed, but in '9-5' jobs this would be great!!
Of course it depends on the user, we should design a system that allows the user to customize his switch off experience. Thank you for the input.
Great idea! Looking forward to seeing it develop into the concept stage. Good work Bernhard
Thank you Megan :)

Like the Idea, to switch off, could it be more flexible, about the times use i.e. Like a Dimmer switch rotating This could allowing people to pick up their kid from school  early ,or miss traffic jams.
Yes Kas, great that you mention it. This Inspiration is not limited to 5pm, its much more about finding a appropriate point to stop working.
Kas has a great point her Bernhard, about a dimmer switch. This implies a slow wind down to 5pm or "chillout time" and makes it more of a transition between work and play. great idea tho!

Julian are you talking about something that happens during the working hours? would be interesting to handle it like a debrief. Maybe some kind of meeting? Also i would like to ask how we could help people to switch off then they arrive at home. Imagine your phone or mobile devices would change profile, log you into different accounts, change colour theme?

I like the idea of a debrief in work, something informal maybe, or that is work related but presented in an informal way. I also agree with your thought process of separate accounts/profiles or systems for work and home, allowing you to "detach" from work.
Love this idea! maybe you could think about how this could fit in to different types of work and in different country's - cant wait to see the concept for this

self_sterilizing_polymers.description: Illness-causing germs account for more than 25 million sick days annually. Integrating Self-Sterilizing Polymers into shared office products such as telephones, keyboards, mice and pens would reduce illness, improve health and increase productivity.
self_sterilizing_polymers.creator: cb52c557bd16b54ddcc5cb14ea76e6f8

comments.text: This is a really interesting idea Daniel. I think many companies would benefit from self-sterilizing polymers reducing the risk of illness dramatically. This could also be used on handles that are frequently used in and around the workplacegreat work
Risha, I appreciate your response. Office and restroom handles are another frequently used item that would benefit. Great idea.

You could also consider a technique that is currently being studied for medical implants known as nano-surfacing. They have seen that certain topographies are not friendly to bacterial adhesion. This would overcome the need to develop a novel polymer and could possibly be integrated directly into the mold used to create the device, making the cost a one-time cost in the manufacturing process.
Kyle, wonderful idea. I appreciate the response.

self_sterilizing_polymers.title: Self-Sterilizing Polymers

the_office_potluck_gone_healthy_salad_st.description: Office Potlucks are fantastic because they stoke our social networks, but usually entail unhealthy foods. Salad Potlucks are healthy, collaborative, and inexpensive.

comments.text: Humans naturally crave salty and fatty foods, originating as a survival mechanism. Before modern society our species craved these foods to combat periods of famine. Unfortunately today, our society tends to feast not famine.The notion of healthier food options, especially a potluck is a wonderful idea.

Great thoughts Ashley! We're looking forward to hearing more developments on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO...

the_office_shower_share.description: A significant barrier to a more active work day is a lack of showers and facilities to tidy oneself up. Shared office showers would allow people to more readily, more easily, more hygienically (and less smelly-ly) take part in the other concepts.
the_office_shower_share.creator: e14b7c266947919b8bef3d7e2e88b29a

comments.text: I like the idea of this being a shared building resource, much like a cafeteria in a multi-tenant building, that way it doesn't require an individual business to foot the bill. This could be like an airline club that has shower facilities and an attendant for your supplies and cleaning. Could we put in a self cleaning shower stall sort of like those self cleaning public toilets? How can we get businesses to recognize the value (or rather ROI) of this resource to justify it being a value add to the landlord?

I'm reminded of the self-cleaning public toilets, sanisettes, in Paris. I don't recall similar solutions for showers, but it would seem a set of shower stalls with sealing doors, and adjoining dressing rooms for the showers, could provide such a self-attending functionality. There's also at least one company, highlighted by Wired last year, that uses wall coatings to break down detritus and improve cleaning efficiency. (http://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2011/07/self-cleaning-shower-uses-nano-coatings-to-destroy-dirt/).

This is a great idea. I occasionally find a need to use the shower facilities in my office even when I haven't been exercisingcoming in after just getting off of a red-eye flight, it's nice to get a shower in before starting the day.

I really like your idea! It's inspiring and yet powerful. I did face this situation myself in my previous job. There's a park nearby my office. But I hardly went jogging there because I didn't want to be sweaty and smelly in the office. The idea is indeed support people to exercise and be healthy.

For workers which work from 9-5, they will be prefer to exercise before work or on there way to work. In many way, this concept will benefit active workers! Also I like how this idea can benefit not only workers which do exercise, but to those which working a late shift or just too tired and want the freshen them mind!

Nice one Crispin! I wonder if you or others have thoughts about an initiative which could run alongside this structural intervention  which incentivises day-time workouts. Could it be something as simple as a board outside the showers where you chalk up your day-time workouts so those who are super active are highlighted  or something else? (hopefully something else  that was just the first thing that into my head to get folks thinking!)

comments.text: I absolutely love the idea of replacing the obligatory birthday cake with fruit. It reminds of me of Edible Arrangements' birthday baskets, with flower-shaped pineapple and grape-skewers, it brings some curb-appeal to fruit. I wonder if there's something similar to be done with the every-day basket, design it, or stage it in some attractive way. I love having a fruit basket in the office and yet I still often fall into the trap of attractively-packaging of candy and granola.

getting_that_sense_of_accomplishment.description: When you get home after a day at work and feeling as though you have tried your best, worked towards a goal, been stretched, and performed well, you know that your work is contributing to a healthy lifestyle.

comments.text: Positive feedback, and the sense of satisfaction I feel from completing a task are two of my bigger motivators, not just in my work but in everything I do.  However, I also thrive on taking on tasks that stretch me beyond what I think I can accomplish - I've often surprised myself at my own capabilities. I suppose shared reflection may be an important element as well.  As the saying goes, you never know until you try.

awesome idea!

Great builds, James! Looking forward to more switched-on developments in the realm of urban gardening and wellness in our upcoming Concepting phase

Love this, additionally it has been proven that gardening is sometimes as or more effective at curing depression as medication.I believe humans have a primal instinct to be close to the earth. This would solve for that need and create a fun & healthy environment.Check out this article about the mental effects of gardening:http://permaculture.com.au/online/articles/why-gardening-makes-you-happy-and-cures-depressionGreat post Carles!

gamify.description:
Please ignore the project proposal below.
I suggest that everyone joins 1 or 2 of these gamelike events, that go on constantly, w "missions" IRL, exercise, entertainment, competition: Waymarking / Turf Game
gamify.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: I suggest that all employees and employers join one or two of these gamelike events, that go on constantly online, with "missions" out in the real world, to give you exercise and entertainment and a little competitive element:http://www.waymarking.com/games.aspxhttp://www.turfgame.com(the described project proposal above is pretty pointless, when fun stuff like these already exist)
Well, I guess we should be celebrating! Woohoo! This was my first contribution to this site and I got on 2 wonderful vTeams for a great challenge. What a wonderful experience.

Wooohoooo! I finally get a win, since being a regular here for several years!I will discuss with Vishal, who won with a similar project proposal, I suggest that you take some minutes to read through his concept description: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/winning-concepts/climbing-mount-everest-one-step-at-a-time/And then mull over pros and cons, and get back to me with your ideas and suggestions for improvements, please coment with what you see is vital, and what you consider to be slightly "unneccessary".And keep in mind that I would prefer if the model was equally as fun to use and apply in a low-tech (gadget-free) version, as well as in a high-tech, but easy-to-use version, utilizing any or many existing software, technology used by average people + existing social forums and so on(newly found gem, but seems to have little limited target age group: https://www.zombiesrungame.com/ )
and remember: there never exists any stupid ideas, there are only ideas that can be adapted and modified and can improve other ideas, bits and pieces  into becoming great Projects!
Too true, Johan!
Yeah, congrats!
Great work Johan! This is such a cool idea, ripe for all kinds of prototypes. You have a willing guinea-pig for testing right here! All the best with realization :)

I honestly don't get this layout of the competition, what happens now? I have no possibility or technical skill to just "build" this, but wish to give the idea of the concept away as open source, creative commons, to a little team that have the potential tools and skills and time to start to create it
Love this concept! It is a great way to get people more involved in their community at work with something fun!
I remember there was an app that is some like what is described in this concept where by people play a game and then take picture of places and get points.. can't really remember how that app works.

I wonder if the microexercise concept could be expanded to include exercises such as 'doing the washing up' , 'window shopping', 'sweeping the path at home - with a broom!'. Exercises that is incidental to a second goal. Speaking as one of the target group (I haven't done been anywhere near a gym since I left school - and I'm very relieved at that!)  I need to feel engaged and interested in something else to feel like the exercise is worth the bother. For years window shopping after work was my exercise, now that my feet have broken down I have to find other things that I can do that are interesting and involve exercise.

of course the framework are open to individuals "innovating" their own challenges for the opposite team to beat.Even the smallest ones will make you do microexercise, such as hiding the TV remote controls in the kitchen, so you will need to walk into the kitchen and search both high and low before you can change the channels.

Thank you everyone that shared your thoughts and ideas! And thank you everyone that studied the concept proposal and evaluated it.If you have possibility to discuss something like this in your company or work place, please do! And let me know if you are going ahead with any kind of project like this!

Not a fan of the 'stick' but do enjoy the gaming aspect and concept.  Perhaps points could also be assigned to volunteer physical activities like planting trees with a local green team, or participating in an AIDS walk, or working on community clean ups, etc.  Effort and time could be verified by the corresponding NGOs.  If companies find partner NGOs to work with you could collectively impact the community through planting trees, community gardening, etc while also gaining ground on the physical goals and competition. More bang for the buck.

Love the idea of microexercise! Has anyone mentioned BJ Fogg on here yet? If not... please check out http://www.bjfogg.com/  Fogg has come up with the idea of using Tiny Habits to change behaviors or create new habits. In addition to the gamification, you could create tiny habits of microexercise. Key is having triggers to trigger the habit/exercise at that moment in time. Motivation is also key - the game provides motivation, but we can probably come up with other types as well. Buzzword Squats instead of Buzzword Bingo - If you use a buzzword, like 'incentivizing' or 'paradigm shift', that's the trigger for you to do a microexercise like 10 squats. The motivation might be the rest of the folks in your meeting cheering you on.

thanks for the advice on BJ Fogg, looking at it now.The Bingo idea, is a one that I had played with earlier, but in another sence, to over the course of the challenge mark sites and actions that you completed, as 'tasks' that create more fun into going extra steps each day. (hiding the remote control for the TV, to make you walk up to the set to change stations etc)But your thoughts about group 'pressuring' you into doing squats in a public meeting, that sounds little bit like those awful 'Phone marketers' methods of bullying their staff. It should really be communal work done, not one doing the exercise and the rest cheering and taunting him/her. (but I will keep it in mind, perhaps it could be tweaked a bit?)
Yeah, bullying is bad. Didn't mean it quite like that. More fun...
I know that you didn't mean any harm by it. I simply tried to imagine what the worst case scenario would lead to, if there were no "guidelines" on how to apply that type of motivational trigger.

From my point of view, there are several key things that need to be in place for gamification to work for the long term.- Easy -Whatever is done, it has to be easy. The more I've let the QR idea float around in my head, the more I see there are some circumstances where it makes sense and some where it doesn't. For example, I'd much rather just swipe my badge at each floor than stop to get a QR read. The recent suggestions on automatic picture recognition or GPS tracking/tagging fit into this.- Instantaneous Feedback -When I accomplish something, even something small, I want to feel that "rush". I need to be told right away I've scored points, added to some total, got a new check on the checklist, etc.- Automatic Goals -One of the most addictive part of many online role-playing games is the fact that there's always something (a new level, better gear, etc.) just slightly out of reach. The system provides these. Yes, I can go off and do my own thing, but there's always a progression path being laid out for me to follow so I'm not ever left with nothing to seek after. It also provides minor wins on the way to accomplishing the bigger goals.The following don't hurt:- Competition -Seriously, we all like to win.- Physical/Virtual Rewards -I'd rather not admit the amount of time I've spent trying to gather badges or accomplishments in games over the years. You haven't really "beat" the game until you have all of the badges.- Recognition -I used to work in the awards and recognition industry. It's important to note that for many people, the recognition of those around them is far more important in the actual physical award. Actually, the physical award is only really a tool to get more recognition.There's a lot of different ideas being proposed, and each is touching on at least one of these areas. I think it's clear no single approach is likely to cover everything for everyone. So, my question is "what is the best way to tie the different games together?"

Great thoughts, on the competetive side, I guess that if the team that challenged you, could send notifications of their accomplished partial goals to you, that would trigger you to do better, to keep up.The recognition: Have you seen my suggestions on the donate-options? Where the teams put a cash bet for each challenge, the winners will be able to see the loosing team donate their bets to charity.

I think Trev's idea about automatic goals that lead to some recognition along the lines of foursquare badges is a good idea.  It will get users more tied into the game so that it quickly becomes a habit instead of something they do occasionally when they remember.  I know I consistently use apps that give me coins to unlock parts of a game.  And I remember to use them more often than even some of the more exciting apps because it becomes a part of my daily routine.

Johan, yes, I've looked at your suggestions regarding team-based donation options. I think they are really good, and will certainly provide a bit of healthy competition in the approach, as well as providing recognition (and bragging rights) to the winners. The other suggestion I floated about having the organization provide some form of donation for groups or individuals reaching certain points could be a supplement to this. It provides the organization as an organization the opportunity to participate. Even if their donations really end up being solely for PR purposes, they still benefit the charities. So, I think the ideas can certainly work together.

I think Trev is right, the donation piece could be key to continued involvement.  Putting money on the line always motivates, even when it is a small amount.  I've heard of this helping people stick to diets very successfully, so it should work for this too.For the organizational donation, corporations could be persuaded to guarantee a matching donation up to a certain amount.  Perhaps a company agrees to match up to $1000 in bets per year.  But maybe that figure goes up to $2000 in bets matched if employees earn a certain level of points.  That would motivate people to really participate in the activity side of it rather than just write off a lost bet as a donation.

There have been a few concepts written about the potential for stair-walking (ways to encourage it, or make it more appealing), and I think that making it into a game is a great way to go.  In large office building, have a competition with two categories - one for number of stairs walked per worker, another for number of elevator trips prevented.  The first category helps encourage people on the upper floors to participate (since they rack up more stairs per trip), the second category rewards frequency.  Teams (companies, departments, floors) could buy in to the prize pool (on the order of $5/team) and the winning team gets a gift card at a vendor at the local farmer's market or other healthy equivalent.  Hold the competition over the course of a month to try to make it into a habit.  One low-tech way to track it: have a dispenser of tokens on the 2nd floor, and spots to deposit them at each subsequent floor.  I like the idea of encouraging employees to come up with their own challenges and ways to measure them, but it might help get things started by providing a few ready-made challenges - so I suppose the above is an example of one of those.

I love the idea of having physical "symbolic" objects to move from one place to another, but don't know if it is really feasible (risk of cheating by taking the elevator and bringing all of them in one trip or similar) But I will think about that, and how to possibly convert your idea into a digital "stamp" or something else. (perhaps using camera, taking a pic of a place, and prooving with the date and time-stamp in the image that you where there)

I love the idea of taking a photo at the goal place - since smartphones with cameras are so common, people can just upload the photo to the appropriate album when they take it.  That also makes me think of the possibilities for scavenger hunt-style challenges - blending into some of the other concepts posted here.  I think that the danger of cheating is fairly site-specific - whether it's easier to cheat or do the right thing.  If you have to get a token (or take a picture, etc) from the subway stop one stop away, people will just walk that last stop rather than get back on the train.  But the stairs are a harder one (depending on how far away the elevator is).

Why not just have QR codes posted in the stairwell halfway between floors? When one reaches it, one can scan the QR code, recording the action for whatever points/prize/badge/recognition is part of the game. As it's halfway between floors, one can't just pop out of the elevator to scan the image. It requires at least the equivalent of a full flight of stair walking (up or down).

The QR codes could also be posted out in public spaces, such as hiking trails or the middle of large parks, thereby allowing friendly competition between groups, as suggested by others.In any case, the gathering of electronic tokens, whether by QR codes or other means, should certainly be tied to a badge or level system (also suggested earlier), as it allows one to "compete" with one's own self while still publicly displaying the accomplishment.

Great ideas, thanks. Regarding QR codes outdoors I have thought about the possibility of it being torn down or cleaned away by city cleaners. It would be bad for the game if the QR codes disappeared and people couldn't mark those points.There is possibly a solution with image recognition feature, such as the one in images.google.com, if you have a sculpture or another typical landmark as the place to go to for a photo.I don't have enough knowledge, since I don't have a smart phone, but if someone would like to try it? let me know about that potential idea.
low tech version could be a whiteboard tablet, placed at secret locations in the stair well :)

I'm not entirely sure if this will work, but when you're travelling or walking on road (horizontal plane) shouldn't your GPS be able to track your location and even your speed?This won't be as effective for climbing stairs though...

I think you could involve municipal governments to post QR codes in permanent locations that city cleaners could maintain or at least not remove.  This could also set up a network of tracking points that individual challenge builders could work into their own game as it fits their locations.  You might even be able to work codes into municipal bike share systems like the Boris Bikes so that users wouldn't even need to scan an extra code.  The bike system could be used to track distance traveled.  Bonus points could be given for rush hour or lunch hour usage.

If participants live in a city where there is a sculpture, statue or land mark or pretty view in a park, they could do a photo of it, from the same place, every time they walk to it, and they could let this project create a stop-motion-animated gif of those images, to a short film, to share on their facebook-page and similar, See a sample of a human stop-motion: http://youtu.be/xgxxxKwlra8
thanks for adding me to your team Johan!  It's such a great idea.  We're always playing these little games through our routines, but this would help us and the environment!

I study at Srishti School of Art, Design and Technology (Bangalore, India) and we worked on a similar brief for designing an app. Sadly, I was a little late in noticing this challenge or I'd have entered. But for now, since your idea is the nearest to our idea I thought I'd share our insights!We realised how "playing" in teams is more motivating as the other team members are also looking out for your wellbeing along with there being a sense of inter-team competition. So I love the idea of the pedometer challenge. But perhaps you could take this idea forward? Say if you and your co-workers form a team, then on days when all of you'll take the stairs you get additional incentives. More points maybe (if you want that in the equation)? Or having a streak gives you even higher points thus motivating you to maintain this habit on a more regular basis.Another idea for gamifying something, to help motivate people to eat better is playing a sort of health-food secret santa. This moves away from your idea of gamifying exercise, but eating right is important when you do physical activity. Each person gets assigned somebody to whom they deliver a healthy meal secretly and if the system works, somebody delivers you a meal too! The assigned people get shuffled so you never have the same person in a row. This is a concept more fit for students and would require more active participation. We were focusing on students as our target audience, but I'm sure this idea can be furthur adapted to fit a workplace environment.I hope this helps develop your idea!

the person wearing the pedometer would be incentivised to compell their team mates to also walk the stairs, even though they do not count their steps, because of solidarity, and to keep them company. its a fun way to start the work day to talk with your coworkers on the way to the office
I love food, and I love the idea of a food Secret Santa. Or how about a Non-Denominational, Delicious Goodie? :)

Its a fun concept, I can see potential in healthy food, but clearly see issues with food-allergies and similar. It would be extremely difficult to maintain such a project in a large scale.But please try it if you can, at your respective places.

I think it's a great concept. One of the games could be setting up a parking area that is far away and a point structure for ppl that park there. You could get local coffee shops, restaurants, etc. to mark a spaces for the competition and you score points by distance. Snap a pic of your car and the sign in the spot and get points toward free stuff.

Great build David. I have free parking on the edge of town here in Wellington, New Zealand and it's been amazing how much it has encouraged me to walk the city rather than try and park close to where I'm actually going. I like how your thoughts here turn something like that into a game & support local businesses too  even though they might donate free coffees, etc to the scheme  I bet they'd benefit from additional patronage as well.

In some cities there are parking zones, with different tariffs depending on how central location it is.So as a bonus for such a game, you would save cash also on parking fee.Perhaps the game could be keeping track of that amount also ;)I smell an update coming to the concept description.
Ah  the sweet smell of collaboration! ;^)

In this case it smells like asphalt but i'll take it! On your comment Meena: I think it is imperative to create incentives that ppl can really hold in their hands, aka coffee, when it comes to getting people to participate in a health initiative and to get ppl to have a laugh in the morning isn't a terrible idea either. "Is that Johan in jogging shorts in front of Starbucks this morning?" ---The new business casual
If participants could be told that they're only say 3 flights of stairs away from winning something, then that would be a great motivator...
Great gamified-goodness build, Shruti!
Yea, I like that idea and they could get updates like "You've climbed the Empire State Building" or "you've climbed to mount everest"

I could see stores or entire shopping centers celebrating people who are "power shoppers" people who traverse a mall or walk around a complex for an extended period of time. The value for the mall, people stay around for longer. The value for people, they get exercise and have the opportunity to get discounts. The malls would sponsor this. It would be tracked with mobile devices, or simply by people checking in at stores, signing in at a small kiosk or something.

Greate idea. Why restrict it to the commute? This idea might also create opportunities to get moving throughout the day. e.g. Rather than send that email or make a phone call to your colleague, use the opportunity to get a few more steps in.

You are right, competitive users would become creative to cause more steps to be counted. But I think it should not need to be a requirement, since people work in different situations, and I don't wish to interfer in work hours, to maintain efficiency there, and to utilize the trip to and from work (or to the supermarket) where lots of people cannot see the potential of getting some extra low-impact exercize in those moments of the week.

Johan-I really like this concept! Great way to get people more involved in their community at work with something FUN!It is rewarding that activity that I'd suggest a modification to- I've seen and participated in "virtual points" schemes and competitive formats that don't offer any tangible benefits, and the ones that do offer free stuff are oftentimes products that are personally irrelevant to the participant (e.g free coffee mug with a company logo). Why not incentivize participation with time off? More time doing small activities at work lets you cumulatively earn a day off to go skiing/biking/hiking or on a meditative retreat. Employers and employees could have a dialogue about what the parameters and rewards are, and the possibilities of the reward structure could be tailored for each company's specific goals and personnel. Anyway, I'm pulling for this concept either way; good luck!

Hallo.I am really loving this concept.I think it could be possible to use Yammer as social network for the application, people log-in with their office email account, in this way could be possible to know wich company is playing the health game. It can be challenging inside the company, and between company.The problem is to understand the how, how to convince the people do that... ok, we can have badge, but they are not so "funny"...I have seen the underground piano stairs and how many people moved from automatic stairs to the piano... because of the fun... maybe just like the badge, at the second time you know what happen and so you will take the automatic stairs again...It is needed something that involve you to do the stairs, because of something magic in the stairs... that remain magic anytime you take the stairs... (Imagine the stairs that lead always on the top floor, and from there take a slide that takes you to the right plan. This is fun is not it? - I understand is not applicable... :) )Hope this can "unlock" something.D.

Gamify Microexercise:NFC/RFID Reader between floors (ex btwn 1st and 2nd), employee has playing card and every X floor badged with that playing card there are some prize.Time can be tracked so people can challenge each other by how many steps/floor and time. The prize can be a coffe?Problem: Install many reader as many floor... and set up a system that track everyone.

Thanks, I do understand what you are thinking about, but I think there shouldn't be any infrastructure or installations needed for such a "low-budget" project, but possibly any high-tech solution (that use existing things to piggy-back upon) might turn up, thanks to your thoughts.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel liked the simplicity of this idea and the accessibility for engagement.  How might this idea transcend the workplace?  How might efforts be tracked/measured and shared?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

We'd also suggest you take a look and join collaborative conversations on this concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/climbing-mount-everest-one-step-at-a-timeLet's get some cross-pollination going between these ideas and build upon the goodness that each has to offer!

I know it woud be a lot, but an app would be perfect for this. You'd just need a checklist with the ability to add pictures and the ability to get tokens. A lot like the Foursquare comment by Wout. This would allow for a wider spreading idea and no need for people to pollute their existing social networks with work-related stuff (which I think people might be hesitant to do).I think if you were to use an existing social network, a Facebook fanpage would be best.
Great thoughts on using Facebook  at least for a prototype. Did you know that our own OpenIDEO platform was prototyped on Facebook?!

Nice idea Johan,You might have heard of Ingress, a location based game released by Google: http://www.ingress.com. The app puts you in teams, and you have to travel to 'portals' (which are monuments, sculptures etc in real life) and capture them in order to catch the enemy team. These little location based games are similar to Niklas' suggestions, and could be very easily adapted to exercise.I like James' idea about opening it up to various forms of exercise. It might be nice to allow people to incorporate their everyday fitness routines into the games. You set up with some mates, set each other goals and compete in terms of time spent at the gym, hiking, rowing etc and how quickly you reach your goal (which could be a strength target, distance run etc). This could be app or social network based as you suggested.https://www.fitocracy.com is another site worth looking at - they are encouraging fitness through social engagement but seem to be more geared towards serious fitness programs - the advantage of this is it's the 'every little helps' idea!

Love this idea. I think using gamification-elements to motivate people to live a healthier life is absolutely genius. Small games and challenges on the way to work, during lunchtime and on the way back home are great since this are the whitespace times when people actually have time and attention and do not clash with oficial working hours.I'm just wondering how you want to collect and present those challenges? One could easy set up an email group where small teams create challenges and report on the progress. This would be an easy and viable solution. Or you can even think about a bigger solution like an own app which shows a daily challenge for each user. This would also allow to push spontaneous challenges based on the location and could make it an even better experience.I also love the idea of comparing results between different departments, offices or even companies. Would be interesting to see if the finance guys are more active than the sales people ;-)

I have been thinking about potential of facebook, in order to set up a group or "fan page" and use their integrated notifications to the members that have "liked" this group, in order to show progress of points or metres. I think it could be done, totally without setting up a whole web page, forum or something expensive like that.What do you think about just piggybacking onto existing facebook-twitter-Google+ ?

I'm a fan of leveraging existing networks. If I take a look a the big ones:Google+: For me it feels more like a feature in the whole google product experience than a real social network. Facebook: Yes, all my friends and colleagues are on Facebook but in my opinion FB is to noisy and messy. I don't check my groups regularly (and I'm only member in a handful of groups).Twitter: I love Twitter for its simplicity. It feels easy and fast to tweet and I think that is exactly what we need.What about creating an own Hasttag for each office which is taking part in the microexercise? So if I want to share my progress I just "check in" each day by tweeting that I accomplished my goal with this specific Hasttags. All my colleagues can easily search for the Hasttag and see all activities during the day.An example: Jumped of one station earlier today. #microexercise #TeamOpenIDEOThis could be even developed further with a simple website which uses the Twitter API and filters for all tweets with a specific Hasttag.What do you think?

Thanks Great thoughts! ( i share your feelings with G+ and FB ) But am not totally satisfied with how Twitter is "acting". Isn't hashtags "disappearing/becoming forgotten" after a couple of days, or is it up to the active tweeters to keep repeating their daily tweet?How do you feel about the discussion with Delia Kulukundis ideas below? Do you have knowledge about instagram and pinterest, and how it would be possible to utilize those "to mark the daily effort" in a photo-proof of some type ? (hashtags exist also on instagram)

I like this concept as well.On a network like Foursquare you get points by checking in.We could do something similar, but you'd need to check in twice. At the starting point of your healthy activity, and at arrival. A cheating check could be performed by the time in between the two check-ins. You can select, "walking", "running" or "bicycle", and the app would calculate your speed.Hashtags might indeed be useful. #bycicle #TeamFinance #Start and followed by #Stop could do the same as checking in.We could design a lot of great badges for the foursquare extension!Interesting link about rewarding for running: http://aboutfoursquare.com/foursquare-and-runkeeper-partner-to-reward-you-for-running-without-checking-in/

Hi Wout, hi Johan,I really like the idea of checking-in into an activity and post a picture after you accomplished a task.Regarding Pinterest/Instagram:I think Pinterest is more a passive community and only 1-2% of all user are really creating content. The rest is just repining existing stuff. And most pictures come from blogs and other websites, so Pinterest is just an aggregator (a goof one, tough).Instagram is a nice idea but I think people use Instagram to tell stories with their pictures (or take pictures of their lunch). I would not use Instagram for this purpose since I carefully select the pictures I upload.Again I think something like Twitter works best since you have all the needed features (#Hashtags, Pictures, Filter) and people are already using Twitter to communicate progress and achievements.What do you say?
updated
some of the text got lost in the update due to the glitch in openideo-servers. Hopefully you get the basic idea for this concept

gamify.title: Gamify microexercise [updated may 5th]

py/tuple: Is this concept addressing clear health needs for users?
Indeed! It’s addressing an unmet need in a new way
Yep – it’s addressing a need but in an already crowded space
It’s not clear to see how this idea would significantly improve people’s health
Overall how do you feel about this concept?
This concept rocked my world
I liked it but prefered others
It didn't get my overly excited.
Does this concept feel like it could potentially be sustained as a business or movement over years rather than just months?  Does it feel like it will continue to be relevant in the future?
This concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
It’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue – but there’s reason to feel hopeful
This concept may have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and stay relevant
How easy would it be for people to get involved and improve their health with this idea?
Very easy. It's clear how people could get involved quickly in this concept
I'm not sure if I can grasp how people could get involved easily
It seems challenging for people to get involved quickly in this concept
Does this concept have the potential to reach large numbers of people?
Sure. I could imagine this would spread like wild fire
It's interesting but feels like it would be slow or challenging to grow
It seems somewhat limited in scope

company_car_bicycle_fleet.description: In the UK, the weather is unpredictable so while cycling to work may seem a good idea in the morning, the cycle home can be quiet bad or vice-verse which makes you not want to take the risk of cycling in!  This concept aims to reduce this risk.
company_car_bicycle_fleet.creator: f139a238cf01e5992bc890f004f96299

comments.text: Cool concept, Shaun! A great way of reducing the excuses for not cycling in to work. What if the individual drove to work and cycled home from work. However, the next morning was not safe for cycling. Since they left their car at work the previous day, and they don't live on a public transport route, how would they get in to work?
Thats the scenario i'm not sure of! Was hoping noone would notice or could help me out with a solution! At the moment, 80% of the time it works everytime :)
Great concept! I've submitted one that is also based on bike riding, I think they complement each other very well! http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/co.-bike-bus/

company_car_bicycle_fleet.title: Company Car/Bicycle Fleet

wellness_officer_role.description: Each week/month a different employee could decide what health initiatives should take place in an organisation in order to maintain enthusiasm. They are then responsible for maintaining the drumbeat around any initiatives.
wellness_officer_role.creator: 351cea61c679f5c87ea4721911926306

comments.text: Hey Lorraine  this is such a fab idea. However, I've noticed that it's not currently published on the site, though I can see it with my Community Management super power access ;^) We'd love to have it entered to the challenge. If you're still keen to have it included, just hit the Publish button up there on the right.

wellness_officer_role.title: Wellness Officer Role

compete_with_coworkers_to_be_the_biggest.description: Companies like Agora in Baltimore have created workplace competitions that reward the "biggest losers".
compete_with_coworkers_to_be_the_biggest.creator: cd8202f4c30dff6cbc6bdb927043271a

comments.text: This carries an underlying and REALLY important consideratio: the people who will benefit most from being reached and having behavioural change embedded are not the folks already in the gym 5 days a week all year round. Identifying some of the blockers to making a lifestyle change (embarrassment in the gym, no obvious buddy system) and then tackling those blockers with positive inclusive and rewarding programmes like this could be hugely beneficial to all parties. No matter how slow and sweaty the workout you're still lapping the guy on the couch!!!

I like the friendly peer competition and wonder if you could add more value by creating a 'continuous' and more inclusive reward program?  It would be nice if those who didn't 'win' were also incentivized to continue working on their goals.

Good stuff. Offering challenges is a great way to build that community, create momentum, and gain accountability.To be more all-inclusive challenges could accommodate various measures of health. Performance measures such as strength (e.g. squat x lbs.), endurance (e.g. run a 5K), function (e.g. complete a pull-up); or aesthetic measures such as lose x lbs or a new body fat goal.
Interesting to see many great posts in our Inspiration phase about the power of peer pressure! Looking forward to what these insights might trigger for our upcoming Concepting phase...

compete_with_coworkers_to_be_the_biggest.title: Compete with Coworkers to be the Biggest Loser

got_inspiration_board.creator: 78c75d64a57bd170f2633a381b1c9707

comments.text: I love this idea! This could really motivate and inspire a work force, by forming bonds between co-workers being able to share and inspire each other in endless different ways. This could also provide a platform for the more shy members of the workforce, for breaking out of their shells and communicating amongst their fellow co-workers in an informal manner. This would really increase productivity and moral of the work team in and maybe even out of the office. This is a Great concept.

Great idea Rob. I really like the idea of being inspired by others inspiration. What do you think of potentially building a social component to this. For instance, if you sign up with 2 more co-workers you each get a "point". The more co-workers you can get to commit to an inspiration the more points for all.Points can be cashed in on professional development for the employee or employee family members (e.  certification programs, cross company mentoring programs etc) that the employer has pre-chosen. There's a few ideas others have put out regarding a points system, so this inspiration wall really defines wellness beyond typical exercise/healthy food topics. It allows you to peer into your coworkers ideas of wellness!

Really potential idea bob. I really like the idea of putting up inspirations in a collaborative place where people can interact physically. This would really help increase positive behavioral communication among the workforce by extended margins.

got_inspiration_board.title: Got Inspiration? Board

forced_breaks_from_the_computer.description: We all sit at our desks for too long in one day.  I heard about a company that periodically locks employees out of their computer for a forced break when they have been logged in too long.  This forces people to get up, socialize, and MOVE!
forced_breaks_from_the_computer.creator: 8d99349d8bee7e7eba943c56e2fe26b7

comments.text: Hi Nitida, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

forced_breaks_from_the_computer.title: Forced Breaks from the Computer

employee_appreciation_report.description: A weekly/monthly evaluation report where the employer tells the employee what things they did well that week/month.
employee_appreciation_report.creator: d6b2480531a2a0b58bac44ade6d30f60

comments.text: Fantastic concept, Zheela! A more frequent alternative to the standard appraisal meeting. It could also be used for employees to communicate with their colleagues. This could result in a workplace with less friction between employees, and may reduce bitching.

employee_appreciation_report.title: Employee Appreciation Report

using_habit_forming_science_to_our_advan.description: A treasure trove of scientific analysis has been done on how people form habits and how habits can be changed (for better or worse).  If we can find the trigger points for unhealthy eating/living at work, we can use this information to guide change.
using_habit_forming_science_to_our_advan.creator: 9c78d2970452794013457bbcf72b452b

comments.text: Great video!  I'd be interested to see what Duhigg has to say about creating new habits (as opposed to changing existing ones).  For example, creating a habit to go for a walk in the mornings or after work.

Thanks for your note Ashley!  I need to reread his section on the workplace in "The Power of Habit" to see his exact thoughts on this from the book.  My general sense from his viewpoint is that new habits are easy to create, but extremely difficult to make powerful enough to overcome old/destructive habits.  Seems like it is overcoming these old habits that is the real challenge.  I'll read more and see what I come up with.

The Power of Habit does go into creating new habits as well.  In this case, I believe the cue is just as important as the reward.  People need to have some kind of frequent trigger that makes them think of their "need" to do or have the thing that will later give them a reward.
Excellent share for this challenge, Maegan!
Thanks Meena!

using_habit_forming_science_to_our_advan.title: Using habit-forming science to our advantage

bring_your_workplace_outside_.description: There are plenty of parks and green spaces in cities across the world that are yearning to be used. Let’s use them!
bring_your_workplace_outside_.creator: 2b7c8d8c9a1294b4d6acb9511a3bc414

comments.text: Great inspiration. I like the idea of having the option to work in an environment where you feel you will be more relaxed and will perform better.
Thanks for your input, Maroun. It's really useful to hear your feedback.

This idea in practise could make a great impact on the quality of life of individuals. In certain countries, particularly here in the UK, people often begrudge going to work on nice summers day, and feel that they are missing out on precious sunshine and warm weather. This way they will be able to combine the two and not feel like they are missing out.
Thanks Kas, really great to hear your thoughts.

Glad you posted this! I work in an office with a desktop computer, but I've noted to my boss that if we had laptops, we'd be able to accomplish all the same tasks while taking our work outside, with the only difference being increased exposure to the natural world and sunlight. Like Jack commented, SAD (Seasonal Affective Disorder) negatively impacts many people. When workers are stuck indoors from 8-5, especially in winter and higher latitudes, that can mean there's no daylight left for soaking up after work. It's important that employees, as human beings, are allowed to enjoy the natural light of the sun. Here's an interesting and related article: http://health.usnews.com/health-news/family-health/articles/2008/06/24/host-of-health-benefits-attributed-to-sunlight

I love the idea of working outdoors to promote well-being. It takes you back to school when the prospect of a class outside was always really exciting. A change in routine is so important to stop work from becoming mundane. Natural light is also crucial to peoples health and a trip to an outside green space certainly provides natural light. Seasonal effective disorder can really limit peoples lives. So important to be connected to the outdoors. Love it!

Thanks Jack - really great to hear some feedback, particularly relating it to memories of school. It could be a lot like that but, also, if the infrastructure was there in parks then not only could it allow groups but also individuals to use the space. Now, we just need some protection from the English winter rain!

bring_your_workplace_outside_.title: Bring your workplace outside!

radio_taiso.description: Many Japanese companies start the day with a mandatory exercise within the workplace that helps employees to warm up their body, getting ready for the day ahead.
radio_taiso.creator: 1c49514bac39228bcfa6e7cbf1022fb1

comments.text: Very insightful. Workplace exercise not only promotes a healthier lifestyle but assists in fostering stronger relationships between employees.

Really great inspiration Sheana! I love the social interaction that this can bring, as well as the physical exercise and break from work. How can we encourage other countries to take this on? How will companies and institutions evolve from something like this?

Yes, this practice has been present in most Japanese companies for decades. When all this fuss about quality management burst in the 80's and Occident started to look at the best practices of countries in Asia, mostly Japan, this practice came to the surface. We came to know about Mr. Juran and Mr. Demming the fathers of Quality Management. They started to work with Japanese companies and government after the end of WWII. The reason the flag of Japan is a circle, besides the heritage of the philosophy of being the rising sun, is also because to pay a homage to Quality Circles, the pragmatical way of applying Juran's and Demming's theories in quality, because thanks to them Japan was able to rebuild itself. One of the practices they established is this one... reaching to their heritage they came to the insight that exercising at the beginning of the day will be of benefit of them individually, in benefit of their company and ultimately in benefit of Japan, their country.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Thank you! I'm glad many have found it inspiring.
I love the way this simply weaves health into the regular work routine and makes it accessible to everyone.
I enjoy the harmony of it, where everyone participates automatically!

I was a primary school english teacher in Xi'an one summer and as soon as the bell sounded the start of morning & afternoon break, all students and teachers alike made their way to the playground and line up in class order. Then 3x songs came up and our 500 little beings began do the moves to the aerobic dances and sing along to which ever song came out of the school speakers. This was great fun and really awoke them for the next set of classes :)These poor kids started almost at 7am and finished at 5pm. Long day !!
Great share, Sheana  it's brilliant to gather global insights during our Inspiration phase and this is a fab one!

radio_taiso.title: Radio Taiso!

pe_for_adults.description: Time invested in team sport and exercise to energise the workforce increasing optimism and productivity.
pe_for_adults.creator: 0d68366e439f762c5fb44b5e266b19f3

comments.text: Hi Chelsea, great thinking. There are loads of disused space in cities which could be redefined for sport. It always surprises me how much sport actually happens in big cities. There are courts, pitches and parks squeezed in all over the place, with people cycling and jogging across the cities. Imagine if we could improve things further and for sport to be integrated with our working lives!

Absolutely! You can probably let offices get creative with where they decide to implement their sports. I was thinking about how to quantify the increased productivity that would result from adult PE. It would be awesome to create an app or online profile for companies to record their progress, and maybe those who reach certain levels can get deals on health-related schwag (e.g. 10% at a sports equipment store for hitting certain numbers). Such profiles could record time to finish recurring projects, number of ideas that come out of brainstorming sessions, or even how quickly and effectively an idea traveling through different teams. This way the entire movement could be quantified on one platform and individual companies could see how they stack up against the rest of the PE embracers. Nothing wrong with a little competition!

Like the thinking Chelsea. I think it would be really important for us to come up with a way to measure the impact of the time spent playing sport, beyond general happiness. I'd bet my bottom dollar that overall happiness will directly influence the productivity. The app sounds like a good idea. I wonder how the app could be used to measure the productivity of people who don't work in creative agencies and perhaps  work to a stronger routine? What experiments could we run?

I think there are definitely ways to measure productivity changes at non-"creative" agencies. I'm just doing a little 'out loud' brain storming here, so forgive the jumbled-ness:Some measurements for productivity might include client acquisition and retention rates, account life cycles, employee turnover rates, return on investment, revenue per employee, time to complete routine tasks, employee timeliness (both to meetings and completing projects), ability and efficiency in reaching goals, or accuracy in completing administrative or account-related records.Since no two companies are the same, an app or record-keeping device might be beneficial if the company could choose or even personalize the points of comparison to review, but that might be something for further in the future.I also think that such record keeping should be completely transparent to the employees so that they do not feel this is a big brother tactic by management to keep an eye on their work.For an experiment, I would connect with companies that have already implemented PE and ask them what benefits they have seen in their employees, and ask the employees how they have changed since implementing PE (It might be as simple as "I have had meaningful conversations with everybody in my department" which leads to more fluid transitions; see HBR April 2012: 'The New Science of Building Great Teams', by Alex "Sandy" Pentland). This is a great way to discover other areas to monitor to measure productivity.Taking the findings from companies that already have PE, develop a program for companies that are thinking about starting a PE program and get some measurements at a "pre-PE" state so you have something against which to measure. Then implement the PE programs and check against new measurements that are coming in. These companies would be great candidates to help design and test an app so that when it rolls out to the public most of the major kinks or issues will be identified and ironed out.If the app can in any way monetize the benefits from PE, that would be awesome. Big data is getting some criticism for showing all this data that people can read but doesn't lead to any insights or changing behaviors. Your idea is an awesome way for people to react to the data recorded and have meaning behind it!

Hi Chelsea,Happy New Year and excuse the late reply. I think your point about employees not feeling like they're being monitored is really important. I think PE should be used to benefit the company as a whole and not to target any individual. However, I don't think this means that we shouldn't measure the impact of the initiative.Perhaps data could be collected in a way whereby employees are asked to rate the scheme with their opinions, rather than officials scoring them for performance. I agree with you that simple experiments are always a good way to start.I suppose it would be too much to suggest that a few hours of sport a week would make a huge difference to a company's profit within the first few months of experimentation. The aim is really to create a cultural shift in working culture which would take time.In this sense the criteria being measured should be chose in relation to the direction the company wants their cultural make-up to take. This data could then be collected and measured.First Months:- Meaningful conversations (as you suggest)- Job satisfaction- Friendships developed at workOver Time:- Number of sick days taken- Employee turnover- Relationships with other local firmsOver Years- ROII'm a firm believer that cultural improvements have a strong impact on overall productivity and profitability.ANY COMPANIES UP FOR TRIALLING OUR IDEA?!Cheers Chelsea

Happy New Year, Paddy! Love the measurements broken down by how quickly they can be tracked! I totally agree that cultural habits are huge in how productive, profitable, and happy we are in the workplace.Hopefully a software company would be up for testing the idea/helping design and build a simple cloud-based program for employees to start tracking and evaluating the program!

I like this concept a lot and I have some ideas for you: In terms of the app, I dont think that it would feel like employees are being monitored, what if the app was how employees coordinated to play specific PE activities, it could become a place to post photos of a successful event, and i think it could also record individual satisfaction too. This kinda relates to another concept on here about happiness. This app could offer users a way to share their mood post PE and if this app already has your name and such things then it seems to me it could be an easy next step to compare employee happiness with job performance (granted that sounds like monitoring, but maybe the employees wouldn't mind if they were open and happy from all that PE)  I bet this would really create a strong sense of community among coworkers at all levelsAlso after reading this concept I began to wonder if the endorphins released in PE would be beneficial in the brainstorming environment. Is there a way  this energy could be channeled into thinking about new products or services for a company? Maybe a casual atmosphere where all different types of people from a company (still energized from PE) are mingling could be a great  place to new ideas. Maybe there could be a hybrid activity that was PE and brainstorming combined !

Hi Kenny,That's really interesting. Yeah why not have ten minute brainstorms interspersed with 10 minutes football/basketball/softball/ sessions, could be really fun. Company directors would be more willing to invest if the activity was more directly related to actual work!! Nice thinking.

Great concept Paddy. I remember the feeling of looking forward to PE lessons and the sense of satisfaction after it. It really brought everyone together from the quiet ones to the loud ones. Like you have stated discussions takes place and remember doing that a lot. I think this is a good platform to keep healthy and to increase your productivity at work. Love it!

Cheers Mohamed. I reckon it could work! We'd just need to find a company willing to give their employees a free hour once a week to kick off an experiment. You know any progressive companies that might be up for it?
Love this concept pe was my favourite lesson ! It will help improve health and work relationships

Cheers Naomi. My concentration and sense of cameraderie at school was so much stronger because of the sport we played together. How could we encourage company directors to take the risk and invest employee time with this initiative?

Great idea Paddy! In every office, there's at least one gym/athletic buff who has mastered his/her "PE Course". If there's a way to incorporate his/her lifestyle tips, advice and even leadership to get people to jump on the bandwagon, it would create a sense of "If ____ can do it, I sure can too!"
Cheers John. I agree. It's amazing what a group can achieve when each individual is encouraged to surprise themselves by the people around.

Rocking visualisation, Paddy! Am especially digging the inter-business play-offs and potential for new business opportunities. Last year when I was visiting IDEO Palo Alto, there was an Google-Facebook beach volleyball game which some IDEO peeps somehow joined in on  gotta be some killer business opps with a mash-up like that! ;^)

Cheers Meena,Yeah - you never who know who you might meet and where the next business opportunity might be, so why shouldn't it happen on a pitch instead of a meeting room?! Sounds like its already happening.Clients could sponsor teams to help fund the initiative.

comments.text: Great concept Beth, and an employee is more likely to go to the gym if they're meeting a friend/family member there to work out together so it's a win win.

Very good idea! opening the gym to family and friends would definitely make it more attractive for people employed in companies to use the facility. On the other hand, in my experience, another reason why people do not use the gym facility at disposal in companies is also one that demonstrates priorities. Since time is limited, use of the gym usually coincides with the lunch-break. Often, employees and business-people prioritize "lunch" as an informal business opportunity over practice at the gym. They may already have memberships at gyms outside the work-place...etc etc. And informal lunch meetings are always a good way to get business done :)Maybe, we could consider rendering gyms in companies also "healthy social places" - where healthy and nutritious snacks and local and sustainable grown food is served. And of course tables where people can sit down, enjoy their lunch and also invite people from outside of the facilities? Maybe, already existing healthy caterers and local growers that practice sustainable agriculture can be invited to deliver the healthy lunches/snacks at the gyms?
