I love this because you can achieve challenge by narrowing down to small task you can handle with. It has been a real milestone to reach the summit. Also use this idea to help the healthier organisation and transfers the total funds collected to the agreed upon charity/cause.

Thanks Xiaoxu for the comments and reinforcement. It is about small steps leading to achievement of bigger goals. The 'fundraising' element has come up a few times - definitely worth looking into. This way there will be different/ multiple motives to get involved - well being, adventure, charity, team work, healthy competition etc.

I love this because it makes you feel like you're accomplishing something great and meaningful rather than simply forging through what can be the drudgery of exercise. The competition with another organization provides extra incentive. Although the height of Everest is arbitrary, we ascribe so much meaning to it that it would be a real milestone to reach the summit. However, how long could such a challenge last? Once you've climbed Everest what else is left to do? Everest again? I just wonder how to retain the attention of people in an organization after they've completed the challenge once. In the interest of sustained challenge, maybe some lesser mountains should be first on the agenda, working your way up to Everest. For the ultimate challenge, there's Olympus Mons, the tallest mountain on any planet in the solar system at ~22 km high. Anyway, maybe I'm latching onto this physical analogy too much, but for me it's the defining feature of the idea.

Thanks Jeremy. "Analogous achievement" is indeed at the core of the idea. It's about adding more meaning to the exercise. And yes, definitely a good idea to have smaller peaks to scale before going for the Everest. The excitement would have to be sustained by providing a variety of challenges.

I could see this as being a great "energizer" within organizations, especially if different teams can compete against each other. A large, public display board showing total steps for each team in a main office, for example, would help increase a sense of motivation for the project.  Each time an employee passes the screen and sees their team being behind, for instance, he or she may think, "During my break I should go outside and rack up a few more steps for my team," or, "All my team needs is X number of steps to get ahead...I could get those in half an hour at the gym this weekend!"   Then he/she can enter those steps into the mobile app or web interface, see the numbers on the main board updated in real time, and feel the satisfaction of knowing he/she made a difference for the team.
Thanks for the comments Ben. A live scoreboard in the office along with a web and/or mobile solution would definitely add another dimension. Seeing live updates would indeed be quite "energizing".

be as inclusive as possible, to look on them (whether other agencies, community groups, or individuals) not as competitors, suppliers or clients but as partners, people who can create something that you do not have the power to create alonestart smallfind common ground - problems that you can all see, resources that you can all usesponsor a free flow of informationlook for ways to leverage your resources and expertise

I love this because you can achieve challenge by narrowing down to small task you can handle with. It has been a real milestone to reach the summit. Also use this idea to help the healthier organisation and transfers the total funds collected to the agreed upon charity/cause.

Building off my previous suggestion, the achievement goal could stay relevant by resetting each year (or some other appropriate period). Because insurers can't practically let people run down their premiums forever (though 'running off your rate' is a catchy tag line), and the health benefits that justify the reductions require ongoing exercise, there needs to be a mechanism like a reset (or gradual rescaling) that encourages people to stick with the goal (or sign up for Everest #2) while still delivering value to all stakeholders- the employee, the company, and the insurer backing it.

Instead of simply tying it to charitable gifts or in-house empty rewards why not coordinate with health insurers to incrementally drive down insurance rates for each meter climbed or step taken (or each everest climbed, it can be scalable)? Participating employees would directly lower their own rates, combining friendly competition with monetary benefits (even if very small, very psychologically compelling and easily counted). This would provide direct incentive for individuals to get healthy (just in case feeling good and being healthy weren't enough) and in addition to all the benefits you've already identified, the overall effect would be to lower health care costs in general- greater company wide health means lower premiums for the whole pool in addition to the incremental reduction in the individual achievers plan (substantive or symbolic depending on what can be negotiated with the sponsoring insurance provider).

Brilliant suggestions Ivan. Making a clear link with the challenges and health insurance rewards would make things very clear and concrete and bring more people on board. this makes so much sense, both from a micro and macro level. Thanks.

Glad you liked them, it's an idea that could actually be applied to several of the concepts that won (Healthy Benefits and Health Leave could adopt some form of this model). Tying in the insurer not only provides clear rewards, but it also takes the administration and execution costs off of the company and puts them with the insurer (who at least theoretically is not in it to scalp people for a huge profit and should be on board with plans that reduce the likelihood of illness that will suck money out of the pot, allowing them to reduce premiums).I think it is important to consider the administration costs of any wellness program because money spent by a company on employee is, at the end of the day, money the employees could be taking home in direct salary, returning to investors, or putting into development. Health care costs are a huge part of the stagnation of real wages so hopefully by bringing the insurer in everybody could win- the employee gets healthy and saves a little money, the insurers liability goes down, and the company gets more productive employees that it can both pay more and who, by being more productive, increase the value of the company.
^^forgive the shoddy grammar in the second paragraph, should proof before hitting post!
I think that this is a great concept and would love to se it be implemented. This idea would also work well in schools and universities to increase health and fitness awareness. Congratulations!
It could be a big event like Dance Marathon, a fundraising event where participants "dance" or stay on their feet for x number of hours. At my university it was held for 26.2 hours.

Thanks Aedhan and Sipra for the kind words and encouragement. I am really excited about the potential of this idea. I hadn't heard of Dance Marathon - just checked it now and it's amazing! You've given me another dimension to think of. Thank you!

Congratulations! I won also!I would be happy to join/combine our two concepts, and cooperate our efforts (I got a little virtual team of ideators on my concept, that I would think will help and volunteer some time)Are you willing to make our two concepts into one joint project? ( I will not feel offended if you want to runt your own concept totally by yourself. And I am not too pretentious about any of my ideas, in mine concept :consider it as shareware and open source )And I give you as inspiration, a newly found gem : https://www.zombiesrungame.com/ (but I guess they got a little narrow targeted age group?)Please, you may write directly to my email for longer conversation : johans.nya   @  gmail.comCongratulations! Wooohooo!
Yay! Congratulations Johan. Well deserved. Thanks for sharing and the invitation. I am currently traveling but will write to you soon to explore ways of working further on this!
Congrats to you both, sign me up for a few steps on your first virtual Everest! Really excited to see this materialize!

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel thought this could also be great for measuring activity levels in companies. Could there be a competition for which company gets there first? Could it be like a real marathon where people fundraise for a worthy cause as well?  How might data be recorded and what other metrics might be measured? Could it work as a global platform where you could view competitors' progress as well?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Awesome! Thanks OpenIDEO for the shortlisting and for all those valuable questions. I definitely need to include these additional elements during the refinement phase - 1. competition; 2. connecting to fundraising/ social impact; 3. recording and measurement. I'll work on integrating these as I build on and refine the concept.

We'd also suggest you take a look and join collaborative conversations on this concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/gamify/Let's get some cross-pollination going between these ideas and build upon the goodness that each has to offer!
Fantastic! Will do :-)

Hi, I have been reading through your concept proposal several times, and follow the interesting discussion here in the comment section.If you will find anything of value from my concept proposal Gamify Exercise, or in the comment section on it, please feel free to use it, and combine into yours if needed.Because I was thinking maybe we could combine our efforts in some ways? If you are open to collaboration?

Hi Johan, thanks for dropping by. Absolutely open to collaboration. Feel free to use anything from this concept or the comments section. I'll have a more thorough look at yours and look for ways to combine our efforts.(PS - I'm traveling at the moment and have intermittent access to the internet, but will update this soon)

Great that you guys have begun to combine - they're both awesome ideas and work perfectly together. I'm imagining a kind of 'leveling up' scenario like the Fitocracy App/website has, where you can choose to either compete with friends/colleagues or just go it alone and steadily build, passing landmarks along the way. Awarding badges might be great for this..completing all the tasks in different categories etc.. so there could be mountaineering categories (as the heart of the concept suggests), maybe biking and running totals too.. you could aim to run from one side of your country to the other in the space of a year, etc..Visuals could be amazing too! Profiles to show how high you are on each mountain etc..
I had not heard about Fitocracy, will investigate it. Also got a tip on my proposal about www.ingress.com (something that Google runs)

Regarding badges/tokens etc I think they are mostly a nuisance, and will spam up your friends facebook-walls :)I think points or distance metres could be used for participants to brag with on their facebook-wall or tweet about them, but i feel that designing badges/tokens are unneccessary work.However, I can be convinced, if someone shows me that they gain more participants and more metres done!
Thanks Johan and James! I've checked out Fitocracy and Ingress, and overlaps between both our concepts. I think visuals and profiles would be a great add-on!

Hey guys. Great updates!.... I wasn't really envisaging the badges being capable of spamming anyone - more of a personal online/app trophy cabinet that you can shoose to show or hide. Fitocracy generally have 3 for each category.. take running for instance.. they start with 'I seem to be lost' - given for accumulating 20 miles total. The next badge is 'Hallowed Harrier' - for reaching 200 miles, and finally 'The Shadow of Hermes' for reaching 1000 miles in total. You can see the outline of the badges in your empty cabinet and you slowly obtain those that interest you.Taking your Mountain idea, with steps, users could perhaps begin with much smaller mountains like Ben Nevis or Koszisco, then graduate to Everest once they have 'leveled up'.. or like you say, they could contribute to it as part of a bigger team.If you wanted to extend this on a tangent - maybe try using a cycle to work game - you could put a virtual Tour De France in, and assign different legs to different riders in the team.. differentiating the fitness levels needed to allow participants of varying fitness (or distance from work!) to still feel part of the same team.Lots of fun to be had finding real races/challenged to turn into virtual 'micro-excercise'. Good luck over the last few days!

All these ideas sound awesome James! Love the extensions to include important challenges (Tour De France etc). An individual might not feel ready to run a Marathon or cycle around the country... but when it's small steps that add up and fit into a bigger challenge, it'll feel like a fantastic accomplishment. Also like your idea of levels/ badges!

I've mentioned badges a couple of times over in the other concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/gamify/). I completely agree with Johan on not wanting to spam everyone (there's a reason I have pretty much every game blocked in my Facebook news stream), but I think I was really thinking more along the lines of James with the "personal trophy cabinet" idea. I like to collect (and to occasionally show them off at an "appropriate" time). In many ways, badges are like quests in online role-playing games. They provide "little" wins on the way to a larger one.One day I think I'd like to hike the Appalachian Trail (http://www.appalachiantrail.org/hiking/find-a-hike/interactive-map). Part of the reason would be to just be able to say I've done it. Maybe I'll get a badge for doing it via this project before I go out and do it for real. :-)

"Small wins" will definitely play a big role for this concept to be successful. I'd love to record my collection of challenges participated in, and enjoy the well-deserved bragging rights! Maybe some feature in the execution of the idea could generate interesting visuals... perhaps,   a photoshopped version of your Appalachian adventure!

Agreed. I go into the offices of our sales staff and see all of their awards up on the wall or shelves. I wonder what it would be like if next to these sales awards I was to see certificates and the photoshopped pictures of all the places around the world they had climbed. Come to think of it, even the silly awards produced by our engineering and QA groups for product testing competitions are hung up around the offices as badges of pride. If the organization wanted to get even more involved, they could even set aside a wall where the names and pictures of those who had completed certain "climbs" would be displayed for all to see.

There are so many virtual challenges.. it's limitless! Most of the ones we've talked about so far are long-distance/endurance.. but what if you started thinking about shorter distances over more regular periods, and collecting group times? It becomes less about one-off achievements and more about sustained increases in performance: Say.. an office or team of 5-10 people want to collectively run a marathon a week... can they plan a tiny bit in advance and beat last week's time? Or how about an Ironman triathlon.. some can swim, some can cycle and some can run.. they just enter their efforts into a central app/website and they become fitter as a group, taking a real collective sense of pride in each others' improvements.
Sounds great James! Love the idea of regular and sustained achievements, and especially the Ironman triathlon as a group effort. Even I would finally achieve one then!
PS - have included above scenarios in the refined concept!

Congrats for the refinement phase!!!! This has great potentials and can be tailored, scaled and adapted on the particular needs/desires of employees and companies in specific settings. The idea to link it to the openIDEO model of setting challenges is a total added value. I think that, in fact, some of the "challenges" to be defined and chosen by the employees/teams in offices could also actually have a broader social impact. So, they could tackle the broader "social determinants of health" (as the WHO defines them). The walking, running, stepping and so on measured by the pedometer or mobile application could also be transformed into "credits" that go towards the achievement of a specific social impact goal (for example: decrease domestic violence, increase social inclusion of marginalized children in schools, etc etc)...:)

Thanks for the comment and suggestions Gaia! The theme of connecting the goal towards other social impact goals (or even fundraising for certain initiatives) seems to be recurring. I'll test this further in the refinement phase!

When I read through the concept and the current postings, the term "walkathon" kept coming to mind, and it seems to fit in well here. So, if the company or group had said, "When the group (or for everyone in the group who) accomplishes X, we will donate Y to Z.", we have another form of motivation.Now I'm working on the goal not just for me, but also for other people. I think it's related to Michael Norton's TED talk on "How to Buy Happiness" (http://www.ted.com/talks/michael_norton_how_to_buy_happiness.html). Accomplishing the goal for me improves self-esteem; accomplishing it for someone else makes me happy.
Trev, I got some options for donation in my project proposal. Will think about your other suggestions.

Fantastic reinforcement Trev. And thanks for the reminder and link to this TED talk. I am enjoying how 'collaboration + achievement + fitness' have an edge with the "contribution" factor as an add-on. So many dimensions of well-being!

Thought you guys might be interested in this amazing initiative posted by Samuel Cox over over on the Lively London Step By Step concept: City Peaks http://citypeaks.co.uk What learnings can we draw and builds can we make from this for Vishal's concept?

Wow! Thanks Meena, this is amazing! So many overlaps. I can imagine a similar website for this concept that would have the different challenges visualised in a similar way and eventually, a live leader-board in action! (PS - sorry for not updating continuously - will do it in a batch over the next 48 hours as I'm currently traveling).
No worries & safe travels!
Updated! All other ideas and suggestions are now ready to be processed :-)

Hi Vishal and the virtual team, I think this is a great idea and I can really see how it would come to life. But to bring it to maximum scale I think some thought into existing partners to link up with would be good. For example I know that the Global Corporate Challenge (GCC) http://www.gettheworldmoving.com/ has some similarities and already has a big user base. And I'm sure there are others too.How could we tap into existing enthusiastic audiences - in and outside of work,  to impact on more lives?
Oh- and I should also have said, how do we make this different to other existing platforms/schemes.
Thanks Claire for the comments, questions and for sharing the GCC initiative. I'll look for similarities (to know what'a proven and works) and also for differentiators. I'll update this soon!
Adam posted this in the Work(out) Stations concept: http://www.treadmill-desk.com/2007/07/walking-across-america.htmlI think it is a great example of this kind of thing in action.
Fantastic! thanks Nigel :-)

I think this is a great idea. One idea would be to make it a "healthy competition" rather than just a collaborative challenge. In a large company, different departments or regional offices could compete against each other to climb everest first. This would create an opportunity for people across an office to get to know each other better, and the competitive element would be a motivating factor. Going for a run with the whole floor could add 20x the number of steps that running by yourself could.Smaller companies could compete all together against other companies in the same industry or geographic area, creating a sense of community with groups of small companies as well.To tie the whole thing together, the idea of a leader board that has been suggested would work well in conjunction to the app that was suggested. This would be accessible to all the competing teams, and could be projected on the walls of their offices, updated in real time. I've seen a similar idea in action for blood donation.

Wow, thanks for all those builds Nigel! I love the element of collaboration + competition. I will include this as I refine the concept. A live leader board/ tracking system would be great. Just knowing it's been measured "right" and in a standardised way would make this stronger. Would love to hear more about the blood donation tracking system you've seen!

I wish I could tell you more. I just walked into a blood bank once a few years ago and saw a leader board that was prominently displayed, and had several different corporate teams. It seemed like a great way to motivate people to give blood, as well as a great way for the companies to get recognition for giving back.For the leader board for this concept, I think it would be fairly straight forward to build something that could integrate with Runkeeper, Nike+, Garmin connect, and other common apps to track steps in real time. That way if a whole office goes for a run together, all the other departments or companies involved could see them quickly advancing. I think it could be a neat way to increase engagement and motivation.
Great analogous thinking around the blood bank competing corporates, Nigel. Loving the builds going on here.

I really like your concept! Is a great idea the collective motivation that it would create and also the global community of people trying to achieve this challenge. I think these facts are very important for those who are not used to do exercise regularly, because they would feel that are being part of something big.
Thanks Maria! You'e right - the core of the idea is the 'analogous achievement' - giving it a whole new meaning!

Vishal, This is a really super idea. The suggestion Riyaz made would be a nice addition. Keeping a video game-style leader board might work, too. I would add that I like that there aren't incentives. Though perhaps there could be something where every time the mountain is climbed the company/organization/community could donate to an organization selected by the members of the organization (as a sort of a walk-a-thon element).

Thanks Areca. I love the donation idea to celebrate the achievement. Employees participating could also get their friends/ families to contribute, and maybe the organisation could match the funds collected!

Vishal, This is a really super idea. The suggestion Riyaz made would be a nice addition. Keeping a video game-style leader board might work, too. I would add that I like that there aren't incentives. Though perhaps there could be something where every time the mountain is climbed the company/organization/community could donate to an organization selected by the members of the organization (as a sort of a walk-a-thon element).

I've had to re-post this concept due to some challenges with the OpenIDEO platform last week. Since I didn't have a record of the original post (lesson learnt), the language has variation, but the  essence stays intact. Shout out to Suzy and Meena for your inputs.

We're so excited that you reposted this Vishal. As I remember, the term I used to describe your epic idea was analogous achievement. As someone who works remotely out here in New Zealand, while my OpenIDEO colleagues work in-office in California + London  I love the idea that we could set a group target and do something like this from our respective locations  and maybe even compete with another IDEO team like our buddies over at IDEO.org  bring it on!

Thanks for the encouragement Meena. I love your take on the idea - group challenges especially given the trend of virtual and remote teams. This could be another benefit for the individual and organisation. Competing within teams and across functional areas/ business divisions would be fun too. I also remember you suggesting other names as the concept develops - Collaborative treks/ journeys?

Hey Vishal, thanks for re-posting, it is a great idea.  I also wanted to re-post my thoughts so here goes: what about expanding the idea to include people in different locations and set a bigger goal, perhaps walking 'round the world' or walking 'to the moon'?  I could imagine this inspiring whole communities to work together or even compete with other communities to be the first ones to achieve the challenge.
Thanks for re-posting these ideas Suzy! Much appreciated :-)

Hey Vishal - super idea! Infact, our team at work with colleagues across the US and in India recently completed a challenge for completing the distance between the US and India. A couple observations:- The competitive spirit it generated between subteams was palpable and definitely a plus!- Some subteams initiated group walks around the office to rack up the 'miles'. Again, brilliant for teamwork- On the 'negative' it seemed like the same people (usually the already healthy ones) showed up. It seemed that getting healthy was not incentive enough -- and the rest of the team picked up the slack.So maybe there's some opportunity to build in not just the distance to a mountain, but also goals for how many shoulder the weight of a mountain (e.g. for every new person, you gain a bonus) Also for those that don't see health as an incentive, maybe there could be other incentive programs which entice them while becoming healthy is a side-effect/consequence ?

Thanks Riyaz! Great to hear from someone who's 'been-there-done-that', and to understand what works and what doesn't. Love the 'bonus' idea for every new person, and also looking at health as a side-effect. Every week, every sub-team, and each team member could set a goal for total number of steps, and make it loud and visible in order to maintain accountability. There could even be photo-competitions to track the journey and capture moments, and maybe there could be some sort of 'buddy-system' - pair the usual healthy suspects with the ones who need a push?

A great concept, i like the idea of the team encouragement. This will bring the workforce closer together, making each member more comfortable around each other. Especially like that everyone works as a team to achieve the epic goals!

Thanks Dalv. It's interesting that you've picked the elements of "team". It reinforces the point for me that well-being isn't just about health and fitness, but the office culture, the people you work with and the relationships you share with them can have a huge impact on your overall wellbeing at the workplace.

Sense of participation of your concept is really exiciting. Maybe, several teams try to climb mountain Everest at the same time and teams compete. The question of who will climb first could accelerate.
Thank you Ozge for the comment. Love the idea of the race and competition - seeing another team climb more and faster will be a good push for the others. Healthy competition is always fun!

Congrats on this post being a Featured Concept last week! We're sorry it got lost along with a day's data during our pre-Xmas outage but we're super-psyched that you've posted it again  and gone into the donation pool for the International Diabetes Foundation: http://bit.ly/YtmLgX
Thank you for the nudge and the donation :-)

I really like this idea especially for office which spent most of the time sitting instead of excite. Maybe set up weekly challenge between employees and the winner gets a discount on sports equipment or gym membership!
Thank you Yamasha. It'll be great to change our routines and do simple, regular exercises. And I love your idea of creating some incentives for the employees. Competition + Collaboration!

the_cheating_jar.description: People make New Year's Resolutions related to health, wellness, etc. then feel terrible when they lapse or fail. Shift discourage to encourage, and help people get back on track. "Cheating" on a resolution isn't the failure, completely giving up is.
the_cheating_jar.creator: 87af6ce9789c8f54ca8eea53fdcae003

comments.text: Interesting concept, Diana. A great way of showing people that cheating isn't the 'be all and end all'. A lot of people see cheating as giving up. Organising a Resolution Team would really motivate people to stick to their goals. It would be positive peer pressure. Pressure to come across as a strong willed person to your colleagues. However, what if people were cheating whilst at home, and were not honest about it with their Resolution Team peers?
I like the idea of having a group that motivates each member to achieve their resolutions and goals.
Thanks! The hope is having this social structure and mutual support would help increase likelihood of success.
One of the great strengths of this idea is the team aspect. The mutual reinforcement that comes from making commitments to a group.
Agreed! I've read studies before that said 2 key reasons for success in maintaining personal goals such as for losing weight is 1) tracking (hence the notes) and 2) a buddy system.

Good, simple idea! Having the 'punishment' predefined will help to prevent people panicking and just quitting their idea if they do mess up. Perhaps it would work best if all participants were doing the same/similar activities so they could be done together to prevent any cheating? It could also be used as a way to split larger offices into groups e.g all runners have a jar, all cyclists have a jar... wont work with everything and everyone but could help in some cases I think.The $100 dollar deposit is good for giving a reward at the end, but people might just say "screw it" and give up if they get to say $80 in fines? I guess they would already be doing pretty at their goal if it got to that though...

Thanks! Good thoughts~I can see how in some instances, it would work well to group people based on same/similar activities, while for others, they may prefer to team up with folks with different types of resolutions, so that they're not directly competing with each other in that sense, but are really competing with themselves, and the team/buddy system is really to provide social moral support. The idea is meant to be simple and flexible enough for people to customize it to what works best for them!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks, OpenIDEO!

This is a great idea. I think dedicated time to health will encourage us to make the most of. Too many of us leave PTO untaken (according to CNN, 25% of Americans don't take any http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/13/opinion/obeidallah-vacation-health/index.html) Some companies have eliminated sick days and personal days and put all time off in the same PTO bucket. Good concept easy to understand and the online platform makes it easy to mobilise and spread to a wider catchment area of users.

comments.text: im loving the visuals, these facts are on the ball, our bodys often die out and leave our brain unresponsive cause of slow blood flow and by doing these activities, it really makes sense why we should raise our blood level

Thanks Victor appreciate it! Creating a better balance between mind and body I believe is essential for a worker to stay focused and alert for the entire day. These exercises are designed to do just that.
Great variety of pictures Lee! I agree with the fact that workers stay trapped in their own bubble. This could be an effective way to get them involved and push their mental health to a higher limit.

Thanks Seyhan. Your right it is sometimes near impossible to get yourself out of that frame of mind. By offering a quick, fun and interactive game once in a while will not only stimulate the mind but give the worker a well deserved break which is so often neglected in society today.
Good concept Lee! The pictures say it all
I agree with Andrea, powerful pictures to explain the concept.

great idea, i think this will bring unity and self motivation to people at work, in order to become more socially involved and live a more active lifestyle outside of work. good use of picture as well that compliment the concept idea.

Like this idea a lot and would love to see this embedded in my organisation's culture. Training focuses more on learning and development rather than keeping in mental/physical shape which I find really important to be effective. You could offer some RCT experiments to employers for teams that are struggling to show them the benefits of adopting these schemes not only for staff but also overall productivity perhaps?

Very interesting concept Lee. Mental stimulation is very important to peoples well-being. It could also be an exciting way to learn new skills which exercise both sides of the brain, such as Juggling and also Drumming rudiments. Perhaps a work place stomp band project would be an exciting activity which also has a fun outcome to the mental stimulus it creates. Really interesting concept with lots of potential avenues.
The stomp idea is a great idea. Would be a good way of getting people to work together and take part. Even the kitchen sink!
Haha, especially the kitchen sink!

This concept reminds me of the Nintendo Brain Training game. The aim isn't a display of the users skill, but an opportunity to regularly stimulate the mind. I agree with your concept because I think mentally and physically challenging activities are great ways to charge the mind and body.It would be great to see some sort of 'ranking' embedded with your concept. For example, the Brain Training game provides a 'brain age' at the end of challenge; A low age being good and a high age is not so. Letting the user know where they stand in how well they completed a task may be an encouraging platform for them to improve at the next attempt. However it would be best to avoid names in rankings, this concept isn't about competition but more about the individual.Great work Lee

Great concept Lee, Exercise that stimulates not only the body but also the mind is great! (Like the Kinect you had in one of your visuals) The flow chart also really helps to grasp this concept. Good job!
Great concept! I love the idea of exercises that stimulate the mind. Really nice visuals aswell, you've put across the idea well. :)

Amazing concept. I can see a lot of potential in team building. Also its a very good motivation to get up from work and do a quick and fun exercise. Of course after you return fresh and with new ideas.
Great use of pictures, this makes the concept easier to understand from a visual point of view. Powerful concept.

Really like the concept Lee, the employees will look forward to the tasks or games that they will be involved in and will get them out of doing the same thing everyday. I like the way you have broke down the three different health areas as well. Simple but would be really effective.
Cheers Chris changing the daily routine will keep people engaged and active having a positive impact on their work.
Great concept Lee, you have visualised it really well which makes it easier for us to understand. Its really good that the concept covers all different health areas in one. Good work!
Thanks Gul appreciate it!
Great stuff, Lee. Could be great for you and others here to play round with what this initiative might be called. Knock yourselves out  looking forward to what you come up with!
Thanks for the feedback Meena! Your right this concept needs to be named to branch out from the typical brain training you see every day. I'll definitely look into it!
Great concept! Youve illustrated the concept very well via the visuals. Good work
Thanks Megan.
Would this be the creative side of the brain to switch off the logic side
Using both sides of the brain but in a fun and interactive way taking their mind off work and keeping active at the same time.

Great idea and the benefits it brings to participants, however how does the concept measure or assess physical health elements like BP, Pulse, BMI,calories intake etc and at what times are workers suppose to use this facility lunch time or start of day? Does it also produce a quantitative measure on psychological health such as readings for brain speed, memory and speed intelligence?

The physical side of the activity can be measured independently by the individual. The main idea is to let the mind and body work together to work both sides of the brain improving ones health each day.
Good concept and powerful pictures and thoughts!

body_and_mind_working_simultaneously_tog.title: Body and mind working simultaneously to improve overall health

_stairs_to_heaven_.description: Creating an interesting stairs’ space to engage people to use everyday. Transforming your office stairs to be an art gallery, a hall of fame, an information board, a social gathering notice, or anything! To create a dynamic, fun, and fit activity.
_stairs_to_heaven_.creator: 53d1e48a25558088d98dd689364720aa

comments.text: This concept will definitely build a more comforting and colourful atmosphere. The idea of having displays on the stairs will cover the boring plain colours and allow designs to be acknowledged by colleagues.

I like it! I think I'd feel more encouraged to take the stairs especially if it was more spacious and interesting than the plain and cramped ones we usually see in buildings. I think that it'd have an edge over using an elevator because of how it can provide a more unique and interesting experience than having to use an elevator and wait idly for 10 minutes every morning.Since elevators are usually cramped and silently awkward, I like how this idea can focus on encouraging social interaction and lightening the mood to get people to try this option. I think it should provide a very light and energetic feeling; maybe adding large glass windows with a beautiful view can help? :)

Love this idea!Many local governments / mayors etc could allow companies, arts orgs to "take over" the stairs of public spaces too (e.g. train stations, overpasses etc). Rather than selling advertising, could companies transform stairs into exciting spaces that people want to use, encouraging the population to get exercise and delivering commercial impact for the companies involved??
Our concepts for this challenge our very similar and I believe if combined could make a real difference - I have added you to my virtual team, please let me know your thoughts!
Love this concept! Great way of encouraging people to use the stairs. Putting displays that will educate them aswell is even better, great work Lily!
Really interesting concept!
Hi, Lily! I find this concept very inspiring. It is fresh but at the same time intuitive for me. Good idea I think.

_stairs_to_heaven_.title: "Stairs To Heaven"

let_there_be_sun.description: Create a working space in the office that is lit up by artificial sunlight lamps to give a boost of energy to employees while working. During winter many countries have less daylight and you might not get any sunlight at all during winter time.
let_there_be_sun.creator: 78232688d00263aca701dd490dc3f5be

comments.text: I would have loved to have such area in the office. Great idea.

Hi Elin, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

30_minutes_break_to_learn_how_to_play_ag.description:
“Playing isn’t just meant for children.
Playing isn’t something we are meant to
stop at certain age. Playing isn’t something
we are meant to lose” Marcela Chamorro
30_minutes_break_to_learn_how_to_play_ag.creator: 7e3883e51e55e086af83ab891b6b7665

comments.text: I think this is a great idea and I think a good way to get some traction would be "useful" play specific to the company's mission. For example, if an engineering company had to play with legos and a publications company had to play scrabble they could use this play to inspire and enhance their work productivity.
I love this concept!  It's especially applicable for companies looking to recruit and retain Gen Y employees, who tend to value creative space and fun in their work environment.
It's interesting the way you think it can be supported. Specially the web site, and thinking about some platform where the workers can share its opinions and collaborate with the different companies.

Thank you! I believe so too! It's a matter of convincing companies that the idea would benefit them as much as would benefit to their workers. Would be amazing to inspire companies to take responsibility on improving and changing the way we work, to make work another enjoyable part of every worker life.

This is such a great idea Izaskun! Getting adults to release their inner child through play, I can really see this producing a much happier work environment. It would be such an awesome way to release stress, and bring colleagues together. And I love the visual boards, well done!
Cheers!!

30_minutes_break_to_learn_how_to_play_ag.title: 30 MINUTES BREAK: to learn how to play (again)

green_workplace.description: A work place that full of sunlight and "green light".
green_workplace.creator: 2d410803009b0859bc82ee8c14963b32

comments.text: This concept could be incredibly impactful for people who work in densily populated areas with limited outdoor green space. If paired with UV lights during the winter months, it would also help to combat depression and weather associated mental health issues. The idea could expand to incorporate indoor atriums and indoor plants and trees to facilitate better air quality in the work environment. Additionally, bringing more natural and uv lighting,  and plantings into indoor exercise areas would further the benefits of the green workplace into other areas.

green_workplace.title: Green workplace

broken_elevator_day.description: A series of employer implemented "days" where the employees would either choose to participate in the healthy option, or pay a small fine (for charity) for convenience.
broken_elevator_day.creator: 4c46debca2be5a606f3f6623d649eabf

comments.text: Simple but smart and affected ways to aware people about health issues, i think that all of the 3 examples of the themed days will work, especially the "broken elevator day"! Also adding a fine for people who do not want to take part, is even better although they think they can get away with it by the fine, they will eventually give up and start taking apart aswell.
I agree, really simple but smart approach- great idea Cady!

Hi Cady, interesting idea.  There's always the question of whether to lead with the carrot or the stick when creating incentives.  As an employer you need a mix of these, do you think there could be a carrot component like getting a bonus or food for taking part in some of these so it had a balance of both positive and negative reinforcement?

Hey Nathan, thank you for your comment.  I agree with you that a carrot benefit could be beneficial.  Perhaps something like offering a free, healthy lunch for the employees who took the stairs on a floor that would maximize their traffic, or having a day where the company selects a restaurant in the near vicinity and offers to pay for healthy menu options for the employees that walk to and from the restaurant.  If the company wanted to add a monetary or prize incentive, they could post a sheet of paper or dry erase boards on the entrances to the stairwells and every time an employee took the stairs they would add a tally. At the end of the day, they could add up the tallies and if a certain quota were met, such as # of employees X4, the entire office could receive a reward.

I agree with Nathan. I think the idea of doing this in a purely positive way would be more effective, and wouldn't make people with disabilities or chronic health problems, that couldn't take the stairs or walk further, feel penalized and pay fines. Plus I think you would get the same result with a purely positive (reward those who participate) approach.

Excellent idea, I try to get people to walk even just down 3 levels at work and people still choose to take the lift. If you are using the lift for less than 3-4 levels then maybe there should be something that prevents you from doing that also. Or to use the lift, in addition to Dale's response below, get them to actually pay 1 every time people want to use the lift.

Cadi, love the elevator and charity idea. Could this idea leverage the coin wars for charity approach? In coin wars, teams get positive points for coins and negative points for dollars. The strategy is to put coins in your own teams bucket and put dollars in your opponents bucket. The team with the most points wins, often this is not the team with the most money.What if companies engaged in "stair wars"? Teams would get points tied to the amount of floors travelled. Teams earn points for using the stairs and docked points for using the elevator. The event could take place over period of time with the winning team receiving; dinner out with CEO, gift certificates, donation to favorite charity, etc. The bigger the prize the more opt-in participants.The stair war event would have a web site to inspire competition and recognize efforts- displaying a team leader board, team tracking and more.
Good idea!  I like that your idea incorporates some competition- with the right incentive it could really motivate people to participate.

My office building is really poorly designed.  The elevators are in front of the entrance way and the stairs are hidden away.   All in what has been described as an environmentally efficient building.  We need to make stairs take pride of place in our public and workplace buildings...  I know that this is a bit off the track that you are suggesting Cady - but we need to influence the design of our buildings so that it becomes harder to use elevators and easier to use stairs (for example)

broken_elevator_day.title: Broken Elevator Day

healthy_work_life_balance_health_day_off.description: In order to achieve a work life balance, it is important that the employee is in touch with the family happenings and viceversa. Different activities could be lined up to celebrate this day once a week which could involve the family members too.
healthy_work_life_balance_health_day_off.creator: 4e080e54c725f83ff82a30f8f6f48d48

comments.text: Great idea Ranjani! This seems like a good way in creating a healthy balance between home and work. It also sounds like it would brings employees together as well as the families and could be a great way to build friendly relations in the workplace, and as a result create a happier workplace. I agree with the points made below that it may be costly and take up too much time that a company may not have to spare- but it could maybe be done once a month instead of every week? Just a thought, awesome job overall!

Ranjani, this is a really nice idea. It's proven that keeping a healthy lifestyle is important and a great place to start is certainly in the workplace! The examples of exercise that you give sound great fun and productive too. However, what about the ol' catchphrase time=money? Will companies be keen on spending a day or even just a few hours a week away from work?

Perhaps if the pilot showed good results (increased work productivity and satisfaction) then it would help motivate employers to see the sense of this. I've worked for a few companies (including IDEO ;^) who acknowledge the benefit of activities beyond traditional work to enhance work culture and productivity plus we had some great ones that came through the Inspiration phase from the likes of corporate giants like Google. Let's challenge ourselves to come up with ideas to get other businesses excited about the potential!

Thanks Will. With regards time =money we will need to prove to HR and their likes that this can actually increase productivity by decreasing abseentism and making employees healthier and happier! It involves some cost analysis. So yeah ..a healthy work life balance can  have a rippling effect..

I've been reading into planned exercise at work and productivity thereafter and it generally seems like it works! Japan are the leaders for this type of 'break' from work where they give employees the chance I stretch their legs at particular times during the day.Can we push other countries to follow? Let's hope so!

Nice one Ranjani   and I can imagine this complimenting many ideas that may come up during this challenge. Tip: When you see concepts (now or going forward) which you think could fit within your idea  you can hit the Update button on the right of your post and add relevant posts to your Build Upon feature. That way the people who wrote them will get an email notification and are likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. And as you're already doing  joining conversations on their ideas is great as well. Fab to have you  join us on OpenIDEO!
Thanks Meena, I seenn that and did post a comment in Ashleys profile as I thought the casual friday concept would collaborate well with what I have mentioned.

healthy_work_life_balance_health_day_off.title: HEALTHY WORK LIFE BALANCE! Health Day @ office – one day every week.

customize_your_cubicle.creator: 398e62b1556a0f7d4c769bd612c63989

comments.text: Great idea!  I missed this one before posting.  I love the idea of plants around the workplace.  I think we underestimate the contribution of these little green guys to our health.

Good call Meredith. And given the emerging theme across our challenge of peer-to-peer motivation  I wonder if there's an opportunity for companies to stimulate cubicle customisation and pride with monthly competitions? Looking forward to what your thoughts here night spark for our upcoming Concepting phase!

play_parks_for_adults.description: Who said we needed to stop having fun after our responsibilities? Why don't we continue playing like we used to when we were kids? Because there are no spaces to do so, and we can do something about that.
play_parks_for_adults.creator: a11c7d024a0a7a22809b6e4be3c4c523

comments.text: A great inspiration, this caught my eye straight away.

YES! Exactly! Besides, running around and playing is super healthy. Probably reduced outdoor play for kids today is part (though certainly not all) of the reason obesity is increasing. And who doesn't want to jump into a giant ball pit! Adult sized playground equipment, here I come!

We could offer employees bulk deals on ‘healthy’ versions of these products for their homes, and make them standard at work.

healthy_beneifts_rewards_for_a_healthy_l.description: Healthy Benefits is a rewards system and companion social networking site designed to motivate employees and their families to live healthier lives.
healthy_beneifts_rewards_for_a_healthy_l.creator: 78d764d29ad400b224e9ee42af05f50d

comments.text: Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our export panel liked your more holistic take on gym-based reductions by insurance companies and applauded the ownership of benefits by the company. Given it requires a lot of partnerships & fact checking to make it work, they encourage some thinking about how to make it easier to implement during Refinement. What might a low-tech version look like and who within the company might run it? Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Allowing employees to self report all of their healthy activity and eliminate fact checking would make the process simpler.  You could pilot the program with only self reporting and see if you have any fraud or if fact checking is worth the cost and additional complexity.
I like the idea!You could also allow employees to get health benefit points for choosing healthy food at lunch or in the vending machines.

This is amazing! I just started on a project to create a database for a check in system that I was planning on outsourcing to actual Gyms and also insurance companies to be able to track and give discounts to people that are exercising and maintaining healthy lifestyles. After reading your concept, I feel that working with your database would be a much better way to approach my project than trying to work directly with insurance companies. I would love to collaborate on this with you! Please contact me if you are interested.AMAZING!

I think this is a great idea.  Social currency is a great way to reward people for actions they would not have otherwise taken (in this case logging in health-related data; exercise & diet).  Just look at Foursquare and how badges motivate people to share what they've done.  I think a mobile app would be helpful as well to help people log data as they go through the day.  Currently I use MyFitnessPal to log diet and exercise.  This app has the capability to share socially but I haven't really used it in this capacity.  Perhaps part of the reason is I don't see group challenges such as calories burned, weight lost, most balanced diet.Another idea would be to add in medical information from physical examinations; blood pressure, cholesterol, blood sugar levels, etc.  This would also motivate people to get their regular checkups.Business models include:1. Freemium app (lite version) and paid app for more functionality.2. Advertising as you suggested (health stores, gyms, equipment, etc)3. I also like Eliza's idea of wearable devices; wristbands, pedometers, etc.  Perhaps you could sell some devices that get integrated with the system.

What if we took this concept one step further and paired a wristband that would track your vitals, along with activities and would sync up to the healthy rewards points.  Wearable devices are not a new concept, but the way in which we incoporates it into our lives is new.

"The Social Networking site can also be used by staff and their family members to provide each other with moral support, share healths tips, and keep each other accountable."Getting rewarded with discounts, and benefits is a fantastic way to keep people motivated in reaching their wellness goals.  And, I also thought this was key.  Family and friends, speaking from personal experience, do wonders in motivating you to keep pushing forward.  Well thought out concept, Jason!
I really like this concept.  Points could also be traded in for discounts on health insurance.
I think this is a great solution that appeals both to the wallet, by offering discounts, and to the body, by allowing more vacation days and family time.
Congratulations for your idea! The fact that not only the employees could participate and have the rewards but also their families and other companies is very interesting.

Like this concept. I am working on a similar points based rewards system for healthy choices with local homeowners looking to live in healthier and more sustainable homes. The environment of the office (and the homes) is critical to the success of any healthy office challenge.
Thanks Jim!

Could be a great idea for people who are trying to be more healthy but may not be popular for a mixed group of healthy and unhealthy. A plausible problem could be alienation between those who are already healthy (having tons of points) and those struggling to engage in a more healthy (heavy efforts needed to get points). I think this idea would work best with a group of employees that are semi healthy or unhealthy people trying to become healthier. Fantastic idea to help motivate people.
I really like this concept!Having a "healthy benefits" reward system could be an umbrella concept that integrates a lot of other ideas put forth for this challenge.

healthy_beneifts_rewards_for_a_healthy_l.title: Healthy Benefits- Rewards for a Healthy Lifestyle (updated 1.28.13)

Wow this is the most powerful 'stop smoking' campaign I've seen. This would be great to do in the UK and would stop a lot more people from smoking !  - Cant wait for your concept Suzy!
Suzy I love this, thanks for sharing. Really powerful
Wow!

cellphone_app_that_does_not_allow_email_.creator: 91dbbdada550a4c5413752521ce56579

comments.text: This is a great idea. I was just searching for an app to do just this - shut out anything coming from a work contact after working hours. Email, phone calls, texts - everything
It would certainly make eating out more enjoyable without checking your email every 5 minutes.

cellphone_app_that_does_not_allow_email_.title: Cellphone app that does not allow Email after work hours

cat_cafes_but_with_corporate_sponsorship.description: Already a huge phenomenon in places like Taiwan and Tokyo, Cat Cafes do exactly what they say on the tin - offer you the chance to grab a coffee and a catnap with the resident kitties.  Sounds crazy?  Quite the opposite...
cat_cafes_but_with_corporate_sponsorship.creator: e5da1c40289d2b5455db5f7ee62e5dd0

comments.text: Such a fun idea. Also, unlike many ideas on this site; its very cheap. Companies could even adopt cats of their own. Great work!

Thanks Sam - a 100k investment doesn't seem like a ridiculous ask for companies at a certain scale and this has the double-dividend of doing something for animal charities as well as improving employee wellbeing.  Thanks for your feedback - we shall see...

I do love this idea! And the point you've made about so many animals needing care makes it an idea that would help beyond the workplace into society by providing abandoned animals and strays with a home. I know a lot of people who would love to have pets but just don't have the space/means to do so, and this would give them an opportunity to nurture their love of animals. I for one would love to take a break to cuddle a kitty :)

Thanks Asma - glad you like the idea!  Just to reiterate, I can't claim originality as this concept already exists and has been proven to be successful in Asia.  I think it would translate to other markets though and I think it could be even more powerful if linked to an employee wellness/CSR programme with a big employer.   Anyway, thanks for the feedback, it's much appreciated.

Having had cats for the past 18 years-and now no longer having them-I can attest to the calming effect of having them around.  Even though I think your idea is out of the ordinary, I think it's a great one and one worth pursing.  I think it would work especially well in New York City where I live.  There is an abundance of huge corporations and agencies that house adoptable cats.  Good Luck!Best, Rob

Thanks Rob - it's a bit left-field and a bit tongue-in-cheek concept (a slightly spurious reason to post a picture of the gorgeous Tucker) BUT... The popularity of Cat Cafes in parts of Asia (and the analysis of why they're so popular) seems to point to a very real human need around connecting with animals as a way to relieve stress.  The fact that they are so popular in dense, urban environments where people lead such fast-pasted, high pressured lives is, to me, telling. I've heard of a charity in the US that specialises in rehoming cats in retirement homes because, again, a link with improved health and wellness outcomes has been established.  Given that there are so many stressed people out there and so many animals in need of care and affection, this seems like quite a neat way to square the circle.  But I can't claim originality - this concept exists already - my build is simply to add a corporate sponsorship dimension ;-)

Having had cats for the past 18 years-and now no longer having them-I can attest to the calming effect of having them around.  Even though I think your idea is out of the ordinary, I think it's a great one and one worth pursing.  I think it would work especially well in New York City where I live.  There is an abundance of huge corporations and agencies that house adoptable cats.  Good Luck!Best, Rob

I really like this idea! Would be great if I had a chair to tell me that I'm sitting in the wrong posture and that I should change it before it becomes a habit! Maybe the sensors could be detachable and you can place them on cushions or something, so it becomes something portable :)
Good concept Alejandra, not everyone knows what the correct posture is, so this chair will really help them out.
Thanks!! :D
one of the best ideas. innovative yet simple. :) well done Ale
Thanks!! :D
Great concept! It's hard to know if you're sitting correctly sometimes, so feedback on the screen would be very useful to have. Good work on the illustrations aswell :)
Thank you!! :D

thank you very much! I check it! :)

Cool concept Alejandra, the benefits provided is what really makes this concept work, from having the correct posture your decreasing user's risk to sustain any injuries back injuries etc, increasing productivity in the workplace is another advantage good idea.

Good use of technology I cannot wait to see that techno-chair. Good concept I would like to join forces with you in the devlopment of this chair.

check_in_for_your_health_.description: Almost everyone these days has a smart phone and uses it to check-in.  Why not use a mobile app to track healthy employee behavior and offer rewards similar to Foursquare for positive behavior.
check_in_for_your_health_.creator: 839d7ed1c80c12fc97c6d9f2d133039f

comments.text: Hi Zeina, great concept! Who would subsidize the cost of the gym discount? If the employees were taking full advantage of the scheme, the cost financially would be vast for the employer. What about alternative rewards?

Thanks Sam! My original thought was it would be a flow through effect.  The employer could subsidize the gym memberships - if their employees participate, the company could collect participation metrics and share them with their insurance provider to reduce their premiums.  Healthier employees means less health related payments for the insurance company so its a win win all around.I can see how an employer could come up with a library of rewards though to use that are not discounts or cash.  For example, they could offer flexible work hours, one day a week working  from home, longer lunch breaks,  or maybe even other perks such as upgrades on flights or tickets to a ball game or other event.

workout_meeting.description: Redefine the "workout" by enabling people to work out together while actually working! Encourage people to exercise while meeting up for business by providing the necessary space, materials and support for physical activities in meeting areas.
workout_meeting.creator: 87af6ce9789c8f54ca8eea53fdcae003

comments.text: I really like this idea - My own experience is that many people also use things like fiddling with a pen to help keep focus during meeting - Why not replace it with something more healthy?  At the same time, it will take serious work to build up etiquette around this concept in order to ensure that it isn't a distraction.  I can imagine a lot of people getting frustrated and feeling (with justification) that the lady in the corner doing lunges isn't paying full attention - I guess that this is where prototyping comes in!

Great idea Diana- I especially like the idea of using these workouts as icebreakers to kickoff meetings. :)Seth is right though in pointing out that it could lead to be a distraction in some scenarios, so definitely would have to be tested out. Maybe there could be certain cases where it wouldn't be allowed- say, the more serious meetings for example?

Great thoughts here, Diana. And I especially like that it could still be done with low investment by the employer  simply by encouraging walking meetings, etc. Also digging your notion of gaming to motivate participation.
Thanks, Meena. Hopefully there's more chance of implementation if organizations can try it out with lower risk/investment, or are able to adapt to their specific needs/environment.

Thanks AJ

great concept, i like the idea of actively participating in recreational events this is something i would also encourage everyone to do. activities such as dodgeball is a great exercise for building a team and intyeracting with other people who you might not have known. sometimes people do need a time dring work where they could release stress aswell and playing a game of dodge might be the solution to that.

With this in mind, as we approach the upcoming Concepting phase, perhaps folks might like to think about ways of group goal setting as well. I actually meant the potential for groups to set goals on platforms like Stickk (which seems to about individual goals?) ... but if you're keen on developing a concept as a group, that's great : ) In the past we've had members our community set up Yammer groups, Google Hangouts or Skype sessions to develop virtual group concepts... or offline brainstorm sessions using our Brainstorm in a Box toolkits. company_mood_o_meter_.description: Tracking company wide morale and wellness by asking employees simple questions as they ‘tap out’ of the office, displaying the results of the mood-o-meter in the lobby and rewarding the whole company for positive results.
company_mood_o_meter_.creator: 06b51d45ed9615591a4674945a756773

comments.text: Hi Nadine, seems your ahead of the game on this idea....I put up a crude version of a mood o meter on our white board at work. I placed a neutral face on it and over the last few weeks it has been updated by others from time to time. However I'd like to develop the idea into an app to be used and accessed by our staff. I'd like it to gauge some objective information firstly...like sick days, amount of annual leave days rejected by the resource dept, staff shortages etc. But Id also like our guys to log in and hit a mood button to sum up their day with perhaps a comments section. Has anyone else developed this idea???

Hello Paul,as i wrote earlier, i already created an application called CompanyMood.It's mood-tracking on a weekly base instead of daily.You can take a look at it here:German - https://www.company-mood.deEnglish - https://www.company-mood.comPlease give me some feedback, if it fits your needs and if not, what exactly do you miss.You can find also a introduction screencast under http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hxf7rpirI_I but it is in german.

Hi Nadine, seems your ahead of the game on this idea....I put up a crude version of a mood o meter on our white board at work. I placed a neutral face on it and over the last few weeks it has been updated by others from time to time. However I'd like to develop the idea into an app to be used and accessed by our staff. I'd like it to gauge some objective information firstly...like sick days, amount of annual leave days rejected by the resource dept, staff shortages etc. But Id also like our guys to log in and hit a mood button to sum up their day with perhaps a comments section. Has anyone else developed this idea???

Great, simple idea!I'am working on something similar for about 10 months as a side project and i just released the beta.It's still under heavy development, but maybe it's interesting for some of you?https://www.company-mood.comBestMarkus

I like the concept. Tracking where the generic mood of the workplace is low may provide information as to how we can improve the morale. This gives us a starting point, possibly eradicating what is creating a poor atmosphere and find gaps where morale needs to be boosted.Great Work Nadine

This is a great concept Nadine, I wonder if we could get people to 'tap in' too, I bet most people would say 'I'm going to have a good day'. Starting off the day with a positive affirmation is shown to have influence over how an individual acts. Then asking people to tap out and say what kind of day they had is likely to be more positive too and set them up for a great evening personally.

Nice idea Nadine. I like that it alerts the company on their employees morale, improving their state of mind would no doubt lead to happier workforce. Maybe they could also state why they had a bad/good day? I wasn't sure if you meant they'd be asked other questions, or just whether it was good or bad? But it would help the company see what they're doing right and wrong, and what they could do to improve. Good thinking!

There's a great TED talk about the last 15 minutes of an experience leaving the greatest impression (will find link and post shortly) therefore, if a company could do something to lift the last part of the day eg: 5 great ways to relax when you get home e-mailed out by the organisation's health guru then perhaps we could influence recollections of the day and a calmer transition back into home life in the evening ie: no ranting about the lows of the working day or an annoying colleague etc.

tandem_taxis_replace_driving_culture_wit.description: According to The Guardian newspaper, 2012 was the year of cycling. However many people are reluctant to get on a bike, especially in busy cities like London. Tandem Taxis could help people get more comfortable with cycling, one ride at a time.
tandem_taxis_replace_driving_culture_wit.creator: 31b94a38190f523464b73235e6674825

comments.text: As someone who has chickened out of cycling in London for fear of my life, I would definitely give this a go. What a great idea!I wonder if companies could financially incentivise people to do this - e.g. the company will pay you for the miles you ride? Or give you money to redeem in the healthy canteen??

Same here Beth! The idea of cycling on busy roads terrifies me! And I know a lot of people who enjoy cycling but only ride in parks because they feel this way too. So having someone to teach you and ease you into it is a really great idea Sarah! :)And I like what Beth's proposed about incentives- redeeming lunch coupons for the miles you ride could really encourage people to take part.

This sounds really fun, some people can not have bikes because they do not have the space to keep them, this comcept will really be great for the ones that can not have their own bikes. As well as keeping fit and healthy, it will be quicker to travel aswell.

I love this.  It has the potential to take away the fear of cycling and it could even be used to buddy up colleagues who might otherwise car-share.  It also adds a social element to your commute.  Interesting thought to potentially link to the government Bike4Work scheme.

This is awesome, Sarah  I love the simplicity with which this could be prototyped to see if this would excite people.  I'm wondering if the core concept here is about tandem cycling or teaching cycling, do you think this could be expanded to work for people who just want to learn to bike ride on their own bikes as well?  I could see it as a fun way to meet other co-workers or new people in the city. Great stuff!

tandem_taxis_replace_driving_culture_wit.title: Tandem taxis - replace driving culture with a cycling culture

comments.text: i like the way the employees are introduced to the idea at the start, it certainly makes feel more responsible of a plant when they have grown in physically themselves!
This would be awesome in urban and suburban environments. Being NYC and being surrounded by buildings all day can take a toll on a person
Lovveee the idea!! Recently came to know twitter has a rooftop garden: http://blog.sfgate.com/techchron/2012/06/11/twitter-employees-revel-in-companys-new-headquarters/

Wow, this is awesome! This would have benefits on so many different levels - physical, emotional, social. There could even be (monthly) workshops on urban/ indoor farming. I'd love to go to lunches with my colleagues where we all pick something that we've grown in the office - each one brings an ingredient! This also reminds me of a previous comment i've posted regarding a weekly event called "Sexy Salads" which take place at 'The Hub' (http://www.the-hub.net). Each individual brings in one ingredient and then the group puts it all together and makes something out of it. I went to these whenever I could - always tried something new, met new people and felt so creative and inspired. Here's a video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=akejdYwVv84
Way to go, Colin  lots to love on this. And maybe even a group of businesses might set up a garden like this  imagine the collaboration & amicable competition this might foster!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
I love the idea of every company having to have a garden!
