wellness_dashboard_app.description: An app that allows you to track and report your wellness across a holistic and customisable array of different wellness measures.
wellness_dashboard_app.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: this app would be great if your local gp or gym trainer has it connected to yours, so they can also see your progress and remind you of your needs, it's a vice versa thing, seeing how you're doing and people seeing how their clients are

What if.. There was a way to incorporate advice from medical experts, gurus, mental health professionals, etc that popped up from time to time to help you achieve your personal goals in a smarter way? Maybe there could be milestones along the way that encourage you to push yourself. Or a new level of happiness/wellness you could achieve that results in further advice from the "experts"..  I think the most engaging apps are more than just a set of reminders, they encourage active participation or semi-active participation like a time sensitive achievement or something...

I like the idea. There are some already some apps available which work on this problem as well. You might want to have a look at these apps for the further development of your concept.---(1) Mappinesshttp://www.mappiness.org.uk/Mappiness is part of a research project at the London School of Economics.The app helps you to track your health and happiness. It beeps you once (or more) a day to ask how you're feeling, and a few basic things to control for: who you're with, where you are, what you're doing (if you're outdoors, you can also take a photo). The data gets sent back with your GPS location. As a user you get interesting information about your own happiness, which you can download or see charted inside the app  including when, where and with whom you're happiest.(2) Lift Dohttp://lift.do/Lift is a simple app which helps to achieve any goal, track your progress, and get the support of your friends. You can create habits you want to achieve and track your progress. Friends can follow your progress and support you on your way.(3) Eversthttp://evr.st/As Lift its a goal tracking app. You can capture goals and dreams, break them into small steps, learn from others and document your journey from dreaming to doing.--I really like your idea as a starting point and I'm sure that you can make much more out of it. Some comments already deliver some really great ideas.

Really interesting idea, Nathan. I particularly like how you can see results from all areas of life and not only at work. We sometimes forget that our health is based on what we do all day, every day and not only whilst we're at work. The examples you gave are good but are there any more? Just to help us understand the concept a bit more...At this stage, is it simply tracking device of health with a report or does it nudge you to remember to do something too? What might be really nice would be for it to give tips on health and advice to keep for and healthy. Love it and would love to hear development thoughts.

A possible way to extend on your concept (or maybe you already had this in mind).If the app timestamped your every update, your wellness history can be graphed against time to provide some feedback. A bit like a stockmarket chart, which tells you whether your "family" parameter has been going slowly downhill for the last 2 years, or if your "work" parameter goes downhill on particular months. You can use that feedback to warn yourself of an likely downward trend or make you reflect on why certain months are good/bad for you.

Love it. It could even be based on tools such as the "wheel of life" (http://www.mindtools.com/pages/article/newHTE_93.htm). Individuals can define categories/ roles --> define the ideal balance --> measure how they are doing.
Vishal - many thanks I'll have a think about that and see how I can incorporate it. It's a really nice example.
Great micro-macro thinking!

wellness_dashboard_app.title: Wellness Dashboard App

on_your_way_home.description:
Employers could align with local community groups to find micro-volunteering opportunities on your way home from work.

This concept has ben completely updated to reflect everyone's input from the community. Please add your thoughts in the comments
on_your_way_home.creator: 6d6bc76c5c7da502c99a5c5b5a11d28b

comments.text: Congrats XD
Congratulations Matt Cooper and also to all of us for being the team of a winning concept.
Ditto Mukunda! Congrats Matt and team :) I have really enjoyed working with you all on this wonderful concept.

Matt,I have compiled all the comments from everyone who contributed to this concept and here is a list. May be this will help you modify the description of the solution better.1. Bonus and applaud for employees, but no direct benefit. Bonus would be unexpected.2. Advertisement in local newspaper by company taking up this scheme.3. Asking employees to find out if they want to help anyone or spend time with anyone in the locality.4. Put this as a small ad in the main company advertisements as CSR activity.5. Open a facebook page regarding this.6. Asking previous/present interns in the company to find out and advertise about it in their own locality.7. spread the message to old-age homes8. past employees who may be old and they may be interested to find people, help them or get help themselves.9. adding activities to the sessions, so everyone can establish some common ground.10. encourage employees to communicate between themselves to find similarities in the interests of those they are trying to help. 11. reach out to older folks via the community blackboards which are are common in many low-income neighborhoods across the country12. as a cricket-maniac nation, many of our professors love to take part in the annual cricket match we organize in the department on the occasion of Teachers day. After passing out, alumni come back to take part in the match.13. There are many small initiatives like that in every village that can be captured as a spreading point. 14. Partnering with a micro-volunteering platform like Sparked ( http://www.sparked.com/ ) that already has the connections with organizations looking for volunteers could save lots of time on marketing / finding clients, and can provide a reason for the visit.15. getting the older generation involved is a lack of familiarity with technology. Maybe this is one of the things visitors could help with. 16. help my father to blog 17. a system where visitee is encouraged to teach the visitor a skill or a recipe. It would be engaging for both people involved, encourage repeat visits over long periods of time and will possibly even give the visitee a sense of fulfillment. 18. elderly folks could include a wish list of activities they would like to fulfill on a given week. Your idea has led to me to ask ... what if employees ALSO included a wish list of things they would love to learn?19. Could one source of that fear be that vulnerable people are opening up their homes to people they do not know?20. I would love to see employers give employees some training on working with seniors, as part of this program. Not only would it make participants more effective, but employees may soon be dealing with aging relatives themselves.21. In different forms, this kind of community will probably be found in all countries. Women usually are busy in the household chores, particularly in village ares. It will be a nice break for them. After pregnancy many of them don't take necessary precautions owing to superstitions and alike. It will be an interesting point to teach as they look up to educated people.22. As both the employee, and elderly individual, would know or have an  idea of what to expect during the visit, the awkward or nervous feeling of meeting a stranger for the first time could be significantly reduced or gone.23. Check out http://fixperts.org - I absolutely love their model of short, low cost instant outcome projects done for free, for the community. Could those principles be merged into your concept, and an office environment?24. Furthermore maybe look into organizing a staff rotor or a set time a lunchtime for the employees to carry out their visits, instead of at the end of the day when their less drained. Good concept!25. In the same way, may be we can play once a week, a game of their choice. And the company may make it an opportunity for bonus if the employee goes to the activity by walk or by cycling.

Mukunda, this is a great list of the earlier ideas!  It really helps at this late stage to be able to read all of the ideas in one post.  It makes it easier to see where we can most clearly offer ideas.
Mukunda, I agree with Mike. This is a fantastic list you have compiled. Thank you, its very helpful indeed! :)
I agree! It's fantastic to have such a pro active team. I'm going to do my best to encorporate some more of the feedback, your list has reminded me of some things I didn't include. Thanks!
Thank you all. May be we can make a visual representation of the concept like an info-graphic to capture the small and the big pictures at the same time.

Taken from Matt some comments below, "One of my biggest concerns is that people will worry that they need to 'entertain people' and so some reason for the visit could be crucial."I think that this definitely holds a lot of weight in deciding whether a scheme like this will be successful. I personally haven't partaken in anything similar but I feel it could be beneficial for both parties to set up a system where visitee is encouraged to teach the visitor a skill or a recipe. It would be engaging for both people involved, encourage repeat visits over long periods of time and will possibly even give the visitee a sense of fulfillment. The elderly have huge banks of knowledge and skill which are too often not passed on. Sharing of cooking, gardening or even something as trivial as playing the spoons could work well and should be encouraged.
I strongly support your idea of skill sharing, yuji. I interact with a lot of old people in my village and it is always wonderful as there are so much to learn from them.

Great idea indeed Yuji! :) Your idea triggered one more thought for me. Earlier this week I suggested perhaps as part of the registration process, elderly folks could include a wish list of activities they would like to fulfill on a given week. Your idea has led to me to ask ... what if employees ALSO included a wish list of things they would love to learn? There may be an employee for example that wants to learn how to knit and at the same time an elder that would like to spend time knitting with a companion.  Or perhaps there maybe an employee that has been wanting to learn how to play chess, and there is an elder that would love to play chess or teach someone how to play it.

I think having the visitee passing on skills is a great way to get the older generation involved in the program.  Many of the people who need the visits the most might be too proud to ask for the help and time they need, but if they feel like they are giving back something of worth it won't feel like charity to them.  I know when my grandfather visits he is always looking around for some work he can do for us - he hates the idea of being taken care of.

"He hates the idea of being taken care of."Excellent point, Mike. I have seen this in the attitude of many old people. Because they were a lot active and hardworking than our generations, they still want to contribute.Some skills which can facilitate exercise can be taught to them, so they can contribute and do some exercise at the same time.
Jacqueline,I appreciate the idea of skill-sharing in your point. As I commented on Mike's point above, your idea will indeed fulfill both the elder's need to learn and to give something back.

Thanks for the kind words.Mike touches on an important point, it will definitely be a challenge to provide this kind of service and having the elderly person not feel patronized, especially as everybody has a different level of pride.I'm sure with some work it will be possible to get through to even the grumpiest of old sods!

Maybe some of the new friends could even collaborate on Beth's idea for the Grandwikihttp://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/-grandwiki-collecting-and-sharing-lessons-of-the-past-for-healthier-living-today/
Thanks all for the thoughts, great to get your thoughts on the various elements of the project. There's lots of food for thought here...

One thing that can help address these concerns is making sure we LISTEN and "meet the person where they are at".  There might be something happening in their life that is causing some distress and if we don't acknowledge that, we aren't doing a good job at acknowledging them.  I agree, no one wants to be patronized or "taken care of" but they do want to be cared for and know someone cares about them.At the core of all this, it's about listening....

This is a GREAT idea!  I know there are many companies who also allow employees to "trade" work time for volunteer time as part of their work/life balance program.It is very important for companies to give back to the communities they reside in.

Hi Matt,Love the big refinement - very clear message.  I have a couple thoughts on the areas you're still refining.  I think limiting the number of spaces makes some sense, but more to manage growth.  At first it will also create a level of prestige that will make people excited to be a part of it.  But I think you want the program to mature into something that feels very open.  I would think of it the way facebook grew.  When it first started we were very excited we could be a part of it when it was only a few schools.  But we were always more excited as it expanded and we could add friends at other schools.  And as it grew in users, facebook also grew in scope. It used that limited access to create prestige but now feels almost universal.  The program could work in the same way so that it has high level success at each stage.  If you do limit the access, I would promote it as managed growth rather than that you are trying to let only the best use it, because I think that message could discourage people.  I hadn't noticed much focus on pregnant mothers before, but I think that's a great addition.  It is a big adjustment for families.  Even Duchess Catherine has needed to reduce her schedule of activities So if it has that big an impact in the most ideal of situations, I would think there are those at the other end of the spectrum who would really benefit from help with a quick errand.  Even something as simple as somebody who could pick up some things at the store as they get their own groceries would be a huge help.

Thanks Mike, your comments have made me think about the longer term development of the scheme. I think this starts to identify some key phases to the project. From early adopter through to widespread awareness. Exactly like Facebook, as you rightly say.I'll see how I can show this longer term vision.

Awesome concept update Matt! :) I checked out the wordpress site and think the HOW IT WORKS scenario really helps tell the story - clearly and quickly. Suggestion: I noticed minor content edits were needed in the OVERVIEW section. I have edited below for your reference if you'd like to just copy and paste:On Your Way Home (OYWH) is a scheme that companies can opt into to promote and manage micro volunteering by the employees in their organisation. The volunteer's time is structured around the working day and is given to local elderly members of the community.Finding the time to volunteer can be a challenge, and so, OYWH aims to fit the time around an employee's daily routine. Perhaps you have time to spare on your way to work in the morning, or if the evening is better, why not donate some of your time On Your Way Home?
Amazing. Thanks so much. Especially for making it so 'copy-and-pasteable'.
Wohoo Matt! Fab Refinement updates  and great to see your post-it note process over on the Wordpress link.

Another comment:Employers, who has shift system for employees, can ask the morning shift people to get involved in this in the evening. There may be a bonus and applaud, but I don't think any reward should be involved on a do-and-get basis. Intrinsic motivation will be needed for this.To aware the people about this program.1. Advertisement in local newspapers by the employer.2. Asking employees to find out if they want to help anyone or spend time with anyone in the locality.3. Put this as a small ad in the main company advertisements as CSR activity.4. Open a facebook page regarding this.5. Asking previous/present interns in the company to find out and advertise about it in their own locality.

You have raised a really good point about the promotion of the scheme. Getting the message to the older people who will benefit from the scheme might be difficult, so we will need to find good ways to get messages to them.Your suggestions are great, I wonder what other services that already have connections to old people might be able to spread our message?

We can spread the message to old-age homes. Also, there are clubs in almost every place in India where old guys hang out and do nothing except talking. The message can be spread in those clubs. Even employers have the contacts of past employees who may be old and they may be interested to find people, help them or get help themselves.Thanks for your appreciation, I am a newbie to OpenIDEO and it is really encouraging.

This and your comment about football a really interesting insights, Mukunda. They also touch on a point made by Jacqueline which suggests adding activities to the sessions, so everyone can establish some common ground.I think the most exciting thing about Matt's concept is the relationships that will be formed. This is obviously something which is really valued in India.Following on from your idea, it might be interesting to encourage employees to communicate between themselves to find similarities in the interests of those they are trying to help. For example if over lunch two employees realise they are both visiting people who are into gardening, could they suggest that the both of them meet up around that shared interest?I know that my grandparent, when he moved closer to us, found it hard to settle into the new community - the friendship he made with another two guys his age was invaluable. And it happened simply by running into them in a coffee shop and talking about the war!

Hey Mukunda  great to have you onboard! Your input is especially valued here as we're keen to consider how all our shortlisted ideas might be scaled to reach maximum users... so it's brilliant to get diverse global perspectives. From my own experiences in India, I think it's also possible to reach out to older folks via the community blackboards which are are common in many low-income neighbourhoods across the country. (perhaps chalking up info on those could be a discreet 'on your way home' task itself)

Thank you Oscar and Meena.Not only football, there are many other aspects that the older people are missing. For example, as a cricket-maniac nation, many of our professors love to take part in the annual cricket match we organize in the department on the occasion of Teachers day. After passing out, alumni come back to take part in the match.If something like this can be organized in institutions all over the country, where alumni comes back to their alma mater to contribute. This will be a strong intrinsic motivation in itself, where not only faculties but also their parents or family members can take part.

Meena,Community blackboards are surely a way that i didn't think about. Meanwhile, another idea strikes me. My father (age 65) opened an organization of pensioners in my village and neighboring ones where retired people meet up once a week at someone's home and have a good time. There are many small initiatives like that in every village that can be captured as  a spreading point. As an engineering graduate, I used to tell them about scientific discoveries et al in the meetings whenever I was on vacation. It used to be a precious time for me.
Great share of a personal experience where you both gave value and felt valued, Mukunda. I feel these are both key aspects of Matt's concept here.

Thank you Meena.I think we can improve this concept along the way in the process of realization. Employees who take up this work may have ideas to improve which can be encouraged,. May be the personal perspective they will have will add value to it.

Thanks for all of your feedback Mukunda, perhaps you could join our team and offer feedback and ideas.it would be really great to get a perspective from India, i'm sure there are many ideas that could improve this one.
Thank you Matt. I would love to join your team.Before that, may I know how much time I will have to commit for being in a team.

Great idea, and I was really inspired to discover GoodGym and Fixperts.I would like to build on the ideas for how to find the micro-volunteering opportunities.  Partnering with a micro-volunteering platform like Sparked ( http://www.sparked.com/ ) that already has the connections with organizations looking for volunteers could save lots of time on marketing / finding clients, and can provide a reason for the visit. I'm not sure if there's an equivalent in the UK...

It seems like one of the barriers to getting the older generation involved is a lack of familiarity with technology.  Maybe this is one of the things visitors could help with.  Facebook seems almost natural and intuitive to many of us, but it is a big system that can't be fully explained in one visit.  I bet many newbies to technology would benefit from many short facebook lessons that help them connect.  The repeated lessons would help keep them from being intimidated and frustrated.  It seems like a lot of grandparents get help setting up an account but don't get that continued help in really using social networks.

Nice one Michael. I do this kind of thing for my parents (in their 80s) and a number of their friends. It's amazing to see how they start connecting with distant loved ones & local friends as they start to feel less intimidated by social media.

Oh  and another thing I did a while back was help my father to blog at: http://munirsmemories.posterous.com I'd edit his writings into bit sized stories & push him to dig up photos to go with stuff and post it all for him. He was stunned how folks from all over the world were interested in his life stories. I've heard about some hospices who have volunteers come in and do similar stuff for their residents. This could also be an On Your Way Home kind of thing  and has the power to share stories, wisdom, history and help the elderly feel less isolated and under-valued.

Mike's point about familiarization of technology to old people is a really good one. Its an important issue.My father didn't know how to take out money from ATM and he learned 3 years after he was carrying one. Many old people in my state, where LPG cylinder is still a dream for many, doesn't know how to operate one even after getting one somehow.
Meanwhile, thank you Matt for including me in this team.

Meena's story reminds me of NPR's series of interviews that served to record many of the stories of the older generation.  And it reminds me I need to ask my grandparents for more stories about them, but also about their parents and other relatives I never knew.

Hi Matt,Below you mention the stress or fear of those who need the visits keeping them from signing up.  Could one source of that fear be that vulnerable people are opening up their homes to people they do not know?  I would prefer to be optimistic and think this wouldn't happen, but it would be tragic if someone used the program to take advantage of an isolated person.  Would it be possible to tie membership to organizations that could vouch for the member?  Maybe tying it to work where companies would verify the identity of the person providing the service?  And on the other side maybe a civic organization could make the first visit to each person who requests the survey.

Really good point, Mike. I think a proper process to ensure the security and safety of the person receiving the service must be taken into account. However since the employee will be bounded by the responsibilities of his job, it is expected that he wouldn't dare to commit some act like that.The persons rendering the service will have to carry the company id-card with GSM (which most companies has now-a-days), which can be later tracked in case of any mishap. Some technical intervention will be necessary of we think seriously about this point.

Love this idea! Just read that a longevity study showed that loneliness was a big predictor of early mortality.Some ideas....*I would love to see employers give employees some training on working with seniors, as part of this program. Not only would it make participants more effective, but employees may soon be dealing with aging relatives themselves. This can often be stressful and impact an employee's working hours. As a result, employers may benefit directly by including training.*In terms of reaching seniors...-I wonder if you could put announcements in Social Security or Medicare mailings-I've also found Case Managers/Social Workers to be good resources.
thanks for the suggestions, perhaps you'd like to join our team. I'd appreciate your feedback and thoughts moving forward.
Thank you Matt. I would love to join your team.Before that, may I know how much time I will have to commit for being  in a team.
Hi Matt, yes I would like to join your team. Let me know how I can help. -Reba

Another point in line with my comments below.Village women in Assam, a state in India, are always having a kind of cooperative society where they deposit money ($0.2-10) monthly in a group of friends and it is ubiquitous in every village. They also organize self-help groups, sometimes even subsidized by government to do handicraft works, and meet up regularly. Those communities can be captured and this concept can be applied upon them. In different forms, this kind of community will probably be found in all countries. Women usually are busy in the household chores, particularly in village ares. It will be a nice break for them. After pregnancy many of them don't  take necessary precautions owing to superstitions and alike. It will be an interesting point to teach as they look up to educated people.

Hi Matt, wonderful concept! To Asma B's point below, I also love that yours focuses on providing companionship for the elderly. As I read your concept's description, a thought came to mind that I would like to share. You noted that "A system could be set up with local councils or community groups or where elderly or isolated individuals could register, to receive brief home visits." Suggestion:  What If elderly individuals (as part of the registration) could also include a wish list of activities they would like to fulfill in a given week? Some folks for example, may want to go for a walk. Others may want to play a board game, a card game, or simply have a book read to them. These are just some ideas, however, I think having an activity wish list could be beneficial in the following ways:   As both the employee, and elderly individual, would know or have an idea of what to expect during the visit, the awkward or nervous  feeling of meeting a stranger for the first time could be significantly reduced or gone. It could also help the employee better prepare for the visit. (i.e  bring the book s/he will read that day, or bring his/her walking shoes)  The elder individual would get the opportunity to fulfill activities on  his/her wishlist! :)

Hi Jaqueline, your suggestions are really useful, a system for people to select the activities they'd like to participate in would be a great way to frame the whole reason for meeting. One of my biggest concerns is that people will worry that they need to 'entertain people' and so some reason for the visit could be crucial.Establishing the ground rules and expectations for each meeting will be key to preparing people, and hopefully reducing any stress or even fear.It also makes me think about how the requirement may change around the year, and how the system will need to be flexible enough to respond to this and suggest the right kind of activity.It would be great to share any future progress with you, so if you would like to join our team i'd like to get your thoughts as the idea progresses.
Thanks Matt! Sure, I would be delighted to join this team and contribute to this wonderful concept :)
nice way of giving back to the community , this can really make a difference if it works.. liking it alot!!

Great conversations going on here, Matt! As you flesh out your idea and update your concept post based on this collaborative input  might be good to think about the journey of both an employee and a recipient and outline a scenario for each. Here's an example: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/winners-announced/opencity-bringing-open-source-princi/ to get you digging the goodness of this approach ;^)

Hi Matt, great idea. I love the simplicity and honesty that comes from just giving someone a little of your time. Is it possible to build on the idea and provide a goal, or an end objective that might motivate people and give them a tangible outcome to be satisfied with? This might remove the awkwardness of meeting that isolated individual for the first time and trying to find common ground to talk about.Check out http://fixperts.org - I absolutely love their model of short, low cost instant outcome projects done for free, for the community. Could those principles be merged into your concept, and an office environment? Maybe the workplace has a 'On your way home' board which employees update as their projects develop - keeping the rest of the office updated but also making everyone feel satisfied that the company they work for is making a real difference.
Great builds, Oscar  and indeed, there's lots of goodness which might be drawn from your Fixperts example.

Hi Oscar, as Meena says these are great builds. I'm not familiar with Fixperts, but they seem to have a very similar system for facilitating connections.You raise a really important point about having a reason to connect to people. I think there is a real barrier if people worry about what they'll talk about or how conversation might flow. So identifying a good reason to meet in the first place would be a really important step in establishing the first contact.Also the ideas about visualising the activity is great, and I love that your suggestion is as straightforward as a noticeboard. It's very easy to get carried away with technical solutions which could be another barrier to access, a real problem to be tackled considering the basis of the idea.If you like to stay involved it would be great if you joined our team. I'd appreciate your thoughts and feedback as i try to expand the idea.
I'd be happy to! I can see this being a really tangible step towards a more integrated community. Something we're going to value more and more as people get ever older.

I love the fact that this concept is 'giving back to the community'. It would make employees return home with a sense of accomplishment and positivity. This would also benefit the employer by demonstrating that their workforce is positive and hard-working one, that care about their community maybe attracting an interest for possible future employees. Furthermore maybe look into organising a staff rotor or a set time a lunchtime for the employees to carry out their visits, instead of at the end of the day when their less drained. Good concept!
Thanks for you feedback, I think the option to do this at different times in the day is a great one. The more flexibility the system has the better the chance of uptake.

I feel there is definitely a way to connect Megan's solution (the corporate garden) with your solution Matt. We discussed the possibility of growing vegetables very efficiently and easily in her solution. One of the aspects of your solution could be delivering free healthy food options to low income families and expanding the corporate garden concept to become a community garden.

Hi Bobby, i like the idea of delivering fresh food to people. Other people have suggested that the service need to offer specific activities such as reading a book or playing a game of chess, but the idea of delivering food - or even just a pint of milk - could be a great ice breaker for a first time meeting.thanks for you feedback!

Hi Matt Cooper,A wonderful idea indeed. What i would like to do as an employee is that to meet a bunch of old guys somewhere near their locality and make them do exercise, and along with them I will also do exercise. Lots of old people, particularly in India, used to play football. I used to see it in the form of a annual match between our school teachers and students. It was a nostalgic day for all of them. In the same way, may be we can play once a week, a game of their choice.And the company may make it an opportunity for bonus if the employee goes to the activity by walk or by cycling.
Thanks for your feedback. It is a great idea to find out the interests of the people involved, then we can make sure they are matched to similar people.

Great Idea. Many people get caught up in rush hour during the commute on the way home and this time could be put to good use. Helping out the local community is a great way of being productive with this time, then the user could leave at an appropriate time. This may also lead to the user meeting new people, providing a great social barrier. Good work.
Thanks for your feedback. when you mentioned the rush hour it made me think about interesting ways to brand and describe the service. If you have any other ideas please let me know.
lovely idea, gives them more of a reason to bond with each other!
Thanks for your comment, if you think of any ways i might refine the idea please let me know!

Great concept Matt! It reminds me of my concept. Your concept is similar on the way that workers would be doing routes together on their way home. I really like the idea of adding the fact of doing good at the same time. Congratulations!

Hi Maria, I like your concept very much. You have clealry given a lot of thought to the systems that will power the service. It would be great if you could join this team, it would be fantastic to get your thoughts on the the way this concept works - from computers to iphone and beyond.Let me know if you'd like to join in!

Matt - Great concept. Have you explored opportunities for employers to offer support for their employees; flexible arrival or departure times to help accommodate the stop on the way home?One potential partner that came to mind was something like Meals on Wheels. Participating offices could serve as hubs - Meals on Wheels could drop off a batch of meals at a participating office, then employees could drop them on their way home. I imagine such a system would create a lot of logistical relief and a concrete means of action for your idea.Good luck!

Thanks for you feedback, the support of the employers will be vital of course, but you make a great point that employers can offer support in ways other than financial. Flexible time is a great example of this.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel liked the tie-in with the commute home, on the basis that laziness always wins. How could Bupa make this self organising, like the match.com of community activities?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Hi, Matt. Brilliant concept. Just wondering, people often feel drained upon leaving work. However, in the morning before work, or at lunch time, employees may feel more fresh, and in a more positive frame of mind. Maybe employees would be in a better place to make visits at an earlier time of the day?

Really great idea Matt! I've seen other's mention micro-volunteering but I love that yours has focused on providing companionship for the elderly. I agree with Sam in regards to the time though, most people are knackered after work so lunch time could be a better option.

Sam, yes that's a good point. I imagine that there could be 'slots' that volunteers and beneficiaries could setup and apply for. It may well transpire that mornings are better for some. And possibly even that the time of year / season may affect the bes time for a visit.
Nadine helped a great deal with this project. Nadine's page: http://www.openideo.com/profiles/honeyisthatyou/

on_your_way_home.title: On your way home – please add you voice (Updated Tues. 29 January)

py/tuple: Is this concept addressing clear health needs for users?
Indeed! It’s addressing an unmet need in a new way
Yep – it’s addressing a need but in an already crowded space
It’s not clear to see how this idea would significantly improve people’s health
Overall how do you feel about this concept?
This concept rocked my world
I liked it but prefered others
It didn't get my overly excited.
Does this concept feel like it could potentially be sustained as a business or movement over years rather than just months?  Does it feel like it will continue to be relevant in the future?
This concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
It’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue – but there’s reason to feel hopeful
This concept may have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and stay relevant
How easy would it be for people to get involved and improve their health with this idea?
Very easy. It's clear how people could get involved quickly in this concept
I'm not sure if I can grasp how people could get involved easily
It seems challenging for people to get involved quickly in this concept
Does this concept have the potential to reach large numbers of people?
Sure. I could imagine this would spread like wild fire
It's interesting but feels like it would be slow or challenging to grow
It seems somewhat limited in scope

comments.text: Hi Raghu, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know at hello@openideo.com if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.
I would be happy if you could help out. I had to rewrite the idea three times before the stuff got up loaded! I did write in and then tried again, I just keep it simple.

Thanks! Looks great.

building_blocks.creator: 1dc382123d8b3f4877a701dfe11c060d

comments.text: love this inspiration!the employees can also socialise at the same time while they are building lego. A really good way to realise stress ^^
Thanks! they could get quite creative with the lego too :)

Interesting! well i think if you could incorporate a communication system that can work around the workplace instead of email? maybe that could work really want to see the concept for this ! great job :)
thanks. i agree, the communication wall could replace technology communication for employees and employers and could hopefully start to get people interacting and socialising with one another more!

Can be used a as notice board to convey informative messages the kiddagarten way that is using LEGO blocks or even more interesting doing some creative feel good and inspirational art each time an ideas comes in the mind of any employee at that workplace.
thanks! i agree, making some art will let your creative side out and may even help trigger ideas or inspirations for work!

comments.text: Hi Meena,appreciate your comments.I feel like I should thank the 50+ people around the world that had input to this concept in the last 2+ years. There is much for detail available and a technological feasibility is finished as well. I would even argue that it is ready to be implemented as a technical prototype already with 4-6 weeks of additional detailed design work.

Great stuff, Peter. Something we're also keen to focus on is the community aspect of workplace wellness. Does anyone have notions for building upon this fab concept to promote community connectedness between individual users? Almost 2 weeks left for Concepting  let's grow these great ideas for maximum impact!

comments.text: This is a great concept and another great example of how the best form of advertising is word of mouth. It would be great to see what types of people or job roles are most trusted in particular work sectors or companies; Who influences change in these sectors?
Very strong inspiration, could it apply to other jobs and their customers?
Just reading the headline I was smiling and nodding. Hairdressers truly are the psychologists of the modern society!

Great share, Andrew! And thought y'all might enjoy this clip from a TEDx campaign in Buenos Aires which leveraged hairdressers as well: http://blog.ted.com/2012/05/17/how-60-hairdressers-are-spreading-ideas-in-buenos-aires/
Great TEDx clip, does make you question who might the other key catalysts be - and how they could be mobilised for health
Indeed  will be great for folks here to think about that for our upcoming Concepting phase. TEDxBuenosAires has also had other ideas on this: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QzmlUNTblvo :^)
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

comments.text: I think this is a good idea because, it would allow people to relax wherever they are, which is something I think most employees need, considering their work load etc.
Stress may void your productivity and affect your mental and emotional health. We need something like a japanese zen garden.

a 'japanese zen garden' sounds awesome. imagine having a space/retreat offered by the employer/company where one can relax, rest, power nap, meditate, relieve stress... sounds great and then when one has revitalised and reinvigorated it can improve further performance!

a 'japanese zen garden' sounds awesome. imagine having a space/retreat offered by the employer/company where one can relax, rest, power nap, meditate, relieve stress... sounds great and then when one has revitalised and reinvigorated it can improve further performance!

i agree!! i was thinking instead of building a japanese zen garden in the office (which will be hard to implement for alot of people) i reckon just changing some of the corridors to have features of a japanese zen garden to help with the relaxation while you walk from room to room would make a difference in your everyday stress levels.

Wow yeah that would be good i cant help but wonder how you would do this, you should look into what sounds make people relax I'm sure the pitch of the sounds would have to be adapted because you are indoors? I'm not sure but it might be worth looking into. looking forward to your concept!

comments.text: When I attended the Management Innovation Exchange (MIX), I heard Whole Foods CEO John Mackey discuss 21st Century Leadership as requiring 3 things:  emotional intelligence (know yourself and your relationship with others), spiritual or values intelligence (be able to discern purpose), and system intelligence (be able to see value for the whole of a system, not just its parts).  When I rock climb, I learned to master my emotions - in fact, a lot of sports require mental training to be successful.  I don't think work is much different in that regard.  The MIX's Beyond Bureaucracy Challenge, co-sponsored by McKinsey and Harvard, chose Pamela Weiss as an M-Prize winner for helping to create a Personal Excellence Program for the company Genetech.  Read the story to see the amazing results:GROWING PEOPLE: THE HEART OF THE ORGANIZATIONAL TRANSFORMATIONhttp://www.mixprize.org/story/growing-people

Emotional Intelligence is so important but under taught.  I love focusing on it.  To get more attention for your post and to help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. Check this post: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/winners-announced/amnesty-observer-app/ where a scenario is given to get people digging the goodness on a concept. You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.

comments.text: nice work daniel, inspiring and also many  people out there are into the idea of working standing up

a simple extension of the standup meet.  Many people prefer to walk about whilst on the phone, or just getting ideas straight in their heads.Making this an incredibly creative space with areas for colaboration - pin boards, interactive whiteboards will make this a really vibrant space -  but also we need to remember the introverts amongst us -  quiet reflective  standing spaces would be great too!

Daniel, I think this is a simple, effective and practical solution! I like that a few of these rooms can easily be added to an work environment. It also breaks up the sometimes mundane routine of the workday. Specifically, though, I think the best route to take with this challenge is creating the right environment; an environment that will encourage healthy activities- which you've done! In a way, it's easier to give a workplace a makeover than expecting people to drop their bad habits. Again, great idea, and I hope you make it to the end!

Taking the community nature of farmers markets and bringing that into the workplace could be a very infectious way to spread healthy eating trends in the office.  Do you know if there are any companies that offer a service like this that a company can hire to come in on a given day?  I know that "Farm Fresh To You" (http://www.farmfreshtoyou.com/index.php?cmd=officedelivery) picks up food from farmers markets and delivers it to customers at their home or office.  Perhaps a similar company structure could be used to provide a farmers-market-to-the-office type service where employees could browse and grab different things?  Thanks for the idea!

Interesting stuff, Jenny and way to go Leeds University! Looking forward to hearing more developments on outreach-farmers markets in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Could also be good to think about Maegan's musings which go beyond a specific location and could be scaled. Lots of potential avenues to explore to fuel innovative thinking!

I would suggest that local organization events could be organized through public meetups or workplace lunch and learns. Pairing members in teams or some kind of buddy system to help people work through health challenges together can be beneficial, especially for motivating and helping each other reach their goals!

laughteristhebestmedicine.description: We all know the phrase 'laughter is the best medicine' so why not share create a hastag #LaughterIsTheBestMedicine - or #LitBM - where people can upload photos of themselves laughing? People could follow the link for a daily dose to lift their moods.
laughteristhebestmedicine.creator: 31b94a38190f523464b73235e6674825

comments.text: Bupa could also sponsor comedy clubs, laughter courses or apps to encourage people to de-stress.

Great idea Sarah!  Why limit viral photos to cute cats and fancy photo filters?  I love the idea of adding something both positive and easy to share to the viral mix.  Have you seen Dylan's post about smiling (http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/smile-it-s-good-for-you-/#c-09690d18641d287575b616dc670a0f60)?  I bet he'd love to hear your thoughts on his concept.You also might want to connect them to your post using the Build Upon feature. This helps us all join the dots between related posts and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus you'll get more DQ points!. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Search terms like 'laughter' or 'smile' and drag anything relevant over to your Build Upon field. Keep up the great work!
Thanks Nathan - I've added Dylan's post so my post has now 'built upon' his. Cheers!
Awesome.  Great job and happy NYE.
Here at Bupa we've brainstormed another hastag -  #whatmakesmefeelhealthy - which could also create some fun competitions!

laughteristhebestmedicine.title: #LaughterIsTheBestMedicine

giving_the_gift_of_health_a_healthcare_g.description: Give the gift of health, with a healthcare app you can redeem at your local doctor, dentist or a partner wellbeing organisation (i.e. yoga studios, kick boxing, etc.).
giving_the_gift_of_health_a_healthcare_g.creator: 31b94a38190f523464b73235e6674825

comments.text: Cool concept Sarah.  I love how you're popularizing something that is normally considered personal through positive social interactions.  Using it for yoga classes completely makes intuitive sense but the idea of using it for a dental cleaning is something I'd never have thought of.  I wonder what really innovative marketing might look like for this?  Perhaps seizing on to holidays like Facebook causes did to make your birthday wish a donation to a charity, this could be a donation to your health.

Agree entirely with Nathan's comments. Have you heard of Gift Cannon http://www.giftcannon.com/? It's a great company allowing you to gift something to a friend. It's aimed around food (going for a drink etc) but could be used to prototype your healthcare gift app.I was talking to a friend the other day about needing to book a dentists appointment. My problem is a) it's not at the top of my 'to do list' to call, b) I don't really have a dentist I use on a regular basis and c) it's a fairly expensive thing to go and do. My friend kept reminding me to book the appointment but having a 'gift' sent to me with possibly a number, reminder and/discount (which my friend could have gifted?) would have inspired me to book the appointment earlier...I also feel people simply book a doctors appointment out of habit when going to see an osteopath, physio, nutrienist etc could be more beneficial. A friend could send suggestions through the app...?

giving_the_gift_of_health_a_healthcare_g.title: Giving the Gift of Health - a healthcare gift app

smile_it_s_good_for_you_.description: It's quite simple really, just smile. Smiling has myriad health benefits, notably relieving stress and lowering one's heart rate. No fancy gadget needed, only the managerial support for a company-wide smiling campaign that cultivates happiness.
smile_it_s_good_for_you_.creator: 043a035e3af19c9e51c8e56b7d5101d4

comments.text: Great idea Dylan! I'm not sure about the designated areas for smiles only- as Kenny mentioned below it could lead to forced smiles. But I do love the idea of placing funny pictures and other amusing things around to get people to smile, it could create a lovely happier atmosphere in the workplace. Good thinking :)
Brilliant, really like this idea it reminded me of a tweet i saw the other day: "Start smiling! Laughter is proven to reduce stress, improve the blood flow and reduce heart problems."
It does exactly that

I love this idea Dylan.  It is so simple and yet so powerful.  How do you keep it from feeling cheesy though?  I definitely can think of times when I feel like people's smiles are fake and feel inauthentic.

I wonder if employing a bit of co-creation in this campaign might help with what you raise, Nate? Perhaps folks could be encouraged to upload stories to a site on what / who made them smile. Photos could also be uploaded. It could even be prototyped on something simple like a Facebook page. (for those who don't know, OpenIDEO was actually prototyped as a Facebook page initially!) To get folks further motivated, maybe there could be some kind of friendly competition between departments to see which one is the biggest smile-generator? Looking forward to ideas from others here on how we could build this concept and incentivise authentic, mass participation.
Nate  just noting that Kenny has replied on a new thread above in case you're interested in following the conversation...
Awesome point Meena.  Responding on Kenny's thread above.

If it's the greatest number of smiles we're after, installing cameras throughout the office and running the footage through facial recognition software to count smiles and report back the winners would be one crazy big brother move. Though, giving up privacy for rewards is a behavior most of us have accepted.

Laughter is key to reducing stress and maintaining positivity and happiness. Kenny is right forcing someone to smile will have the reverse effect. The wall is a great idea in encouraging the smile. You could also have a memory bank whereby the user could upload all the pictures, videos or quotes which make them smile. When they feel like they need a boost they simply open up these memories reliving the great moment keeping them smiling.

Right, never want to force smiles on people, only encourage it. Whether it takes a mouth full of pens, a traveling troupe of comedians or silly pics on the wall, the right solution will likely differ from participating company to company. Regarding a virtual treasure chest of happiness reminders, I would imagine that would be pretty personal for many, so privacy would be key. At first visualization it's almost too much like a Facebook, but studies show that browsing on Facebook actually makes people depressed. Perhaps this is more like Pinterest, but with a flowing browser of personal digital media mementos. Wouldn't want to fill that up with advertising, so maybe company-sponsored subscriptions instead. It would be very interesting if people actually visited their personalized site when they were blue, and left it feeling elated.

This concept definitely could erode in to an insincere "keep calm and smile on" if people are forced to smile and sometimes people are legitimately upset. Meena I think it would be great to see photos of people I work with sincerely smiling. Maybe an in-office Polaroid would encourage people to share their smiles if they could write a short explanation of why they are happy and post them up in the coffee break room. Maybe a wall of smiling faces of your co workers would create a positive and relaxed space to go and joke about things...

Great builds Kenny  loving the in-office polaroid idea! Feel free at add any bits and pieces from discussion here to your actual post. With just under 2 weeks to go in Concpeting, let's build these ideas out :^)

I heard in a TED talk today that putting a pen in your mouth forces you to smile. I just tried that and it works and it made me laugh. Maybe the pen trick could be a contingency if a person can't bring themselves to smile..

Great points Kenny. It is so important for this not to have a reverse effect.  I dig your idea of a photo wall, there may also be a way to make this tongue and cheek and ask people to do cheesy things in funny ways to overcome the potentially forced smiles.  Like asking people to have a cheesy smile off and photograph it.

smile_it_s_good_for_you_.title: Smile, it's good for you :)

I echo your thoughts Claire. Perhaps different themes can be injected on a regular basis, say fortnightly to keep the interest going. These ideas can also be crowdsourced to a community such as the OpenIDEO platform.

comments.text: I like the idea's simplicity - how can you make it sticky for people how have loads of stuff pass over their desk?

I like the thought of creating something which is inexpensive yet effective also the impact to bring a more happy working environment, also the features contained inside the box which is a bonus and is the best part, good concept.
Thank you, Gurdeep.

Hey Kailin, rad idea.  I love its simplicity and how you've identified a variety of potential use cases.  I'm wondering how to make it go viral so others can try it.  Do you think there could be suggested ways to share positive feedback received through the box?  Or perhaps a digital component to it as well?  Keep churning, this is an awesome concept.

Hey Nathan, thanks a lot! I think it's effective because it's feasible anywhere. There definitely could be an app developed where coworkers respond to comments received and make their own reply. Sparking positive dialogue could be a beautiful addition. I always thought it would be cool to have a ticker in the office, like the NY stock exchange, only with motivational or inspiring comments. Also, Better Boxes' comments could be displayed on a wall in the office, which would perpetuate the positivity within the offices' walls. Thanks for the feedback!

hands_off_the_bathroom_door.description: Why do you have to pull a bathroom door to exit? With variable post use hygiene it would make more sense if bathroom doors were designed to open out and not require contact by a hand on a shared surface, thereby lessening the spread of germs.
hands_off_the_bathroom_door.creator: d116d48848c5783e5a748bf6c0a56ba4

comments.text: I can empathise with this concept. I try to avoid public toilets where I can because of the lack of hygiene but of course there are situations where they can't be avoided. I tend to always open toilet doors using the very op of the handle as this is where I feel people are less likely to grab the handle. I agree that an alternative could be using your foot for example to push/pull it open (a door that swings in both directions would help). And you would think that companies with more money can install automatic toilet doors.Great work Kyle

Have you seen the new Ford commercials?  The one where the guy has a bunch of groceries in his arms and uses his foot to tap the underside of his Ford's rear bumper and the door automatically opens for him...hands free.I read Matt's post below highlighting the reasons that doors open inwards.  It would not be fun to get hit by the bathroom door if it opened outwards.Another solution to add onto the handsfree soap, faucet, dryer, etc. would be to incorporate a sensor on the door where you could tap it with your foot (similar to the handicap door buttons) and the door will open inward without you having to touch it.

I think this would be a great idea for the workplace and any public space. Keeping your hands clean and staying away from germs and viruses is good for everyone - the employer as well as the employees.I would like to add an important feature - a very visible representation that shows that the door is surely locked. Many people touches the door handle to the restrooms one extra time after locking the door to make sure that the door is really locked. I would like the representation of the locked door to be mechanical and visible since for example a red or green light (like in the video) might not give enough sense of security. One way of doing this would be to make the bolt of the door lock visible by making the are around it transparent, in glass or plastic. In addition to this, a clear representation of locked/unlocked would be to have a light in the door handle that is red when locked and green when unlocked, to make it easier to see which toilet is free. Like in this example: http://www.flickr.com/photos/assaabloy/6302892420/

Elin, I like the idea of the lighted handle. In my original idea I was thinking of this more geared towards the main entrance of a multi user restroom that wouldn't actually have a lock on it, but I definitely see the value to the handle for a single user restroom. I guess with an LED, the power consumption is low enough that powering it would not be a big issue, but the use of electricity is one reason I don't like the solution in the video. It is too complex and just changing the swing direction of the door seems so much simpler.

I think this is a really interesting problem, and there's nothing more ironic than using a hands free soap dispenser, a hands free tap, and a automatic hand drier, only then to be faced with an inward opening toilet door.However there are some other practicalities for the directions of door opening: http://uk.answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20100201045659AADRZ3kSo the solution needs to be a bit more in depth. It will then be interesting to see how the cost efficiency is dealt with.

So if we can't change the structure of the entry due to architectural limitations, what sort of other solutions are there? Outline a door sweep on the floor to alert passersby? A flashing light based on a proximity sensor inside as someone approaches the door?What else?

I wonder if a simpler solution would be a door handle you can operate with your elbow?A quick google reveals solutions like this: http://www.barbourproductsearch.info/door-handles-hygienic-prod004934.htmlI wonder is this solution also improves inclusivity and accessibility for users with poor eyesight or limited mobility.

I guess the original thought was that people going into the bathroom would generally have more bacteria on their hands than people who have just washed after going toilet... I think we know that a fair proportion don't do that though.It would be interesting to see the sick days in comparison though.

I really like your idea!There is an existing product called the "Step N Pull' which allows you to pull the door open with your foot. This could be a good low-tech solution but would only work for non-locking bathroom doors. http://www.stepnpull.com/
Who do we need to have involved in making this change? Is it architects, code enforcement, local health departments? Who are the people who need to buy into this idea to make it happen?
Awesome idea Kyle.  I've had this thought many times myself, cool to know there's a solution out there.  Is there a low cost way to test it?

Nathan, thanks for the comment. As I just commented to Elin, I think the solution in the video is way too complex, however it is a good solution when you can't change the structure of the entryway. The low cost test is simply changing the directions of the hinges.

hands_off_the_bathroom_door.title: Hands off the bathroom door
