secretgym.creator: 31b94a38190f523464b73235e6674825

comments.text: Brilliant Event for Well Being. Being quite a fan of Immersive Experience such as Secret Cinema and as an attendee of Secret Music with Laura Marling I came across people who were there for the sake of experience and not necessarily cos of the artist. Everyone was excited, some came in groups, pairs, couples or alone but despite this all seemed to be immersed and genuinely happy to be there. As Secret Cinema lovers may know, although it is not strictly compulsory the more you prepare the requirements such as dress code etc the more fun you have therefore most people do pay attention to detail, time and money to be the part. Personally I think the same will happen to Secret Gym as to fully enjoy the experience, most people are likely to be committed in working out in prior to the event therefore The Secret Gym will act as a great motivation for healthier life style. Like other people have mentioned below, this will be an amazing opportunity to well being orientated or interested people to meet up which now a days are quite challenging as most people tend to work out alone ie, jogging or even going to a packed gym most tend to work out alone or in usual group of acquaintances. Taking care of our health is not a drag and this concept realises that well. If this sort of event is to happen I am very much likely to participate myself.

This concept of a "meetup" is similar to Meetup.com. I like the idea of the meetup, but I'm wondering if people would be amenable to being surprised by the activity. What if you just rotated the activity, but it wasn't a surprise.

I'm curious if, perhaps like with standard "ice breakers", people would be more likely to enjoy a particular activity if they're surprised with it on the spot rather than knowing about it in the beginning.Take the cinema model as analogy. I might not choose on my own to go see an art film or a rom-com, but surprised with it, sans preconceived expectations, there's a chance I'd just let myself enjoy it. You definitely have a point thoughsome people just don't like surprises. I'll bet there's a way to do both perhaps, with rotated events and also with surprise activities.

Perhaps some middle ground would be to allow folks to choose an activity genre?  For instance, you could choose "Outdoor activity", and be surprised with climbing, spelunking, hiking, etc.The element of surprise is necessary to break the ice, and make it a fun adventure.  But, most people are pretty comfortable in their habits.  So what's a way of encouraging people to break through their shell?
I love this idea and I think it's very important to make body health
I love this idea because it's like PE class all over again! It's a shame that we lose the "mandatory" opportunity to work out when we get out of school life.
I love this idea because it's like PE class back at school all over again! It's a shame that we lose that "mandatory" exercise opportunity after school life.

I really like this concept as it really does a great job bringing like minded exercise buffs together to try out new methods of exercise. While people need to be open-minded when it comes to finding out what activity they will be doing, it might be nice to have some kind of survey or options people can fill out beforehand. Maybe the site can present 3 possible options, and it is a mystery when you show up which one you will be doing. This way you still have the element of surprise, but people aren't stuck doing something they are not interested in. Also, while marketing is key in getting the word out it might be nice to find some way to still keep the "underground" aesthetics of this concept alive.

Good point Amanda.  But I think the element of surprise is what can really differentiate this idea.  Maybe the tag line is something like 'exercise for the curious minded' or open minded.  Hopefully spending an hour or two doing something different every few weeks wouldn't put people off?

Digging your Exercise for the Curious tag line, Suzy. And I imagine there could be a way that users could suggest activities / locations they're interested in to go into the pool of future surprises. Often I think the surprise would be the location as much as the activity.

Yeah agreed! It is definitely important to maintain the surprise and adventure element of Secret Gym, because that is what makes this idea so special! Maybe in that case, when members sign up to be a part of the program they can fill out an introductory survey. That way the site will get to know that member better and gauge their interests in terms of fitness preferences. That way, the planned activities can also be sure to meet a variety of tastes and be sure to give someone who generally sticks to aquatic sports an activity such as hiking or flag football.

While I like the idea, it seems to me the type of people who would stay with it would be the type that's already fit, active, going to the gym, etc. Not to mention it seems like the cost would be greater than simply going to the gym as well as the time required.

Sarah, I really like this idea also. How would it bring the outsiders in. For example many people get intimidated by gyms because they already see healthy people and they are embarrassed so they stop. So employees could see healthy co-workers and be embarrassed then their could be a divide in the work place or health people vs intimidated people. How could this be solved? Love the idea!

This could be one of the strengths of this idea.  Since it's a secret activity nobody knows what to expect.  And some of those very healthy co-workers could be surprised by an activity that doesn't fit their skills. For example, I am very fit in terms of cardio activity like running or rowing.  But if I signed up and found out it was rock climbing, you'd find I'd struggle more than most people with nerves and not much confidence in my upper body strength.  And activities that require hand-eye co-ordination would be even worse.  So it might be a great equalizer.
For sure mike I agree with you. but what about the intimidated people?

In your advertising you could certainly emphasize that this is a great way to try new activities and jump-start an active life.But the real way intimidated people are going to get comfortable is word of mouth.  As they see people like them trying SecretGym and hearing about their good experiences, they will be encouraged to give it a try.  This is the same process that happens with all new ideas.  There are always early adopters and those who are a little intimidated and wait to see.  Eventually the concept proves successful and they are encouraged to give it a try.  SecretGym can't force intimidated people to try it, but they can be welcoming to all levels.  I think this is where the ranking levels could really help.  Somebody who is intimidated isn't likely to stick with the problem if they're surprised by an especially challenging activity.  The rating levels help them find an activity that suits them.  The one thing that could get intimidated people to try the program early is encouraging corporate users to make this a team-building event.  In this way somebody else makes the first step, but they see how welcoming and encouraging the program is.  This could get them to try it again on their own.

I agree with you regarding the team building event. Sure one would maybe have to sacrifice the whole secret aspect but it would encourage everyone. In a way forcing people who would normally be scared.

I don't think it sacrifice the secret aspect. I was picturing small teams within companies signing up for a departmental outing.  They would just sign up the whole team for one day's activity and everybody would be surprised together.  But for many companies this might mean they'd need to be able to sign up a month in advance.

Difficulty Rating and Hints as Engagement Driver:Hi Sarah, I love this idea: there's not enough mystery in the world :)My thoughts:I think the level of information you allow could make a big difference in uptake/ attendance. My idea: Add a "difficulty rating" to the event. There is a local hiking program where I live and their ratings of "very difficult" and "easy" have helped my friends and I choose what we'd like to attend. I also think you could build a lot of enthusiasm and engagement/ interest by offering 3 hints as the day of the event approaches.  Hints can stir conversations on your social media sites and also you can use a Facebook whisper code ( some phrase a member would whisper at a physical retail location) to push your participants towards something like a health food store/ restaurant (read: Sponsor) where they can grab an extra hint.  Ex. Hint: "Get ready for Hills!'

Digging your builds here, Ally! I also go hiking (in NZ) and we have a rating system too which I've found super helpful. And as someone who handles social media for a number of organisations (including for OpenIDEO ;^) I can well relate to your notion around teasers to heighten enthusiasm & engagement.

This is a great way to build excitement and further engagement.  I think it would be fun if you set it up so that you pay less if you sign up before the hints are out.  Not a huge amount, maybe around a ten percent increase per hint just to give a little reward for putting yourself out there for the full surprise.  And the rating system would also be a huge plus, especially if there was some type of regular schedule so that people could know for example, on Tuesday nights I can sign up for a huge challenge.  Or Thursdays I can count on a lighter challenge where I can try something new with no fear.
And Sarah, thanks for adding me to the team even this late in the process. I'm glad to help where I can!
Great idea on the incentive to sign up early with no clues... I'm already seeing a Take-the-Plunge button ;^)

Or... "I'm feeling lucky"I like the idea of hints as the day draws closer. Maybe there is a flexible pricing system where the price goes up as more people join (similar to how Megabus and airplane tickets are priced), and the hints are scheduled. That way, the capacity of the venue or event can be managed well, and people know that they can save money by signing up right away. If you wait for the hint, you might pay more (or not) and you might also not get in if capacity is reached.

I love this idea, it goes beyond the workplace into the community, it reminds me of the games of urban tag popular in Tokyo and feels like it has the potential to become a bit of a craze- literal speed dating and an alternative to coffee, lunch and drinking to meet like minded people-One of the barriers to health and well being , and gyms overall is they are not exciting, intriguing or involving ( communal) , which your idea is, in spades, so the language around this idea is also important.

Sure their is only 20 hrs left but here are some links I got to help towards the comments I brought up regarding co-workers potentially being intimidated.http://www.livestrong.com/article/420337-how-to-not-be-intimidated-in-the-gym/http://www.leancurves.com/how-to-manage-gym-intimidationhttp://exercise.about.com/od/exerciseforbeginners/a/gymfear.htmMight generate some ideas.

Sounds like a great concept. It would be best to give some hint of what the activity will include, but leave the route and details a mystery. This way people will be able to better prepare by bringing a swimming suit if the secret gym event involves that, for example.

I'd like to add to this idea: Add a "difficulty rating" to the surprise event. There is a local hiking program where I live and their ratings of "very difficult" and "easy" have helped my friends and I choose what we'd like to attend.

Maybe a secret charity (revealed at the same time as the activity) could benefit from the fee charged.  Maybe involve a rotating cast of health and fitness related charities. Then it benefits the active lifestyle of those involved and the broader community.
Nice build on the idea Mike.
This could work really well if the charities also did the organizing. Otherwise, if fees are given to charity then it could be difficult to make the program sustainable.

Maybe it could work like a lot of road-racing companies that benefit a consistent charity partner.  A well-developed charity could provide advertising support while the SecretGym team could run the operational side.  A lot of charities are able to provide advertising graphics and signage that would help promote events.  Also, being connected with a well-known charity might drive up participation enough that even after diverting a healthy portion of the fees, the SecretGym concept remains sustainable.  I'm picturing something like the Susan G. Kommen runs/walks or the MS bike rides so popular here in the States.

Hi Sarah, I love the 'secret' aspect of this idea.  Could it also be a way of introducing people to lesser known sports, eg archery, poi spinning, rock climbing, etc.  It could be a way of showcasing local sports clubs (activities ready made and easier to tap into?), and could boost flagging club numbers, perhaps?  What sort of spin could SecretGym! put on the event?  A social meal together afterwards giving people a chance to exchange their views on the sport they've just experienced?  eg after a martial arts session you all go and eat Chinese food.
Canny build, Suzy. I'd sign up to the martial arts gig just to get in on the social meal Chinese food part! I like how your suggestion would push SecretGym to become part of a city's social fabric.
Great idea!  Specialized gym and sport clubs could even be recruited to sponsor the events if it helped their club numbers.
i like it.. haha imagine having to surprise someone with your new physic.. this is the best way to do it, it can get people to notice your body and boost confidence without being too obvious.

Sarah, I think this is a really cool idea. I think it has potential to be a standalone business following a combination of the Groupon and Priceline models.The company, SecretGym, has a different price point each day, such as ten dollar tuesday, five dollar fridays, six dollar saturdays and so on. When you sign up for a day, you pay before you find out what the session is - all you know know is that the experience will be at least 50% off the normal price for that activity (and you can see the historical activities at each price point). You find out as soon as you pay so that you know where to meet and what kind of clothes to wear. The money paid is split between SecretGym and the activity provider. For example, one day might be climbing. A regular day pass, rentals and a lesson at a climbing gym would normally cost $36, but through SecretGym it costs $15 - $7.50 goes to SecretGym and $7.50 goes to the climbing gym. After the session, the climbing gym might decide to offer to credit the $15 towards a membership, potentially converting a number of first time climbers to become regular members. It is win-win-win: the participants get to experience a lot of new physical activities that they otherwise wouldn't get around to experiencing at discounted prices, SecretGym has a high margin business from connecting participants with new experiences, and the activity providers get a small amount of new revenue while potentially getting several new long term members.Employers could sponsor a weekly mystery activity. Every Wednesday, for example, an office could pay for anyone who wants to go to try out whatever the activity is that week, creating a great team building opportunity.
Wow  great builds, Nigel! Sarah  you may want to think about adding a few scenarios to your post during Refinement (both on the user + provider side) Excited to see how this concept evolves.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel loved this! How and where might you seed this idea?  Are there any existing organisations you might partner with?  Maybe check out RunDemCrew from our Inspiration phase.Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!
yeah this sounds interesting i will be drawn to getting involved with this concept, it sounds fun and entertaining..
I thinks this a really cool idea Sarah. Have you heard of Good Gym www.goodgym.org - someone like these guys might be a more interesting and interested partner than Virgin Active

Hi Alexander! Indeed, I went on a run with GoodGym a few weeks ago! That is a great idea - they could be fun to partner with. What if we rallied a load of different health clubs in one city to take part?

I so need to sort my life out and get on a Good Gym run. It'd be interesting to see if you could get loads of different clubs together. The hook for them might be tricky ... maybe it's about getting interesting businesses/organisations with cool venues that people might be interested in working out in?
Cannot agree more, this has so much potential in solving this Ideo challenge whilst also helping create a positive healthy community

I really like this concept! Is a good way for people to disconnect of the routine and change their gym activities into a most exciting way to do exercise. It could be possible to use social network inside the companies to promote this activity between the employees!

This would be brilliant for those who are members of gyms and are already confident in taking the step into exercise....  would this add value to potential partners? how would it affect existing gym membership contracts - would people have to pay more fees?  What about those who are not as confident in either their own ability or  fitness - how could they be enticed into the unknown?  Is this a concept that is universally scalable?Good idea - would love to see it being refined....

Love this idea! I can easily see how the community would find each other, and the word-of-mouth potential that would come along with it. It's almost like a fitness "flash-mob". Head to secret spot, work out, meet people, have fun... and then seamlessly get back into your routine!

As an avid gym goer and exerciser, I'm very interested in this idea! We all get those days when we just don't feel like going back to the same old gym and there are always days when self motivation is low. How can we change this? With secret gym? Maybe... hopefully! I really love the idea of having a set meeting place and then the activity is done from there. It gives lots of people the chance to do a fun activity with people they don't know. In London (with so much going on and plenty of facilities), the possibilities of activities are endless which is why it'd be a great place to pilot the concept.

I love this concept, it has a very strong appeal. I think you are right that people are getting board with gyms and the idea of teaming up with a partner would really help promote and enhance the experience. There is also a boost in incentive for participants having variation of activities. Social networking is such a powerful tool for promotion. Could the activities be tailored to peoples abilities so as not to alienate those who struggle with some fitness tasks?
Really digging the allure and intrigue that this concept would create!

comments.text: If location is a concern, I'd love to show you this http://faircompanies.com/videos/view/high-line-abandoned-nyc-rail-becomes-skinny-park-in-sky/This is an amazing park in NYC where an abandoned railway line that is high up above the streets was transformed into a skinny park. It's beautiful and really speaks volumes about how to effectively utilize space.

Your visual annotations shows a great deal of your thought process to this concept. Well done its a good concept with great visuals and now you can look into how you can integrate the gardening sessions around the workers working times.

the secret garden idea is beautiful and it is very connected - that is it could be to the compost chalelnge that  Wout Helsmoortel proposed http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/the-compost-challenge/It could be interesting to link the two ideas for an integrated approach :)
Thank you Gaia! I will look into this :)
Thank you for adding me to the virtual team Megan! I am very happy to contribute thru collaboration :)

yh this is a great concept, a place to escape and recover from the demands of work

There is this amazing concept called SquareFootGardening. I work at Columbia College in Columbia South Carolina, and we partnered with churches and organizations in underpriveledged communities in the region to fight obesity, diabetes and poverty. Square foot gardens are much easier to maintain and create than traditional gardens. They sprout more vegetables in less space and the food is free for local people. originally it was intended for individual households, but it's able to serve entire communities. The ease of construction and use, means that they could be easily created efficiently in corporate settings.This could contribute to the secret garden, creating not only something practical for nutritional needs, but doing so in a highly efficient way.http://www.squarefootgardening.org/
Thank you for your input Bobby! Yes that would be really interesting, I will look into this.
You're absolutely welcome, the work we've done with these got us the Washington Center Civic Engagement award and 25,000 dollars to put towards expanding the project.

Nice concept! I think the idea of building communities around these secret gardens is really interesting. Also is a good way to make the most of those parks and areas that are nowadays without any use.

A different way to escape form the routine and fight the stress at work, great concept!
Thank you Andrea :)

This is a very interesting concept. I particularly like the involvement of the local community contributing to the garden. I can visualise the garden becoming into a social gathering location, where members of the workplace and community can unite in an informal and calm environment.However, I feel the real potential from this concept is beyond this. If you take the London City Hall building for example: to put it bluntly its a building with offices and meeting rooms. But architecturally its magnificent and transforms a working place into a landmark.Now imagine a magnificent garden so beautiful that it becomes a landmark in itself. Not just your ordinary garden, but a green space of beauty! This may encourage wider communities to visit these special gardens and perhaps contribute to the garden. Companies that support this concept would take a great sense of pride in creating something that people would travel to see. Almost like a piece of art.Great work Megan.

Thanks for your comment Jonathan! Yes it would be a great idea to build upon the community aspect of the garden even further; making the garden into a sort of landmark enticing people to visit sounds very interesting and I will look into building upon this.

If the garden has a tool shed, this would be a good place to store and make available high rubber boots and overalls. I saw a group photo of the class in their garden, and the kids are all in their proper gear. That's what made me realize that the same thing can be an important part of the office garden concept.

recharge_water_bottle.description:
Recharge is a smart bottle concept for better hydration within daily life.
This smart water bottle visually expresses how much water you drink within a day and alerts you when to drink.
recharge_water_bottle.creator: be3ef5a5cb2c1ff619b302560ae90346

comments.text: Very cool, quirky idea. Can really see the visual impact around the office/workplace making a difference. Hope you go somewhere with this!

Not drinking enough water can cause loss of concentration, mental and physical fatigue and dizziness. This simply concept would allow the individual to record how much water they drink everyday and see how much they need to improve. You could even integrate connectivity between the bottle and a smartphone to warn you when you haven't drunk any fluid for a prolonged period of time, sending you a message or vibration to alert you.I feel drinking enough water is one of the most neglected routines for most people today. This concept would certainly help improve this problem.Great concept Darius!

I love this! Also a great way to make the surroundings understand that a refill is required. I can imagine that in many work situations supervisors see drinking water and refueling as a waste of time. This bottle is a constant reminder of the importance of hydratation. Good job!

Great idea Darius! Hydration is so important and often neglected by people during the working day. Having a water bottle that reminds people to drink could really improve peoples drinking habits. Having the bottle connected to a computer is also a great way of relaying information. It could be connected to a central workplace database to give a workplaces overall hydration rating. That way colleges could also encourage each other to help improve the overall health of a workplace and make the system more communal. It is great that this concept also tailors to any person in any environment. It has great potential to scale far beyond the typical office environment. Brilliant concept!
Nice idea to create a community. Its another powerful incentive to drink more and create an awareness to the benefits of water.

Great idea. Want to have one for me :)This is a nice concept which should work with personal tracking devices such as Nike+ or Jawbone Up. One more idea: The bottle save show much water you've drunk during the day. Maybe you should ask the individual how we felt during the day, if he was productive, etc. So you can easily create some data to show that drinking is important not only for the health but working performance as well.
I like that idea, really personalise the products feedback. Using personal data and graphs to compare and contrast the users water intake would really add to the incentive to drink more.

Nice solution to a perennial problem. I would buy it if it were available. The standard recommendation is for adult females to drink 8 cups of water per day, and for adult males to get 12. Anyone who has tried getting 12 cups per day probably has found that it's nearly impossible to sustain this without some sort of method. A lower tech trick that I've found useful is to use a quart drinking glass while at work (I've used a quart mason jar). Counting 3 quarts is easier than 12 cups. But the disadvantage is the bulky size of the quart vessel. The Recharge concept resolves the "keeping track" issue while keeping the size convenient.

recharge_water_bottle.title: Recharge water bottle

collab_cooking.description: Some professional people like firemen and similar do a communal and collective effort in buying and cooking healthy lunch and dinners. This has decreased the total number of minutes that they are occupied with shopping and cooking their own food.
collab_cooking.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: Another good inspiration for this is The Hub (http://www.the-hub.net). I have also mentioned them here (http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/breaking-the-status-quo-to-keep-our-body-and-mind-healthy#c-660401e8c4f49bde3738f433f3ee190b)Most Hubs have a weekly event called "Sexy Salads". Each individual brings in one ingredient and then the group puts it all together and makes something out of it. I went to these whenever I could - always tried something new, met new people and felt so creative and inspired. Here's a video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=akejdYwVv84

We did something similar in my former workplace (www.aiesec.org). We were quite a global team (17 of us from 13 countries) living in Rotterdam and we had weekly team dinners. Teams of 2-3 were formed and we were treated to some truly global-fusion cuisine. These dinners were optional, we RSVP'd so the cooking team could plan accordingly! It not only got the entire team together, it even allowed the cooking team to collaborate outside the office environment.
Many students also use that system in college if they are sharing a suite.

Interesting Johan. I go hiking / camping quite a bit here in New Zealand and  we always cook our evening meals together  because it's fun, uses less fuel resource + time than cooking separately and means we can share the load of carrying ingredients in our packs. Had never thought what this might look like if transferred to the workplace! Looking forward to hearing more in the upcoming Concepting phase...

collab_cooking.title: Collaborative Cooking and shopping for groceries

comments.text: Great concept! This is a very interesting concept that I find very beneficial for work places as colleagues will have the opportunity to leave their work area and have time to relax and have fun.
love the concept, colleagues will have the chance to play with each other instead of only working!
Thanks Mash :)
I like this concept, most companies have a set routine or even individuals, but have something different to your whole routine can be a new and enjoyable experience. Well done Sanjali.
Thanks a Lot :)

Awesome idea Sanjali! I don't know anybody who DOESN'T like air hockey- and this would be such a great way to relieve stress and get colleagues to socialise and relax in a fun competitive atmosphere. Love this concept :)
Thanks :) glad you liked it !

Nice idea Sanjali.. I like the concept of having a game room. Its very essential in corporate office environment to have something different to your whole routine. Air hockey or any other small activity in the area which can take their mind off the chaotic schedule for a while can be very relaxing experience. My concept also incorporates relative bottom line, an office area which itself is relaxing and gives and open area environment to get inspired of and de-stress mental and therefore physcial health in tough corporate world. Hope to build something more on this through soem collaborative brainstorming or each other's ideas.Have a look at my concept : http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/break-out-of-the-cage-/

Amazing Sanjali...Great concept. Will definitely ask my boss to bring atleast two air hockey table in our office. Yes we do have pool tables but what is the use of having them when they are mostly crowded.And the idea about swiping the ID card and allowing an employee to play maximum two times will keep it away from getting crowded.Never thought about such an idea. Thanks for one ;)

I thank you for cheering up my concept :)And yeah you are right by swiping the ID card will help to keep the place uncongested ! I also thought of having thought of having those Arcade Racing Games [ http://www.bmigaming.com/Games/Pictures/video-arcade-games/dido-kart-std-2-video-arcade-racing-game-injoy-motion.jpg ]That would be also real entertainment for employees :)

Studies say that work stress has become so big these days that it has actually started hampering personal lives of people. I think this concept where 'everbody' can enjoy a little fun time during office will be great as a reliever from the problems. Great concept and nice job done!
Thank you Praveen  :) Actually nowadays ppl are so much stuck in work that they forget to relax. There is no harm to be bit childish :) Cheerz
Nice idea, Its important that workers have play time!"the pool tables are almost ALWAYS crowded by the good players"Would this not still happen with air hockey tables?

Hey hey :) Air Hockey is a fun game which can be played by anyone... There is no age-restriction.And as I also mentioned you don't need any extra-ordinary skills or any instruction/guidance to play it.Moreover it's also interesting for female who are not that confident with pool or even Foosball. Besides that an air hockey round finishes more faster than a round of pool. According to that none has to spend their free time in standing queue.And my research tell me a pool table is much more expensive compared to an air hockey table. Companies could easily afford some air hockey tables than pool tables.

Great idea! loved it. it's different than just having a play corner ... and yeah well said it's also eligible for female. And I agree with you... pool tables are really costlier than air hockey tables. Affordable for companies with low capital and who want their employees to have fun while working. nice concept.  ..... Simple, yet fun.

Wow! How much I wish that happens. As you pinted out that many of us actually don't know how to play pool. Air Hockey is simple yet fun and the amazing part is that everybody can play it! Also, it's a stress buster i think! Nice concept and I really hope people adopt this!
:) cool u guys liked it .

canada_s_healthy_workplace_month.description: An online resource for registering teams from your workplace, selecting S.M.A.R.T goals for the month ahead (from a wide range of healthy actions) and monitoring your progress in line with other colleagues and teams and companies striving for change.
canada_s_healthy_workplace_month.creator: 7e7dcb823cb8bac78bee007e8041492e

comments.text: I really like this idea!Makes me wonder if you could also look at running "healthy families" challenge through workplaces - supporting employees to create changes in their families thus rippling out the impact to a broader network...

Sounds great! I think the key ingredients in this example seem to be the peer pressure of community, and the measurement of progress. Specific drives and projects for specific (but hugely varying) goals. It's truly an enabling model. The framework and management of this example should be right up BUPA's street. Perhaps where the IDEO concepting stage could help would be in expanding the premise in exactly the manner you suggest - how does something triggered in the workplace permeate the home environment? And other such builds etc...

As well as the focus on goals (and performance), I really like the sense that you can benchmark multiple workforces/employers - should encourage friendly spirit of competition! And continuous improvement if its followed up the next year (powerful for an employer).  And like the focus on culture and norms (not just get fit!). To make even stronger could add explicit focus on a) what happens the other 11 months b) taking the challenges/goals into daily/family life  how to make any change/goal spread and then stick.

chronic_disease_free_workplace.description: To encourage all workplaces to strive to support staff to avoid, manage or recover from chronic disease as these conditions are identifiable, reportable and their management would lead to the greatest business and community impacts.
chronic_disease_free_workplace.creator: 3199f8856e47136833a7ae7961c2a5e2

comments.text: Great job describing a robust program to help employees Justin.  To help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. Check this post: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/winners-announced/amnesty-observer-app/ where a scenario is given to get people digging the goodness on a concept. You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.
thanks for the advice Nathan, will come back to it and update soon. Justin

The name sounds terrible for those people who have chronic diseases. It (CDF) implies unemployment or discrimination. So I would definitely work on a better name for it. I am also seriously concerned about privacy issues.

Hi Valerie, agree completely the name isn't 'comfortable'. I guess what I was (am) trying to do is deliberately use direct language to engage with the predominant problem at hand.I could call the concept 'the overall workplace wellness initiative' or something like that, but I'm keen to see how people react to the concept of directly naming and attacking the cause of 'un'wellness.It's also designed to respond to the employer. "What is causing me to lose productivity? Chronic Disease. Let's fix that", again testing a very deliberate, active language to see if it works with employers.I have no doubt that if the initiative was implemented it would be renamed to be more palatable but for now I'm going to stick with it to monitor overall reaction - though I do really appreciate the feedback.I'd also say that as a father of a teen with a chronic (and incurable) disease in Type1 I know all too well about the potential for discrimination etc, but in this openIdeo environment I think it's worth pushing the boundary a bit with the language.In terms of privacy, I am a public sector service designer for a living here in Australia and work every day with Privacy as a design constraint / appropriate protection - I've developed the concept assuming it would be implemented within the legal and moral privacy framework, but again can see exactly what you mean when you raise the concern.Let's see how it shakes out! And again, thanks for the comment.

chronic_disease_free_workplace.title: Chronic Disease Free Workplace

drdoctor_patient_communications.description: DrDoctor is a tool to let patients communicate better with their hospitals. By putting their appointment details online and making it possible to interact with them, we can give patients ownership over their care; hassle free.
drdoctor_patient_communications.creator: 03f1feae7c9dc3b25553887ee58ee947

comments.text: I think this is a good concept, it is good at finding the time to arrange and following up appointments. It can improve the administrative purposes of hospitals and allow patients to take ownership of their appointments. It is so useful for the workers and obviously it would improve the NHS.

its interesting but I am cautious. This would require a lot of legal advice I am assuming - HIPAA regulations in the US - and probably in other countries around the world. Furthermore, who would fund the service - would it be for profit ? If so, would you want the patient (getting better service), the doctor (getting feedback and no lost time spots) or an employer (healthy employee = higher productivity) to pay for the service. I think the healthcare system certainly needs more simplification, but would like all situations considered, to understand it this does add simplification or another step in the already lengthy healthcare routine...

good concept, something similar exist netdoctor.co.uk but very nice, we often are more flexible online and are spend most of our time online anyway, making this would prove to be very convenient for many people that are always way too busy for an actual doctors appointment

I love this concept! I often find myself struggling to find the time to arrange and follow up appointments this could really work. Furthermore this system would be extremely beneficial to both the NHS and patients. Great idea.
Amazing concept mate. This will definitely be beneficial in the future.

This is a good concept. Patients having instant accessibility to the appointment details will allow them to do things much quicker than calling up the Doctor's. I guess it just needs trust that the public will respond to this service and actually use it. However if they do then I can see this being a very practical toolGreat work
One of the areas it would be great to explore next would be how to involve the public fully to maximise the value delivered :)

What a great idea and concept! I have spent too many hours between meetings and in lunch breaks hanging onto the end of a 'phone trying to arrange or re-arrange medical appointments.  In an era when we are always being told that identifying illness early can make all the difference to succesful treatment anything that makes actually meeting up with medical experts easier can only be good.

Sounds great, Tom! During our OpenIDEO challenges we hope that our community will collaborate to strengthen and build ideas, together. Do you have any issues or areas of opportunity for DrDoctor that you'd like to share to help folks understand where they might join the conversation on building the idea further?

I'm really interested in the accessibility aspect; how can we make sure this would work for everyone, whatever their IT literacy, or accessibility needs are. I'm also interested in what features people would find most useful, so to add the most value as quickly as possible. Thats just a start!

Interestingly, a friend of mine is Autistic and in residential care.  I went to see him a couple of weeks ago only to be told that he had a hospital appointment.   I was happy to go with him.  Unfortunately his carer who was driving him to the hospital was late so we were too late for the appointment.  The proposed system needs to be accessible to carers.
Great observation, reflection and build, Michael!
This is a useful observation. Looking forward to investigating how we can make that possible. Sharing information between parties can be difficult, but sometimes key
This is a great idea Tom.It is so useful for the workers and obviously it would improve the NHS. Congratulations!
Great idea - this is one of those rare win-win ideas. If executed well, it could save the NHS millions and be a much better patient experience. Good job!
Great idea, smartphone technology is the future for communications

An excellent concept to equip the NHS for the 21st century- a practical and efficient solution to the often protracted and frustrating business of making and changing appointments.  GP practices also need this.
Hurrah for DrDoctor! This is a great idea!

A great concept that can only act in benefiting all relevant parties. No doubt your experience working daily within the NHS has allowed you to identify the patients need for ownership of their own care.  Furthermore it seems this tool would act in saving the NHS valuable time and money by reducing late cancellations and non attendances, allowing resources to go further as a result.  A forward thinking initiative by a forward thinking team.
Fantastic concept which can only improve the administrative purposes of hospitals and allow patients to take ownership of their appointments! Superb work carried out by some highly talented guys.

Brilliant concept! Looking forward to the first version especially considering that it comes from the same guys who have won National awards streamlining and improving the NHS. All the best to the team at DrDoctor!
Great cartoon!

great idea - making patient life better and healthcare specialists' jobs easier and more efficient too. taking the hassle out of appointments is a no-brainer, as is reducing all the inefficiencies and waste in hospitals. i love the cartoon too!

comments.text: you could get a boundless energy from this, for the rest of the day
Boredom = stress, interesting I think there is something very true in this.

Agree with Bernhard. How could one combat both or eliminate one in order to facilitate a better, fun, enjoyable environment.... Smiling and humour has been linked to reducing stress, creating an enjoyable working environment and connecting one with others. Perhaps spontaneous witty messages manifesting a 'moment of joy' making one smile, think, question and temporarily forget their worries... Does the workplace offer squeezable tangible artefacts also proven to help relieve stress? Would a stress space be offered to shout, scream and get their worries off their chest? Would one relieve stress through a tangible form or through a virtual means? In a collective group or individually? ...

health_coaches_in_the_community_.description: Bupa sponsored course to become an accredited health coach open to all.  It would equip them with the skills to advise and support their family, friends and colleagues as they make a positive change in their health behaviours.
health_coaches_in_the_community_.creator: 06b51d45ed9615591a4674945a756773

comments.text: We absolutely love this idea and if you noticed, it is, and has been for a while, a key component of our Healthy Workplace initiative in India. We agree that the best influencer is a person within the community - "someone just like me". As such, in our take on this concept, we want to train regular employees in the company once we deem it as a Healthy Workplace, to become lifestyle coaches, teaching their fellow co-workers in 16 week sessions how to make exercise and diet part of their lives and prevent diabetes.

We hope you might take a look and join collaborative conversations on the following concepts:http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/workplace-health-buddies/http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/motivating-companies-to-become-engines-for-chronic-disease-prevention-/Let's get some cross-pollination going between these ideas and build upon the goodness that each has to offer!
very nice, this will bring healthier communities to us, and it can prove to be very educational for people that want to get fit!!

Hi Nadine, this is great.  I'm thinking about how it could have even more reach so, once an individual has attended the course and been 'accredited' they could use their new found coaching skills on friends and family as well as colleagues, thereby spreading their knowledge and support to a far wider network.
Love the 'accreditation' idea - makes this concept more scalable and spreadable!

Fantastic idea. Most offices have certified 'first-aid' and 'Occupation Health and Safety' staff, but this would be a much better inclusion. While first-aid coaches is a "reactive" measure, I love the "proactive" nature of this concept. Getting an organisation like Bupa (easily in partnership with a fitness centre) to sponsor the training and accreditation is a great incentive!

I think this idea has a lot of power; particularly if you build a variety of badge/certificate opportunities (nutrition, fitness, meditation, stress management, etc.) Ideally these courses could be long enough to really create a sense of commitment (it is generally recommended that 21-30 repetitions will make something habitual).  Since the goal is behavior change it will be key to give enough time for these changes to take place and then for post-program support be given to ensure continued adoption.

I think this is really interesting given that individuals within a work place will have their own 'crowd' and probably greater influence and permission to motivate them versus a stranger. I know that at IDEO, we can drum up a group of folks to go on a run, dance class etc with relatively little effort. Also like the potential for sharing the knowledge back out with the non-work community

health_coaches_in_the_community_.title: Health Coaches in the community

outdoor_gym.description: Development of outdoor gyms to encourage a healthy community in both work and the local community.
outdoor_gym.creator: 6a92cc847768907d5c1967628ff40ea4

comments.text: Hey Adam,Do you have any ideas about what specific sorts of outdoor gym structures would appeal to an adult audience?  While even kids' gyms can be hit or miss, I really can't think of ANY successful adult outdoor play equipment that's broadly successful.  Seems like that's a real opportunity if we can figure it out together.I'm drawn to physical play far more than the average adult, but my favorites are always the polyhedral rope gyms: http://bit.ly/UGx0Ke.I notice the most common adult-oriented outdoor equipment are the "fitness centers" that help people do standard exercises and calisthenics.  These are really lame in my humble opinion, and I've never seen anyone under the age of 60 use them.  Even then, only rarely!What about a grown-up seesaw?  Or something with industrial-strength elastics?  I'm imaging some sort of "spider web" feature where you could be timed on you ability to move through an elastic web to certain waypoints.  This is starting to sound like a great source for a lawsuit, which in my book is a always a good sign for fun...    :)

Love the idea of an adult seesaw! Did you see my inspiration? I suppose I should have posted it as a concept -- I didn't quite understand at the time! http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/the-anti-gym-play-park-for-adults-/Rock walls are one of my favorite things. I'm a university student and we have an indoor climbing gym. For a permanent outdoor feature, a bouldering wall could be installed. We have something similar -- no top rope or harnesses required. Effectively, it's just a short rock wall so you don't fall too far, with a squishy pad underneath. Soft rubber chips might work well outdoors, like they have at some kids' parks.

Outdoor gyms are great - there are quite a few dotted around in parks near to where I live and are popular! Currently, they're very basic machines (basic works!) but could we adapt that to the 21st century, maybe with technology? Could workers track progress (like Nike+) or could they compete with one another? Great concept and visual too.
Wohoo Adam. Great thoughts about accessibilty and democratising exercise!

nice theme of exercising and using outdoor space... how about perhaps utilising the urban environment and own workspace...Your surroundings is your gym! How many calories do you burn going up a flight of stairs? Is this increased if you take each stair and what about two stairs at a time? How about when you shake a bottle of water? Does walking from the station to work equal 10 minutes on the treadmill? What about if you are carrying a bag with a laptop?  perhaps one can question if it has to be a stipulated space or if everything is a gym...  love your idea of measuring satisfaction and activity...Will the employer reward the employee for making these subtle choices? A little goes a long way... Can you compete with other staff and employees to see who has had the healthiest week? Who walked the most this month? Or would you compete against yourself trying to out-perform the previous week? Would you incorporate eating habits and patterns? Would you score points for choosing an apple over a calorie fuelled snack? A great possible way of exercising, losing weight, staying fit, being healthy, collaborating with teammates, fellow employees, relieving stress, having fun at work, sharing experiences and building a healthy, happy community.

outdoor_gym.title: Outdoor Gym

community_canteen.description: A canteen in which employees are empowered to choose the meals that are provided
community_canteen.creator: 1df587aac917c8569ee1d683c1147a05

comments.text: Love this idea. It's a great way to bring everyone together to improve they're workplace.

I like the idea. To build, it could be another idea to enable employees to simply rate the food they eat from the canteen. It is a post-assessment instead of a pre-selected choice, which you propose. But it could also be as effective to allow people to rate (say, from 1 to 5 stars) a few metrics of the food they ate (health factor, presentation, quality, etc...). I would propose to do this via an app, and the person could be prompted when they walk into their work canteen.

Thanks Allison. I like your idea of rating the food by categories, and yes an app would be a good way to do this. The rating system would be fundamental to this concepts success so the more information that one could gain from it the better. Thanks.

Great idea, Jack! I never eat at my work cafeteria, but I might consider it if I had a vote in what is being offered. My building also has a restaurant in addition to the cafeteria. I think you have an opportunity for wider community (economic and health) impact by getting outside businesses involved in using this application and letting their customers participate in selecting lunch offerings as well. This would mean you don't lose all the people that will still leave the building regardless of what's in the cafeteria. Also means this app could be extended to companies that don't have cafeterias.

Thanks Areca. That is a great idea for expanding the concept beyond the cafeteria environment, and would also be a great way of helping this concept to reach smaller businesses with less resources available to them. Thank you that is a very interesting point to help develop this further.

Good idea, I especially like the reward 'treat' system. Its a great idea to get workers involved in all areas of the work place, which they may have taken for granted before. It will encourage workers to eat a healthier balanced diet if they choose the meals, making the dining experience more personal.

Thank you Tommy. I agree it is really important people feel a connection with their dining experience and it should be more personal. Do you have any suggestions that could make this system more effective or able to reach more people?

Great idea Jack. Allowing people to become involved in canteens will prevent the stereotypical canteen with low value foods containing high levels of fat, salt and sugar. It would encourage people to make better choices in what they eat for lunch introducing new healthy alternatives  which could be voted upon. Creating cohesion and collaboration between co-workers making them work together to improve the health within the workplace.

Thanks Lee, yes I think empowering people to have the choice to eat healthy as their own is very important, but creating an environment in which the healthy choices are tailored to many tastes is a way of encouraging healthy eating. Involvement is key for this concept but if the outcome is an improvement in workplace dining then there should be plenty of incentive to be actively engaged with a system like this.

This is a great idea.  Since oftentimes canteens are a source of collaboration in the form of complaints shared between coworkers, this concept could turn discussion towards positive change.  It might even start to connect coworkers offline, as participation and the experienced outcomes (i.e. meals served) could be the basis for smalltalk.  As a pilot, perhaps this could be tested via a simplified survey structure, or a facebook group using likes on pictures as a voting mechanism. To extend this idea beyond the company walls, the canteen could take the top voted meals of the month and open up to the local area residents for "a dinner at (company name)", sharing company healthy favorites and helping connect to the community.

Thank you Emily. I think that a facebook pilot would be an excellent way of testing the concept. I think empowering people to be actively involved in their meal times is very important. Connections with the community is equally important. Thanks for the great feedback!
Great Concept Could others concept to make Great Fruit juice to go along with the meals
Thanks Khushwant. Fruit juice would be an excellent addition to the concept!
Great Concept  What I meant to say could use others concept to make Great Fruit juice to go along with the meals

Sounds interesting Jack! To help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. Check this example: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/winners-announced/opencity-bringing-open-source-princi/ where a scenario is given to get people digging the goodness on a concept. You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.
Thanks for the advice Meena. I will get on it right away!

community_canteen.title: COMMUNITY CANTEEN

brain_food.description:
If breakfast is the most important meal of the day, what does that make lunch?
How many people brought lunch to work today? How many people ate at their desks today? How many people got exactly what they wanted for lunch?
brain_food.creator: 09c9825a62e9330a8d26f2f141092b28

comments.text: What people eat at work is largely determined by availability, so a proactive corporate role in providing healthy food options is good for employees and business in terms of a healthier, happier workforce.

Fantastic suggestion.I'm currently based in Australia and I am shocked at the poor choice available to me. From vending machines to local cafes where I work in the city. It's all bread, bread, bread - very hard to find healthy salads, or other options for lunch. Companies could do a lot by providing nutritional advise, subsidising healthy food options or rewarding healthy food choices. I love the connection to local farmers :-)

brain_food.title: Brain Food

smoke_a_carrot_stick....description:
Cigarette breaks for those that don’t smoke. 

“Taking breaks may feel like running away, but it isn’t: rather, it’s a way to refresh ourselves to dive back into the fight more effectively. So give yourself a break. A regular, active break.”
smoke_a_carrot_stick....creator: 2b7c8d8c9a1294b4d6acb9511a3bc414

comments.text: I have always felt that the non smokers in the work place get a raw deal. Its either smoke and get a break, or dont smoke and continue to work. I think this concept has clarity and allows those non smokers a chance to relax for a few minutes throughout the day. Good idea Will

Thanks Julian. I think at this point it's mainly to do with perceptions of breaks and smoking breaks and if there is a difference. Are there allotted times for breaks in general workplaces? How can we change this?
I also really like the idea of giving non-smokers a chance to relax for a few minutes. Hopefully with some incentives that may be able to happen!
Great concept, I like the idea of listen the favourites song during the last time of the break.

Yes it has proven to be popular and the greatest thing about it is that songs usually last between 2-3 minutes which is the perfect time for a a break (so bosses don't get angry!). Thanks for your input Jordi.
Really clever idea Will. It links with the saying "Rest is key" that little breath of fresh air and time out will re energise any worker. Great stuff

Thank you Chris. I agree that fresh air and rest can bring greater results from people. At your workplace, what are the facilities like and are you able to take a short break? Would you and your colleagues benefit?

No problem. At my workplace only if you are a smoker you can go for little breaks. In between your official breaks such which is every 4 hours, 15 minutes rest. I think it would benefit hugely especially around busy periods such as Christmas when stress levels are very high customer based and worker. For example: Christmas just gone if i was a smoker i would have been outside every hour.. So the idea of taking a few minutes just to think and regather yourself would improve the whole way you feel before, during and after work. Hope this helps Will.

Wow thanks Chris. I agree with the breaks giving a morale boost and minimising stress at busy times. If we could incorporate this into workplaces and help to make it acceptable then i'm sure we can help to create healthier workplaces.

Nice Ideas, somewhat similar to my concept, (Oxygen Break - Smoking Breaks for Non Smokers). Its great to see the different angle you have taken, and how our ideas differ. I like how you have introduced hot beverages and healthy snacks as an incentive for non smokers to take a break.
Thanks Tommy - yes I agree; anything that can get workers out to enjoy some time out is certainly a positive!

I really like this concept.  It is interesting that cigarette smokers are somewhat incentivized for unhealthy behavior because it creates an excuse for them to take a break.  It would be great if companies could structure in the alternatives.  For example, placing snacks in outside areas, which prompts people to get fresh air and step away from their desk.

Thanks for your input Evan. I agree with giving workers an incentive or reason to get outside and take a break. Fresh air is a proven solution to some problems such as stress and a few short breaks can increase productivity. What's the situation like at your workplace? And what would get you to take a break?

I worked for a firm where all the bosses smoked - all decisions and posting were decided in the smoking shelter....  How many firms are like this - loads - I like this idea cause it works to change this..  Good job.

Thank you for your thoughts Paul - It's really great to hear this from someone with first hand experience and seeing this in their workplace. If we make these 'thinking spaces' more adaptable then they could create better results in workplaces!

I love this idea Will. Smokers often get breaks throughout the day to help release a little stress, why can't these breaks be healthy rather than harmful? I love the idea of introducing a sense of luxury by using fine china making the break time that little bit more celebrated. Great concept!
A quick blast of my favourite song, what a cool idea! Could we include a dance floor?

Hi Jack - thanks for your input. I think that by giving workers some sort of reward or incentive to get away from their workspace for a few minutes and take a quick break. Luxury items may be one of those... are there any more? What would get you up and out for a few minutes away from your workspace?Hi Beth - thanks for your input. The song idea was something which I thought of when I was taking a break. I realised that by giving myself a time limit, I was more likely to savour the time more efficiently and by listening to one of my favourite songs, I'd enjoy it too! There could be various ways that we could make this happen from simply having signs encouraging to having music ports where you could plug and play your device or select music from a stationary screen. I hadn't thought of including dance floors - that's a great idea! It could really encourage workers to get outside (or just away from their workspace) and have a fun few minutes. It would also help blow off some steam. Thanks for the great thoughts Beth, keep them coming!

I think for me some form of entertainment or maybe be even a home comfort would make me take a break. Perhaps workers could bring a home comfort with them to work (provided it is healthy). Music is also a great comfort, when you here a song you like it really lifts spirits!

Brilliant, love it! Could transform office spaces too

permission_to_take_a_break.description: Many people rush lunch breaks. We might dash to the nearest fast food restaurant, or true workaholics may skip lunch altogether.
permission_to_take_a_break.creator: e71ca4a9bf140eee52eee72061a84d5d

comments.text: Nice idea.  It becomes hard to think straight when you've been looking at the same screen for hours! Actually taking your break at lunch can only help your mind-set.

Good spot re: the importance of lunch breaks (he says sat at his computer on OpenIDEO during a lunch break...). Wonder if there are any IT solutions to basically shut systems down over a lunch break period, or get managers to effectively close their office. I find even when I have a full lunch break time, the lure of the online world (shopping, emails, twitter, Batman sites) way too tempting.

Thanks for your thoughts, Alexander. At least you've made a start by taking time off work. The next stage is to pull yourself away from the computer! One solution to the problem would be for managers / supervisors to change their attitude towards lunch. Once they realise the benefits of taking their full lunch allowance, they're more likely to pass the message on to their employees. The characteristics of the boss also has an impact; if he/she sets rules over lunch breaks, and takes the hard line, their employees have no choice other than to abide by the rules. I see IT solutions that shut down computer systems being necessary to those individuals who work independently. If you work in a company with numerous employees, what's your bosses view on taking a lunch break?
I think this is a great concept Sam, I've recently started making sure I thank my full hour break and have noticed a real difference.
Hi, Claire. Thanks for your feedback. It's great to see people are taking time out of their day to recharge their batteries, to make for a productive afternoon.

I really like the idea Sam. Promoting that the workers take their full lunch break is a great idea.  As currently there are probably many companies where the employees work through their lunch break so aren't having a rest period during the day. Which must effect there work that they do.
Thanks, Chris! Exactly my thoughts.

Nice idea Sam. Yes work is important but break is equally important too and to encourage employees to take their full lunch break is a good idea. Like Chris mentioned a resting period for your body can have significant effect on how you continue the rest of your day.

permission_to_take_a_break.title: Permission To Take A Break

chipotle_rewards_its_managers_for...deve.description: Chipotle's Restauranteur program (for General Managers who build excellent restaurants) rewards employees based on how well they develop happy, engaged, empowered teams.
chipotle_rewards_its_managers_for...deve.creator: 23fcfb2eccb65e426ed18995810db074

comments.text: Interesting inspiration, looking forward to seeing a deveopled concept of this.

Really interesting, AshleyI read an article in Australia recently which looked at the impact managers have on employees health (leading by example) then identified that they are themselves the unhealthiest employees! That has a huge impacthttp://www.smh.com.au/national/health/too-many-managers-lead-way-on-poor-health-20121101-28mxk.htmlMANAGERS might be called ''fat cats'' for a reason. They are among the unhealthiest employees in New South Wales.Managers had higher levels of drinking and low fruit and vegetable intake, and about 70 per cent of them were physically inactive.I think it is also interesting that a "one size fits all" approach to health at work doesnt work - targeting messages is really important

chipotle_rewards_its_managers_for...deve.title: Chipotle rewards its managers for...developing other managers

bring_outside_inside..description: Using windows and mirrors to reflect the outside environment into your workplace.
bring_outside_inside..creator: f591c182c288c70704a72c863ad3fdeb

comments.text: The idea of bringing nature from outside to inside a work place using mirrors really draws my interest. This is great concept Andre. Employees will feel more relaxed in that kind of environment rather than being surrounded by plain colours. Keep up the good work.
Good concept Andre, Interesting way of bringing nature inside a working space. I agree with the fact that the workers will feel less stressed and healthy at the same time, great work!

"A system of displayed mirrors that reflects, through windows, the natural outside environment, workers will experience this in their working area, during daytime."I dont quite understand that statement.However the following makes sense, i get where your coming from and i do agree that the environment we work in does have a great effect on your mental wellbeing.My main concern like you mentioned would we, how applicable would this be to various workplaces. e.g. a large company in the city might not have such a good view because its crowded.The small company might also face the same problem.
That is why, as I explained, a vertical garden outside the building would solve the problem.
The titles of two songs I heard explain it all :"Let the sunshine in" and "Everybody loves the sunshine". I like that you avoid technology to bring  interesting scenes into the workplace.

bring_outside_inside..title: Bring outside, inside.

comments.text: Being able to keep track of our fitness whilst performing our normal daily routine is beneficial for everyone. I think this concept is great motivation for users by visually showing them how well they have performed each day.

Very catchy name for the idea :) Very nice! It reminds a little of teh concept of life-coaching ;)

Hi, Gaia.  Thanks for the comment.  Now, that you mention it , I think you're right.  I think that there is a life coaching element here.  I used to blog around the topic of LifeWorkouts, a holistic approach to living life...and you caught the influence.  Thanks for sharing. ;-)
I applaud your innovative ideas! I value your desire to make an impact, as Salt & Light, in this world void of God's transforming power!
Thank you, Alex.

Great share, Una! You might also be interested in this post on Walk Stations: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/moving-always.../ Looking forward to seeing you on more conversations across this challenge!
This is great. I knew more than one person figured out how to do this!
Hopefully in the upcoming Concepting phase, folks can think of innovative ways to scale and incentivise initiatives. Looking forward to seeing what folks come up with!
this along with more natural light and air - close to a window perhaps so the person working breaths clean air as opposed to the dusty office air as it is in most offices.

meetalith_outdoor_public_work_circles.creator: 14768bda906a02dc9cfb1395d708758a

comments.text: I love this Alek. There is a real sense of connection to the outdoors that comes with areas like these. Stone Henge for the masses not just druids, hippies and tourists. I love the idea of involvement among local communities and creating a sense of ownership to hopefully reduce vandalism and damage. Perhaps these could be made even more accessible to urban areas without much green space by incorporating public art style circles. These could also be used as a tool to make use of and inject some life and activity to derelict areas. Great stuff!

Splendidly on the money as always jack, It does spring to mind that these circles could be a little more disconnected slightly more from its current levels of druidyness. The art circles could make welcome additions to those deprived areas. Perhaps it would make each one all the more interesting as Unique public spaces to the respective area.
I dont mean to be negative, but this seems to me, to be a rather terrible idea, are you sure you have thought this through? I am interested to know if your really cut out for this sort of work??

Thank you for your kind constructive feedback Zed, You'll be quite happy to know that I am just as cut out for this line of work as your lovely self, I'm even capable of using your & you're correctly. As for the project, I believe that the concept may require a bit of tweaking to perfect. Therefore I have added you to my virtual team so you can continue to provide your excellent insights.
Thats what your mum said.
yes, yes she did zed.
Getting everyone outside sounds like a great way to escape the chaos of the workplace! The graphic is nice an clear too!!
Great concept and good extra information add on the right side about which inspirations and concepts inspired you!Good work! :)

Great concept Alek, It will be really nice to have offices outdoors especially in summer as you have mentioned. Working in fresh air will keep every one healthy, happy and refreshed. Most people hate to work indoors during summer when theres a beautiful weather outside and they have to miss it, this concept will really work. Nice one!!

Really like the concept and its historic references. This public space, location wise, goes beyond the workplace and appeals to users beyond the workforce, bringing the community together. I also like how you have outlined the considerations, shows you have thoroughly thought this through.

Fantastic post Alek!  Here's a quick tip: we're starting to see a couple of related inspirations around working outdoors and you might want to connect them to your post using the Build Upon feature. This helps us all join the dots between related posts and will show up on your Collaboration Map for this post. Plus you'll get more DQ points!. Hit the Update button on the right of your post, then scroll down to Build Upon. Search terms like outdoors, parks, etc. and drag anything relevant over to your Build Upon field. Keep up the great work!

kill_those_germs......_before_they_kill_.description: 80% of infection diseases are spread by touch, research from the British Toilet Association shows that 30% of the general public do not wash their hands after using the toilet and 88% do not wash their hands for long enough to kill germs.
kill_those_germs......_before_they_kill_.creator: 9c05dd5bb434d8f313650d1b0fa7c556

comments.text: Good concept Risha! hygiene in the workplace is very important germs do spread very quick from the use of keyboards etc... A well thought concept

Great concept! I love the strap line! Working environments are one of the worst places for spreading viruses. Implementing this simple but effective idea and preventing illness within the workplace will have many benefits. I like the idea of maybe developing this concept into automatic anti bacterial gel dispensers or adapting one of the suggested ideas. Good idea Risha. :)
Great Idea from my understand Men are worst about hygiene, so that a good place to start
If i was to test this product I would definitely be starting there. Thanks Khushwant.

Would be a great add-on to public restrooms as an additional product line sold alongside other innovative restroom appliances (waterless urinals, paperless hand dryers). Particularly useful application in food prep environments such as company cafeterias and restaurants. I wonder if this solution is cost effective; have an idea as to costs involved to manufacture at scale?
I like the idea of this device being used in food prep environments and potentially hospitals too. I'm not too sure about the costs involved but I will definitely look into this. Thanks Dylan

Like the idea Risha! I agree with the previous comments that it could take some degree of time to make sure that your hands are completely clean before leaving the restroom. Maybe you could integrate this into the working environment. Maybe at the desk over the keyboard as I've heard that is one of the worst areas where germs accumulate. Nice visuals as well!
Thanks Lee! That is a great idea, could be integrated into a desk lamp or maybe into a portable device to check for bacteria on the move.

I like the concept a lot. Creating an environment where bacteria and germs are reduced has all sorts of benefits. However maybe you can slightly re-direct your approach as to how you go about it. These sensors may be quite expensive to set up and only really tell people to go back and wash their hands. A user doing this would only go back and touch the taps and spread bacteria and germs.Instead of having a bacteria scanner, why not introduce an automatic anti-bacterial gel dispenser device. Nowadays every toilet has automatic air hand dryers and most toilets have automatic taps where waving your hand in front of the sensor on a tap would trigger the water to pour from the tap. If this could be implemented into a anti-bacterial dispenser then people would be sure that they have killed 99.9% of bacteria without spreading it anywhere else.This could be a very good concept, great work Risha

I like the idea of automatic anti bacterial gel dispensers. I'm not too sure how much a UV device would cost, but if i was to integrate the light into an existing device such as taps could reduce the costs. Thanks Jonathan

Interesting idea. I like the attention grabbing introduction. However, for employees to wash their hands until they are completely clean may take a few attempts, and a long time spent in the toilet. This may result in long queues for the sink. This may encourage people to skip washing their hands altogether.
This is a interesting point, the UV light could be integrated into the actual taps. Therefore you are able to see and remove the bacteria clearly. Thanks Sam

A great concept though you might need to look further into the use of UV light in detecting bacteria, is it feasible or some microscopic viewer is needed to be integrated into the proposed handheld UV ray device.
Thanks Ernest ill look into the different types of UV lights available

kill_those_germs......_before_they_kill_.title: KILL THOSE GERMS...... before they kill you!

comments.text: I really like the idea of forcing people to take breaks, or rather stopping them from working. Maybe there is a way of letting you know you have a break coming up, so you can prepare for it, with out obviously pestering you by reminding you how much more work time you have left.
What a cool app, I like the way your visual looks, also the suggestions features is what makes this app good, its versatile as people who work from home can use this app aswell.

This is a great idea, as were becoming a world obsessed with technology why not use it to our advantage and promote a healthier lifestyle. This is a concept that would be easy to integrate into a workplace and I would definitely use this app! lovely concept.
As someone who spends way too much time wasting time on her phone, I would definitely use this app! Great idea Rachel and I love the visuals of the app

This concept is an interesting way of using technology to be healthier. Its great that various communication products can be used for this app/website, which means not only people who work in an office, but people who work from home can benefit from this aswell.
