how_does_my_health_compare_.creator: 06b51d45ed9615591a4674945a756773

comments.text: I think it is a nice idea. My applauses.

Hey there Nadine  If you're interested in pursuing your idea further, you might want to check out the Knight News Challenge. They're focusing on the topic of health and the winning entries will receive grant funding to bring ideas to life. You can check it out here http://kng.ht/1aunB0h.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel felt that the big challenge here is considering how we'll get all the input and standardise it. Potentially worth partnering with organisations such as NikeID and supplementing with other information?  Where else might the data come from?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Great idea! Possible add - ratings could combine both overall health and improvement. The farther away from ideal health, the more improvement is weighted, and the closer you get to ideal health, the more overall fitness is weighted. It's a way to level the playing field and make sure the platform is inclusionary of all.I think this is great for large companies that have a health initiative or goal in place (active.com might be a perfect testing ground and their partners/sponsors are all very health conscious companies as well). My concern is with smaller companies where it would be pretty easy to determine who fits which anonymous profile - so it might make sense to make it possible to join by geography, but increase access to information if you add in your workplace (like glassdoor, the more info you give, the more you see).Congrats on a great idea!

Re: the small company issue and maintaining anonymity, how about broadening not by geography but by sector, and specifically by job type.My mom works IT for a small construction company which has an office and a large crew of outdoor workers. The users could then choose to join the group "Construction Industry" to be compared to other similar companies, or perhaps could join an "Office Clerk Role" group which compares them to other office workers, regardless of industry.

Hi Nadine,I love the simplicity of this concept, by pure coincidence I stumbled across the BBC world BMI international comparison tool earlier today. The BBC tool is very quick and easy to use and it gives a quirky comparison. However it isn't particularly accurate as BMI's aren't an accurate way to test obesity. For example weightlifters or bodybuilders would be considered obese but in reality have very low body fat. It would be good if you could enter more detailed information but in the continued clean and simple theme, such as the type of sports regularly participated in even fat pinch measurements which are actually a very good way of indicating levels of fat on the body.--> http://www.livestrong.com/body-fat-pinch-test/Obviously this wouldn't apply to everyone but their needs to be a way to make it more accurate rather than just a fun tool.Anyway, best of luck, looking forward to seeing how this is developed.Jon

The idea certainly has a lot of potential and could definitely get to be a value-adding feature for bupa. However, there already are similar online tools that allow you to understand your overall well being in comparison to others (I'm thinking of websites such as Livestrong.com, or NikeID). I think in a way the challenge has more to do with how you keep the user consistently aware of his progress, particularly with something as challenging and long-term as health and weight. One option could be to design this as a computer 'app' that is consistently running on the background and notifies you when you have reached one of many potential short term goals (such as, for instance, consume less than 2000 calories today, or eat a certain amount of fruits and veggies in a week, etc.). What is more, you could also present this information in a rather unconventional way-- saying, for instance, "Today you consumed 600 less calories than your previous average. This is equivalent to a light bulb running for 'x' amount of hours. If your entire neighborhood [refer to user's zip code here] did this, you could light up 'x' amount of houses for a day", or something of the sort (something that creates more of a narrative that the user can immediately relate to, as opposed to just saying "Today you consumed 1400 calories"). This approach is somewhat similar to what was recently developed by mint.com to keep users aware of both their short term (daily and weekly) and long term (yearly) financial goals investments, both online, as a computer app, and as a mobile platform.

Hey Nadine,I have put together a quick Survey for the comparative element of my 'Glassdoor for Health and Fitness App'. A bit of the content is derived from building on your above concept. Will be happy to share all the data with you when (if!) it starts rolling in. Would be great if you could help spread the link to this survey too! Many thanks!http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/KFQPNGT
Results are up on my Glassdoor page.. they are encouraging.. hope they can be of help to you too!

James, brilliant idea. The two ideas are certainly stronger together and I was really impressed by the survey that you produced. As you can see, i've tried to weave the services together more in the refined concept post. Thanks! Nadine
Lovely refinements. Coming across your concept really helped me turn a corner with mine. Let's hope something comes of them both!
Nice one on the collaborative refinements, Nadine!

I'd also love to see a couple of user scenarios added to your post of how folks might interact with this idea and the benefits they could draw from it. We've seen some great examples across the challenge of this and it really helps ideas engage and shine. Here's an example to get you thinking: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/winners-announced/opencity-bringing-open-source-princi/

Great concept. I like the idea of making it anonymous for the users and using the system as more of a comparison tool rather than a competition tool. Knowing where you are less healthy and what activities makes the user more healthy is a stepping stone for the user to find improvements in their day to day work life.
Thanks Jonathan, I agree that anonymising the data is particularly important if this is going to be used in a corporate context. Thanks for your support, Nadine

...Beautiful idea! And this system could have an added value and go beyond calculation. Storytelling health, could be used to introduce best practices of how people with similar health conditions to the one detected actually succeeded in overcoming the health challenges. And the collective efforts of co-workers, family and friends should also be emphasized in this process, in order to increase participation and show more strongly how much is health actually social :)

Gaia, what a great build on the idea. This is a really nice way of continuing to develop a rapport with users of the site and helping them find new ways to overcome their health challenges. I've included this idea in my refined concept. Thanks, Nadine
Excellent idea
Thanks Justin, I appreciate the support for the idea.

I really think you're onto something here Nadine. On an individual level it would be interesting to see how you compare with your colleagues, but I think an even more powerful use of this data collection could be comparing company averages and medians.As well as comparing the benefits package a company is offering, can you imagine be able to glance into the actual real-life health consequences of working in a particular environment? If individual were able to weigh up the health and well-being of existing employees against one another from company to company, it could act as a powerful incentive for companies to take more repsonsibility for suppplying workers with the adequate tools and environment to look after themeselves better.I have posted some similar thoughts through a related concept below.. maybe the two could work together really well!http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/glass-door-for-health-and-fitness-rating/The one caveat - if data on existing company health was made available, there would have to be some kind of fail-safe whereby people with chronic conditions are not discriminated against at interview stage for fear of affecting a company's statisitcs. I am sure there are ways though!

James, I read this reply after I posted on your concept. Nice to see you also thought about discrimination.Nadine, great idea!With this kind of data available, and knowing that health issues costs the society a tremendous amount of money (cardiovascular disease, heart disease, cancer, mental illness) the government could give benefits or lower taxes for companies that reach a certain threshold.If a government or state would say; we'll lower income tax with 1% for companies with a health&fitness rating above 85%, I bet a lot of companies would start measuring and improving health right away.
Brilliant suggestion Wout. That would certainly help to motivate the company as well as the individual. Thank you, I've added your suggestion to the refined concept. Nadine

Fab concept Nadine.  This could be a really powerful tool to help motivate people to be healthier.  I was thinking a way to prototype it could ask people to opt in to a pilot test and use their real data to manually prepare some interesting comparisons and send them weekly updates.  The automation of the whole thing could even wait until after the initial group helps tweak and refine the process.
Thank Nathan, great suggestion for the pilot. I've integrated your idea into my refinement. Many thanks,Nadine

Nice concept! Is a good way to encorage people to be more healthier. Also it could be posible to give tips and motivational phrases so the website it would be more attractive for those who are not used to have a healthy lifestyle.
Great idea, there is something interesting that caught my eye

college_students_trained_to_deliver_heal.description: Charitable organisation Peer Health Exchange gives teenagers the knowledge and skills they need to make healthy decisions - by training college students to teach a comprehensive health curriculum in public high schools.
college_students_trained_to_deliver_heal.creator: b3effac10dd2bc451e0d2641f24e2a1d

comments.text: Teenagers need these types of authentic conversations. As a high school teacher, I can tell you that there's a lot of value in kids hearing positive messages from a variety of sources. In fact, the "slightly-older peer" idea strikes me as similar to another widely held best practices in education, Vygotsky's "More-capable peer" concept, whereby people can learn the most from a peer who is just slightly more advanced. The "zone of proximal development," I believe he calls this. Having outside professionals come in and talk to kids is a fantastic idea. Often times there are important things that we teachers want to tell our students but can't, no matter how young we might be. Perhaps the structure and dynamic of the institution just makes it so. Also there are many issues, legal, ethical and otherwise just tend to get in the way of these types of authentic conversations. But teenagers definitely need these types of positive mentors and "real" conversations - this seems like a fantastic idea!  What if every school had people like this coming in on a regular basis, not only to talk about health, but other important topics as well? Perhaps an antidote to Holden Caulfield syndrome?

Fab P2P inspiration, Beth! And folks might like to check out this youth-oriented P2P initiative from elsewhere in the world: http://bit.ly/10JASho  not focused on health but still inspiring about the potential for this avenue.

college_students_trained_to_deliver_heal.title: College students trained to deliver health messages to high school students in peer to peer exchange

shared_lunch_with_healthy_recipe_exchang.description: Help coworkers from visiting unhealthy fast food chains and indulging in excess calories for lunch. Create a healthy lunch recipe exchange. Have folks sign up for the challenge and bring in one main dish, but eat for the whole week.
shared_lunch_with_healthy_recipe_exchang.creator: d1ae42cadb4aa797eec3a709bad99487

comments.text: This is an interesting approach to healthy eating. If the test case was conducted on employees that always leave the office, it might help to prepare them with resources (recipe sites, how to create a balanced dish, etc.) and give them extra time in advance of cooking. I know when I tend to eat out more, it's because I haven't had a chance to run to the store for staple ingredients or have been too busy to find an ideal recipe. After they've had time to plan, they could ease into it with maybe two lunches a week and working up to each person doing a dish on a given day. I like your idea of creating health guidelines for the dish and I would add allergies and intolerances to that list. Having a plethora of resources for gluten free allergies and others would help those that aren't accustomed to cooking specialized dishes. Also, what would be done if someone didn't like the dish? I think it would also help to set a budget early on or make the sign-up voluntary at first to get all the kinks worked out. I think smaller groups of 5 would work best because most recipe sites are for families between 4-6, so that seems ideal considering servings and budget. All of this also helps if co-workers eat the dish together and it gives them a reason to bond. I also think what you said about tracking energy levels and other outcomes is great because if it does work out, it gives people more attainable results and reason to eat well.

Thanks Naomi for the comment! I love that you brought up allergies and food intolerance because I have Celiac disease and I eat gluten free. Feeding myself is always a chore. IF lunch teams are kept to 5 people as you suggest it would be easy for teams to have a pow wow about what can be eaten and what cannot as a team. I also like getting support from the workplace about providing recipes and easy access to ingredients!

shared_lunch_with_healthy_recipe_exchang.title: Shared LUNCH with Healthy Recipe Exchanges and Potlucks with Co-workers.

healthy_hotels.creator: ea730fd6255c151bd2c2ee17476fd39e

comments.text: Great idea. I'm in a hotel 2 days a week, every week. Do I ever relate to what you're saying! I wonder if Marriott might be interested. They have several different specialized hotel formats. Why not another Marriott format that implements exactly what you are saying?The comments from Paul, below, bring up a good point... The cost factor. I think the intriguing question is whether this could be viable and yet still keep the price low. There would need to be trade-offs to reduce costs in some areas in order to add amenities in other areas. I think the easiest target for trimming cost without sacrificing quality of experience would be to reduce room size dramatically. Do regular business travelers really need large rooms, especially if there are great communal and social activities available outside the room, such as gyms, etc.?

I have had enough of travelling to poor hotels that only offer food that is laden in fat and sugar - this will be a bigger challenge to the lower end hotels that many work travellers are now obliged to use due to curbs on corporate spending......

comments.text: I also feel much more productive and focused in rural places when working with a team. This is a great idea, in fact you can immediately start developing it as a concept which would definitely merge with HUB Global.

That's a great inspiration, FelipeI had the benefit, when living in Melbourne a few years ago, of working from the Melbourne Hub. I found it a brilliant way of connecting with like minded people. Whilst this was certainly not rural, there's a lot to be said for connection in cities too, which can often be quite isolating at times. The space was filled with natural light, plants, music and laughter - I was really happy and productive working there. I wonder if there's something in the informality of these spaces that is worth exploring. There is also a focus on support and collaboration, creativity and connection - a great reminder that mental health is equally important as physical.

bupa_openhealth_platform.description: The OpenHealth platform keeps you informed of your health status in real-time via a tracker implant, passing on direct, personalised feedback. The platform is freely accessible globally, until the point of access to healthcare.
bupa_openhealth_platform.creator: 10a203cc95e80240480837bc10448ef0

comments.text: Fab use of video Fiona!  You've created a completely compelling vision for the platform.  I'd love to hear more about how you could do a prototype of this platform for experimentation.  Perhaps focusing in on something like workplace illness first could help make the amount of information you need to track easier to start with.  Look forward to hearing back from you.

Thanks Nathan, i'm so glad you like the concept and video. It would certainly be great to prototype the OpenHealth platform and i agree the workplace would be a good place to start. Perhaps Bupa would be up for doing a live prototype in their offices? If we could get a good enough digital platform working we could trial it in IDEO and our offices too....any other ideas?

Mega-applause! Congrats! Your visuals are awesome. But the idea still booms through nice and loud.As a prototype, how about you simply start by tracking blood sugar levels? I am just thinking that bombarding people with all their vital signs at once could be a bit of an overload, and even a scare for some of the hypochondriacs out there.Monitoring blood sugar levels also provides a great foundation for distributing preventative healthcare and medical advice; when blood sugar is in danger of dropping too low, users receive a warning to top up with some slow-release calories. Diabetics are already using this technology, but I have been thinking for a while that if this combination  of data collection and nutritional information is accurate enough, you could have on your hands a world-beating weight control device.Scenario: A user sees his blood sugar level cruise up nicely into the safe zone as he heads into work after a healthy spinach omlette for breakfast. He is getting peckish at around 11, and wonders how a selection of different snack options might affect him; he sees that if he were to grab a chocolate bar, he'd pick up very quickly, feel great until 1145, then drop off steadily before becoming ravenous before lunch, at which point he'd probably overestimate his lunch needs. He also see that If he chooses a handful of mixed nuts though, he's likely to see his energy rise more slowly, but maintain itself steadily through to 1pm without suffering a crash from the sugar spike. Allowing the user to make informed choices about diet would be incredible; great idea! Hope the implants can be made available to all before too long! Good luck with getting to refinement stage!

Fiona, Bupa is considering all of these ideas and selecting which ones are most exciting as they move into Refinement and the Winning Concepts phases.  In the meantime prototyping something out certainly shows your commitment to it and sends an encouraging signal to the sponsor.  Is there a way you could prototype it without them during the challenge?  This may pique their interest in continuing to collaborate after the challenge ends.

Great video, very informative. When it comes to the system the thought is nice, i have concerns when it comes to implants, that even advert a particular product. Companies could abuse the system to raise their sales?Could even result in stress like "OMG i hope it does not beep", there are a lot of people who do not see a doctor on regular base but still they are very healthy.Please correct me if i got it wrong.

I agree, Bernhard. Implants tend to scare people away and close the corridore of acceptance even if the idea is a good one. Perhaps the concept could be presented in a way that minimizes this reaction?

Such a great concept, Fiona. It reminds me of a cross between a home energy monitor (I'm the new owner of an Owl monitor http://www.theowl.com/products/intuition.html) and the Nike fuel band; a produc that we enjoy using, provides us with interesting information and benefits us?I'm sure that the general public would be happy to use a platform which they could ignore/forget about until they needed to check their health. No one wants an intrusive device which needs regular checking or is demanding of time. Simple suggestions and recommendations on how to run your day has a real need. Especially for those trying to diet or solve a health problem. Could blood pressure tablets be eliminated if people understood how to do this naturally (change diet/habits, take up exercise etc etc)?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Really good find. Having a goal that supports a larger good is a great way to build community and sustain motivation. Reminds me of initiatives such as Team in Training supporting Leukemia and Lymphoma or the Hero Workouts at CrossFit that honor fallen soldiers/police officers.
Fantastic initiative. Love the combination of health and community. Look good, feel good - all at the same time!
Congrats on this post being today's Featured Inspiration!

Amazing project! I like that it gives two options of participation - group runs and mission runners. I also think the name "coaches" is great, it shows the older or vulnerable people as the ones actually helping the runners, gives them a lot of respect.I think it could be a great inspiration also for the "Singapore" challenge!
Into itreaching out to "isolated" people makes for a neat take on the group-run meet-up.
Awesome insights and provocations for further thinking here, Suzy!
I especially like the consideration they've given to incentives, motivations and nudges. Everyone knows that getting active is important for health  but most of us need a good prod to get going!

comments.text: Really good idea Haytham, I really like the points system you're proposing. Great work!
Thanks Asma :)

This is really great stuff!!!! and I very much like the comments about the "human factors" in which the potential business model is based. While reading, I had an association about the "life coach" model. Maybe this could be useful here to further develop the typology and the  methodology of work of "healthy partners" that could be seen as "life coaches"...Awesome, really!!!!

Well, a mixture of human and technological factors is needed. More knowledge about "life coach" model is vital and LIVE application should be monitored. My inquiry again; what will be the measurable tool? Participation? Change in BMI for example? Less medical visits?Thankshaytham
Really nice idea, Haytham. Well done!
Thanks Beth :)

This looks great guys; I really like the iterations and the direction that this is heading in.  Ive read quite a few great concepts in this challenge, all of which I feel do a great job addressing the design problem at hand.  However what I think sets this concept apart is that it is the foundation for a great business model.  The concept has the potential to offer great financial and emotional value in peoples daily lives, which is the first major step in business model development (value capture).  Before we move on we must know exactly what our concept/company does, and what resources we need to provide our services  I believe that at our core, we would be a medical tech start-up than anything else as we offer nothing tangible besides what maybe a rewards card.    The next big step (after much more refinement and research) would be to use our networks (Bupa, Ideo, etc.) to develop business partnerships with companies associated with our healthy lifestyle.  These partnerships would render our organization business model nearly irreplaceable with is a key aspect in all business.  I look forward to really putting in some work on this this weekend.  Good work guys!Kareem

I like this phrase much "These partnerships would render our organization business model nearly irreplaceable with is a key aspect in all business"; this is the core of the concept. Thanks Kareem.Haytham

workspace_design_that_is_both_quiet_and_.description: Open concept offices do not work for every business. Design quiet spaces designated for work with soundproofed cubicles and "quiet work area" signs. Have a separate area with tables, chairs, TV, etc. to break from work and chat with colleagues.
workspace_design_that_is_both_quiet_and_.creator: 5c721798c073cb92d98511271e5e6327

comments.text: Great, comprehensive ideas. I love that this concept considers break areas part of the workspace, it's such an important part of networking and connecting in larger office. I was part of a quickly growing, 200+ office and one of the best networking opportunities was the conversion of a meeting room into a "Rock Band" studio.

Excellent concept. One very important thing to consider here is the co-existence of introverts and extroverts. These are very different personalities and have very different preferences. Healthy communities and workplaces should consider and cater to their different needs. Your concept makes room for this.

I think I would add to this concept by suggesting creating work space that caters to the variety of communicative needs a company has.  For example, my school library at Teachers College is broken off into 3 floors.  The first floor is utilized more for resources and instruction from library staff, the 2nd floor is literally called the collaboration space.  This is a boisterous place where students come together to discuss their group projects.  The third floor is the dead silent, I'm studying, don't talk to me, area.  All 3 floors serve a function that collectively provides the perfect work area for each student's needs.  I believe this can be translated further in the physical work place, even by simply rethinking of how a conference room could be retooled.  Awesome concept Brian!  This could spin off in so many ways!
Congrats Brian  on giving everyone lots to think about on the very first Concept on our Workplace Wellness Challenge!

workspace_design_that_is_both_quiet_and_.title: Workspace design that is both quiet and collaborative

work_n_wellbeing_app.description: Have fun with your workmates and get fit!
work_n_wellbeing_app.creator: 996c762de35de859ba8d34edd96afaff

comments.text: Hi Seyhan,I really like the concept, the visuals are clear and concise. Getting everyone involved in fitness activities can be hard as some people simply just don't enjoy physical activity, this may be due to confidence, lack of skill, laziness or they just enjoy other less strenuous ways to spend their time! Maybe you could incorporate an 'introductory' section to the app which might encourage people to try new things. People could sign up with co-workers or they could possibly see who has already signed in. These introductory session could teach the basics, safety and serve as a way to gauge what skill level different people are at. Could be a great way to encourage people to try new things and meet new people/colleagues.Good luck with your concept!Jon

Hi Jon, thanks for the comments I agree with you about people may not be so keen on trying out sports and exercises. I really like the idea of basic training and calculating what skill level people are at, but this also has the downsides. Having thought about this in depth, for example if the stronger groups of people are divided and the less skilled are divided this could automatically create negative impact on the less skilled people, they may feel less able or intimidated by their physically superior colleagues (divisions in groups etc) and this may result in them not using the app and not getting no exercise done at all. Dividing people into groups can always arouse sorts of problems. In my opinion I think the app is already good in the aspect of organizing events with workmates, so its best to give the freedom on what exercises people want to do and who to do it with.Please let me know what you think..Thanks for the comment it got me thinking :)

I agree, you certainly wouldn't want any negative impacts on group dynamics, however speaking from experience as a sports coach trying to involve people of different abilities in group activities doesn't always work especially in team sports. On the other hand their are some sports/activities that can be done together and work very well. For example check out an activity called 'Crossfit'. It is a new activity that has become hugely popular, it allows people of all levels, ability, strength and endurance to work together and It has very fast results on fitness and well being. Reebok have also bought into the franchise which has given the sport a huge injection of cash and notoriety.Anyway, best of luck Seyhan! Jon

Hi Seyhan, Great visuals and video! I love the spontaneity and playful gamification of your idea. On a previous challenge, one of my concepts ended up heading in a similar direction. I'd love to start to try and realize it soon, and may be back in the UK later this year. Have a look and see if there is room for some collaboration to prototype a hybrid:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/flash-sports-app-for-the-live-linking-up-of-local-sports-facilities-availability-with-residents/Best,James

Thanks for your positive comments James! I had a look at your Flash sports app and it is similar to my current app concept in many ways. Prototyping a hybrid of the two concepts would be very interesting as with apps there is always room for improvements.Thanks again

Good Concept! i am now wondering how we could make the activities more attractive for those who are not so keen on sports or feel bad because they are not as talented as others. Let me draw a picture, most of the companies employees like football and play it since they are small. Now of course a football activity would win the votes.One of the employees never played football and is scared to make it less pleasurable for the others if he joins in.I thought the app could hand out points for people who do not participate in the activity, someone can collect this points if he successfully motivates the college to join the next activity. Or an employee with a certain amount of points is allowed to select an activity of his choice.What do you think?

Thanks Burns! I totally agree with an introduction of point system similar to this websites DQ points. I like the idea of someone getting extra points for motivating a colleague to join into the activity. It is certainly a point to think about in depth, thanks for your comments.

Great concept Seyhan! Have you think that what can happen if someone has other kind of mobile and can't install the app? Is there any other alternative?Great work and congrats for being on the Top 20! :)
Thanks Sonia, for the people who don't have smartphones internet logins could be a way of using this feature :)

This is a great concept. Perhaps you could integrate team goals in your app. For example, a goal would be set for the entire team that is participating to run 5 miles. Collectively they could aim to reach their set targets if they cant join the rest of the group to run on that particular day.Great work
That could be an added feature to the app and a point system could be created to determine the more exercising people. Thanks Jonathan!

Nice collaboration, guys. Seyhan  don't forget to ad your favourite builds to your actual post before the end of the Refinement phase. And if anyone's particularly helped shape your idea here, you might give them a hat tip by adding them to your Virtual Team. Bring on the builds! :^)

Nice one Seyhan  and as you mention... there are so many possibilities here. Maybe, to incentivise participation, there could be some kind of points given for various types participation (kind of like our DQ points) and a leader board for who's coming up tops. And and I wonder if it would need to be specific to a particular company  or whether it might be more based on location? Looking forward to thoughts and builds from others on this one!

I really like your idea Meena! Each team could set a goal and a way to celebrate when it is achieved, so the team will be earning points until the goal is reached.   Moreover, prizes could be offered by companies for the team that earns more points, in order to promote a healthy lifestyle among the employees and encourage team building activities.Both, self-determined celebrations and prizes offered by employers, could be very encouraging!

Great!!! I was wondering about the time-management/time consumption for the together health activities in the office. I mean, time is always an issue at work, so would these health activities take place during/instead of lunch breaks? Or would they be considered more as team-building occasions and thus organized during work-time? In any case, would it be a risk to let people decide to exercise at home if they did not want to participate with co-workers? The idea of team-building is strong and those who are given the chance to not participate miss out on this added value...

Thanks Gaia, you're right time management is an issue nowadays we live in a very busy world - everyone's in a rush, this is why I aimed this concept to be an open platform kind of approach. For example users could organize their activities during or before lunch breaks but do not necessarily have to do these activities at lunch, it could be after work or before work (however the users want it to be). So in a nutshell the activities created could take place any time anywhere depending on the users. You're also correct about people missing out on the fun and exercise but we simply can only encourage people to take part in the activities, but getting those people who don't want to join in on the group fun involved would definitely be something to think about in the refinement stage.
Great work, this can be accessed easily as it is an app. But also keeping people physical and mentally healthy plays a key part in the concept.

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel thought this feels like a nice digital support to the Recess concept. Perhaps you could reach out to those concept authors and get them involved in your Virtual Team. How else might this get started?  Is it pre-populated with activities?  Or a questionnaire to understand more about you and make suggestions?  Is it smart enough to suggest connections to co-workers?  How might it extend beyond the workplace?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Im not sure i completely understand or agree with what your proposing. Would this work for workers who operate full time? Or those that are work in very active workplaces?From my understanding this concept appeals to people who want to get fit with co-workers, so why not just join a gym?Im just confused, could you clarify for me please?

Speaking from my own perspective  I've never been a gym person. But if I used this app  I might find out about a lunch time round-the bays cycle session or post an afterwork walk to a nearby park and find others that want to join me. Perhaps my walk get heaps of votes and start running them regularly? Tip for Seyhan: To help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. Check this example: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/winners-announced/opencity-bringing-open-source-princi/ where a scenario is given to get people digging the goodness on a concept. You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.

The idea is to get fit not only physically but to maintain positive mind frame with co-workers. Joining a gym could get you fit but the advantage here is to have fun with friends. I believe people are more likely to spend time and get some exercise done with their friends rather than paying and joining a gym. As you said some people may operate full time, hence they can use personal exercises (this could be quick stretches or workout routines to follow in their own time). You are right about the concept not appealing to certain people, however, this concept not only appeals to those who want to get fit, the main picture here is having fun while getting fit."Fitness needs to be perceived as fun and games or we subconsciously avoid it"Hope that clarifies it a bit more for you :)
Ok i think i understand you more now. Good work!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Oh I totally love this app, based on my personal experiences. I have relocated for work several times and have needed to find ways to make new friends in a new place and connect with my new colleagues to do things in the local area. The app just makes that all a whole lot easier. Just building personal connections with colleagues, whether it be a physical activity oriented thing or not, is quite healthy for the work environment.

py/tuple: Is this concept addressing clear health needs for users?

This concept rocked my world
I liked it but prefered others

This concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
It’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue – but there’s reason to feel hopeful

A great way to get everyone from all sectors and positions involved in one group activity. A great inspiration.
I agree Jonathan, in another inspiration someone used the word "Workmate" and we all have those. Making use of those relations in a positive way could trigger a lot of "Good"
Great inspiration Jonathan! :DI found it really funny and useful!

live_your_life_by_changing_another_life_.description: Having a company choice or individual choice to give their spare time or to helping out within their community.  Having people from different professions coming together to get involved in activities.
live_your_life_by_changing_another_life_.creator: fbb88ea9ebaaaf2be3376906fb48ab7c

comments.text: Wow.... I wouldn't just say it's a great concept but also great thinking! To help others brings a certain happiness which will also give the helper mental peace.Employees will work in a pleasant atmosphere . Really nice !
Thank you very much for the comment Sanjali, giving the employees mental peace will help them work more pleasantly.

Great concept! Its a great way of creating social interaction between co-workers and involving the community. It would probably boost productivity and moral within the workplace, where the employees would  feel a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction. Good idea.
Thank you for the comment Megan, workers feeling a sense of satisfaction would encourage them to get involved again.
I like the way it brings people together within the workplace but also has major benefits for the employers as well
The concept has to be beneficial to everyone, each person gets a satisfaction out of the activities. For example the employee will feel like they have spent their time well, giving back to others.
Good idea. Theres nothing more important than bringing poeople together.
I'm glad you like the concept, it definitely does bring people together. Thank you for the comment.
very cool concept!!! i really liked it.....It will bring people together.....
Yup spot on, it will bring people together.
I like this! Its such a good way of bringing people together within the workplace.
Thank you for the comment, i agree with it.
nice concept i think this is a great way of bringing the community together and creates harmony. i like the idea of people getting a feel good factor/ accomplishment outside work.
Thank you for the comment Mr. Agu.

"Giving employees the choice to go out during their break times to help those who are living in poverty, disabled or less fortunate." Does this not already exist? Theres nothing stopping people from helping others on their break?Im not quite sure you have thought this through completely, and decided exactly what the concept is because i dont understand what it is your proposing, the benefits or anything.I think that you should think more directly about encouraging companies to participate in a scheme to allows homeless, disabled and those in poverty to be mentored by the employees in the workplace.The benefits:- it would allow the company to discover potential talent for their business- It will allow the company to connect closer with the community- they will be providing experience, knowledge, and the tools for these people to take new direction in their lives- The employees will gain self fulfilment by helping someone else better their lives.- the community will benefit from it as it would allow them the opportunity to gain experience, knowledge and the tools to move forward in their life, as well as just be a part of something which will also give them self fulfilment.Everyone benefits and it costs the workplace NOTHING!it can be implemented in any workplace, and can be measured by the rate of unemployment decreasing as more people would have the correct tools and experience to be acceptable for jobs
Thank you for this comment Djorn, as you said this should be more direct, which will benefit everyone and can be integrated into any workplace with no costs.

customise_and_play_with_lego.description: Customise your workspace with Lego, to create a more adjustable, moveable, interlock able and adaptable workspace. Whenever your needs change, use Lego to adapt your working style, or just to take a 5 minute creative break.
customise_and_play_with_lego.creator: 2d5efdf8a05bbea1d95d198cf20b70a8

comments.text: Lego is a great way to be creative with your mind and take mind off work whilst on breaks. This is a great concept as it allows the user to construct items they feel are best suited and related to  their workplace.

Great concept. I feel that the image is quite a strong one. Perhaps there could be tasks set to create ornaments using lego to improve the workplace visually. Installations or small objects created by the employees would make them feel that they are contributing to 'making' the workplace their own.

Love this concept Charlie! This concept is fun and creative building structures with Lego as well as social bonds with fellow co-workers. This would result in a much happier productive workforce, who would look forward to their day! Its so easy to implement in a everyday working environment. This is a Great idea.
Fun concept Charlie! Playing with lego at work, could be fun moreover increases the creative work and the happiness.

Lego is such a creative tool and is also such fun to play with. Having a tool like that in the workplace is bound to create a happier working environment, which means happier, less stressed, more productive employees. Great concept!

I really like this... LEGO is a brilliant way to have fun and be creative, also if the worker gets bored with the way their desk looks they can simply destroy it and rebuild. This links with childhood memories and taking time out just to relax and do something fun. It would completely change the look of an everyday office.

I can attest to the power of taking a break to build with LEGO.  It helps to step away from the task at hand and refocus your thoughts.  I'm partial though...I work for the company and we have bricks at our desks/conference rooms.
Scale the size of the Lego bricks and you could create a truly configurable office space.. want to create your own thinking space?  Create a team room....
Great idea Charlie! I love the idea of getting people to be creative at work, it could really lighten their mood during a tough or boring day.

I like the fact that you can take your mind off your work and having the lego to hand. It would be interesting to see if people could make something that day based on they way they are feeling or something that stuck out in their mind that day.
also its so colorful. a very good contrast to a grayish day.
I agree with Lee, it would be interesting to see the outcomes based on events or feelings of a person during the day. Could be a creative way to express it?

Nice concept Charlie! I think it is a great way to take your mind of work and just have a play time. The fact its lego it does not have to stay the same so this can bring out the creative side of a person.
I wish i had Lego available on my desk. I would 100% use it for prototyping. Amazing idea. Great work.

Great idea Charlie. Lego is such a great tool to get people to switch of for a short while and just play. I think the play is the important aspect of this concept and Lego is a great example. But perhaps there are plenty of other toys or playful products which could perform in a similar way. It makes me think of the street artists who use Lego to fill gaps in walls. Fun innovation at its best. Taking the stress out of work with mini play breaks is a fantastic idea!
I really like the idea of customising workplace in a fun way.Great concept Charlie

a_global_standard_for_a_nutrition_api_th.description: Knowledge is health.  I propose a standard, machine-readable means of presenting nutrition information. Grocery stores, restaurants &schools would publish this data, and developers would create tools to allow people to better understand their diet.
a_global_standard_for_a_nutrition_api_th.creator: e18dc7afd27f3a31380e6238edc6226b

comments.text: Interesting idea! A similar idea that exists is the calorie counter app that allows you to see the nutritional value of food by scanning the barcode:https://itunes.apple.com/app/calorie-counter-by-mynetdiary/id287529757?mt=8You could incoporate the idea you mentioned, of having the stores you shop at giving you a summary for the weekly nutritional intake of your families shopping, into an app like this.
Great point. I'm really after the automated nature of something like an API. But adding barcodes is a great idea for a client that we could develop.

Hi Nick, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. Great photo, thanks!

agree

co._bike_bus.creator: 467171e7c50b651a97a26b0905c90cd5

comments.text: great idea, I think this will work!
Thanks Petrit :) Unfortunately I believe it didn't make the cut for the next phase :(

Hopefully you'll still make the most of collaborative feedback here and may even find someone who wants to prototype the idea with you. We've received some great stories of OpenIDEATORS taking their own ideas forward. Here's one of my favourites: http://bit.ly/pwI6JL

Yes Meena! I believe it will move forward. I know some folks who are developing an app for bike buses. I will share with them the feedback received here and the idea to focus the app for in-company health/environmental programs.
Awesome! Do let us know how things go in good time, especially how an OpenIDEO feedback contributed to the process: http://bit.ly/action_stories
'any' OpenIDEO feedback (not 'an' !)
Great concept. I came across a "bike bus" for first time last week, and wondered where it had been all my life, id welcome a way to get in on more of these journeys.

Yes, the bike bus concept already exists (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bike_bus), and I believe it can be a great addition to a corporate health program, besides other benefits for the environment and social interaction :)

Hi Gian! I liked your concept. In some cities there are traffic jams which make drivers 'mad' when they are going to work in the mornings. Your concept solves this problem in a healthy way. However, you should be sure employees are safe with bike, about helmets and so on.
A great way to put people on bikes then driving everywhere, more advertisements should be created to promote bike users.
Thanks for the feedback Ozge! I'm sure if this is done in partnership with companies, they can support their employees with pro-tips and gear for greater safety
Love this concept! I love the way it makes your journey into work more interesting instigating social interaction, whilst keeping you fit. Great idea.
Social + Fitness + Safety :)

I like your concept, as it would reduce the stress of travelling in by car with the morning traffic, and it addresses the social, and physical health of the participants of the scheme, as they socialize with others,and get fit on the way to work.

change_behaviour_change_the_dress_code._.description: Incentive employees to workout after the office by allowing gym clothes at work.  This visually shows their families, colleagues and clients about their new habit adoption.  It can start a healthy conversation and use peer pressure to keep it.
change_behaviour_change_the_dress_code._.creator: 488536e4c0edc7508918e593b01e32b1

comments.text: Nice idea. Companies should create own work-out dresses which employees can wear like a team jersey. I also like that this might be a good signal within a company. People wearing work-out dresses signal that they care for their health and are committed to work-out. This might inspire other people who are not committed to doing sports. If all my peers are wearing work-out dresses I would like to as well (call it good peer pressure :)).

I agree Niklas! It can be a low-investment change with a powerful impact.  The idea is that we don't create a new workout dresscode that can lead to more consumption, but guidelines of appropriate workout clothes for companies. Maybe they can even be corporate making people at gyms or in the street realize the commitment the company has with the health of their employees:)  This concept can be built upon on!
