_casual_friday_gets_active.description: Instead of wearing jeans for Casual Friday, ask employees to wear their workout clothes.  Load the day with a morning yoga class in the conference room, a salad-style potluck, and at least one walking meeting to bring happiness and health to work.
_casual_friday_gets_active.creator: 23fcfb2eccb65e426ed18995810db074

comments.text: I liked it. People would proprably work more relaxed.Maybe you could also think about the activities that you mentioned and talk about one for team bonding and one creative exercise.

I love this idea! At my previous company we had a similar fitness challenge where employees were encouraged to take a 30 min walk around the site after lunch everyday.  The program lasted for a summer and over 50% of our company participated at least once.
Very nice concept ! But maybe you can consider different day. Maybe Monday ? Everybody hates Mondays and that could be a good motivation to come to work after weekend...
I like the idea of Monday, too. And the yoga would be a great way to start the week.
Excellent point Julia!  I bet having Fitday on Monday would be an employee satisfier.  What are your guys' thoughts: would people be more likely to participate on Monday or Friday?
Sounds like a good topic for some rapid-prototyping... :)
Great idea!  And then you're not taking away the casual Friday.  And hey!  A track suit is still a suit, right?!
It seems like these day there are a lot of offices that are casual everyday, so in those cases Fridays would make the most sense.
I was thinking Monday would be good too - right after the couch potato / dining out kind of weekend you might have had. Motivation Mondays? Maybe that's too perky : )
Any day would work, really: Monday to help ease into the week, Wednesday for a mid-week morale boost, Friday for a good ending, or Tuesday/Thursday just for the heck of it. =)
And what about gifting a pair of "Nike" to the most active employee of the month?

Great idea!  The office could provide some fitness incentives (like a pair of Nikes) and announce the winners at the Fitday Potluck.  There could be individual competitions (e.g. most stairs taken, most salads eaten) and team competitions by department or group (e.g. most walking meetings held, most Office-Walks-Around-the-Block, best fitness casual participation)

I think this is a great idea - and possibly an opportunity for athletic wear companies to partner with healthcare providers - manifesting this simple idea into a global movement towards healthy, feel good living!

Depending on the company and the resources at their disposal, giving out running shoes or other equipment (or making them available at a discount) to employees at the start may be a better option. Chances are the employee who is the most active already has their own stuff. Though if it's a decent item, or one that people end up replacing a lot (like shoes, I suppose) it would work fine.

I really dig this idea, and I'll try to get it started where I work now."Fit Friday" definitely sounds the best out of the name ideas I've seen. Simple, and gets the point across.Expanding on Lorena's idea, you could use pedometers, or some other workout-logging tool to create a competition within the company for who can achieve the most, either individually within a department, or collectively between departments (Sales vs. Support?). Fitocracy might be a decent tool for this, as it already gamifies working out.Love it!

For the name, improvising from "Fitness Friday" by Beth Worrall "Fit Friday" sounds more catchy, witty and it was the word that came straight into my head reading brief intro to your concept. I love the idea, I think it is great, definitely would love to see it happening. It would encourage both health aware and unaware individuals to exercise even if it means Friday would be the only day in a week they get off their sofas and office chairs. Furthermore I personally find a huge number of individuals oblivious to healthy life style are likely to start being healthy once they have been educated in clear of prejudice. There are prejudice against some exercises such as yoga or pilates but once they have been introduced and individuals start noticing benefits from exercising, their opinions change radically. Usually the only social activity at workplaces or in fact social activity in general involve alcohol since that is considered by many the norm and/or cool however Work Clothes Friday would be great assisting as well as being a wake up call to realising the importance of our health. Perhaps back in the student days, our youths were opt enough to allow junk kind of living but we only get older, our bodies won't be able to cope one day at times without notice. If you are at work it is likely to mean that you need to make a living, reach your dream, take care of your loved ones but what can money do if you are not there?Love your idea and I sincerely hope through this concept and many others that all the population, let's dream big, realise the importance of health and break the prejudice that it's only for 'goodie goodies' nor for the privileged. EVERYONE has their right to health.

This is a global idea that could start a global movement. For habits to be established it needs to be a regular thing. Maybe this idea could be tied into group fitness app & pedometer metrics. Great idea with many spin off ideas.

This is a global idea that could start a global movement. For habits to be established it needs to be a regular thing. Maybe this idea could be tied into group fitness app & pedometer metrics. Great idea with many spin off ideas.

Ashley, first off, like many others, I love the simplicity of this idea. The moment that I put on work out clothes and a pair of good runners, I feel like I SHOULD and NEED to be working out! But the hardest part isn't convincing myself to go, it's actually changing and getting ready. Because once you do so, you feel like you've invested the effort to be ready, you can't turn back now! That's why I love your idea. It provides a step over the mental hurdle 'exercise' can be. I would love to see the simple usage of pedometers in this. It could be something as simple as having the newer/smaller pedometers in the running shoes, so that every Friday (or which ever day) can really be a measurement of how much is walked. Or even Nike Fuel bands. It would be great to have this all equate to something large but not overwhelming (ie. x steps = y kilometers = mt.kilimanjaro)Either way, reading the comments below, it needs to be customized to the office demographic and culture, but I think your idea rocks!
Sending this on to our HR department. Such a simple way to boost employee morale and health. Thanks Ashley!

Awesome Hanna!  I'm also in the process of pitching this to the corporate offices at Chipotle.  Let me know how it's received and--if all goes well--implemented.  How big is your company?  So glad you think the idea has potential!
I wish all employers would do this, especially in offices where you're sitting for hours and hours. I'm sharing this EVERYWHERE!

I think that is a great idea. Employers are constantly seeking ways to reduce healthcare costs and have begun to implement efforts in wireless tracking devices that monitor employees daily activity. This idea plays to healthy feel good living. Happy Employee is an effective and lasting one was well.

What a simple and brilliant idea! You can even have a juicer or blender related appliance in the break area and have a "team turn up" or whatever you want to call it and get co-workers together to make healthy smoothies around three o'clock to avoid the lull in the afternoon.

I love the idea of a "Team Turn Up".  The benefit is tri-fold:  1) directly beats the 3:00 lull, 2) creates community and fun, and 3) replaces a healthy snack with what's usually an unhealthy habit.  Great suggestion!

Thanks! I think the suggestion for Monday yoga is a great idea too! You can call it "Funday Monday" or "Mellow Monday" to start the week on a good note. You could even have themes for each Friday's Team Turn Up, like a different fruit/veggie smoothie a week, maybe even start Team Turn Ups with "Team Turnip" and have green smoothies. That may be a little lame but just an idea!
I'd call it "Feel Good Friday!"  In fact, that's what I plan to call it when I use this with my staff next fall.

Great suggestion Rebecca!  How awesome that you're planning to incorporate Feel Good Friday with your staff.  I'd love to hear more about your organization and implementation plan if you're willing to share:1. Could you describe your organization?  E.g. how many employees in the office, how many employees will participate in Feel Good Friday, what type of attire is worn on a typical day?2. Could you describe your plan for implementation?  E.g. are you going to announce FGF at a staff meeting, via email, at a conference?  What types of Friday activities do you plan to implement?I'd love to also pitch this idea to my organization (Chipotle's Corporate Headquarters).  It would be awesome if people who are interested in implementing this could all share ideas!

I love this idea. One of the most fascinating traits about exercise is how addicting it can be. Unfortunately, many people get lost in their weekly routine and don't even give exercise a chance to squeeze in. Workout Clothes Friday gives the employees the chance to try many different exercise options. This method would certainly explode with popularity within a company. Once a week is enough to plant the seed of a healthy lifestyle that will begin to influence the rest of the week. Fantastic idea! Very practical and down-to-earth!

Love Workout Clothes Friday!! Many congratulations to all. Fitness Friday has a nice ring to it. Even if you say Friday Fitness, it will emphasize the purpose. As Friday rolls arounds, Friday Fitness can serve as a reminder -- it's a participative day to share in the workplace for fitness and revitalizing our relationships (internal and external) through fitness goals. Certainly this concept creates a whole lot more meaning for casual Fridays. Company sponsored fitness gear, like tee shirts can be awarded monthly for employee volunteers creating unique or inspiring ideas. Everybody can vote, too. Great work!

I like the idea of this being implemented on a larger scale like in a business park. That would allow for smaller breakout groups. Though I like the concept overall I think that generally workout clothing (especially for women) tends to be form-fitting and females may seem self conscious wearing that type of attire around male co-workers, especially if they are already unhappy with the shape they are in. If a whole office park was involved there may be enough participants to have some women only yoga. Overall it'd be good to implement on a day when no client meetings are scheduled, and perhaps the conference room can be repurposed. The healthy lunch meeting may also be a good time for a guest speakers that can address work/life balance and health issues, or to hold "check-ups" to ensure that teams have healthy work interactions.

I like this idea the most so far because it's relatively simple to implement (rather than creating a whole work-out station that might impose on tight company budgets). My only concern is that this kind of activity could be harder to implement in certain kinds of companies - like federal agencies for example. Not to single them out - I just have experience at one and can't imagine any of my former colleagues wearing any kind of work out clothes to work, let alone do any kind of physical exercise with each other in the same room. There is also a big age difference, ranging from people in their late 20s to 80s (there is a senior employment program in place). I think it would be good to explore how the idea of Work-Out Clothes Fridays can be catered to employees of all different ages.

This is such a simple idea and I love it. It has so much potential for scaling and implementing it. Maybe a way to give recognition it is having some authorities or organisation to create an endorsement or recognition for organizations that promoted work life balance, and include this as one possible measurement.

Great idea!  Companies like Google, REI, and Apple are applauded for how they create a happy, healthy environment; I can imagine them all participating in a "Casual Fitday" program (or whatever the name might be).  Maybe at some point, recognition as a Casual Fitday organization would be criteria Forbe's "Top Companies to Work For" listing.

Is it important that people wear a full workout outfit, or would wearing sneakers to work accomplish a similar thing? For example, Sneaker Fridays would still allow people to do walking meetings, walk to work, and remove at least one barrier to working out (having to bring your sneakers with you to work...which is the bulkiest item of gym apparel).

I think this idea is great in terms of getting employees motivated to workout! At least for me, I know that after a long week the hardest part about working out is actually getting dressed in your gear and dragging yourself out to the gym. If you come to work already dressed in exercise gear, it is way easier to motivate yourself to take that extra step and actually do your workout. As I personally don't like yoga, it would be nice to alternate the group exercises each week. Not only will offering alternatives to yoga like kick boxing classes, self defense techniques, zumba, and hip hop classes keep employees excited and appeal to a variety of exercise taste, but it has been proven that switching up your workout routine keeps your body challenged!!

Great idea!While "work out clothes friday" doesn't have quite the same ring as "fitness friday" does, the implication is different. "Work out clothes friday" doesn't necessarily imply that any real "fitness" is required to participate, which sounds like fun, not work, and might mean that those employees who tend to be "fitness" adverse will be more likely to join in, which is the real goal of a program like this in the first place right?Creating a healthy "community" in some workplaces is easy because it tends to create itself, as those who are healthy gravitate to each other. But how is that community nurtured and encouraged to grow within the workplace?  An idea like this is great because it doesn't feel like "fitness" itself is what's being encouraged, its the idea of fitness. And everything starts with an idea.

Chris, I think you bring up an excellent point about the name - it should remain focused first and foremost on the attire for the day, and not necessarily on the activities of the day.  One of the first steps to doing something active is changing your clothes, so the goal to get to people to work in fitness casual.  Once they're in the door, there will be so many activities for which they'll already be appropriately dressed.  Ideally, someone who doesn't intend to "work out" that day will still come in fitness casual clothes; even better, this person actually will participate throughout the day merely because they're already dressed for the occasion.What do you think about the name "Fitness Casual Friday" (to play directly off of "Casual Friday")?
How about "Workout-Fits-Friday"
Throw a fit! in your workoutFit!

Ashley,Loved this idea. It is necessary to replace the "beer-soaked-friday" to "yoga-stretching-friday."To make it more fun, we can add a little bit of "masala." there are many workout genres getting popularized like dancing workout, dancing to the tune of Bollywood songs, mix-n-match with martial arts etc. Those genres can be taken up in alternate Fridays as a surprise to the participators.

Great idea - there could be a standing class (maybe around lunch-time) where the theme/type of workout could rotate.  To ensure people still attend despite the workout changing, it would be important to ensure the workout is pretty versatile (possible for many skill levels), and maybe begins and ends with familiar activities.

Maybe ending the day with a class might be better.  Then nobody has to change out of their workout clothes for the rest of the day.  And I'm sure everybody would love knowing the stress is over an hour earlier on Fit-Day
I love this idea.  If you need a simple website built for it, let me know, would be excited to help see this into action.

Nathan - thanks so much for offering.  I'd love to hear your (and others'!) thoughts on what you imagine the website to be.  Off the top of my head: - I imagine a login where companies can create a Fitness Casual Cohort (that could be divided into many levels, so larger companies could have internal competitions or divide into departments)- The company could have a "menu" of different activities the each user could add to their Cohort (e.g. Office-Walks-Around-the-Blocks, Standing Meetings, morning yoga) as well as the option to Create-Your-Own activity.  - Some sort of interface for participating Cohorts to see other participating Cohorts, and an opportunity to engage in Cohort-to-Cohort competition.- The site would have a link to Instagram and a mobile interface are a must; the former to embrace social media, and the latter because Fitness Casual Friday is about being up and away from your desktop computer!  Nathan and others - I'd love to hear your thoughts

This idea is great because it's easy to implement. Depending on the type of work, Standing-up work hours can be introduced. I used to stand to work intermittently through out the day when my back was really getting to me. Not to mention that Donald Rumsfeld works on a standing desk. I find it so energizing and in a cubicle environment could also promote communication.I myself is a yoga teacher. If the concern of fitting in a full class in the morning is difficult, companies can offer short 20 min classes through out the day, meditation, pranayama, or a quickie asana. People can take advantage of them during lunch or whatever breaks they usually like to take. A peaceful mind can be as powerful as a fit body. To give it a fun name, wonder if "offbeats friday" would generate creativity, inspiration and motivation for healthier and more fun-fill, at the same time more productive Fridays.Namaste,Bo

Bo, I like your idea about having shorter activities throughout the day.  While reading, the thought came to mind to turn the 2:30 coffee-urge into a Office-Walk-Around-the-Block.  It'll get people out of the office, providing a mental break that will help boost productivity for the rest of the day.  Since it's a walk, it's not intimidating for people who aren't uber fit already, it promotes community, and could possibly replace coffee/fatty snack habits for some.  It'll only be about 15 minutes, and since people will already in workout clothes, it'll be really easy to elect to participate. If people want coffee still, that's fine - but get it before or after the Walk!

This seems like a great idea, especially the walking meetings encouraged by employees already wearing gym shoes. I think, however, that if management is on board, they should take another step and add incentives. This will take away the lack of commitment someone may have - for instance, 3 Fitdays participated = $3 off on a healthy lunch (sponsored by the company).

I really like the idea for providing an additional incentive for participation.  This could be an opportunity also promote community - e.g. if for three weeks everyone in your department participates in at least one walking meeting, the company will host lunch (a tasty/healthy one) during the next Fitday.
i think this idea is brilliant, solely cos it's so easy to adopt. it definitely works and though it may be a simple idea but nonetheless a great step towards greater ideas!
I absolutely LOVE this idea!How about "Fitness Fridays" or Fitday? :-)
Excellent naming ideas!  Terence made a suggestion above include the "Fit-Day" idea.
I vote for fitday!
"Fitness Casual" ?
Joel & Anthony, I love the merge of these two names.  I can hear the dialogue:   "...Er, what is 'Fitday'?"...."I'm so glad you asked, on Fitday we wear Fitness Casual instead of Business Casual".
Great collaboration guys! This is what the Refinement phase is all about. Bring it on...

Great concept. I agree that people wearing workout clothes to work would potentially encourage the employees to engage in activities to keep fit. Being able to cycle or run to work for example and then remain in the workout clothes would make the employees feel more comfortable about performing these tasks.

A Fantastic simple concept, Its simple and effective to be easily implemented in working environments. It could also be a way to socialize with weekly sport activities with other work departments or other businesses.

What a great concept!  I really like the idea of a walking meeting.  Depending on the organization, it may be difficult to hold yoga sessions (which I also love, btw), but conducting business while walking can be done anywhere (ok, maybe not the North Pole).  It's a great balance of work and fitness.
Great concept! It can be so easily implemented into working environments.

I love this idea Ashley! Many companies already have several sports clubs within the organization. Whether it is yoga, basketball, zumba, squash, or any other; maybe 'Fitday' could be a day where the people come to the office already wearing their workout outfit (instead of bringing a duffel bag), so that by the end of the day people go off to their weekly practice. This could also help raise awareness on some of the activities that people in the office are engaging in, and potentially conquer new adepts for all sports clubs, resulting in a healthier company overall.

that is a great point, javier - aside from overcoming the barrier of "changing clothes", fitday could have the benefit of raising awareness. i would also add that there would be some positive peer pressure at work too, as others who did not wear workout clothes to work would feel inspired by others to join in the fun! :)

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel noted that this relies on an office champion to implement. How do you reduce the burden of designing the activities? Could Bupa partner with local gyms to provide classes and they sell 'Friday packages' to local businesses? Could work out well for gyms filling up their quiet time during the day?Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!

Great build on the existing popularity for Casual Fridays, Ashley! And I wonder whether neighbouring businesses could be encouraged to have a friendly sports match at the end of the day  maybe once a month. Could be great if you help folks understand your idea a bit further by filling out the remaining questions on the Concepting form  you can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button on the right of your post. Looking forward to hearing your thoughts on how the idea might be prototyped, scaled, etc...

Good concept Ashley..I just posted my idea and as I was going through everyone else's..I thought ours was collaborative in nature..Combining what I suggested with the Casual Friday theme may work wonders if implemented well!

Ashley  you can check out Ranjani's idea here: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/healthy-work-life-balance-health-day-office-2013-one-day-every-week./ We're always fans of collaboration, cross-pollination and conversation. Creativity loves company!

Meena, thanks so much for posting the link!  Ranjani, I completely agree - your concept of having an array of management-sponsored healthy activities would fit perfectly on Workout Clothes Friday.  I could see an office culture growing to look forward to Friday; wearing comfortable clothes, starting the day with a drop-in yoga class, and then looking forward to that week's Work-Life Balance Challenge.  A pilot program could help identify which activities the community is more drawn to - those particular activities could become monthly or quarterly events, thus increasing employee's excited anticipation for the event, and reducing the demand on management to come up with new ideas for every week.
Totally agree..
Great Idea!

Hey Ashley how about "ActivWork Day". "Mom are you sleepwalking? Why are you leaving the house in yoga clothes?" "It's ActivWork Day sweetie. We wear Active Wear to work today. We set personal and group goals. We even engage in friendly inner office, company wide and external competition. The goal is to create a wellness culture and promote teamwork." Very cool concept Ashley. Lululemon and Athleta will love this. Active Wear Apparel lines are almost indistinguishable from traditional Casual Wear. So everyone can still be dressed appropriately. The best way to get (and stay) active is to set goals. ActivWork Day could also encourage offices, departments, or teams to set personal and/or group goals. They could engage in friendly competition or work as a team to meet those goals. For example: a run/walk relay challenge; a group weight loss goal; or a fitness accessment challenge. The "ActivWork Day" games/activities can be moderated by a personal training professional. It can also be folded into any of the ongoing "Get Fit America Challenges". Great concept Ashley. I can see my team and i revieving an award for the most improved relay time at the holiday party. ;-)

"Fitness Fridays" is a great concept! I love the idea of having it be a building or area-wide program where employees from different companies could interact and get to know one another. This concept takes "Casual Fridays" to the next level - providing more fun, healthy and social opportunities for everyone. It would also help soften hierarchical structures and strengthen trust and respect across departments and management structures. Well conceived!
How about 'Fabulous Fitness Friday'?
*Fridays
I really like this concept and the idea of having a social network where workers of different companies could share their experiences as well as encouraging some to the others. Great concept Ashley!

Really like this idea. As an added benefit I believe this would also help staff communication and "bonding", with everyone getting together and doing something out of the ordinary as a group regularly. I believe it would give you something to discuss with your colleagues you do not always talk to, meaning making potentially useful work connections at the same time.The only challenge I can think of, (which is not my opinion but I can potentially imagine it being my managers) is that "slouchy" clothes could lead to you being slightly more unproductive as you feel relaxed. And would not be at all acceptable if you had meetings with anyone outside the company on a reguar basis on a Friday. As I say not my opinion but just a thought..All in all a great idea.

Really like this idea.. I think it will completely change the workplace morale on a friday as everyone will be in there own clothes and being themselves. The exercises/classes could vary every week to make every week funner and different. Really good concept.Name idea:  Fri-fun-fit-Day

Really like the concept of getting a better use of casual friday. There's so much potential in this concept. incredible idea of getting them into workout clothes and once that's done, they would have urge of participating themselves in various activities management can plan for them or they can come up with through healthy communications.My idea similarly incorporates the concept of giving employees the chance to collaborate and work in an open office environment and then they'll find themselves the way to be more productive as well as less weary of office lag. you can Check out my idea here: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/break-out-of-the-cage-/
How about "THE ULTIMATE FRIDAY"
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Ashley this is a great idea!  The best thing about this is that for those that don't participate in the yoga classes / physical activities, the yoga clothes provide a great reminder to everyone that it's important to stay active.  I can imagine myself thinking "Oh yeah, I guess I should start exercising again."  And, since the clothing is comfortable and less of a hassle, I'm sure many people will take advantage of it just from an ease of access level.  I'm sure it will perform much better than what some teams do, "Formal Fridays".   One challenge to consider is employer liability.  The reasons why many companies don't provide in house work out programs or gyms is because there's a potential for someone to get injured.  The walking meetings are a good substitute.Perhaps you can tack on building awareness, like an email sent out every Friday with a "Little Known Fact".  Great job.

Great point.  Simply getting people into workout clothes (without the direct expectation that they must also do something active) is a win.  If you're already in active clothes, you're more likely to participate in active things throughout the day, or begin to plan for them on Fridays.  I also like the idea of a weekly "Little Known Fact".  Debbie Ng had an idea to have a governing body officially recognize companies that participate" they could possibly sponsor the "Little Known Fact" emails.
Newcomer to this site and really like this idea.If you would like to make "workout clothes Friday" a bit less literal and a bit more catchy, how about something like:"Gym kit for Fri-fit"
Awesome!  I love how it rhymes; "gym kit for Fri-fit" would make an excellent tagline.

_casual_friday_gets_active.title: "Casual Friday" Gets Active

py/tuple: Is this concept addressing clear health needs for users?
Indeed! It’s addressing an unmet need in a new way
Yep – it’s addressing a need but in an already crowded space

This concept rocked my world
I liked it but prefered others
It didn't get my overly excited.

This concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
It’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue – but there’s reason to feel hopeful
This concept may have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and stay relevant

Very easy. It's clear how people could get involved quickly in this concept
I'm not sure if I can grasp how people could get involved easily

Sure. I could imagine this would spread like wild fire
It's interesting but feels like it would be slow or challenging to grow
It seems somewhat limited in scope

stretching_time_in_the_new_stretching_ro.description:
Highlights:
- Every employee can stretch.
- A schedule to commit, 10 minutes every 2 hours. 
- Go to the stretching room.
- Stretching time!
- Break: coffee and fruit.
- Go back to your desk... New energy flows and your back smiles.
stretching_time_in_the_new_stretching_ro.creator: 6d0e618c47253c8f9297769e1737eaea

comments.text: This is a productive way of relieving stress within the workplace. Sitting in the same position for hours is not beneficial.
I like your concept beacuse I think stretching is so important for many reasons. Is a way to disconnect a little bit of what you are doing and come back to your work with more energy!
Good idea! I often find myself uninspired and fidgety if I sit in one place for ours, this is a create way of relieving stress and boosting productivity within the workforce. Great concept.
Great idea Gabriel. Why wait for stress to build up when you can prevent it or tackle it? I agree with you simple exercise can have many benefits and anyone can do them which is great!

Fab idea Gabriel, I dig the health benefits you listed.  I do eye exercises to keep my vision sharp and one of the most important ones is to stare at something 10 feet away for 10 seconds every 10 minutes so you're not always focused on a screen.  This seems like the same idea for the rest of your body.  I wonder if there's a way to capture the results of this as a way to highlight the people who choose to do it.  Perhaps a hashtag or a foursquare checkin space to make it seem cool.

Thanks Nathan! Integrating social media in the process is great! It could report us the leaders of the new movement in the company (the stretching room mayor in 4sq...). This is also a excellent way to share new stretching routines. Changing routine periodically is the key for people not to get bored with the exercises.
It definitely could both help people from getting bored and a way to get some buzz for a new initiative in the workplace.  Cheers~

stretching_time_in_the_new_stretching_ro.title: Stretching time in the new stretching room!

comments.text: I love the accessibility of this idea, everyone can join at whatever level, great stuff Aaron
Great highlight on the connection to work productivity and quality, Aaron. I feel that this something that people often forget and is becoming an emerging theme across our challenge.

changing_perceptions_everyone_as_an_athl.title: Changing perceptions: Everyone as an athlete

appreciation_board.description: Stress and mental health problems are often triggered by the lack of praise and recognition. We need a new way to say thank you and share how much we appreciate the work of our colleagues. Good news for companies: happy employees are more productive.
appreciation_board.creator: f6aa057164963eb5460768991d5aba1d

comments.text: like it! this is simple and can really make someones day, it will bring peers together but careful about mispoken words, they might hurt, or turn into a space to mock, but still a nice idea

We had a board like this at our office that displayed an inspirational quote each day. We were all encourage to add our "gratitude" comments. Everyone loved it and often congregated around the board to briefly discuss. It's hard to walk away from the board without smiling.

Hi Jessica, that's cool and exactly what I would like to achieve with this concept. Very good that you deliver some kind of proof that people are using a board like this.Do you have any ideas how the concept could be refined?

This is a great idea! Its a great way of communicating within the workplace, encouraging less confident people to maybe express what they think of their fellow co-workers. I love that it can bring co-workers together increasing the social interaction in the workplace; therefore having a much more positive workforce. Good concept.

I agree with Asma B- LOVE THIS IDEA! People are sometimes embarrassed to give praise, or don't think to do it often enough, this would prompt people to say thanks or well done on a regular basis for all to see. Fab.

I LOVE THIS IDEA! Such a simple concept that would be easy to implement in any workplace, and yet it sounds like something that would do wonders for boosting peoples self esteem and bringing colleagues together. Great thinking Niklas!

appreciation_board.title: Show love and say thank you to your colleagues with an "Appreciation board"

office_in_the_clouds_good_for_workplace_.creator: 6788c6373d08c20cd00d8214af0534d0

comments.text: that's a good idea! rather than being stuck at the office all day, employees can move around and be in a different, maybe even more healthy environments, to work in. it will also let employees spend more quality time with their families. however, will some employees take advantage of this and spend more time doing personal things, rather than to work? maybe there could be a limitation to the hours of cloud time they could have during office hours?
Well said Yin San, limitation should apply on non office hours. It wont be a an absolute non-office working routine there will be times employees are required to come to the office.

of course. this links to what odeshea mentioned about it affecting colleagues. as well as spending time at home, spend should also be spent in the workplace to develop better relationships with colleagues! it will allow more personal interaction with one another, which could promote a better, healthier working environment!

Great inspiration Ernest, I agree this would provide a lot more freedom 'at' work. However you do need to consider the effects this will have on social health, like in your question what effect will it have on colleagues?.. hmm well i think if you somehow incorporate a way for colleagues to communicate with each other due to the difficulty of doing 'group' work using this system- looking forward to seeing your concept.
Thank Odeshea good informative input from you, will keep that in mind when I am concepting.

I love your title! This is the great thing to jobs in design we can "play" while working. Would be great if we could apply this to other job areas.
Exactly that was the idea behind it, to enable all job sectors to be able to have fun in their work places.
Great Idea, could get people from smoking less at work, if they are less stressed and chilled out
Simple, effective, easy to implement and, for sure, inspiring!!!!!I like it.

Time might be incredibly safeguarded by method of this application and can get the new parts been arrived. Extraordinary thought. I might want to impart here a source where you could have the capacity to get suitable application like said here. Get more apps herehttp://www.contus.com/mobile-application-development.php

Great stuff Sarah! And another way to measure impact might be to weigh up days saved in sick days with holiday time gifted, if that were the incentive to be offered. I think you're really on to something by encouraging folks to take a proactive part in earning extra time off  has the potential to make a significant change to work culture if pitched right.

Also  just noticed  the image you've used here is licensed to a stock library and would have been paid for by the source you have cited. Would be great if you might find alternate image to illustrate your great post.

take_your_kids_to_work_day.description: Growing up in the US, one of the best things was Take Your Kid to Work Day - a day that helps kids understand where and how their parents work and employees to engage with each other through their kids which can boost morale, retention and more.

symphony_at_work.creator: 1df587aac917c8569ee1d683c1147a05

comments.text: I don't play an instrument but think this is a great idea.The company, Dropbox, has a recording studio in the middle of their office.  I imagine the glass wall that you can see into is sound proof.I would get in touch with them to learn more about the concept, how people engage with the studio (to they collaborate on music or not??)  Seems like a great way to bond with your co-workers.
Thanks for your comment Kyle. It's great to know that some companies already benefit from a system similar to this. It would be really interesting to hear Dropbox's thoughts. Thanks.

I feel like I can partially relate to this concept. I play the piano and have one at my house. Nowadays I rarely get the time to sit down and play due to other priorities and just not finding much time. However occasionally I do jump on and play a few songs. Personally I find myself playing the piano just to unwind. Also, sometimes I do find myself disappearing into my own bubble when I jump on the piano stool. Perhaps users of your concept may feel the same way and use musical instruments as a way to unwind.Great work Jack
Thanks Jonathan. Great to hear that music has that effect on you. Seems as though many people feel the same which is really nice back-up for this idea.

Fantastic idea Jack! Im a massive lover of music and what better way to spend your breaks than by learning or playing a instrument, by yourself or with friends! I would love to see an employer take the initiative on this one. And in response to your comment to Jorge, i think im the same. Music for me is an escape, a form of relaxation. I think this is true for many people.
Thanks Julian. It's always nice to hear that people see music as a great way to relax and the benefits are cherished by many.
I like your concept. I agree with you when you say that music helps to switch off from the stress. It can be used likemusical theraphy for workers. Great pictures too.

Thank you Jorge. Do you play an instrument? Or would you like to learn to play? I would be really interested to know what people think are the major benefits to playing music. For me it is an escape and rewarding relaxation. Do you think the same?
I agree with you and I like the fact that you can disconnect from work and learn how to play an instrument at the same time.
I love this idea. Also Instruments are such beautiful objects. I can imagine the positive impact on mood from just having them around.
Thanks Berns, I really appreciate your input. Do you think that the beauty of the instrument itself has a health value in terms of a working environment?

I once heard that classic music, playing jazz and looking at art prevents Alzheimer, the instruments i would consider as art.Also would it motivate people to play the instruments together, that again is positive for communication and team building. In my opinion everything about this concept is good.

I had never heard that music could help prevent an illness such as Alzheimers, that is really interesting. Yes the community aspect and collaboration would also be great for spirit and morale. Thanks Berns.

Music focuses the mind - add it to alexander technique and posture improves, brething improves and stress is reduced..  You can add so much to this.....Junkyard drumming - build the instruments in the first place - so there is no cost - just time and a requirement for a slightly soundproofed area....How about adding a conceptual art project in and include local schools or nature reserves in to it?

Thanks Paul, Yes there are multiple benefits and also variations which could be added to this concept. I like your idea of making the instruments as a cost effective method of supplying a workplace with musical equipment. This would work well in a stomp band style of music but there is a very high skill level in manufacturing some instruments. Community involvement through art would also be a great addition.Thanks for your input, you have some great ideas!

Love it!I used to work in an office for a tech company. A couple of my colleagues were very good at playing the guitar and would regularly strum as they worked / thought through a particular challenge etc. Personally, but I found it incredibly relaxing to listen to. What's more, it  was brilliant to work for a company that allowed people to be themselves in a workplace - from playing music to wearing whatever they liked. Made a big impact on me

Thanks Beth. It is great to hear that musical instruments in a working environment have already had a positive impact on somebody. Yes that fundamental of being in a relaxed work place with freedom for self expression is a common reoccurring theme.Thank you for your input.

As a youngster, I was an avid musician and my daily practices were a great break from my school work and other activities. They gave me a purpose and a sense of accomplishment whenever I perfected a line, song or even a grade. Nowadays at work, there aren't many things to give us a relief from day-to-day routine. Would bringing back instruments do that? Maybe... hopefully! I would love to see workplaces take this on... I can just imagine different areas of workplaces take on different sections of orchestras! Accounts on the brass, management on the percussion... etc and then even a band could be created! That would certainly make Christmas parties a bit more enjoyable ;)

Its great to hear your thoughts Will, since posting this people seem to agree a work place band/music group would be great incentive to break from work by learning instruments and practising with colleagues. I like your idea of different departments forming different sections of an orchestra. Hopefully this would introduce a sense of togetherness within a workplace as well as meaningful down time and reflection.

Love the concept! Really would love to see it become more communal like the previous comment with office bands.An office concerts  at the end of each month, sharing what each person has learnt could be a fun incentive.

Thanks Darius, I really like the idea of adding extra incentive by having workplace concerts. If the musicians are enthusiastic enough this could also apply outside the workplace. Having concerts within the local community. This could raise company profile and also engage more people with the idea of using music as a tool for healthier working life. Great contribution, thanks.

Love this Jack. Music is usually a release for most people, by combining this with possible learning a new instrument will keep people engaged and learning a new skill which will stimulate their mind keeping them active and alert for the entire day. I myself would like to try this as I've always wanted to learn a new instrument. Great work Jack!

Thanks Lee, I was inspired by your concept on mental stimulation. Having a release from a working mentality is healthy for people and I feel this concept would allow for meaningful down time. Thank you for your contribution.

Great discussion guys! Jack  if you'd like to acknowledge the input of others in this conversation, you have the option to add him to your Virtual Team. Just hit the Update Entry button up there on the right of your post & scroll down to the Virtual Team area. We dig folks who design better, together!
Thanks Nathan. On it!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Wow, thanks guys.

I love this idea! It reminded me of an article I read in Inc. Magazine a few years ago: "An Office of Rock Stars."http://www.inc.com/magazine/20101101/an-office-of-rock-stars.htmlI believe that learning and playing a musical instrument will help expand creativity and happiness in the workplace, and employees teach each other is not only a resourceful way to implement the program but is a great team building and communication building practice! There are also lots of music apps available for free or cheap that can be used to teach music theory when an instrument isn't handy.One obstacle: getting bosses and managers to okay employees using office time to learn an instrument.One solution: collect some measurements from your experiment to demonstrate to uncertain bosses that this does indeed increase productivity.

I love the quote in the article from Dan Hoffman - "We're like a lot of companies today: We work all the time," he says. "Work life and personal life have become totally blurred. Having a work place band could also add extra incentive and community spirit. Love it!Thank you so much for your comment.

breaking_the_status_quo_to_keep_our_body.description: We get used to status-quo: the same people, same routine, same office, same kind of projects. Why not breaking this status-quo by organizing activities that force us to go out of the office, talk to other people and find new inspiration?.
breaking_the_status_quo_to_keep_our_body.creator: 3bf2e6d38edf9285f8b93ebf657594c2

comments.text: To change my routine, stay inspired and meet new people, I often found myself leave my office to work from The Hub (http://www.the-hub.net). They have really amazing and collaborative work spaces and a great community. I imagine there are so many other existing spaces and opportunities to break the status-quo.

This reminds me of what a more manufacturing-intense economy discovered decades ago and manufacturing firms today still employ; line workers need to be rotated in their positions in order to continue to maintain their edge.  Not only do we need to look at our own jobs differently, often by doing just what you suggest, Marcela, but we need to do other jobs!  Shaking up a work routine is helpful in keeping employees sharp, engaged, happy, and successful.  This is also reminiscent of the Foreign Service, the US Diplomatic Corps.  Diplomats will shift posts every two or three or four years.  The State Department invests tremendously in language training and moving expenses for our diplomats, because they find that diplomats that move with frequency are more effective.  They frequently must face a steep learning curve, a new set of customs/contacts/actors, and a new culture.  Diplomats, to an extent self-selecting, love that challenge.Is there something that multi-location or multinational firms; or even firms with many different functions can learn from the State Department?  Is the tremendous expense of ensuring employees face regular steep learning curves something that helps employees attain a healthy level of satisfaction?

Nice one Marcela  and during the Inspiration phase we're keen to collect examples of companies that are doing just this  such as Google: http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/bipedal-your-ideas-/ For more tips on the Inspiration phase, check out: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

breaking_the_status_quo_to_keep_our_body.title: Breaking the status-quo to keep our body and mind healthy

mindful_meditation_breakfast.description: Voluntary meditation sessions that look to promote positive ways for individuals to deal with stress, boost working memory, strengthen focus and build camaraderie.
mindful_meditation_breakfast.creator: 21cc12d53d08a49cdf5aa85693b2eaa6

comments.text: Stress is "the adverse reaction people have to excessive pressures or other types of demand placed on them at work."Stress is not an illness  it is a state. However, if stress becomes too excessive and prolonged, mental and physical illness may develop.Work related stress develops because a person is unable to cope with the demands being placed on them. It can be a contributing cause of illness and is known to be linked with high levels of sickness absence, staff turnover and other issues such as more errors.There is a difference between pressure and stress. Pressure can be positive and a motivating factor, and is often essential in a job. It can help us achieve our goals and perform better. Stress occurs when pressure becomes excessive.Stress affects people in different ways and people deal with them differently. Some exercise, work out or jog to relieve stress whilst others go shopping, spend time with family and friends or take deep breaths cry, scream, shout, moan. Others drink, smoke or take drugs and intoxicants leading to more problems!How would you deal with stress to promote healthier living in and beyond the workplace? Services available for staff? Smiling and humour has been linked to reducing stress, creating an enjoyable working environment and connecting one with others. Perhaps spontaneous witty messages manifesting a 'moment of joy' making one smile, think, question and temporarily forget their worries... Does the workplace offer squeezable tangible artefacts also proven to help relieve stress? Would a stress space be offered to shout, scream and get their worries off their chest? Would one relieve stress through a tangible form or through a virtual means? In a collective group or individually? Sharing personal experiences, offering advice, insights and knowledge could help reduce stress, distance the notion of feeling alone and isolated, create bonding and friendships between employees and team-mates, co-workers...  How would you relieve stress?

mindful_meditation_breakfast.title: Mindful Meditation Break(fast)

comments.text: In many workplaces such as office environments stress plays a great part in everyone. This mini gadget of being able to monitor your stress levels is a great concept as it will allow employees to know when they have to relax and take a break from all the tension and stress. comments.text: This article instantly came to mind when I saw Steve's post: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/09/t-magazine/where-exercise-and-social-media-collide.html?pagewanted=allWhile the technology is currently lacking in accuracy, I believe its tapping into the right motivations.  People love interactive gadgets.  People love finding new ways to make exercising easy or fun.  And they especially love a competitive challenge, whether theyre pitted against a friend, an unknown group of internet dwellers, or a team of co-workers.  If the devices succeed in making people more cognizant of their physical behavior, one would hope it is enough incentive for the technology to improve and eventually outpace (no pun intended) expectations.

I was probably Jawbone Up's biggest fan when it first came out. I had countdowns everywhere for the day I could purchase it, bought it the day it came out, etc.--just overall, very excited to do this. After a few weeks of use, it stopped working properly and even after getting a new one, the replacement stopped working after similar amount of use. I am a huge believer in this technology and think the potential for increasing activity and encouraging movement and physical exercise, but think the technology has a long way to go. My mom has Nike Fuel and can wave her hand back and forth to get the band to log activity (it thinks she is running). I fully believe that these factors will get smoothed out, but the current capabilities are very limiting and inaccurate, unfortunately. I applaud this idea and think even the simple concept of having a tool to track activity, sleep, etc causes the user to think more about exercising... at least more than without the tool. :-)
Couldn't agree more, Ester!
Ester - I saw this article on my blog feed today and thought you might enjoy it: http://www.fastcodesign.com/1671243/how-3-million-hours-of-user-testing-fixed-the-jawbone-up

comments.text: An additional idea to promote healthier food options "on the road"... In the US, Interstate highways generally have a number of rest stops for trucks and cars. These rest stops are owned and run by the respective states. Since they are state-owned facilities, the states can try out any ideas they wish. This provides a unique opportunity and environment for exploring wellness concepts addressing the needs of people who spend much time on the road. Typical state-owned rest stops do not currently offer meals, but only vending machines containing snack and junk food. The Healthy Trucker Alliance should lobby the states to take action to offer healthy meals at rest stops. For example, the states could explore the concept of allowing entrepreneur food vendors to operate food trucks at the rest stop locations. Such food trucks are common in many US cities and are the US version of street food vendors found in many of the world's cities. The Healthy Trucker Alliance could urge the states to pass legislation to permit such food trucks to operate at rest stops, but only on the condition that their meal offerings were healthful. Some sort of review and certification process would be needed to ensure that the vendors' offerings promoted good health. The environment of the state-run rest stop facilities provides a unique opportunity for the entrepreneurial community to experiment with healthy food offerings, find out what will sell, and to take risks that the big chain take-out restaurants are too conservative to take. The rest stop provides a steady stream of prospective customers from the outset, giving the entrepreneurs a good chance of succeeding. If this concept succeeds, then it could exert market pressures on the commercial fast food chains to evolve their food  offerings in a healthier direction.
I've added a sample campaign ad (as image and attached document) relating to healthy food options on the road. Similar to anti-cigarette public service ads.

Thanks for reposting this awesome and comprehensive concept after our outage, James. Perhaps you and others in our community would like to think about how language which truckers might relate to could be used to create a campaign for this. Might there be a way of spinning it all in a way which gets truckers really excited to get involved? Looking forward to what folks come up with!

Thanks for the feedback, Meena. One universal "language" is sports, and I think that something like the "Highway Hoops" concept has a lot of potential for connecting and drawing truckers into the healthy truckers movement. My sense is that "let's shoot some hoops" would connect better than "let's talk about why salads and cottage cheese are better than burgers and fries", at least initially. I also think that a promising way for connecting to the trucker audience and delivering a healthy lifestyle message is through international ethnic food. I realize that one shouldn't make sweeping generalizations. But my guess is that a significant proportion of US truckers have a background of service in the military, and have spent time overseas, perhaps acquiring a taste for diverse cuisines. (I've sat at sushi bars many times and heard customers talking to the sushi chef about their experiences in Japan while in the military.) So I have a hunch that an effort to promote positive eating behavior changes could leverage the possibility that many truckers may be very open to foods from around the world. Chain restaurants that serve US truck stops may be overly conservative and may underestimate how open truckers may be to eating diverse cuisines from foreign lands. So I guess what I'm saying is that the biggest enemy is allowing truckers to be trapped in stereotypes of how they should behave or what they should eat.

healthy_trucker_alliance_spreads_the_wor.title: Healthy Trucker Alliance Spreads the Word, Connects Drivers

i like it, its the best words of wisdom, words from from experiences are most valuable in life, they sometimes can't be documented and are hard to attain, but s might change it!

I think you're right, Victor.You got me thinking though... They always say a picture says a thousand words, so I wonder if people could, in addition to text, post pictures and photos too? What a beautiful way to capture wisdom and engage people

Like the idea of tapping into the wisdom of the ages. I wonder if we might tap into the wisdom of athletes as well. They've spent so much time focused on their sports, they may have tips and techniques they've learned along the way to improve performance, motivation, and overall health.

Ah man if this gets created I am definitely posting some stories from my Grandfather, who started an aerospace company and built parts which are now on display in the Smithsonian. He inspired me to go into engineering because he managed to accomplish so much for the world and he loved every minute of it.Figuring out how to love what you do and do what you love is the best lesson he taught me, along with many leadership and managerial tips.This lesson is something we need more of in our society :)

I completely agree, thank you for sharing. I have one grandparent left, but a lot of life lessons from my grandmother who passed away a few years ago. She taught me how to sing, and thought I always had much more potential than I ever thought I did. Wouldn't it be great if we could also submit ideas on behalf of loved ones who have passed too?Thanks for your comment, Bryce. Your grandfather sounds pretty amazing

Beth, this idea is awesome both for workplace wellness & cultural wellness.  I love the idea of combining this with the on your way home concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/concepting/on-your-way-home/) to build relationships with those who have so much life experience to discuss.I'm thinking about using social media...  Aren't there many fewer seniors on social media?  Would there be only knowledge transfer or also the building of meaningful relationships?  Potentially both of these could be valuable.  One thought would be to make it an exchange and have the senior share stories and the younger person help them share them through social media.  I know I've taught my mom a lot this way.  It could also tie into making cities more social, where youth could help record these stories online.  I may have just taken your idea way beyond what you were thinking but I got excited so only take what makes sense for your concept in this comment here.

Yes, I love that idea. A combination of skills and experience from across generations. A lovely project for schools or even grandkidsBut I do think there are a lot of older people now using the Internet, which is good too!

comments.text: Denmark is one of the best country for a child to grow up! Here is also a sports kindergarden I had the chance to visit in Copenhagen:http://www.ryvang2.dkKids are allowed to jump on the tables with heavy metal music and you can find big muscular guys playing the guitar being their teachers:)

On a similar note, I interned in Beijing for a summer two years back and saw something remarkable: "adult friendly workout playground" which were essentially: outdoor -all levels welcome- gyms. The elderly would gather there every morning from 5 a.m. to exercise on the machines whilst gossiping and chattering away (others engaged in Tai-chi or played badminton / table tennis on the side of these too). Later in the morning, grandmothers would return with their young grand children (grandmothers often used the instruments whilst watching their grandchildren instead of siting sedentarily on a side bench). In the afternoon, school children would aggregate there to socialise after school and finally young students and workers would replace these in the evening. http://blog.chinatraveldepot.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/beijing-exercice.jpg

Love it! But what I'd really like to see is an adult-sized playground. You know, with adult slides and all that. And really cool exercise friendly equipment like rock walls. Essentially, the anti-gym. The reason why kids don't need to work out. They play. I want adults to be able to play in a park catered specifically to the age group.

comments.text: This is a very interesting concept Daniel! I agree with Sam in trying to implement a reward scheme, the reward being given the ability to choose what scent it diffused within the office that week. This concept can be easily integrated within a working environment and increase the moral and productivity of employees. Great idea.

This is really interesting. I had no idea about how scents trigger the brain linked to emotions and well-being. I agree with subtly transforming the workplace into more of a homely environment, one in which we all feel extremely comfortable in yet not provide enough of a distraction to the employee.Great work
Thanks Jonathan, I appreciate the kind words.

Really simple idea, but also realistic. Like it a lot. Would be interesting to see if it would work with a reward type scheme?So if certain goals are met, nicer smells are used? Or the "employee of the week" chooses the scents being used throughout the office?
Sam, I appreciate the response. I believe an employee reward scheme would be very beneficial.

This is a really interesting idea Daniel. We all relate smells to thoughts and people and so if we could push smells into our workplace then it would certainly elevate moods and minimise stress. Have you heard of 'Olly'? It's a small 'robot' that you can connect up to your e-mails, twitter, facebook, etc and link people to smells (which you put into it) and so when you receive a notification, mention, e-mail from that particular person a smell comes out reminding you of them.Check it out! http://www.ollyfactory.com

comments.text: Neat idea. What if it also reminded you to get up periodically if you were sitting too long? A few healthy suggestions sent to your inbox from time to time, or a buzz from below?

Thanks for your suggestions Charles. Testing would generate some great insight into this. Looking into how other 'solutions' work and how people interact with them, it's clear that too much strong suggestion just doesn't work. Users tend to uninstall app and completely revert back to their usual habits.The key is progressive learning. Not constantly annoying and forcing you to move.

I think you're both right. Thanks for input Samantha, testing would definitely generate some great insights. The prototype is in progress and am possibly trialling it with a small company too.Feel free to speak up on anymore comments. Really helpful feedback.
Clever idea to solve a serious problem. No constructive feedback except good luck!

How about a chair that changes shape every now and then?For example you get up, to get your water and when you come back to the table the chair has changed to more close to standing position.Accommodating a couple of shapes in a chair should be easy achievable.

Yes, could be an interesting area to test. Kind of a haptic response. One basic element to this could be vibration. It's got to be subtle though. People would get pretty annoyed if it went off all time, like an alarm.

Really nice idea. I, for one don't like apps that constantly force you to change my behaviour. They're frustrating and counter-productive. This seems to fall outside of those, more passively addressing the problem, which I think is easier to commit to.I can really see how this could work! Good job.
Thanks for your comments Samantha. Appreciate your support.

I wonder what other effects the collected information might have on the design and use of the office space? If any chair an employee sits in registers that unique person and records their sitting information, by ensuring enough access points in our wireless network (to allow triangulation) we can mine for insights into the density of actors in meetings, for example, or how often particular persons are involved involved in sit-down work with other co-workers, versus those who spend more of their time solitary. If a particular business unit tends toward collaborative work, it could be beneficial to redesign their spaces to facilitate that, while with units that prefer solitary work a company could focus on improving individual working space.

Samuel, neat concept.  This should be very easy to prototype - let me know if you'd like any help with with Arduino.Even if the alternative behavior were simply moving to a different seat, or walking around the office twice, this would still have a substantial impact on health and productivity.  Various studies have also shown that creativity and productivity are higher after periods of physical activity.  If my chair could incentivize me to get up and jog around the building even once every few hours, that would be a big win for employers.

Thats Chris.Yeah it shouldn't be too hard. I was planning some XBee modules for wireless communication between the chair and the Arduino, then get Processing to visualise.Thanks for your input!S

Great concept Samuel!  To help people better grasp your idea you may want to paint a bit of an example scenario which explains someone's journey through the concept you've outlined. Check this post: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/winners-announced/amnesty-observer-app/ where a scenario is given to get people digging the goodness on a concept. You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.
