_201c_measuring_201d_the_company_s_state.description: We all have a lot of things to juggle in life- family, friends, career; our health. And everything has its balance and it’s when we have too much of one thing and not enough of another that it really takes its toll on our state of well-being.
_201c_measuring_201d_the_company_s_state.creator: ad98e86663e2bf242bca0cf45af26cf0

comments.text: Hey there Asthma  If you're interested in pursuing your idea further, you might want to check out the Knight News Challenge. They're focusing on the topic of health and the winning entries will receive grant funding to bring ideas to life. You can check it out here http://kng.ht/1aunB0h.
OMG! This is an auto-correct blunder. I meant Asma of course!

Awesome idea! I think this could be a very constructive reality check! I wonder if GPS location could be a useful tool in auto-filling data? (how much time spent at work, home, gym, other one-time identified locations)I realize there could be a lot of employee-employer privacy issues with this idea but I'd be interested to see where I spent my time if the info was kept private to me! It might also help the user to populate truthfully.

Thanks Victoria! That's an interesting point you've made- you're right that it could possibly have privacy issues, but I like what you're suggesting so there could be a way around that. I'll think on it! :)

Neat idea! Concerning the privacy of the GPS-enabled tool, the specific data could be kept by "WellBeing App, Inc." at a site separate from the employer. The employer could be given only the anonymized data, not including locations. This way, the user could set up GPS "zones" where the application would automatically register them as being at home, the gym, at the office, commuting potentially if routes were set up. At the same time, the user could be comfortable knowing that their company wouldn't be able to look into the data on the site and find them. In fact, sign up for an employee could be relatively anonymous, as well. The employee doesn't need to give personally-identifiable information, and can be associated with their company through a single company key. This way, an employee that wants a truly anonymous experience but still wants to contribute to the benefit of their coworkers can have a blind between them and WellBeing. This would also remove some of the socio-operational barriers to adoption. It is difficult to get any person to add extra tasks to their schedule. Getting people to try a new application, however, is much easier, and automated recording of the basic level of information is both effortless and has a low conceptual cost to participation.By which I mean to say, would improve chances someone would sign up, turn on auto-logging, and then would be helping contribute data whether they microblogged in the app often or not.

Hey Asma,I have put together a quick Survey for the comparative element of my 'Glassdoor for Health and Fitness App'. A bit of the content is derived from building on your above concept. Will be happy to share all the data with you when (if!) it starts rolling in. Would be great if you could help spread the link to this survey too! Many thanks!http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/KFQPNGT
Great idea James! Will do that right now!
Hey Asma, I've published the Survey results on my Glassdoor page, hope they can be of help to you too. I found them pretty encouraging :)
Thanks James, great job with the data visualisations :)
Really cool idea! Your images explains everything clearly!
Thank you Yin San :)
I agree with Yin San, the pictures say it all. Good work
Thanks Andrea!
Love this idea.  My only suggestion would be to allow "anonymous" entries to the data set.  Otherwise, it might be one of those all-wonderful, no-problems kind of business assessments.
Thanks Jim. I agree completely, the information of each employee definitely needs to be kept anonymous or honesty would be a problem.

This is my favourite idea. As an analyst, it appeals to me because I first want a tool which will help me to understand the specific problem for the specific group of people. From that understanding, I can then make recommendations on actions to alter the situation.
Thank you James! I had hoped for it to be a tool that would display the problems in order for a solution to be more easily determined, so I'm glad you think it could work :)

Hey Asma, James, this is a great angle. Painting a scenrio for a minute, perhaps over time companies (or divisions, teams) can have a look for overall trends in work-life balance, and do some data-mining to see whether the ups and downs were the result of externalities or what has gone on at work. In both cases, management can adapt their planning to ensure a more adjusted work-life balance and happier employees. There could be obvious external factors like the school holidays causing more stress for parents - perhaps parents can have their project allocations adjusted and be flexible/closer to home over certain periods. In the case of announcements or reorganisations at work proving stressful, perhaps companies will see the need for clearer consulting, explanation and transparency.There are hundreds of ways this data could be used to effect positive change...Would be great to get more direction on refining from a statistician's viewpoint!

I like this concept a lot. It would allow indidividuals to keep updated with themselves and reassured that they're okay, and not too stressed out.  Which of course is really important, especially when an employee has a heavy work load, because it can really take its toll, and they can often lose their balance.
Thanks for the feedback Liam!

Congrats on being shortlisted to the Top 20 for our Workplace Wellness Challenge! Our expert panel could see connections to the  Glassdoor and Well Days concepts  and liked how they've outlined the ways people would be evaluated. Perhaps you could reach out to those concept authors and get them involved in your Virtual Team. How might you make it easier to collect and record this data, without relying on people filling it in themselves? Look for inspiration at automatic expenses apps for instance.Read more on how to get involved with our Refinement phase: http://bit.ly/oi_refine And here's some tips on refining specifically for this challenge: http://bit.ly/wellwork-tips Ready, steady, refine!
Thank you, it's an honour! :)And thank you for the tips, will definitely take those on board and work on refining the concept!
Simple to view - how easy is it to populate truthfully?  Or is it all about stakeholder perceptions rather than actual concrete fact?

I find this to be a dilemma, often!!!! and I often ask myself what is actually the borderline between "concrete facts" and "stakeholder perceptions"...or better yet, what is actually more "significant" or "relevant in the specific situation? Sorry, it is not my intention to open a philosophical discussion...In whichever way, it seems to me here that team and individual "perception" of the (un)balanced relationships between the various spheres actually does affect the various dimensions of health

The philosophy of most wellbeing issues do surround perception as we are all predominantly emotional.  We like to think that we are logical and make decisions  based on fact, but our perception is limited by our senses so perception rules, I guess.This tool is good to reveal what people think to management, not just what they perceive (through the management filters) the workforce thinks.Good job

You're right about individual's perceptions being the main thing taken into account here rather than concrete fact. But, as Gaia pointed out the perceptions of the employee on whether or not they're happy is definitely the most relevant issue in this specific situation. And as you stated Paul, perception definitely rules when it comes to human emotions!Thanks to both of you for taking the time to offer your thoughts :)

I really like this concept. Since wellbeing is a not a clearly defined state of mind, it will vary from person to person and even from one moment to the other. So by using the life wheel tool, people will get a much more visual response which in my opinion should be used as an inspirational tool for the company and the employes alike. Have you ever thought about adding more than 4 areas to the life wheel? And maybe the system can generate suggestions on how to achieve more balance for the single user and for the overall wellbeing of the company. Just some suggestions that came to my mind when i read your concept. :)I found this link in my bookmarks. They allow you too enter your own areas which has the advantage of individual life wheel creation. Might get in the way of a corporate wellbeing status though. http://www.worklifebalancecentre.orgYou can find the the life wheel under the interact headline.

Very engaging concept Asma and congrats for the refinement phase :) Awesome site, Adam and very related to this concept, it seems to me! The life-wheel test could be integrated into this system and actually slightly re-tailored to fit the purpose here...It is in the best interest of the company/corporation/firm/office to show positive indicators that "measure" satisfaction of employees with the work environment, for both productivity and PR purposes. In case the indicators are not as positive, then it could be interesting to increase the accountability of the office/firm/companies. They could take concrete steps to re-balance the life-work-wheel...

Thank you both for the thoughts and input! And thanks for sharing the link Adam! I love the website- the thought you mentioned "maybe the system can generate suggestions on how to achieve more balance for the single user and for the overall wellbeing of the company." I briefly mentioned creating online noticeboards that would have helpful tips like that in the concept, so I'll look further into that.The 4 titles I chose for the wheel spokes were just what came off the top of my head at the time, so I agree that they could probably be more areas to it! It would definitely get a bit complicated in terms of measuring the overall wellbeing if people picked their own headings. But maybe the company could get their employees to come up with suggestions and pick the most common ones? Do you have any suggestions for what areas would be interesting to measure?You're right Gaia it really does fit in with this concept. It hadn't actually occurred to me that one of the benefits for companies could be using it for PR purposes too, so thanks for pointing that out! It could be a real incentive for them to went to take part and invest in the satisfaction of their employees.
love the concept!!!well presented!!the image just explained everything!!!
Thanks Janet!
Really nice idea Asma. Great image hacks, I really like the pictures they explain your idea completely.
Thanks Chris! :)

I really like this concept, mainly because i myself am looking at visualizing data in the workplace and i really like your take on "the well being of the company". Understanding the individual wellness of your employees is key to creating and sustaining a successful business. One thing to consider is how honestly people will fill out this data. If the input data is not sincere then the visual output will be irrelevant.Great concept and visualizations none the less Asma!

Thanks Julian! I've just had a look at your concept and I love the team data visualisation idea!You're right about that, it did worry me at first- it does rely heavily on the assumption that people would be honest with their inputs. However, I'm hoping that knowing that their own personal inputs would be kept private would be incentive enough for people to be honest- as there would be no fear of being individually judged. What do you think?

Great! Thanks!  I see the angle where your coming from about peoples inputs being private and therefore being honest,  but at the same time I think knowing peoples personal well being is just as important as an company well being. Perhaps only higher management or an unbiased third party could monitor individuals well being, whilst an overall rating was public?

Good point Julian- I like the idea of an unbiased 3rd party, not so much higher management as nobody is likely to be honest if the big bosses get to see! But they'd still have to be a way to make their information anonymous, unless they didn't mind, as taking the privacy aspect away might deter people from using it altogether. But you've given me points to definitely think about!

Great piece of work Asma, the combining of current technologies (ie the smartphone) and bringing workers together at the same time letting the employer know what is going on is impressive.Great visuals too, good work!
Thanks Alex!
Nice work Asma, I especially like the experiment stage, recording into balance wheels would look visually impressive and also easy to read in terms of understanding the change.
Thank you Charlie!

This concept has caught my eye since the pinning up at Middlesex. This is a great concept, bringing the company wellness altogether but also making each individuals wellness wheel private. The employees will feel part of the group and community as they are all working towards the same goal.

Thanks Dalv, I'm glad you think so! Making sure that there's no singling  out of any individual is a way to hopefully bring colleagues together. And encouraging them to strive towards a common goal will instil some team spirit within the workplace.
Spot on, well done with this one Asma.
Thanks again!
I love this concept! Great choice of images too. Well done Asma!
Thanks Nihal!
A great use of images to explain the whole concept overall. Checking the previous weeks against the current week.
Thank you. It should be a useful way to look back and track your progress over time!

Good concept Asma. Its a very interesting concept for this challenge. I really like the fact how you can have your own wheel of life chart but in the end everyone comes together as a team to help each other out.
Thank you Gul! I thought it was really important to put an emphasis on teamwork in this concept, in bringing the workplace together to achieve a common goal.

Great idea Asma, I think it is particularly important not to single people out in this instance. The collected data visualisation is a great way of presenting the overall wellness of the working community. It would be great to make the system even more personalised on an individual level. Visual themes and so on. Although people like to feel a part of something they also value independence and so perhaps there could be some ways of implementing customisation for each individual.

Thanks Jack! It would definitely be interesting to make it more personalised. The above diagram is just a rough overview of what it could look like but it could use some work in terms of customisation. Incorporating different themed diagrams would be cool. allowing them to change colours, fonts etc. Different people respond to different visuals so you've really made a good point here. Thanks for the input

Great concept! I particularly like the fact that the employees' have their own individual wheel and can track their own commitments and not feel singled out or pressured. The employers may also find this interesting being able to see how their employees are doing, and the employees being able to see the whole workforces combined wheel to help depict the strengths and weakness of the workforce overall. Good work

Thanks Megan! I wanted to emphasise that point because sometimes people feel burdened if they're individually singled out- as some will obviously do better than others. Keeping everybody's balances personal takes way the element of stress that competing with their peers could bring.

py/tuple: Is this concept addressing clear health needs for users?

This concept rocked my world
I liked it but prefered others
It didn't get my overly excited.

This concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come

sedentary_sentry_gets_you_out_of_your_ch.creator: cffdc116a275fdefa9c651a3d3630e06

comments.text: it's like the healthy peoples version of a cigarette break, break like these help workers bond and communicate and relieve stress, love it!

Nice idea! I like the fact about having a little break avoiding the sedentarism. It could be great for the employees to communicate each other or having this break at the same time, so they can also interact!

Some way of making sure that the computer doesn't lock just as you are coming to your final slide with the CEO....  Hang on that may me a good way of getting  the attention of your audience - if you have been talking for an hour most people will have lost the attention of their audience unless they are uber storytellers...  This may have an unintended side affect of actually getting people to talk to each other....  The lock out could be a virtual one - and a work to change culture

Paul, I totally agree. In my experience, very few meetings continue to be productive past 45 minutes, and those that do are brainstorms or other active meeting types which would not incur the lockout feature.

Interesting idea Adam and great use of existing research.  One quick thought to strengthen the idea even further - Users may need to use their computer for a meeting or at some critical period when it locks.  Perhaps another approach would be to think about having an office culture that all stands up at the last 10 minutes of every hour so it is a social reinforcement but people don't get locked out of their work.
Hi Nathan, I think that you are correct (especially in open layout offices). A social norm could be more effective and easier to implement/scale. Definitely something to think about/prototype!

Great Concept. Mental health is really important for people who spend most of the day sitting down, so having 5-10 minutes of break every hour will really refresh them. Using technology in a clearver way to do this is great, it can really work!

Integrating this into a regular working environment can allow for close bonds to be formed and evoking an increase in collaboration and team building within a workforce. FANTASTIC!I love the fact of changing the typical workspace environment into something different.which makes it easier to collaborate with colleagues. Suggestion:Maybe the complex could have related  profession in the same complex. e.g design & fine artist.

I was just walking through my Uni campus thinking exactly this! In previous work experience, there is nothing quite like the sociable university! If newly developed workplaces and offices were designed like this then I for sure would love to graduate and be happy to go straight into a job. Universities certainly feel much friendlier and are normally happier environments. I back this!! :)

great concept Brian, really like the idea of green spaces alongside collaborating, getting together and sharing skills,knowledge and experiences... uni is also meant to be one of the best experiences where a person can make 'friends for life'  so a great model to promote  healthy, happy enjoyable workplaces & environments...
Absolutely Ahmed. Why not be able to create lasting friendships at work, because it doesn't always have to be all about work all day.

comments.text: An app like this could could also facilitate by visualizing systems thinking - where do we fit in, how do we contribute?  What are my strengths?  How do I naturally contribute?  I like it.
Thanks Kerry! This type of visualization would be such a powerful tool in the workplace!

Great idea Julian! And good work on the visuals! What I love most about this idea is as you stated: "this app adds meaning and importance to every role in the workplace, from janitor to CEO." This would be a great way to boost the confidence of people who probably feel that they are lower down in the workplace "heirarchy", by showing them that they are part of the team and their contribution just as valuable.
Thanks Asma! What you have highlighted is exactly what I believe is the most important part of this concept. "Showing them that they are part of the team and their contribution is just as valuable"

The visualisations can be added to by including preferences in the way that people work.  What team roles they are good at  and like doing and perform well in, and how they respond to challenges and more stressful moments..This would ensure that local and remote teams are set up in the most balanced ways...

Thanks Paul,Including preferences and how people work to the app is a great idea and opens up new avenues for connections and visualisations. How employees respond to challenging situations is another aspect that would provide useful information to higher management. This information could then be used in creating teams effectively for different tasks or other useful means.

I like your concept a lot. i can imagine this works really well for people who work from home in teams, maybe even different time zones.I also think there is a lot of potential for quality management, giving employees a space to raise their suggestions and concerns can only be positive.

Thanks Bernhard,I agree with you that it could work well for people who work from home in teams. Plus I do also think that the app could create a place where employees can raise suggestions and improve productivity from understanding what people do and how they do them.

I like the output from this app, but I wonder who and how the inputs come about?The app/visualisation must be accurate and very much up-to-date in order for it to be effective. As soon as people notice that it does not reflect reality, they will start to ignore it. In large dynamic companies where projects and roles and changing frequently, it's very difficult to rely on individuals to "push" data to update the app. On the other hand, relying on higher management levels to update the app may create a biased view. It would be quite neat if a computer "pulled" and analysed the big data that is going through the computer networks, and updated the app/visualisation in real time.

Thanks Andrew! I agree with you on several points. The app being accurate is vital because as you say if the information that is displayed isn't accurate then people will not take notice and the app will become redundant. In addition, when applied to large scale companies the vast amount of information could become 'overwhelming'. I also thought about an 'unbiased system' like a computer that would pull all the information together, so that its constantly up to date, with the ever changing roles and projects. Primarily my thoughts were that to begin with; each person would input their own information about certain things i.e "greatest accomplishments in your career","design objectives and philosophies","experience in that designated field" (these are rough ideas, any inputs you have i would love to hear about!). From there every project or task completed, you could have a very quick form with basic data about the task and also about which areas your completed task will affect and help to be completed (i.e 'technical drawings finished' - allows manufacturing processes to begin). This data would then be input into a database and a computer would visualize the connections between various people or sectors that are affected by the completed task.Although i did think that from a different perspective, you could solely use the app as a 'basic' information app. Allowing people to see who does what in the company, their achievements in the company and contributions - perhaps an informal light-hearted version? What do you think? Your input has brought about many good points of how to effectively use this data! Food for thought...

comments.text: Hey Anson! Your right they are similar, but I love you idea about the hired chef that way as you noted they know it will be healthy and made fresh. Depending on the funds this might not be able to be something they do every day of the week but maybe for a short time to get people motivated. The beginning like anything else of trying to eat healthy is always the hardest part, but gets easier over time. Sounds like good motivation to me!

Hi Alicia, thanks for your comments, appreciate it. Yes, sustainability is a key factor. From what I notice my colleague were doing, a lot of them get frozen dinner, $3-5 a pack, I am a big eater, so I would need 2. If the employee is willing to pay $5 a day, the company sponsor $1 a day and the insurance company $1, that makes $7, if there are 20 people in the office, that is $140 budget a day, 20 days, $2800 for a month, I'd say there a lot of chef out there don't mind working for 3 hours a day to make that much money(assuming material cost is 1/4, they are pocketing $2100 a month). Not to mention the occasion xmas dinner, anniversary, meeting client catering, it could be a good startup potential for some chef out there~

An reference for the chef idea: www.munchery.com - in this startup, personal chefs cook fresh meals daily. You can place your order up to 5pm (I think) and set a delivery time for the same day. The prices are pretty reasonable, when you compare to take out or delivery prices for restaurants.

I also like the idea that if it wasn't an everyday chef it could leave room for teaching and for the employees to take a lead sometimes, a great way to incorporate health eating habits and cooking knowledge into meals you make outside of the office!
I love all the ideas and suggestions.. so cool that we can all work together like this to refine concepts =]

Hello Anson and Alicia!Thanks for inviting me to the team! It seems like the similarities between the three concepts we proposed is using the weekday lunch as an opportunity to bring co-workers together, and at the same time promote healthier eating.Perhaps there is a way of combining these ideas, so that whether it is bringing in lunch for co-workers, hiring a chef or cooking together, there is motivation for using lunch time at work to eat healthier and be with co-workers.

Hi Team,Wow, I think we are off to something great here. By the way, Munchery.com is awesome! that is like what I had in mind but better. And what even more amazes me is that this OpenIDEO thing is working so well, it is such a sophisticated process yet executed so simply and it works! look at us! I wouldn't have thought that I would ended up with a team of strangers yet like minded people and working unselfishly for the same noble cause, this is just too good to be true. But it is true.And YES, I think we can definitely pool together our ideas and form a new concept or refine concept, I think our general theme is to utilize the lunch time in the office to promote healthy eating and togetherness. It doesn't matter if it is each individual take turn to cook, everybody cook together or pool in money to hire, just whatever works and suitable in any given scenario and situation!Do you guys where do we go from here? Do we need to resubmit a proposal? or it is get taken care of in the next level..or?

Hey Anson & all,I'm also really impressed with OpenIDEO. I just joined recently, at it is fun! :-)In regards to the idea, what if it were a "eat well together" platform, that helps co-workers plan and eat healthy meals together. Diversity is actually a good thing (after all, always cooking or always eating out or always bringing lunch in can become too much!)A few features this platform could offer:1. A calendar, where co-workers can enter what the meal plan is for each day2. Different possibilities for source of meal: someone brings from home for all, cook together at work, or hire a chef, or even delivery3. A way of combining this with a "meeting agenda", so that lunch meals can also become productive meetings

Hi Joana and all,Yes, I think the "eat well together" platform would be a great idea. I like how it has individual's partciptation and involvement aspect in it and diversity and flexibility. Those are important components for sustainability. By your definition, what is a "platform"?I also think it is important to add the employer and the insurance company into the equation somehow. Not only because this challenge is sponsored by an insurance provider, but because it is sponsored by an insurance provider, which makes it more interesting. Maybe I am reading too much into it, but it is obvious to me that the interest of an insurance company would be 1)build a relationship with their clients, so they are continually employed. 2)less payout to their policy, that's how they can be finanically sound. So if they are not in the loop, first, it is a good resource that didnt get utilized, secondly, and this is same as to the employer, if it is not tie to some kind of budget that is reflected in some kind of parameter, it will often get lost and the initative disappear.(big corperation tends to do that)There are many ways to get them in the loop, hiring a chef is one, but I can see that people might want other choices, like cooking themselves and bring food etc, so having options is good. That lead me thought of other ways instead of always paying for the chef, perhaps an initial investment that's by the employer and or insurance company or even the federation to create that space to eat together in the first place can be an option, I won't be surprise to find that, a lot of the company actually don't have a 'proper' place to do that, or the existing space is anti social somehow.Perhaps the comittement level can continue or expand upon their level of success, perhaps it could be a 10 year plan, and eventually a kitchen will be built, if that don't already have it, or even there will be money to build a gym. Then it really blends into the idea of diminishing the boundary of working or just being, creating an environment that not only allow the employee to benefit at lunch time, but throughout the whole time of employment. The "eat well together" could be just a kick starter to start a long term initiative to promote better work life, a "work well together" initative. In which, each aspect of work is looked at and refined, so that everybody has the optimal working condition and psychological health due to the fact that they enjoy their work. If that's achieved, then it would be a wholesome plan to create healthy communities within an beyond work place!ops..was kinda typing as i was thinking..sorry for the length of this.Anson

I guess it could also involve organised catering - i.e. a company who cooks on other premises to order and delivers - if the company was to go in partnership with a healthy caterer and subsidise the orders that would be an effective way - so the company if it doesn't have a canteen doesn't need to worry about the cooking equipment all they need to provide is the space to gather and eat.
yea absolutely, the plan can be easily adapted to any organization with different resources available~
Thank you very much for inviting me to the team. Would "Refinement" be the stage in the process at which we develop and submit a refined concept bringing together the team members' ideas?

Hi Oksana,Welcome to the team!I am new to this OpenIDEO, so I am not sure where do we go from here...I think there will be a 'short lists' chosen by the administrator, so we first have to be selected.And I think the refinement stage is what you are thinking about.So, let's see, we are like 3 hours away anyway.

mindful_leadership.description: Understanding how Mindful Leadership and meditation techniques can be a powerful force to improve a lot more than just work performance.
mindful_leadership.creator: 78b421309e310f1950b83b418b1ebc04

comments.text: Hi Suzy Thanks for this. I noticed some of the managers in the company having difficulty settling into meetings. They were there physically but they weren't present in the way that they needed to be. We got the managers to shut their eyes, picture a wheel spinning, stop the wheel and have it spin in the opposite direction. It takes a minute and it works. We are able to connect better and thus communicate better. Meetings are shorter and more effective. It was not for everyone though. My experience is that for some, the act of stopping is too hard to do. I made a choice to avoid calling it meditation just in case it put people off. There is a fear of a show of weakness, being different or a resistance to anything new. I think that fear can have a terrible effect on health and be a strain on productivity.  How can companies overcome these types of resistance?What organisation structure can augment a "safe" environment for all?

Right on. Yes, I strongly feel this and http://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/trying-to-raise-the-bar/ integrate quite nicely.Meditation is such a powerful technique, especially for leaders.What if we developed all people in an organization to be leaders?What if they then empower their family and friends to develop themselves more fully as leaders?How might that transform our workplaces and communities?

Yes! This is excellent.  As we grow up, a lot of emphasis is put on sports and athletics, especially in gym class and extra-curricular activities.  More recently, more focus has been placed on healthy eating and lifestyle practices but the concept of "mental health" and "mindfulness" remains almost untouched in the education system.  As a result, young adults are often retroactively learning mechanisms for stress control, relaxation, etc., if at all, and often carry their bad mental health habits into adulthood and the workplace.  If work environments emphasize the importance of mental health and mindfulness as part of their employee's health regime then I thoroughly believe that the ripple effects will be extensive.  Simply things, like providing 30 minute lessons at lunch time or meditation space, can make a huge difference.

mindful_leadership.title: Mindful Leadership

encourage_and_adopt_standing_desks_at_th.description: Encouraging the use of standing desks for part of a work day reduces sedentary behavior and results in healthier, more efficient employees.
encourage_and_adopt_standing_desks_at_th.creator: d5ed38fdbf28bc4e58be142cf5a17cf5

comments.text: I wonder if studies has been done, which shows the difference in productivity and health between employees who sit or stand. If one could show how standing employees are better workers, it would be an incentive for more managers to invest money in changing the work environment. Id like to see these numbers, and wonder if companies such as Steelcase or other office manufacturers have them.

Anne - in a 2011 study conducted by HealthPartners in conjunction with Ergotron in which they recorded results over seven weeks with a group using WorkFit sit-to-stand workstations  87% of participants felt more energised after just an extra hour of standing daily. 87% also experienced increased comfort while 75% felt healthier overall and 50% felt a reduction in upper back, neck and shoulder pain. Experiencing a great boost to their concentration also, 71% felt more focused and 66% more productive. Taken with a grain of salt, perhaps (Ergotron makes ergonomic workspaces) but still interesting.

Hi Rio, great post! I try standing as much as possible at school after reading this:http://dailyinfographic.com/sitting-down-is-killing-you-infographic?utm_source=RHAW+Members&utm_campaign=9f80a9d680-RHAW_Weekly_Update10_12_2012&utm_medium=email

Hi Amy - that's such a provocative title (I don't know if the shock approach works all the time)! I think the trick is to start small - what's interesting is that the people I've talked to who have opted to stand rarely decide standing is not for them. I'd be curious as to how things are working for you!

Yes, the article is very evocative. I agree, the shock factor doesn't work for everyone, but it certainly worked for me! I am more conscientious of how long I've been sitting these days. Also, my legs start feeling funny after sitting for more than two hours, as if I have an internal timer.

comments.text: Great share, K  and I like how it speaks to the 'beyond the workplace' aspect of our challenge. Here in Wellington, New Zealand where I live  it's common in upmarket restaurants to be asked "would you like sparkling or still bottled water or are you happy with Wellington's finest?" I like how this gives people an easy way to choose local water  which tends to be good.
Wellington's finest, nice! Drinking tap water is so much more ecological. What I like in this project is also its "Buddhistic" approach - concentrating on flavors of something so basic as water.

dutch_national_tapwater_tasting.title: Dutch National tapwater tasting

healthkick_a_social_site_for_live_health.description: Inspired by SongKick, what if we had a social site for live health activities in community? The site would allow you to organise and track your favourite health activities, sports games and events, with instant updates.
healthkick_a_social_site_for_live_health.creator: 31b94a38190f523464b73235e6674825

comments.text: Hi Sarah,I like this idea.  It can act as a prompt (like Songkick does) to get involved in healthy activities as well as connecting you with what's going on locally.  Would work well both in your own town and be even more helpful in places less familiar.

healthkick_a_social_site_for_live_health.title: HealthKick - a social site for live health activities in community

csa_box_employee_benefit_social_recipe_d.description: Organizations can create long term health in their community by: 1. Building a system that makes fruits and veggies available. 2. Providing direction and inspiration to enjoy them, and 3. Creating opportunities for building community food culture.
csa_box_employee_benefit_social_recipe_d.creator: 63e7f979acf876855a50c98c1f79d64c

comments.text: A lot of organisations already exist in communities that are trying to do similar work through "outreach" activities: e.g. healthy kitchens showing how to cook tranditional foods using modern, healthy ingredients.  It would be easier to shape some of these ideas utilising them.  One example is the "Southall Health Improvement Programme" (SHIP) which is run as a charity, and whose aims are:> the preservation and protection of good health for the local communities in Southall by:(A) the provision of health education and health checks, and(B) encouraging healthy lifestyles through information and advice relating to health and wellbeingThese organisations are run by community leaders from various walks of life and have links to local GP surgeries to enable promotion.  Schemes that are local are sensitive to the specific needs of their communities - which is particularly important in culturally sensitive areas.

csa_box_employee_benefit_social_recipe_d.title: CSA Box Employee Benefit, Social Recipe Database and Community Food Culture

morning_group_songs.description: Benefit yourself and relief stress by making some noise!!!
morning_group_songs.creator: c78236227a848779699829c0a7e49a5a

comments.text: This is such a fun idea! I loved singing in the morning assemblies at school! Its a great way to get pumped up with positive energy for an eventful day of work.   great work

Interesting concept with good benefits, will be even better if there was a way to encourage people to take part in this, if they do not like singing out loud. Also the grouping needs to be worked out carefully so that not all the good singers are in the same group, otherwise the ones that think they aren't good in singing might feel bad. good work.

Good point gul! But I've always found that the benefits of singing in a group is that the people who aren't good singers don't sound that bad at all when their voices merge with everybody elses. But splitting the groups in a fair way makes sense if they were to sing against each other.

Great idea Gulafrose! I know we all remember singing assemblies from schooldays, even the grumpiest kids enjoyed taking part! It could really work as a method for stress relief in the workplace and sounds like a good way for everyone to just let loose and have fun, while bonding with colleagues.

Nice one, Gulafrose! I wonder whether it might incentivise folks further if you split the group in half and had them sing against each other. I bet that'd make for double the laughs & twice the fun ; )
thanks for the comment meena kadri thats exactly what I had in mind I was also looking thinking that the winners could probably get better drinks than loosing team staff.

morning_group_songs.title: Morning group songs

build_your_stress_away_.description: A way for people to enjoy their breaks and reduce stress by taking part in activities.
build_your_stress_away_.creator: bd180365ea5d589817f838ba55778bfc

comments.text: Good concept! This would be a great way for employees to relieve stress and spur social interaction between co-workers, leading to a more positive productive workforce. Great idea.

One of the great aspects of this concept is that you have something to take away with you that you have created. It could give you the opportunity to fix a home appliance or make a present for someone without having to go out of your way to another location after work.
Great Idea I am sure if this is implemented, it will make people happy, and happy people work better
i agree with that completely, as you can have fun and enjoy time to build and create and be imaginative
Cool concept! It can bring people (who may work in the same building, but have never met before) together to start a conversation and meet a new friend!

Really like this idea and would love to do this in my office, would also be good to link up smaller offices in one area with a shared studio/ craft space so small businesses can also benefit and meet new people at the same time.

I would love to see hackerspaces (ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hackerspace) inside companies. Like you said, it would help employees relax while also teaching them about technology they use (ex: how they can fix their broken electronics) and seeding innovation.

I completely agree. Boston University's hackerspace (BUILDS) is a great example and a model that could fairly easily be introduced into large companies and small offices alike. The sense of community it creates is fantastic as well as allowing for another venue for critical thinking.

Good concept Imrat. I gree with Djorn, it will be really good to have activities at your work place which people can take park in. Releasing stress, learning and having fun at the same time. Great work.
this sort of activity is FUN. Great concept.

I really like this idea, i think a lot of people will be happy to take part in activities at their work place because it means they dont have to go anywhere, they can literally clock out and get to it.Plus a lot of people myself being one find it difficult to find these activities which i might be interested in. So if my workplace could bring it to me, its a double win!

build_your_stress_away_.title: Build your stress away
